I will update this review as I go through the game when necessary.

Lets start with the obvious, there is now a fairly detailed character creator which includes the option to play as a female instead. You also get to change a little of your new Yokai demonforms too. While I feel like William didn't add a whole lot to the story in the first game, this does mean that your character is more of a silent protagonist in the cutscenes here, You win some you lose some. I personally still prefer the ability to play as my own gender.

So far my first impressions are that the game definitely re-humbles you. having finished the first game. Some of the basic combat, especially against the more normal human enemies does carry over. But even in the first level there are already brand new enemytypes. It seems from the tutorial that even our familiar foes have learned some new fancy moves. The concept of the Yokai Realm has been expanded from being just the small circles (those do still exist too) into sometimes whole parts of the map where you are under its impact until you clear out a stronger enemy causing it. These areas also lock away treasure chests within the effects range until you cleanse it.

I felt like Nioh 1s weapon selection was already impressive. Now there are several more weapontypes, including the cool combination of a glaive, guillotine and scythe, Switchglaives. Almost all my prior Souls-like experience being Nioh 1, what I found the hardest to get used to in the beginning is the new Burst Counter mechanism for reacting to enemy attacks when you see a flash of red at the exact moment you would take the damage from it. It being a two button input will take some time to become musclememory. But I already feel like its going better for me. This might be even easier for you if you have played other games in the genre with similiar systems in place. 

What was the Living Weapon now is your Guardian Spirit posessing you and turning you into one of different Yokai demonforms. You can still use their skill while in the form as well tho. You can also collect and use new Soul Cores. Which allow you to summon that enemy to perform its skill for you in fights. I can already see myself enjoying collecting these. You can also level their Core up.

The collected Kodamas have now setup a Bazaar where they offer goodies for sale. For example elixirs, talismans or even gear. The currency that they take is the new Divine Rice that they can give in return for your recycled gear/weapons. So you can get something that you do actually want in return eventually. Enemies can also drop it too. This can be a nice way to get your elixirs back before re-challenging bossfights. Which can prove to be an issue in the first game causing you to farm them out.

If you so choose to, you are able to summon an AI ally to help you if you carry enough of the Ochoko Cup item required to do so at one of their blue marked Benevolent Graves. These are left behind by other players using an item called the Righteous Jasper.

You can edit your hut a little bit with inviting a Guardian Spirit over and adding hanging scrolls and tea utensils.

For some reason I notice screenshots during cutscenes dont turn out as good often. I didnt have this issue in the first game.

I'm not one to write reviews on games much, but I feel like that I should with this game.

Nioh 2 isn't truly a Souls-like game. It's mostly it's own thing. Don't get me wrong here, there are enemies that can kill you in 1 or 2 hits just like in Dark Souls, Sekiro, Elden Ring and Bloodborne. What sets Nioh 2 apart from the aforementioned Fromsoft games is that the combat has far more to it than them and has a higher skill ceiling, not to mention how much faster the combat in Nioh 2 is by comparison. This game tests the player in many things, such as skill, patience, reflexes, and the overall ability not to smash your keyboard when facing certain bosses like [spoiler] Saito Toshimitsu and Minamoto No Yorimitsu [/spoiler]. When I say this game has a high skill ceiling, I really mean it, it's hard. The game does allow you, if you know what to do, be just as unfair as the enemies you'll run into in the game, as another reviewer pointed out.

I probably don't need to mention this, but the character customization in this game is great. You can customize your character in almost any way you want, even in the most unusual ways like exotic eye, hair and skin colors. In my opinion, Nioh 2 has a better character customization than many of the games that I've seen around on Steam and elsewhere.

As far as the story goes, Nioh 2 has a pretty good story that starts to really make sense after a couple of chapters in. The setting is set in the later parts of the warring states period in Japan, with Nobunaga and Hideyoshi being prominent figures (if I recall correctly, the third of Japan's great unifiers, Toguawa Ieyasu, is only ever referrenced once). I say that the game has a pretty good story only because it can be a little difficult to follow at times, but there are aspects that are phenomenal. I'm not going to bother writing a full review on the story of the game, but there's a point that in my opinion pulls on the heartstrings a little bit, combined with the music really adds to the experience. You'll probably know what I'm talking about if any readers of this review make it that far into the game.

All in all, I'd have to give this game 10/10 despite some of the seemingly unfair aspects of this game, purely because nothing is ever truly impossible to beat. Everything in this game has a gimmick, weakness or pattern that can be exploited. If you can't beat a boss in a side mission, come back to it later when you have unlocked more skills in the skill tree or just being a more skillful gamer in general.

I also wanted to post this review after I both beat the game and hit the 444 hour mark, purely because it's like the East Asian equivalent to 666 here in the west, I thought it'd be funny. Also, yes, it took me [i] nearly that [/i] long to beat this game. I think I was actually done at somewhere around the 400 to 420 hour mark. I spent a lot of time dying and coming back because I'm either a masochist or have some variation of Stockholm syndrome (that last bit is a joke of course, please don't get offended with me for that).

Gameplay-wise this is probably one of the best (if not the best) souls-like there is.

The problem with this game, as I see it, is that the attack dedication is way too high while the enemy attacks are way too fast. What you end up with is a game where you feel like you should be able to move and attack quickly and fluidly but you're actually slow and often get stuck in dedicated attack combos that take 2+ seconds to complete. There are grab attacks with virtually every enemy that can near one shot you and have barely any telegraphing, the enemies have near no attack cooldown on every attack so you're forced to just wait until you can burst counter them so you can get a lackluster amount of damage in, enemies can true combo one shot you on an attack that's untelegraphed. There's a number of things like this. It's a shame because I really wanted to enjoy this game and I like the style of the world and the loot system they have going, as well as the fundamentals of the combat system they built, but the game balancing is just so bad that it feels like the devs never played it.

A far better game than Nioh 1. More thought went into the core mechanics, making them significantly better feeling and more rewarding to use and unlock. The bigger issues have been mostly resolved, like getting one shot is mostly contained in the twilight missions and most enemies that can one shot have far better telegraphing and attacks in general are easier to dodge. The new mechanics add more utility and customization to your playstyle, while not being overwhelming to learn.

My only legit gripe with the game is that its still Nioh. The game is incredibly long and gets to that "i just want to finish this damn game" feeling near the end. Weapons start and finish the same but credit where credit is due, they revamped the skill tree system and add some neat new moves to keep things somewhat fresh. 

Its still a Nioh game. You either love it or hate it but as a former Nioh hater, i respect the very very clear refinements and additions. Nioh 1 is good but Nioh 2 is great. Also, you can make whatever weeb character you want and give them MASSIVE boobs. Nioh knows its demographic and half the phantoms you summon arent wearing armor with the chest slider on MAX.

[h1]Quick Info[/h1]

Pretty much Nioh 1, except it's better in almost every way. Good enough for me to 100% it, which is something I pretty much never do.

Take in mind that despite the common misconception, Nioh isn't much of a "souls-like" game. The similarities to the Souls games are surface level, instead it's a mission based fast paced ARPG with Diablo style loot, combos and grinding / loot farming.

[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
	[*]Amazing combat system with 12 weapon types, each with 3 stances / movesets, their own full skill trees (including both passives and active skills), and additional 3 ranged weapon types, ninjutsu tools and onmyo magic
	[*]Soul core collecting system, where you can loot and equip the soul cores of almost every single Yokai (including bosses) in the game to get passive bonuses and use their unique abilities, basically allowing you to slot in up to 6 active skills to further expand the combat system
	[*]One of the best character editors in video games, with an option to save and share presets with other players
	[*]Two entire coop systems. One that works similarly to the Souls games' spontaneous summoning in case you need help with a specific boss or a tough section of a mission. The second one, Expeditions, allows you to play almost the entire game (excluding few duel side-missions) on coop from start to finish in a group of up to 3 players, with every player being treated equally. Yes, cutscenes and story progression work, no, you don't have to resummon anyone if they die.
	[*]A ton of content across the entire main game plus three major DLCs (included in the PC release) that further extend the story
	[*]Genuinely one of the best NG+ system where each cycle adds new content, mechanics, enemy placements, etc.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
	[*]The game's price was increased noticeably a good while after the release, thanks KOEI
	[*]Uses EOS for the crossplay with Epic Games Store. Thankfully it can be completely disabled in the options menu if you want a stable multiplayer via Steam servers, and no Xi telemetry. That, and also the game is playable offline
	[*]The early game balance is a bit rough, the first 4 or so major bosses and a bunch of yokai can feel a bit spongy, at least until you learn how to melt down their Ki and HP efficiently
	[*]The game actually has a really good enemy variety, but just like the first Nioh it loves to reuse the same enemies over and over again in addition to the new ones, so get used to seeing Gaki jumping at you from progressively more absurd ambush spots
	[*]While the NG+ system is brilliant in terms of the content, it's not so much when it comes to balance. The further you go, the more grindy and min-max'y it gets. If you really like optimizing your build you might enjoy it, but for me it eventually started getting tedious
	[*]Despite the huge improvements, Nioh 2 still retains some of the Nioh 1 BS, which is especially noticeable during the dojo fights against weapon masters (they're hilariously overpowered and cheesy)
[/list]

8.5/10. Nioh2 is one of the more unique action RPGs around with a heavy focus on the 'action' part. Combat mechanics are deep and complex, and rewards you for actually learning how to play the game. Visuals are beautiful (subjective) and you'll often see bright vibrant colors interspersed in its dark atmospheres, which are immersive and do a great job of giving the player a sense of suspense. I'll be writing a lot more about its combat mechanics as this is where the game shines, in my opinion.

Combat revolves around a core concept called Ki (stamina) management. This might sound strange at first blush, because in other games you'd usually just hang back and allow your stamina to regenerate. In Nioh2 however, there are a couple of passives that return your expended stamina [i]immediately[/i] simply by timing some actions. This means that by mastering this concept, you'll be able to fight non-stop without having much of a downtime, which makes for exhilarating and fast-paced fights. On the flip side, your goal is to reduce your enemy's Ki by breaking their stance and/or keeping the pressure up and preventing them from regenerating Ki:
[list]
  [*]When their Ki reaches zero, they stagger on every hit. This allows you to stunlock them for a period of time
  [*]When their [i]maximum[/i] Ki reaches zero, you get to perform a riposte attack for huge damage
[/list]

There isn't much in terms of similarity when compared to souls or soulslikes. Perfect deflections and iframe rolls are only a small part of the game and are not very effective. The game offers you a lot more ways to dodge attacks like using yokai abilities, yokai shift, or just muscle through with omnyo magic. Positioning is a lot more important and understanding game mechanics will give you more mileage than relying on reflexes. You'll die in 1-2 hits from small mobs no matter how far you are in the story, so you can't grind your way to breeze through the game like in Elden Ring.

I've gone into NG+ after completing the main story a little and I must say that this is one of the best NG+ implementations ever. Instead of just enemies hitting harder, their placement and moveset actually change, which keeps you on your toes. You also unlock higher rarity equipment and other perks in each NG+ cycle. Definitely worth a few playthroughs.

The reason why I'm docking a couple of points and giving it a 8.5/10 is because of fundamental issues that affect looter games and minor technical problems. Turning on vsync in Nvidia control panel causes in-game cinematics to fail due to an encoding issue‚Äîwhich is an amateur mistake imo. The worst problem of all is that there's just too damn much loot. The game drops so much junk I spent perhaps 10% of my game time managing inventory. Bad idea in an action game. 

Despite these issues, I'd still [b]strongly recommend[/b] the game simply because there's nothing like it in the market (aside from Team Ninja games).

Nioh 2 has seriously broken me.
I can't actually play this game without being afflicted by how satisfying and challenging the gameplay is, atop of just how much of it feels like it's in my control. Nothing else can really compare, for me.
This is not Dark Souls. It goes to same school, and wears the same uniform, but it is Not Dark Souls. This game could eat Dark Souls. 
A stellar character creator, diverse skill and weapon selection, extremely fine-tuned build creation, and a cast of interesting characters will be the least of your worries as Nioh 2 grabs you by the ankles and swings you around and slams you into furniture until you come out as the hardest mf alive.
There is no brooding, and there is no depression; only REpression of the enemies that stand in your way. Fight, outdo, counter, defeat, and absorb the power of anything that dares to even so much as wave a threatening object in your direction. You ARE stronger, smarter, better. You are important. You are the Cool Guy/Gal. You are The One.  Do not let even demons deny you this absolute truth. You are Nioh.

Nioh 2 alone is worth it's full price. Nioh 2 with all of it's DLC is worth the current-day full price of a new game. If you get Nioh 2 on a sale, you are effectively committing robbery.

It's Diablo, but for DMC fans and weebs alike. The story is fine, nothing special, but it doesn't take itself too seriously with camp and comic relief. The characters also have a lot of personality, but the gameplay is where it really shines.

Featuring mechanically complex combat that requires some time investment to fully understand and operate, but once it clicks, it continues to be one of the most satisfying and expressive gaming experiences around. An infinite amount of possible builds and weapon combinations keeps me coming back every few months to a completely fresh, but equally satisfying experience.

It's a game I consistently feel I'm getting better at, and it feels like there's no upper limit to my understanding of the mechanics. There is very little "artificial difficulty" to be found, and almost every death stems from a lack of knowledge or careless mistakes. Enemies always play within the confines of the rules, and things are very well telegraphed through audio and visual cues. There are a couple outlier bosses that just aren't fun to fight (Gyuki, Osakabe), but the game never treats abusing an enemy's AI as the preferred/intended method of "gitting gud" just to beat them, and instead allows your mastery over its ki/anima system to string together near infinite combos on a winded enemy.

TL;DR
Complex but fair game, a deep learning experience that continues to reward you with stylish execution and infinite replay value as you learn and improve your understanding of its many moving parts.

Game 10/10, Combat 10/10, Character customization 10/10
I absolutely loved this game in terms of character customization, appearance, skills, guardians to pick from and the weapon selections. The game is not easy, but once you get used to the combat style and try out different builds you will end up loving this game. I'm quite surprised that this game doesn't get as much recognition as the Souls games, it is one of the best games I have played to date, I would give it 10/10 rating. What I liked the most about this game was the yokai shifts and the selection of Guardian spirits based on your playstyle. I still remember how much I suffered beating Ren Hayabusa with the middle posture at low level, but when I swapped to low posture I had much easier time. That's when I realized swapping postures in the game was very important. There are so many combinations of builds you can play with! Endgame wise, the game is a bit grindy for the best stats and rolls, but I loved the fact that you can farm gear from actual dead players, aka loot grave system. You wish to reroll the gear, no problem just repeat the stage again, simple as that. I wish Wo Long had this option. With over 250 hours clocked in Nioh 2, I truly enjoyed the game. End game wise, completing all underworld levels and depths is a challenge. My personal opinion Nioh 2 combat system is far superior to Elden Ring. The only nuance in Nioh 2 was the inventory management system, at one point you get so much loot, it's hard to manage it especially if you are grinding for a particular set and stat. I also loved finding the small cute kodama spirits, that was such a nice touch added to the game. 

I truly recommend this game to anyone, regardless if you are not into the Japanese folkore. Even if you don't like katana, the game offers so many different weapons to choose from. If you're interested in samurai history between the so-often-portrayed years of 1560 and 1615, and aren't bothered by it being interwoven with yokai, legends, and myth, then Nioh 1 and 2 are without a doubt a must play.  Team Ninja and KOEI have done a fantastic job of portraying all of our favorite historical figures (plus some others that aren't so often portrayed) in a historical fantasy setting that is constantly blurring the line between historical fact, widely accepted folklore, and modern fabrication.  The imagery is dark, and brutal yet also vibrant and full of life.  So, so many things from this game, from core features to one-off lines in the description of something, can be traced to a real life aspect of Japanese history or culture.  It's important to take it all with a grain of salt, as a game with spirit stones and demons should not substitute some good research, but it's a fantastic way to get a broad introduction to many different aspects of Japanese history and folklore that can be very exciting for the modern enthusiast.

All that being said the game itself is fantastic too but that is what so many reviews have already talked about.

[b] Samurai Souls: A Rollercoaster of Slay, Pray, and 'Okay, One More Try [/b]

Hey there, fellow gamer! Are you ready to embark on a journey where your patience will be tested more than a cat watching a laser pointer? Welcome to Nioh 2, the game that's part history lesson, part demon-slaying, and entirely a test of whether you love yourself.

First off, let's talk story. It's like a sushi roll ‚Äì mostly there to hold everything together. You're this silent, customizable hero, diving into Japan's past to fight alongside and against historical figures. Don't worry if you're not a history buff; the real stars here are the Yokai, who come in more flavors than a Tokyo snack shop.

Now, let's get to the meat and potatoes: the combat. Imagine playing chess, but each piece tries to decapitate you. That's Nioh 2 for you. It's like the game took the Souls-like combat, added a pinch of ninja magic, and then decided to throw in a whole new kitchen sink of weapons and skills. You‚Äôve got nine types of weapons, each with its own PhD-level skill tree. And remember, folks, swinging your sword around like you're trying to swat a fly will just get you killed faster than you can say "Oh no, not again."

Here's a tip: dying is part of the journey. You'll die. A lot. But each death is a learning experience ‚Äì like touching a hot stove, but with more demons and less parental guidance.

Graphics and sound? Top-notch. You'll be so immersed in feudal Japan that you might start bowing to your cat. And let‚Äôs not forget the loot ‚Äì you'll find so much gear that it's like playing dress-up with a samurai twist.

So, who should play Nioh 2? Masochists, history enthusiasts, and anyone who thinks they have too much free time. It's a game that will challenge you, frustrate you, and occasionally make you feel like a Yokai-slaying badass.

Overall, Nioh 2 doesn't reinvent the wheel. It just adds spikes and sets it on fire. So grab your katana, take a deep breath, and prepare to shout ‚ÄúJust one more try!‚Äù at 2 AM. Happy gaming!

I bought this game to punish myself.

++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++
UPDATE reivew on Feb 10 2023 after I beat Elden ring

Elden ring was my second soul game after Nioh 2 and it was pretty good.

Nioh 2 is in away a similar hardcore game like that if there is any other word to describe this genre that I don't know so I'm going to compare this game with Elden Ring since since that game is more popular.

Nioh 2 VS Elden Ring:


_____Pros:____ 

+[u] Better character customization. [/u] I mean like, VERY in-depth. Especially the hairstyle customisation, I've never seen a more complex hair customisation in any game like this before. You can pick a base hairstyle and then there are more sub-customisation for you to adjust from then on. I've had the opportunity to make hair that looks exactly like mine irl ( and along with other badass weeby nerd hairstyles ) and it was so dope.


+[u]Better outfit customization[/u]. Yes. You don't need to wear a certain outfit to have in order to just have better stats. The game let you override any piece of clothing that you want that hence create many several combinations which your character can looks unique to other players while still maintaining the stats that you WANT. Really a BIG FAN of this mechanics whenever it is implemented in a video game.

+[u]Better weapons[/u]. No, I didn't mean to including the combat system. I will talk about it separately.  Nioh 2, when you start the game, there is no class for you to choose. Instead you were introduced with many different weapons types ( including: swords, dual swords, spears, splitstaff, axe, hammers, kusarigamas, odachi, odachis, tonfas, hatchet, switchglaives, fists, 
 and 3 range types of weapon: bows, hand cannons and rilfe ) and actually let you try them all out in the tutorial (you can pick up any other different type and use them at ANY POINT in the game and use them if you change their mind without any draw back). EVERY weapon type has like THEIR OWN different varieties that have DIFFERENT buffs and model designs. ALL of the weapon types are very BALANCED and with different style to uses and you can carry 2 melee weapons for such as a katana and a badass switchblade along with range weapons that can you swap them all out on the go.
+[u]Combat system. Better[/u]. I don't wanna sound like I'm disliking Elden Ring but boy, combat system in Nioh 2 is outnmatched. ( and probably in Nioh too, although I didn't play the first game. I just picked up this one randomly). More in-depth is a understatement. It feels way smoother and more invole than just clicking and hitting button. No. You actually need to PRACTICE with you WEAPONS. Each weapon type has 3 stancesL High, Mid and Low. (for example, High stance means your attacks and combos are more powerful that can breakthrough even a well-guarded enemy but usually will have a slower striking speed that could risk you to be vulnerable for incoming fast attack and cost more stamina to use). That's not all. There are several several combos and skills that you can actually perform at each stance you are on makes it even more dynamic and you can switch stance and combos so FLUIDLY just like in a freaking old kung fu chinese movie.There is also a Ki system which is like the rhythm of your attack. When you swing down a sword, it won't swing back on itself, you have to try to time your attack and press the key at the end of your swing in order to follow up your attacks effectively and blindingly attack your enemies without controlling your Ki (stamina) will usually send you to Jesus more often. A good player is a player who is know how to manage their Ki.

Combining all of these together, we have numerous very deep, unique combat styles and appearances that feels very rewarding for whoever master it.

_____Cons: (kinda, maybe)____


+ [u] NO JUMPING [/u] Only sprinting. But honestly, it's not as bad as it may sound. Because of no jumping, player will have to focus on solving the puzzles, picking their battles and pathway if they want to move forward since there is no cheesy skipping by glitch jumping over the area.

+[u] NO HORSE [/u]. Even though Horse in Elden Ring is not the best video ever that can let you ride a horse but it was still very fun riding it around the map. It also help with the feel of your character, you know, badass sicko mode. Again, in Nioh 2, you don't really need this feature though because it's not an open-world game and this game focus on more every step that you take, every corner that you go to more than running through a grass field with only bushes and trees. Sooooooo, maybe not really a bad thing there is no mount in the game.


+[u] NO OPEN-WORLD MAP [/u]. I'm a big fan of RPG Open-world games. Stalker, Subnautica, GTA 5, Fallout games, No Man's Sky, Don't Starve, Minecraft, Stardew Valley and of course Elden Ring. I wish Nioh was on that list too but this game is actually like a mission to mission type of game. It has a story, not outstanding (more like goofy and with a little bit of cringe sprinkle on top of it) but could be decent if you are interested in Japanese history (or asian culture in general). I didn't understand a lot of things in both Elden Ring and Nioh 2 at first but because I was born in a South-East Asia country so I guess I got used to Nioh 2 faster than in Elden Ring. In my honest opinion, the story in this game is not as deep as Elden Ring but I also think the story in Elden Ring is a little bit overrated ( I know all endings and many secrets and I did some research about the lores)

Cons:
-The performance is all over the place
-Very noticable texture pop in
-Lack of fast travel between checkpoints(though this complaint is subjective since all levels are designed in such a way that you can always create a shortcut to the last checkpoint)
-The level design and atmosphere is nothing special

Conclusion:
Overall, nioh 2 is a great game and an improvement over the first one in every way. The customizability and the deep combat mechanics give this game a lot of replaybility. This is definitely one of those games which you can sink more than a 100 hours into and still not be bored.

I loved Nioh, despite not being good enough to finish it, even after several hundred hours.. And this one seems to continue that, with a new weapon type, or two.. But, theyve added this Burst Counter, and I do NOT like it!  It feels very forced, and overly necessary.. To the point where you will find yourself waiting to use it, because its required. The game was already complex, and this just made it a bit TOO complex, imho.

But its still Nioh, plus some. Expect the same experience, with a little more sprinkles. Absolutely nothing TOO major changed.

You WILL die, because of the camera! Far too many tight corridors, where enemies get you back to a wall or ceiling, and the camera gets pinned to the back of your head, and the monster, blocking ALL vision.

I like that I can summon NPCs to aid in combat encounters, if I wish. I never was able to summon other players in Nioh, and dont plan to use it here either. While I like the help from NPCs, I dont want to have someone else just beat the bosses for me. But I must admit, it feels like some of this may have been designed with coop in mind. Some of these attack patterns are relentless, and dont read very well.

I do not enjoy the boss fights so far.. Something changed when Bloodbourne released, and bosses became too difficult to read.. The first thing you fight in Dark Souls 3 is the same. Its this large thing, and its very difficult to tell where it is safe to move when its screen sized weapon comes at you. Its as big as the length of 3 dodges, and its just too much to avoid. This is when i stopped enjoying these games. Bosses move too fast, and take up too much space, leaving it difficult to know how to even avoid damage.  Nioh had much better bosses, imho.

Bosses have WAY too much HP! If youre using normal weapons, instead of heavy weapons like Odachi or Axe, youll be in the fight for the better part of 10 minutes. With heavy weapons, its MUCH easier.. plus youre not stuck in attack animations like lighter weapons. Some fights feelsl ike you have to have a very specific build to get past. Some of the combos are ridiculous, with far too much reach.

If you get stuck on a boss, theres not a whole lot you can do. Because you will be out of Anima if you use your shapeshift, and no way to recharge it. Likewise with okucho cups, health potions, etc. Everything is finite, and needs to be farmed. If youre stuck, you will just dig a hole deeper by repeated failure. Some builds are just terrible for some bosses. 

Hit boxes are AWFUL! particularly with bosses, and grab attacks. But also some abilities with extreme reach. This community will defend games they like, regardless of poor design or not. And there is poor design here

I dont remember feeling stuck in place when using a Bow in Nioh.. In Nioh 2, you stand in place for a moment, after finishing with your bow.. Your character must stand in place, until the animation of lowering the bow, and putting it away behind your back, finishes playing out, before youre able to move. 

Im finding the light armor basically pointless, as a result of enemy reach/hit detection. Many attacks are difficult to read, or seem as though they reach further than they should. As such, my only way of successful progression, is wearing med/heavy armor, with heavy weapons. Light weapons turn a single bossfight into a 10 minute slog, of slowly chipping away the hp bar. The Odachi still reigns supreme, which sucks, because I really love other weapons like duals, Kusarigama, and others.

Just like nioh 1, its a rare occurrence when you can use your spirit form (Living Weapon in Nioh) The gauge takes so long to fill, that I never even have it available for a boss fight, let alone get to use it throughout the normal gameplay. Its basically just a passive boost for me.

Edit 1: 
This yokai shift, and Demon charge bullshit, is really ruining this game for me.. Theres already SO many combos to remember, you now have to also remember to hit 2 additional buttons in a split second, whenever an enemy flashes red.. Oh, but you have to also time it perfectly!   I want to like the game, but this one demon form crap, and everything tied to it, is absolutely ruining it for me!

Edit 2:
I am now certain of it.. Nioh, is the better of the two. Nioh 2's introduction of the Burst Counter, and Yokai form system, simply turns the game into a panic button mash. Split second decisions will often leave you missclicking, while attempting to do 1of 101 different combinations of buttons, and menu swaps. I do enjoy the build crafting, and gear systems, coupled with amazing combat, but that Yokai crap really does ruin it.. 

What they SHOULD have focused on improving, was the mission selection.. Rather than choosing short maps from a hub world, it would have been nice to remain in one actual sandbox to play in!

Many might disagree, but Team Ninja ruined a golden formula, when they added Yokai form. Im going to leave it as a recommend, but my personal suggestion would be to play Nioh 1, instead of Nioh 2..

My hours speak for itself, but this is maybe my favorite game overall and I still have not even mastered every weapon type or completed all of the endgame underworld levels. It's hard to recommend this game because even though it is probably the most in depth, rewarding action game there is, its so deep that the entire first playthrough is actually a tutorial. By beating the game one time around youve just seen the tip of the iceberg. Build mechanics are complicated enough that they introduce them to you bit by bit so you won't even have something resembling an actual build until about NG++, and even then it is not even close to an endgame build. Not everyone is looking for something that takes 200 hours to understand and get good at, but if youre looking for a "forever game" that isn't a mmo or sandbox game, nioh is about the closest thing. No other action game has made me feel the way I do in nioh after stringing together a completely unique combo on the fly.

If youre coming from the souls games, be warned that nioh is much harder and does not offer any way to mitigate difficulty early on other than straight up playing coop. There isnt really anything comparable to summons or mimic tear until later NG cycles, so by the time they let you break the game youre already good enough that you dont need to.

Nioh 2 is the ultimate action RPG. Nioh as a series is like Dark Souls if it had Devil May Cry's depth of combat and set in feudal Japan. This game is more addictive than crack. The combat is so well done, so deep, so stylish, that any minor flaws you could come up with about this game can be completely ignored because fighting literally never gets boring. I've completed all the way to NG+4 "Dream of the Nioh", beat all 108 floors of the underworld, and beat all 30 floors of the abyss. Despite having almost 500 hours played, and completing all the endgame content, I only have mastered about half of the weapons. With how different each weapon plays, I could easily do it all again and have a completely fresh experience. Nioh does require you to master the mechanics of combat, especially ki pulsing and stance switching, so a metric fuck ton of "git gud" is required before you can truly go wild with the combat. 11/10, best game I've ever played, if you don't like Nioh, it's 100% a skill issue.

I am 32 years old.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and we adopted our son together. Both are now 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I felt lost and unhappy. I was self-destructive. One day, I was so angry with everything spiraling out of control that I punched a concrete wall in a moment of overwhelming emotion. This resulted in breaking my fifth metacarpal in my right hand‚Äîthe hand I worked with, played games with, and used to carry my children to bed‚Äîthe hand I desperately needed to ensure I could continue providing.

Upon learning the severity of the self-inflicted damage, I became almost suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man, with no history of depression or anxiety. I had never experienced anger outbursts, nor was I the type to break down and cry, but I was in a tough situation that truly prevented me from seeing the light on the other side.

With nothing better to do, I looked for a game I could play WITH ONE HAND while recovering. Somehow, I stumbled upon this game and read some of the comments. I decided it was worth a try... I must admit I didn't beat the game, nor did I play as much as some of you. In fact, I may have played this game for only a day or two. That being said, after doing so, I had a new joy and hope for life. I managed to leave behind the pain and suffering that had been thrust upon me. I could experience the joy and happiness of other people. I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes listening to this music, long enough to realize that I would be okay.

After realizing this, I turned off the game and went back to work. My hand hurt a lot, but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so sorry for myself and became the father I needed to be at that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving like.

Today, I am close friends with the mother of my children. We don't fight, argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents and friends.

Now I have 3 children. My third child is, wait, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my separation, and we just unexpectedly stumbled into each other's lives. We have been dating for a year and are very happy together.

Moral of the story: you never know what life has in store for you, and if I had given up when all odds were against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

I'll preface this by saying I'm not historically a big Souls-like player--I still can't figure out how to play Elden Ring without a guide. They just usually aren't my kinda game. 

Then I happened to come across a review on YouTube of Nioh 2 and was intrigued. I was a huge fan of Ninja Gaiden in the Xbox / Xbox 360 era and saw a lot of similarities in combat and style (and the Dragon Ninja skin, the nostalgia is real), obviously being Team Ninja. I've never found a game quite like Ninja Gaiden, and Nioh 2 is NOT quite the same, but it has all the satisfying elements that I loved about those games. Excellent combat mechanics, amazing presentation, and punishing difficulty. I haven't had this much trouble progressing in a game since Alma in Ninja Gaiden Black. But I love it. It's so satisfying to master a weapon and go from getting absolutely annihilated every 3 minutes to absolutely annihilating everything in your path. 

I don't have enough hours in any of the Souls games to really compare them, but this game felt more intuitive to me and I've only consulted walkthroughs and guides on particularly difficult bosses. I've always felt like I was missing out by not playing any Souls-like games for more than an hour or two, and now 45 hours into Nioh 2, I can't get enough. Even after all that time, I've barely scraped the surface of the deep mechanics, enemy types, weapon types, builds, etc. but I don't have that panicky feeling other Soulslike games give me. It's overwhelming, but I find it manageable and while the difficulty curve is quite high, it feels fair. 

I'm a couple years late to the Nioh party, but I'm having a great time with this game and will spend many more hours fighting my way through. Highly recommend if you like punishing games that have lots of variety and loot.

Just finished the story today and I gotta say, this game is a gem. Most of the community agrees and I as well that this isn't a souls-like. Yes, it is difficult. No, the game doesn't hold your hand. But all in all, its honestly fair and balanced. Plus with how supportive the community is to not only teach people how to play but even assist in build farming, its crazy how much this game went under the radar and still manages to have people still playing it. 

This is a game for those who want a challenge but doesn't get frustrated at dying to a small mob. It will slap you around and it will kick your ass if you mistime your counter, block or movement. Chi Pulses are the name of the game and the skill combos are the bread and butter. Experiment with weapons in your first play through, along with building tank so you can get use to how certain mobs/bosses work. If you are looking to take a slow pace though, I would not recommend the Summon option in the Shrine as most, if not all, people using it are end gamer that speed run the crap out of it. I would recommend using the "blue" graves for the extra body and assist as it is AI ran and the same for the "red" graves as they drop decent gear if killed (keep in mind that if the enemy does fall off or drown, you will not get any loot). 

I will say, this game does have some REALLY good jump scares as there are mobs at every angle so pay attention and be sure to find a good median between aggressiveness and caution. Lastly, and what matters most, have fun. Don't focus on end game when your playing though, don't worry about builds until you get close to the end and figure out how YOU want to play the game. There is no meta. There are options for everyone out there. Definitely more flexible than Diablo ever was lol.

10/10. Would recommend the complete edition at retail but if its on sale, definitely buy it up and start training samurai :)

Nioh 2 isn't a souls-like, as has been a common misconception since Nioh 1. The most it has in common with Dark Souls is the lock-on, but that's where the similarities begin and end. You don't dodge roll through most attacks, you either block them or don't get hit at all.  This is a high-speed hack and slash with RPG elements and a loot system that gets addicting reaaaaaaaaal fast.

The weapon roster is sublime, with skill trees that actually matter and an endless number of potential builds due to the loot system. Yokai Abilities make you feel like an absolute gigachad, and allow you to dish out just as much bombastic insane damage to the very same enemies who can one-shot you on later difficulties.  Nioh 2 is fair, Nioh 2 is refined, Nioh 2 is one of the best games of its genre.

Nioh 2 is my favorite game of all time. It had the fast-paced combat of the first Nioh plus some minor polishing, which makes the combat feel natural; the loot system of something akin to Diablo; the build variety and options that are making me come back and grind to create my ideal build; and finally, the music, graphics, and environmental work are just full-on tongue kiss exquisite. It's like a juicy burger with just the right amount of flavor, and when you bite into it, the burger juice just gushes on your tongue, and it tastes so good, like the best experience I ever had.

So for the combat, it's just the same as the previous Nioh, but with much added QOL changes and some extra spices, which I really like. I've tried and handled all weapons in this game, and the crazy thing is that no matter what two-weapon combination you use, it's all viable. You don't need to worry much about stats and weapon scaling clashing because of the flexibility and complexity of the build system here. Yeah, it can get overwhelming at first since this game's systems are complicated af but if you learn how things work, then you're in for a creamy ride. Enemy variety have also been ramped up with many new enemy types in every mission/region which always keep me on my toes (especially slow down and paralyzing enemies).

As for the loot system, it's still the same RNG-based loot system as in Nioh 1, which is kinda eh, but I understand that the gameplay loop revolves around this, so I just stick with it, and it's not that bad; every now and then you get some crazy loot with amazing stats, which is just dopamine-inducing (I sound like a gambling addict, lol). That aside tho, the main juice here is the newly added boss skills that can drop randomly whenever you kill a boss. All of the boss skills are super cool, and some have even become my favorite skills to use (I'm looking at you, Arc of Chaos and Roar Power).

Now as for the story and mission structure, I very much like it more than in the first Nioh, not because it is something ground-breaking or something, but because it made me feel something human, with the added anime and fantastical twist. Minor spoilers: [spoiler]You are a silent protagonist named Hide, and you joined Tokichiro in his rise to the top of Japan while watching him slowly get more and more insane until it reached the point where you had to stop him.[/spoiler] Now for me, this just oozes anime story telling and I really like what they've done here. The story is told in a 50-year-long sequence, with you doing the main and sub-missions to fill in the story. There are even some two-ending missions where if you do a specific thing, you can get a different ending, get an NPC to partner up with you in another mission, or unlock a new quest line for that NPC near the end of the game, which is really dope and allows for some replayability.

Finally, the music, graphics, and environmental work, like I said at the beginning of this review, are an instant creamy tongue kiss. First, the music is a mix of orchestral band, digital sound and mixing, and traditional Japanese instruments, which came out great and has a lot of impact on how you experience the game. I beg you to let the music and SFX do the work while you're playing this game because not only is it good, but it also amped up my experience of the game. Daddy Magara, the sixth region, and the interim are some of my favorite OSTs in the game. Let's move on to the graphics and environmental work. The graphics are much sharper and have been updated, but they are still in the same style as the first Nioh, which some people might be turned off, but hear me out. The graphics are nothing like God of War 2018, but it still get the job done. The environmental work tho are some of, if not one of, the best fantastical depictions of Japan that I have ever seen in a game in recent years. Unlike the previous Nioh, which had the theme of feudalistic Japan, where you go through castles and caves most of the time. Here in Nioh 2, you go through some amazing and eye-catching maps (like Daigoji Temple, Viper Sanctum, etc.) that will make you stop and breathe in the environment for a moment. It made me remember first visiting Anor Londo in Dark Souls 1, where the scenery is so beautiful that I need a minute to just take it in. The DLC maps, however, have all of the traits that I've described and bring them to 11. All of the DLC, maps, bosses, and music are oozing with anime juice, and I was worried I might be getting anime swag poisoning at this point.

Overall, this game is just amazing and is one of the best ARPGs or "souls-like" you can play right now. The price is a little steep for the state of my country's economy (went from P999/P599 to P2333/P1399), but it is worth the money with the amount of replayability and content offered to you. I've experienced some stuttering when first booting the game and also if my graphics driver has just been updated (FPS keeps jumping from 59 to 60), but it's a minor inconvenience that can be fixed. If you want to play co-op, the player base is still mostly alive (mostly on random encounters/summon visitors), but if you want to do expeditions, at least on the PC, then it's hit or miss (I've heard the PS version of the game is still pretty much alive), so I suggest joining the Nioh Discord channel and try asking there if you want to do some expeditions.

I want to love this game, but i find it nearly unplayable because it doesn't work on a fundamental level as far as the mechanics go.  Selective input buffering, inputs being eaten by the Ether, hitboxes that can make me want to gouge out my own eyes, and the physics (dear god the physics).  This game can feel amazing to play when everything flows well, but things seldom flow well in this game.  As with the first game, it is a delicate dance and high octane bullshit the whole way through, but overstays its welcome by about 60 hours.  There were several instances in this game where I had no idea what I was doing plot-wise, and wondering why the game wasn't over already.  

At the time of writing, I'm currently in a mandatory boss rush, and hating it so much that I felt the need to vent my frustrations in a review.  This isn't just a one-off bit of passion, though.  I've been welling up my frustration with this game throughout the entirety of this playthrough.  It can work beautifully, and then that sense of flow and thrill of combat gets replaced with the frustration that you have to deal with the same stuff over again, get bullshit constantly thrown at you from all angles, and then seemingly have your efforts insulted by a convoluted and frankly boring plot.  I enjoy Japanese history, but Team Ninja consistently find ways to make me yawn at one of my favorite historical periods.

3200 hours total playtime in 1,5 year and I personally give this game 7 points on 0-10 scale.

1.) COMBAT feels sooooo goood here, definitely an improvement from the first game. Nioh, at that time, came up with this new gameplay mechanic, that is good, and in Nioh 2 this mechanic is polished, refined. It is so impressive the devs were able to push this mechanic to an even higher level. Definitely one of its kind. A game with stamina limitation, which is applied to your character and enemies, but you are given a way to maintain that in good level so that as I play, I feel this "limitation" is not even there (when I play correctly that is). With this I can overwhelm my enemies, making them vulnerable, while I still have the upper hand in combat. This is BIG point that keep me playing.

1.2) This game provide variety of ways for players to approach the game, but CORE gameplay remain the same and ALL needed to play and win this game is to master the CORE gameplay. No need for extra buffs, debuffs, companions or whatever else the game itself provides. They are just here so gameplay may vary for each players and make the game feel fun for a long time. Tips: some part of this CORE gameplay need to be unlocked, it is in Samurai skill tree.

2.) Story is just "eeehh, good enough". Mixed between actual history and fantasy, Worse than the story in Nioh. Here your character is just side character, viewing everything from 3rd person perspective.

3.) Replay-bility is not good. Once every mission is cleared, there is no major difference with their higher difficulty. Play once through and done.

Recommended to play. Do not listen or take advice from random players about how to play the game. Any tips that sounds vague, I recommend just do not take them. You can check the stuff in the game. There is a tutorial in the game as well. DO NOT trust other player who thinks this game can only be played if you have the correct setup. They just suck at this game and felt they should compensate it with "specified" setup just to make them go easy through the game while what they actually need is just understanding the game's mechanics. This ultimately put the CORE gameplay under the shadow and if YOU play this game like that, you still have not experience what this game have to offer (for Nioh and Nioh 2).

One of those "Souls-like" games that's more than just "Dark souls but x," this game does a really good job at having the souls-like tag but still being itself. The combat has higher highs and lower lows, build diversity goes way beyond what weapon you use and what your weight load is, the "faith" and "intelligence" stats don't lock you out of using their respective abilities, and the way the low, mid and high stances keep the combat flowing are just a few breaths of fresh air from some of the others. The way NG+ works is a great leap forward from any of the Soulsborne games, in which going to NG+ doesn't wipe your NG progress and progresses way faster to ease the "playing the game with inflated enemy stats" feeling.

[b]Banger game[/b], slightly hidden gem to me ! It feels good to play & it's pretty long (just finished it main + sides missions). 

[b]The game story[/b] is centred around Japan Samurai era & spirits folklore, it's really entertaining with lot of cut scene almost every instanced levels (missions) you clear. These missions are in 2 categories, "main" that can be pretty long (30/60min) and sides that are faster (5 min for a boss fight, 15min for a mini level).

[b]The gameplay[/b] is very dynamic and quite unique, this game is close to a soul game with it's own twists. It's very enjoyable, you have your dodge, parry and even a way to recover your stamina (ki in this game) with good timing. The fighting style varies depending on which weapons you "main", every weapons have it's own skill tree. It's a bit overwhelming at 1st, but eventually you'll get use to the differents mecanics and master your art ! 

[b]One thing I wish they improve [/b] if they ever make a sequel, it's to change the looting system, the game is centered around looting TONS of weapons & armor, it's your main currency actually in this game, you can sell it for XP,Money, Ranking in your clan, Materials, Improving your gear (later)... It's a bit tidious to have to "clean" your inventory. This game could go a bit closer to Monster Hunter way of doing or just embrace the Soul way of doing and then nothing would stop you to just enjoy your fights and chain missions !

[i]Tips : Invest some points in Nijutsu & Magic, they are really fun "spells" in this game, enjoy ! [/i]

Feeling disappointed with Wo Long Fallen Dynasty I picked up Nioh 2 for the third time. Even after all these years no other action RPG manages to even come close to Nioh's complex and satisfying combat system. Combined with the amount of viable builds and Diablo like gear progression this is one of the best games in the genre.

After over 150 hours I finally managed to achieve 100 % on the game and feel comfortable enough to write this review.  For a  TLDR version this game can be either a 7,5/10 or a 9/10 and that depends on your preferences. To put it simply the game has problems with higher difficulties and scaling. That leads to it changing from a game about a guy slaying demons to a game about farming. If you like a challenge but don't like farming it will be a 7,5/10. If you like a challenge and don't mind farming it will be a 9/10.

Nioh 2 is a prequel-sequel to the original Nioh. You play as a human-yokai hybrid called Hide and participate in the events of the Sengoku Jidai period. At first you start right before Oda Nobunaga's rise to power and eventually conclude the story started in the previous game. You don't need to play Nioh 1 to understand the story. There are some references here and there but nothing substantial 

The game is divided in 10 regions. Every region has it's own set of main and sub missions. Some sub mission can be unlocked after meeting certain criteria. Each mission loads you into a map where you will fight either human or Yokai enemies. Exploring the map will reward you with additional treasure chests, kodamas (every 5 kodamas is a free health elixir at the shrine),  or interacting with Nurikabe yokai guarding a secret passage.  Exploring the map is certainly worth it. For example in the final mission of region 1 you can discover a hidden passage that let's you flank the enemies and destroy a snake statue. It's destruction dispels the dark realm, unlocks a shrine near the boss and drains poisonous water on your path. So careful exploration could be a difference between having a hard fight or a cakewalk. 

Speaking of dark realms this is a new mechanic added in Nioh 2. There are certain areas on the map in which you enter a dark zone. You get a debuff that hinders your stamina (here called KI)  regeneration and to get rid of that you need to hunt the host of the dark realm. The host is a buffed up Yokai enemy. Once you kill him the dark realm disappears, all of the remaining enemies have their ki drained and once killed will not respawn again. Honestly for me it's a mixed mechanic. Once the novelty wore off  it became annoying and before every fight I made sure to use either a spell or a consumable to boost my ki regeneration. 

Enemy variety is excellent. Sure there are some reused or reskinned ones but overall you won't complain about enemy diversity. Human opponents wield different types of weaponry and deal tremendous damage but usually don't have much health.They are also spaced more tightly than Yokai enemies and if you're not careful you can aggro an entire group. Fighting 3+ humans can easily lead to your demise. 

Yokai enemies have a fantastic presentation and a varied move set. They have high poise, deal good damage but have their fair share of weaknesses. All of them won't regenerate stamina/ki. Depleting them out of it will make them stagger on any attack. After a while they will summon a dark puddle that will regenerate their ki and regain their poise. If you completely deplete their ki reserves ( the ki bar becomes smaller after each attack) they will be vulnerable to a grapple attack, (same for human enemies) There are also some enemy specific counters. For example nure onna is a giant big titted snake lady. She is dangerous but her attacks deal almost no ki damage when blocking. The big one eyed oni hits hard but has long recovery windows and his attacks are easy to avoid or burst counter etc. Speaking of which both enemies have special red glowing attacks that deal a lot of damage. You get a move called a burst counter. Basically you change into a yokai and block the attack, denying the damage. There are 3 types of burst counters and each has a different timing to it. For example the phantom burst counter requires you to change right before the hit so it's great to counter attacks with little wind up. 

Of course the game offers you over 45+ bosses to fight. Now in the first game the bosses were for me the low point because they heavily leaned into one shots or cheap attacks. This was partially fixed in Nioh 2. Most of the Yokai bosses are great and fun to fight. During the fight the yokai boss can transport you into a dark realm where he gains enhanced or new attacks and you gain a ki debuff.  Overall this changes the pace and makes more sense than the usual level dark realms. When it comes to human or hybrid bosses I had the opposite feeling. Most of them were annoying and on higher difficulties many of them were obnoxious.  Human bosses don't play by the rules. They deal too much damage, have too high ki regeneration, block too much, have too much health and can do things the player can't replicate. Which leads to most people cheesing them to hell. 

When it comes to character customization this is Nioh 2 biggest strength and weakness. You can create your own protagonist and decide how to build him. There are 11 types of melee weapons and 3 types of ranged weapons There are dozens of armors, many of them being a part of a set, there are 2 accessory slots, skill trees for each weapon, your yokai abilities, samurai skills, 3 fighting styles for each weapon. dozens of guardian spirits that enhance your abilities, dozens of soul cores that grant you special yokai abilities, ninjutsu, magic, special consumables, hundreds of special effects on your items. Add to that new mechanics on each difficulty and you got a product that you can invest hundreds of hours into. Nioh 2 combat is amazing because you can make every weapon and almost every build work. First time I've played a spear and sword heavily armored samurai, Then I respecced into a more agile tonfa and ninjutsu user. After that I wanted to bonk people with my axe and odachi. Each time the experience was different and amazing. Combat is incredibly satisfying. I can comfortably say that Nioh 2 has the best combat from all the souls like games and one the best endgames in the industry. Just type in YT a compilation video and be  astounded of what a truly dedicated player can achieve. 

Unfortunately all of the above is also a negative. Like the first one this game is over bloated with stats, items and has questionable scaling on higher difficulties. I've completed dream of the samurai, then dream of the strong, most of dream of the demon and around half of dream of the wise. After that there was dream of the nioh and the underworld levels. The first two difficulties were fantastic, dream of the demon had me surprised with the increased damage and hp pools but I still managed to beat it. Dream of the wise was honestly annoying. Big hp bars and even the most irrelevant enemy dealt tremendous damage. So to counter that I started farming. Heavily. Better gear, more stats, fishing for better item effects, getting better scrolls and so on. You are constantly under leveled, need more gear, need more resources for tempering it can become overwhelming. The worst part is that you can't craft etheral gear and one item used for tempering weapons is locked behind limited twilight mission or coop.  Why? it ruins the progression and limits the usefulness of crafting and forces you to farm even more. Farming for those isn't made easier by the enemies. They scale better than you and become sponges that hit like a truck. Many bosses have suddenly one shot attacks. human bosses become toxic and you start to question if all of those builds you see online were achieved legitimately.  Every fight is a mixture of buffs, debuffs, consumables or cheese because the game was balanced around having magic and ninjutsu (again). 

In the end I farmed+30 etheral gear and did the final mission on dream of the demon.  For the most time my experience was great but unfortunately by the end I lowered my score for the game to a 7,5/10. For more dedicated players this could be a 9/10.

This game is so fun. Very engaging gameplay with insanely broad customization! The combat is a very polished version of Nioh 1 with added depth, which was already a phenomenal combat system. If you feel like you're tired of playing a dodge simulation, that runs on 0.5x speed, then give this game a try, you won't regret it. If you're a Dark Souls fan, looking for other games in the genre, just know that the combat takes getting used to, it is much faster than Dark Souls, with a more responsive combat system, but once you get used to it, it feels very satisfying to play and succeed with it.

The enemies you fight are very well telegraphed. Every time I died, I knew why and had a basis on which to start thinking how to improve. Never felt like the game is unfair, unlike some other popular games in the genre. Did not need to look up boss tactics at all to figure fights out at all.

If you enjoy following the story and lore of such games, it is easy to follow and prety interesting. You don't have to click on 1000 little notes and items, then figure out the bosses' star signs and then put all that information together in order to have a vague idea of what is going on in the world.

Performance wise, I had no issues, despite the game having beautiful graphics and me not having the best PC.

Overall, would recommend, wholeheartedly!

Best combat and builds in a souls-like and it's not even close.

If you are starting the game and have problems, in the first ng cycle is all about learning the game, don't worry about builds or optimising yet, you can reallocate your stats later in the game at laughably low cost and the game gives you gear more powerful (higher level) constantly, so just equip whatever you like trying to stay in the agility you want (<30% equipment weight is A, <70% is B, the better the grade the more distance you dash and the lower your ki consumption, being in C is usually not good). Try to level up everything up, as the stats are there mostly to equip things most of the game, and most builds want 20 or 30 in everything anyway. If you have troubles with yokais (the dudes with purple ki bar), always try to hit the yellow amrita things, it's their weakspot (mostly the head), they'll be stunned and lose a lot of ki, if they are out of ki it's your time to unleash your damage, as they'll be stunned by anything until they recover. Low stance is for dodging, mid stance is for blocking and meh dodging (will do dash into roll), very balanced, and high stance is for damage (and will just roll when trying to dodge). Blocking an attack is almost always better than getting hit, even with low toughness, so just hold block while dodging (beware, normally only mid stance will recover ki while trying to block)

The game can be hard as it's shown to the player like a Devil May Cry game, showing you little by little while increasing the difficulty, as the game has a LOT of mechanics to use to your advantage and rewards aggressive gameplay, where knowing the enemy and the game rewards you a lot. In contrast with other souls combat, here you will mostly try to actually dodge the attack rather than rolling straight to it, because like in Bloodborne you have both a dash with low I-frames but very quick and a roll with high I-frames but slow with high recovery, which is better for dodging big single hits.

The game gets better after every playthrought, if you beat the game you'll want to play NG+, where enemies have new moves and mix the counterable attacks around. Every new cycle unlocks new types of equipment or build-enabling sets, furthering increasing build customisation.

There a LOT of viable, fun and very different builds in this game, from tanks to high dps glass cannons, mages, ranged gameplay that actually feels engaging and powerful, status effect builds, self-inflicted status effect builds, embracing the yokai side and trying to stay in your yokai form as long as possible, unarmed, bomberman, etc. All those and you still have to choose your weapon that changes a lot how you approach the fights, with powerful but slow axe/hammer attacks, to fast and mobile dual swords/tonfas, balanced but technical with sword, maintaining your range advantage with spear, hybrid between melee/ranged with dual hatchets/kusarigama. All weapons have a multitude of skills to unlock and customise, to use in the free-style combat system of this game.

Go play a from software game they are so much better its ridiculous. This game follows no pattern. One mission a specific mini boss ad will be staggered and allow you to spam him when hes out of ki (like its supposed to) and in the next it will just one shot you when he is out of ki (the stamina in this game). This trend of not following patterns also occurs in almost every boss fight. An attack will do a specified thing 15 times and then one time it will not follow the pattern and 1 shot you. The draw of souls like games is that they are challenging but fair and once you understand the move set and pattern then they reward you and you feel like a god slayer. Nioh is not this. So many times they ramp up the difficulty by using gank fights and especially putting in ads in boss fights which is just lazy poor design. The game also struggles from major inconsistencies. One level will be one of the most amazing areas and fights and layout of any game you have ever played and then bam next mission is gank fights and gimmicks. This game also makes the main parry mechanic for monsters a limited item and if you dont watch your amitra then you can perfectly time it but oh, you cant parry because you dont have amitra and forget about parrying when you first load into a mission because you have no amitra. Whoever had the idea to make a parry thats contingent on something other than skill should be fired. You dont unlock the parry for humanoid enemies till at least 50% of the way through the game and if you miss it then you are basically dead. 
Making a game like this thats supposed to be skill based but have it so reliant on level and making parrying the way it is is just bad design. Not to mention side missions are mandatory or you will be so under leveled it will be impossible unlike every souls game where if you are good enough you can beat the game with any build. The leveling system is so convoluted that you HAVE to look up a guide for it. This game has no flexibility in the way you can play it. I wanted so badly to like this game because of all the good and promise i saw in it but sadly i cannot recommend this game when there are such better options out there.

Actually might be my favorite game ever, just looking at the combat alone. Requires a lot of practice and memory to get good, and the boss fights are incredible. Play either solo or cooperatively and fight the Oni scourge that are running amuck across Japan, even a basic summary about the game sounds cool, which it is. However, the loot system is more akin to Diablo or an MMO rather than a souls-like (basically grindy AF).

The game had a few other problems but I particularly hated that loot one.

Let me be clear that I am enjoying my time with this game. Sadly it's just not a game I can recommend to most because the best parts are too niche, this game is not beginner friendly and it does not get easier.

If you are a Souls fan then this game isn't for you, it controls more similarly to DMC than any souls game. 
That said I am a self proclaimed master of the souls series having beaten every installment to completion over multiple platforms.

The enemy design is my first main problem with this game, some animations they do are either too fast or too slow, and before the turbo autists get on me for whining about their flawless game I'm not talking about hitboxes I'm talking how good they look and move. I will complain about some enemies being able to do 180 degree turns on attacks with even a little delay, especially when that attack is any kind of leap or jump. 

The game has a system where a boss will flash red and unleash a strong attack, this can be easily compared to sekiro's perilous attack, you perform a specific button combo every time at the right moment and you get a nice bonus.
Burst counters range from consistent and satisfying to confusing and frustrating.  Yatsu no Kami is a boss where I burst counter into the ramming attack (which moves awkwardly slow btw) and nothing will happen. I take no damage and the boss just keeps going. Sometimes delaying the counter too much creates a similar issue where I swear I should have failed but I got to dash into her for free to both no reward and no punishment. On the other hand the first boss Mezuki felt harsh but fair and satisfying when I learned the counter timings and started getting the hang of counters in general.

The weapons look great but the armor is meh to me, a lot of the heavy sets look similar.

Don't buy this game unless it's your specific flavor of over complicated. I've got Yakuza for that.

My final issue is that money is too difficult to come across early game and that the prices for things can become outrageous quickly.

I will be completing this game to get my money's worth.

The exception being that first fight with the giant club demon right at the start, and the first boss fight with a more complex version of it.

Don't worry, this lasts for about 2-3 hours of gameplay. Maybe more if you are new to these types of games.
What was once a prodding simulator 2.0 now is a good combo type system now that you no longer have effectively 0 stamina. Suddenly now that you can attack more than once, each weapon's moveset now seems unique and brings different benefits to the table. The burst counters now are very useful - maybe too useful but fun to use.  You now aren't running out of arrows every 2 seconds. Armour sets stats and set bonuses now actually do stuff.  Enemies start to show you more complex movesets and yokai become much more common.  Suddenly crafting weapons now serves a purpose (not really the same case with armour until much, much later).  

Mid game which is where i think i'm at is where the game shines. All the gear looks good. especially the master archer armour. the skill board for each weapon type unlocked by ACTUALLY USING THE WEAPON.. such a simple concept but is really effective.. i've started to notice that the points spent in it now have become more impactful and not just additions one would expect as part of the default moveset.

The customisation is nuts, absolutely insane. Also the enemy variety at the point is excellent. there are only 2 of them that i find are a waste of space but the rest actually seem unique and are fun to fight. (Waira and Rokurokubi) Rest are pretty good and you will find you use different parts of your movesets against them quite uniquely which is a massive achievement for a game like this. And with each weapon being unique, this just makes things even more interesting.

When thinking of the customisation in this game, one can think of it like the following for just combat related items... let's treat every system as a value of '2'. most games have; An array of weapons 1*2=2, weapons and armour with different states weights and set bonuses 2*2 = 4, Levelling starts individually to create different specs 4*2=8, unique bosses, enemies and strategies to beat them 8*2=16, skill tree 16*2 = 32, usable items 32*2=64.   

This game takes this baseline then adds different stances 64*2=128, each weapon having its own skill tree 128*2=256, skills our can slot gained from enemies 256*2=512. and so on.
While thinking of it this way has its clear flaws, you get the picture. Every unique system they added interacts with the last adding more than just one interaction, but another node in a giant web that adds more and more complexity exponentially.

Just excellent. :) give it a shot on sale, you won't regret it.

While Dark Souls is claimed to be a hard game, for me Nioh 2 (and Nioh) is a much, much harder game. 

The combat in Nioh 2 (especially) is fluid in its animations and its combos, while very complex at the same time with its stance system (switching from low, medium and high stance to chain together combos) and ki pulsing to keep the dance of offensive and defensive going.

While this game is a ‚Äúsouls-like‚Äù - it plays very differently from the traditional Soulsborne games. In fact its many mechanics can make this game feel overwhelming at times to grasp and master.

While I personally will never achieve the greatest mastery (or even elegance) while playing this game, it is very satisfying to play regardless - once you find your rhythm. 

With all that said, you will die in this game. A lot. But keep at it, and you will find a game with a lot of nuance to its combat system, a decent narrative - that blends historical events with folklore - and a musical score that sets the tone perfectly.

A punishing masterpiece.

Graphics are decent but not the best.  Where this game really shines is the combat system.  Nioh 2 has one of the most interesting, flexible and well balanced combat systems of any game.  Any character build is viable, depending on your play style.  

There are over a dozen different weapon classes, each with its own move sets in three different stances, making for a much larger number of move sets than most games of this type.  All of the moves for each different combination of weapon category and stance feel very different and support a different style of play.  Add to that different guardian spirits with their own upgrades, complex and highly customizable skill trees and ninjitsu and magic abilities and there is a truly astonishing number of different approaches one can take to each situation, all of which are viable.

The game is quite tough, I am still early on and it is already starting to get quite spicy.  If you like this sort of thing (as I do) then this is a definite plus, however, if you are easily frustrated or do not enjoy very challenging, even masochistic games, then this may not be for you (nothing wrong with that).

The story is minimal but a little more than dark souls games and the lore of the game is actually quite deep, borrowing heavily from elements of traditional Japanese mythology.  There is a lot to explore in terms of setting and lore if you want, though you can just focus on combat if that is your choice.

Like a Dark Souls game, take it slow, take it calm and get into the rhythm... you won't regret it.

Don't buy this game or it's predecessor nioh if you're looking for a great storytelling experience. Both games are horrible at that. What this game offers instead is a great combat experience. 

There's different types of weapons with a lot of move sets, stances and active skill attachments that allow you to customise combat in many different ways, and starting with a weapon doesn't mean you have to stick with it. Personally, I was able to get the veteran skills for all the weapons by endgame. Just make sure you don't throw away your weapon drops of the weapon type you aren't using.

One mistake that a lot of people including me made with nioh 1 was to just play the main missions. This can make the endgame quite difficult because of the steep level requirements. Playing the side missions are really important as it helps to close the level gap. Also, offering weapons and items you dont need to the shrine gets you a lot of amrita for levelling up.

I will say though, managing the gear and items in this game can be frustrating for people starting out. Too many weapon drops and the interface isn't helping much.

That being said, I can gladly recommend this game to anyone looking for a challenging combat experience.
