If you are looking for the ultimate souls like experience with an extremely free-form and expressive combat system, with lots of depth, adjustable difficulty, then this game is for you. It's hard for me to go back to any other souls like after this, except maybe for their stories, because Nioh 2 towers above them all, including WO LONG, Team Ninja's new entry.

Solid action game with a wide variety of weapons and skills to keep the game interesting. It is very challenging to get into but is highly satisfying to finally learn it. That being said, even after the first hundred hours, I definitely haven't seen everything by that point. While I personally don't care for the RNG loot spam, I know many players will appreciate being able to grind for items to make a build tailor-made for their own unique playstyle. The main drawback for me is just how many items you constantly have to sort through. This was already a problem in Nioh 1, and it is worse now with the addition of the soul cores and how many of them are actually useful or not. I'm also not a fan of the rehashes from Nioh 1 or the overly repetitive side missions, but the overall quality of life improvements in Nioh 2 set it apart from the original and provides a much more enjoyable experience compared to the previous title. The highly detailed and visually appealing character creator is amazing and allows for numerous customization options. If you like challenging action games, fun gameplay, and a wide array of weapons and tools to choose from, look no further than Nioh 2. This game is a solid 8.5/10 in my book.

Probably one of the better, if not best, hack-n-slash/beat-em-up/action games within recent history. 
Its primary flaws are sadly its strengths though. This game is not accessible in the slightest, it relies on quick reflexes, good timing, and good combat know-how if you want to do well. It becomes even more structured the later into the game you go.

Combat-wise, the game 110% revolves around the premise that is a stance system. Think of any Devil May Cry game where Dante has more than one fighting style. That is exactly how this works, except learning how to fluidly roll between Low/Mid/High stance makes your game astonishingly good. If you can manage to recognize when to be in each stance you will pass most challenges with flying colors.

In this game, your target is not the enemy's health bar; it is the enemy's KI BAR. As difficulty progresses, you will find that more and more your goal is to hit enemies with elements they are weak to, exploit strong techniques, and counter-attack at the correct point to unleash an absolute mess of whoop-ass on an enemy once their stamina runs dry. Always consider that your goal first and foremost. Going a little bit harder on the aggressive side (in a smart way) also allows you to Ki-Break opponents faster leading to openings for criticals and even Zero-Ki punishes.

Build availability is exceptional with almost every single form of build viable and almost every single form of build you can imagine. Do you want to be a dextrous shinobi with the whole utility belt? This is the only game that has a flippin KUSARIGAMA. Do you wanna be just shy of a bandit warlord? Say hello to Axe and laugh as nothing can guard against you. Do you want to be a monk? Fist weapons are absurdly strong. Do you want to be the OG Samurai? The game would love if you did that. Do you want to be a marksman, carefully shooting out opponents one by one and exploiting the creation of gunpowder? You can basically be a ninja-gunslinger (I'm not even kidding, just be mindful the shots aren't rapid fire). Do you want to be a anime magic priest? Onmyo magic. The list is basically unending.

The reason that builds are also so complex is because later in difficulty you'll 100% need to exploit status effects on enemies. If you ever find yourself not doing enough damage, start looking for a status to specialize in. Lots of weapons and items have abilities which increase base attack % (by a good margin) when an enemy is inflicted with certain status. This pairs well when combining status effects as it causes the "confusion" debuff which is basically an enemy death sentence.

For those who played Nioh 1, this game feels almost the same as the first one with more of everything, maybe easier bosses, but you have 3 new weapon types and new abilities as well as a great in depth character creator.

The game has a lot of "souls-like" feeling in it with check points being shrines that reset enemies in the map and allows you to spend Amrita (think of it like souls) on levels, lose Amrita on death and also find them in items to use.

There are so many RPG elements like in depth character creation, skill point distribution, set bonuses, deep abilities tree for each weapon, fighting stances and a viable weapon variety making any weapon fun enough to play. Magic or Ninjutsu abilities can also be unlocked to use along with any weapon, adding more depth to any build. The more skills you unlock more fluid the combat becomes, making it easier for you to just die. Skills can be reset and it's not so expensive to, you can buy the reincarnation books at the blacksmith as soon as you unlock her, with glory as soon as you unlock the glory guy or with those evil Kodamas by giving them whatever, they're all drunk. (I know I kept resetting my build every 3 missions, not cause it was bad or good, just because it was entertaining to try new things).

The action part of the game is really fluid and worth playing, you got evading and parrying mechanics, different fighting stances each one adding more offensive or defensive capabilities to your character and it feels rewarding due to how difficult some parts of the game can be if you are not paying enough attention, actually it feels rewarding even if you are a souls veteran who finished every difficult game you played in the first attempt without dying or using any armor at all simply cause every new unlock is worth. 
As the story progresses enemies get harder and new ones are introduced, keeping your serotonin in check.

The story part of the game was really nice to me with all the Japanese lore and having a character and monsters directory telling more about each character you see in game as well as creature not to mention I felt really feel involved with the game campaign and it feels personal.

Co-op mode is possible although I haven't really tried, but you need an item, which is not hard to get anyway and the system seems to work similarly to Dark Souls co-op mode.

Finishing the game adds a whole new level of difficult and item rarities, so you can just come back for more. Not to mention items with set bonuses tend to become more common as you play more and find more smithing texts and farm revenants and their shady ways to die.

The graphics are a little messy with too much lighting effects but it looks good anyway and it's well optimized (these effects can be set to low on options making the game look cleaner).

This game is a hardcore RPG set in medieval japan.
Calling it a "Souls like" would be only a quarter of the truth and would not give it the justice it deserve.

Yes of course, the game uses element from Dark souls, you have the equivalent of fire (Which in that case are temple), difficulty is here, you have to manage your endurance when attacking, you can summon allies to help you, you have the equivalent of souls to spend to level up, dying will make you loose those souls, and the similarities ends here.

The game does it's own thing for a good portion of the game.
First of all, you don't play on a huge open map, you play on differents mission that occurs on different maps, maps that can have multiple different mission on it, but they are every time a different instance of the map with some minor changes in it or objectives.
There are no intrusive invasion in this game, it instead take a different approach, when other player die, they leave a red mark on your side, and you can summon a bot of the player that died, and fight it to get some loot.

The gameplay is where the difference lies, first, for each melee weapon, you have 3 stances: up which give you the strongest hit, but leav you vulnerable to attacks, medium which is a good balance of attack and defense, and low which give you a lot of mobility to dodge but you do less damages.
There is also game mechanic that allows you to recover Stamina faster once you get the hang of the gameplay, hence rewarding the player for mastering the game.

And all of that, is combined on multiple weapons that will deal differents damages, wether it's more stamina damages, leaving your oponent open to critical strikes, or more health damages.
Also there is a difference with Fast damages that combine well with element you can apply using Magic on your weapon or hard hitting weapons like the axe or the Odachi.

The game also handle the weapon differently.
Instead of your character knowing al the moves on a weapon, you need dto learn special attack by using the designated weapon. For instance, the more you use magic and Katana, the more point you'll get to spend on these element to learn new spell and move for your katana.

The way the game handle the loot is also very different, and this time it's more akin to a Hack and Slash, where you get a ton of equipment with different level of rarity, with different skills, and these weapon can be reduced into component to make other weapon that can be better depending on what component you're using. They can also be tinkered to match more or less your gameplay.
And if you have any doubt of what skill does what to your weapon/armor, there is an in-built help into the game that tells you EVERYTHING.

As for the story, it follow more or less the Japanese Medieval Era story, where you encounter Nobunaga Oda, with a Yoka√Ø and magic twist.

Overall this game is awesome, does great things by itself and has it's own identity.

Literally the best videogame that has ever been made, by a profoundly large margin. It isn't a Souls-like, claiming it is a Souls-like it equivalent to claiming Pokemon is a Souls-like because your Pokemon gain experience and improve their stats by leveling. Or claiming it is a Monster Hunter-like because it has action combat. It absolutely has Monster Hunter and Souls-like blood in there, but neither is remotely accurate.

It's a mission/stage based action RPG with INTENSELY deep stats, gear, and general mechanics and gameplay with a staggering amount of room for player expression in their gameplay style. If you beat the story, you have not beaten the game, in fact, the first 5 "New Game +" difficulties are all basically just a tutorial for the real game, The Abyss. There are people that aren't even aware that once you've hit the maximum number of stats that can be allocated at level 750, there is an entire additional leveling system AFTER that with different stats you can put point into.

The multiplayer options are 2: Summoning Co-Op, where while you are in a level you can summon either a rando or a friend to come into the level and help. This mode functions like the singleplayer mode and if you die you get sent back to the last shrine you were at and your cooperator is sent home. If they die, you need to go resummon them. The scaling in this mode, and ever enemy layout and types are different than the other MP mode using the Torii Gate.

Torii Gate MP is a different type of gameplay. In this mode you have a bar that depletes if any of the players go down and it drains until they are aided by another player or the player opts to just deplete the bar a set amount and get up on their own. If the bar bottoms out, you lose. Unless you're in a boss fight, if it bottoms out in a boss fight, it simply means that those who are dead cannot be revived and it is up to the surviving players to either beat the boss without going down anymore or fail. Like I said earlier, this mode's enemy types and layouts in missions can range from slightly different to quite a bit different, and the scaling on the enemy HP, damage, and Ki are different than both solo and summon Co-Op. This mode is much, much, harder in many respects than either of the other 2 gameplay options and both requires more game knowledge to do well, but unfortunately it can be "unfair" due to how difficult or even at certain point impossible it is to flinch or stagger enemies or bosses, who in solo or summon co-op you could stunlock but you cannot in Torii Gate co-op. It's certainly an anti-cheese measure and mostly just makes the game tougher, but on rare occasion, it CAN feel a little bad if you are used to stunning/staggering certain enemies and now you cannot.

Getting this complete edition on sale if the best choice you would make in your life, that wife you love, that child you had? Nothing compared to how solid of a choice buying this game is.

As a spiritual successor to the Ninja Gaiden series, the game features a freedom of expression in combat that I really have not seen in many games. There are a dozen weapon types to choose from, and you may use two of them at the same time. Keep in mind to get good at a single weapon you might need to spend a playthrough or two just using that weapon. Add in the new systems introduced in Nioh 2 like burst counters, yokai abilities and yokai shifting and the complexity only grows.
Yet in the midst of the complexity, Nioh feels suprisingly simple once you get the hang of it. Unlike dark souls, that in my opinion only starts being fun when you are mildly ok at the game, there is constantly something fun to discover in Nioh 2's combat regardless of skill level.
Every boss in this game can be beaten in either preferred playstyles, weather that be knowledge of weaknesses you may exploit, through the challenge of learning to evade and perfectly block the enemies you fight, or sheer style once you get good at the game. Its a gift that keeps on giving.
I also want to spend a moment to talk about the level design. While it lacks the metroidvania feel of the world of a souls game, Nioh 2 accomplishes that same kind of level design that I loved in Dishonored 2. Almost every main story level feels memorable for one reason or another while still keeping the focus on its primary gameplay loop. 
While I would say the game is overall easier than the original Nioh there is still plenty of challange to be found, especially in the postgame that also taps into a lot of the looter-shooter/diablo-esque focus on getting and upgrading new items.
Enemy design is extremely varied. There are a lot of unique enemies to be found, with variants that are not just cheap recolors but have new unique moves, forcing you to pay attention what you really are fighting.

In the end the core of what I wanted to get across with this review is that if you liked Dark Souls, you may not necessarily like Nioh. Comparisons are great and all, but Nioh is trying to do it's own thing and it does it damn well. However, I would also say the inverse is true: If you did not like the Dark Souls series you may end up still really liking Nioh; Especially this second game. Or maybe end up like me and love both of the series and have a jolly good time kicking down gods and demons alike.

I've already destroyed this game on PS4, and I only really bought it so I could Alt+Tab to it while drawing on my PC(and I've only recently begun really playing it thanks to my Steam Deck), so this is just a big block of gushy nonsense; skip to the very bottom for my overall verdict.

This is an incredibly fun game that will absolutely seem cheap and unfair for the first 10-20 hrs. or so, but if you stick with it, you'll find a game with more diverse build options, deeper combat, and more replay value than anything else on the market it could be compared to. The way it plays is unlike anything else, and(if you're a Souls vet in particular)some of the new habits you'll have to pick up will take a bit to stick. The amount of systems, commands, and equipment choices available to you at any one point can easily overwhelm.

...and that's a good thing.

The fast-paced nature of the combat, coupled with timing juggling stance changes to restore your stamina to the highest possible point mid-combo and being mindful of opportunities to neutralize enemy attacks via the Yokai transformation system, contribute to one of the most engaging second-to-second gameplay loops I've ever encountered. The cash and prizes you get when wrecking an opponent is a nice audio/visual bonus that, if you really get into tweaking and optimizing your equipment, just makes everything even crazier, once you get into stuff like debuffs and support skills. I can't stress enough how insane this game becomes at higher levels of play; the stamina meter, for instance, changes from a resource to be carefully guarded into an active buff dispenser, boosting attack strength, stamina restoration speed, and/or canceling stamina loss for blocks/dodges if you time stance changes well as you attack. each weapon has it's own skill tree, with stance-specific skills and attacks further augmenting how you play. None of the weapons are objectively bad. Everything is good if you just dig deep enough.

This game goes from unfair to seeming completely broken with the aid of some light reading and basic middle-school math, and that's great; the game rewards your knowledge of it's systems with fun.

I'm too busy making fools explode w/well-timed high-stance Odachi swings and scooping up their belongings to pay attention to things like the story or character motivations, so if you care about things like that, I suggest something more like Dear Esther or Gone Home, this might not be your jam.

TL;DR: An ultra-difficult mix of Ninja Gaiden+Diablo 3 w/Souls EXP-loss-on-death mechanics; you might not like it if you don't like fussing over numbers and items in your inventory, but if that doesn't bother you(or, like me, you live for that)then it's perfect ADHD dopamine fuel, would recommend, 10/10

This game answers the age old question: "What if Dark Souls had a turbo mode and featured Dante from the Devil May Cry series?"

This is the only Action RPG with a combat system on par with Fighting Games like Tekken/Guilty Gear and Character Action Games like Ninja Gaiden/Devil May Cry. I would recommend new players to start here rather than with the first one. As it turns out, Nioh 1 is a more difficult game. This one is a prequel of sorts so it is not only more accessible but also functions as a standalone title in terms of story. Unlike Dark Souls, this is a mission-based Action RPG but it does follow the Dark Souls formula of level design in terms of exploring a legacy dungeon with multiple routes, checkpoints, and the ability to unlock paths back to checkpoints as you progress. You level up your character as you defeat enemies and increase stats of your choice while also unlocking new moves/abilities for each of your weapons, magic, and Ninja techniques. However the combat system here is the main appeal. There are multiple different weapon types with three different stances/movesets per each that can be changed on the fly during combat and each stance for each weapon has their own special moves which can ALL be customized and given customized boosts (like poison, fire, extra damage, stamina recovery, etc).

And... that's just the tip of the iceberg in terms of combat complexity. There are light/heavy attacks with combo finishers, parries, grapples, burst counters, transforming into a demon, magic spells, buffs/debuffs, projectiles, sheathed weapon attacks, directional input commands, dodge attacks, timing related abilities to recover stamina during or mid-combo, custom demon attacks to choose from, and that's just the basics. It does get more advanced than that as well but you get the point. This game is very technical and that's what it makes it so good. So, you love the complexity of combat in Devil May Cry but you also love the exploration of legacy dungeons in Dark Souls? Then this is the game for you. 

That being said this game is a much faster pace than Dark Souls and rewards offensive combo-oriented play like in Devil May Cry so the challenge and skill ceiling are both higher. If you pick up this game and end up losing over and over again to a boss... you can summon a visitor to help you and/or just wait for the boss to glow red and use the Bust Counter. Begin your combo once they are out of Stamina (Ki). This is the secret of Nioh 2 that lets you cheese bosses. Burst Counter did not exist in Nioh 1 and is the main reason I say that Nioh 1 is a more difficult game. This game does require some practice and patience. Although it is a faster pace than Dark Souls, you shouldn't ever be button-mashing. Instead you should be mixing up your combos and looking SSStylish.

Nioh 2 is an excellent co-op game that truly shines when played with friends. The fast-paced action and challenging gameplay make for an exhilarating experience that will keep you and your friends coming back for more.

The combat system is top-notch and offers a level of depth that is unmatched in other action games. The game's weapon and skill customization options provide players with a huge amount of choice and flexibility in how they approach combat.

However, while the gameplay is fantastic, the story in Nioh 2 is somewhat lacking. While the game's narrative is serviceable, it's not particularly memorable, and there are few standout moments that really leave an impact.

Despite this, the game's co-op mode more than makes up for its narrative shortcomings. Playing with friends is an absolute blast and adds an extra layer of excitement to an already thrilling game.

Overall, if you're looking for a co-op game that offers intense action and challenging gameplay, Nioh 2 is an excellent choice. Just don't expect a particularly compelling story.

An incredible followup to one of my favorite action games of all time. Nioh 2 is an improvement in every way over its predecessor. Graphics are excellent, the music is stellar, the plot is tighter, combat has gotten even smoother and intricate, there's only so many ways I can just say it's the perfect sequel. While I still recommend playing Nioh 1 for the story and gameplay, one could hardly be faulted for just jumping right into Nioh 2. Every weapon's moveset is expanded, with a few new additions (shoutout to the switchglaive), yokai mode is an evolution of the living weapons from the first game, you can even collect yokai soul cores like Pokemon to use their abilities in combat.

Performance got a huge upgrade from Nioh 1, with support for ultrawide and up to 120 fps, there's even DLSS to keep your fps high during some of the hectic parts. It's a superb game that fills that itch of Souls games while providing its own spin, I truly cannot recommend it enough. I don't think I've ever said "Damn this game is good" aloud so many times before.

I absolutely love this game but would guess it's not for everyone. The combat plays pretty fast and there are a lot of mechanics to master which overwhelmed me a bit at first--I didn't even use a lot of the yokai mechanics at first as I struggled to learn the flow of combat early game.

If you're looking for more intricate combat with a great amount of depth and variety this game absolutely delivers if you have the patience to learn it. It's worth it to look up some guides for the combat and level progression probably as with any Souls-like, but once you learn it all it can feel really bad-ass. You can always do co-op or summon npc's to make it easier too, but I really enjoyed the mastery I felt from solo-ing the game.

I found the aesthetic and setting to be a lot of fun too. Admittedly the story and characters are nothing too special but they're still fun and not detractors I'd say.

The world probably won't be as satisfying to explore as any FromSoft game and the game uses a mission structure that re-uses maps, but I found the levels/scenarios well-designed and still good.

The combat is definitely the selling point of this game so I'd do some research to see if that part resonates with you. If so, you're probably in for a great time.

Nioh 2 is absolutely incredible. 
The number 1 thing that stands out is of course the combat. Nioh 2 has the the richest, deepest, and most satisfying combat system I've ever experienced. Customising your build and your experience is an absolute joy and I found myself learning more and more about the game every day. Tonnes of weapons and playstyles means that there's something for everyone. If you have ever played Monster Hunter or Bloodborne and thought that the weapons were cool but needed more depth than look no further. Please watch some combo videos online and you'll get a taste for it.
Of course there are other things to praise Nioh 2 for. The loot system is fun and feels rewarding. Seeing numbers go up never gets old.
If you're into Japanese history it's fun recognising famous historical figures and events.
The enemy design is great and varied.
The level design is pretty good for the most part, which is a big step up from Nioh 1.
The game also felt easier, both to understand and progress, compared to Nioh 1. 
The Yokai shift and abilities are extremely fun. I wish more games let you use enemy and boss moves. 
The postgame design is fantastic. There are several new game plus cycles, and not only are they very fast to get through, they all change up how the game is played, whether it's through adding new loot rarities, adding new mechanics like cursed enemies, changing the enemy placements and giving them new moves, increasing the level and stat caps, or adding a new ultra massive dungeon for hardcore players.
There's even more to praise, like going over the combat alone would take an entire thesis with how much depth it has, but I'll leave it there.

If you like action games, with a tonne of depth, and souls games then you owe it to yourself to play Nioh 2.

There's a lot I could say about Nioh 2, both good and bad. It has some of the same flaws as Nioh 1, but overall it was a great sequel that improved on the solid foundation of its predecessor. If you're on the fence, I'd say give it a try. Go in with zero expectations, a lot of patience, and a willingness to learn and play by Nioh's rules. It's punishing, more so than any of the Souls games in my opinion (probably including Sekiro, though Sekiro's bosses are usually harder; Demon's Souls also might be a bit more cruel), but it can be a blast to master its combat.

If you get to the third boss ([spoiler]bastard snake[/spoiler]) and want to delete the game, don't. I was ready to start cheating, but then I beat it. The rest of the game felt so much easier after that.

[b]Pros[/b]
-GOOD HAIR OPTIONS, so basically a 10/10
-Great character creator
-Lots of build variation
-Good fashion (transmog!!)
-Photo mode
-A few pretty good bosses (that I'll remember fondly; the bosses I remember from Nioh 1 were the ones that drove me insane)
-It's just kinda cool--the armor, movesets, weapons, grapple animations, yokai forms/shifts; it all makes you feel pretty awesome (the animation team went berserk)
-Solid enough story (though its not always told as well as it could be)
-Fantastic and complex combat system; the stances are still one of my favorite things ever
-Quality of life improvements, like if you died to a boss, your spirit/amrita return automatically when you enter the boss room again (please do this Miyazaki)
-Some of the active skills are sick; one of the odachi ones is busted, you can cheese a lot of human bosses with it, and there's this funny one with axes where you can throw people like 10 feet away.
-The new game plus modes actually change things, and you can switch between NG and all of the NG+ modes whenever you want
-Didn't make me as angry as Nioh 1 for some reason

[b]Cons[/b]
-Reuses overused enemies including some from the first game
-Repetitive levels filled with enemies that may or may not fit in
-Bosses are hit or miss; a few are really fun as I said, but most are forgettable, and some feel clunky and poorly designed
-Around halfway through, you've seen most of what the game has to offer in terms of level design, loot, and enemy design (at least in NG); it's pretty much the same gameplay loop in similar levels with the same enemies
-Have to grind side missions to stay at the recommended level (I beat Nioh 1 about 20 to 40 levels under and did fine, so maybe that works here too)
-Just about every enemy from the giant monkeys down to the little goblin bastards can one or two hit you at some point in the game if they really feel like it (depending on your build)

I think Nioh 2 is best played at a slow pace. It may not be a relaxing game, but if you go in relaxed and saunter through Sengoku Japan only a few steps at a time, the repetitiveness won't bother you as much, and you might have more fun.

Overall, I've been loving Nioh 2, especially in the lategame, and I think it's worth your patience.

Pros:
1.  Great character customization.  I hate ugly characters, it would be hard for you to make a crappy character.  Also you can adjust your character's looks anytime

6.  Despite my long list of gripes below, the combat mechanics is what kept me playing.

Cons:
1. Lots and lots of reused stage/enemies from Nioh 1.  Made it feel like I got ripped off that this was nioh 1 extended.  Yes the time period of the 2 games link but you shouldn't have to reuse.  Poor excuse, just laziness. 
2. Movements that look good but don't make any sense and it will annoy you.  Enemies can dodge your attacks... but this isn't the problem... it's how they do it... for example an Yoki who literally is 3x your size would "dodge" by side stepping just a foot to one side which visually is still within your weapon's range but magically your weapons will pass thru their bodies... Cast sloth(slow) on them and watch even funnier animations. The same exact movements can be seen in Nioh 1... which means devs just reused lazy design.  Turned me off cuz I thought it was a bug in Nioh 1 and its still here. Not a game breaker but I can't stand how it looks.
3.  Ridiculous tracking.  Results in some very funny animations.  For example:  the very first sub boss you will face, when it whacks you downwards, you dodge to the side but the attack follows... defies the laws of physics... apply sloth for again a funnier animation.  It will literally follow you while already in downward motion even as you spin around the enemy... not a game breaker but funny and annoying when you get hit with something that doesn't make sense.
4. Human enemies poorly programmed.. devs made them just spam atks, no regards to ki management... devs don't seem to know how to make them hard to beat by their own rules so they resorted to breaking their own rules.  Funny thing is when these human npcs become your ally in missions they fight like crap.
5.  Weapon specific Dojo missions.  if there was one thing I learned from Dojo missions is that Dojo missions dont teach u anything u can actually use in the game.  U literally have to spam just a few attacks to beat these "masters" that again don't play by the rules you are suppose to play by. And these fights last very long since u only do so less damage. 
6.  Inventory management is a pain.  Most drops are garbage... and there are lots of them.  u gotta know how to use filter in your inventory... otherwise you spend so much time on it
7.  Underground I believe was a DLC, I was excited that it was 100s of floors only to find that the floors will repeat... again reused maps and stuff.  Almost exact enemy layout.  Didn't even feel there was any variance in difficulty as you repeat each of the same floor layout.

Overall pretty good game.  Despite the detailed complaints I would still recommend especially if you like fast paced action.

Two words describe this game: janky Darksouls

If you are like me and love Souls like games then you definitely heard about this game. I was excited for another action combat rpg. That was until I got to play it.

This games combat is by far the worst part of the game. It really is just janky. The button maping makes no sense. Why are the dodge button and the interrupt dodge attack different buttons? What I mean is for me, you have dodge as X and during boss red eye attacks you have to push R2 + O. Why not R2 + X? Best part is that for most other action rpgs, your dodge button is never X. It's usually O or a trigger button.

So you hear this and think, why not just change dodge to O? Because you can't. The one button you would want to change your dodge to as it makes the most sense, cannot be changed. You cannot change O to any other command other than "interact". This is just plain stupid.

Okay enough about the controller. How about the actual game? The "combat" is rigid and feels not complete. Your attack combos feel rough. Not being able to cancel an enemy from attacking you by dodging makes no sense. You HAVE to block if you are getting hit. You cannot choose block or dodge. The single worst part of combat is your "ki/stamina". Needing to push R1 after every single combo you do or you run out of stamina is bad gameplay. If you are mid combo attacking and you get hit or need to block means you cannot push R1 to recover your stamina. So that means you are now stamina starved and will get hit. This whole system feels like you are being punished for trying to weave in attacks and blocks. It feels bad to run out of stamina because the enemy forces you into a defensive position. I believe this is meant to slow combat down so you cannot just R1 spam to victory. But instead it breaks the tension a boss fight gives. Ruining the whole experience.

Overall, this is a bad way to do action combat and this team should look more into why games like Darksouls are praised for their combat.
My play time speaks for me. It's a game I consider damn near perfect. I plan on completing the campaign several more times.

Not to brag, but I consider myself quite good at a variety of games.
I am used to bad hitboxes, stupid amounts of damage, and excessive tracking, as I have played and succeeded at games like the Souls series (and multiple games from that genera), witcher 3 on death march, and the Monster Hunter series going as far back as Freedom Unite.
I play and enjoy a variety of difficult platformers and persevere through every challenge presented.
The point of all that is to establish my history, I know how difficult games work and am willing to put up with annoying mechanics...
This has to be one of the worst Souls-like games I have ever had the displeasure of playing.
To be completely honest with my experience, I never made it past the first horse demon.
I like to have a challenge, so when presented with one I'll work my hardest to overcome it.
The tracking and damage on such a large foe is completely absurd, small enemies should move fast and larger enemies should move slower with both having fair amounts of damage.
As I was still in the early game I'll disregard the stupid amount of damage he did and focus on the excessive tracking.
Damage doesn't matter if you don't get hit, but the bullshit tracking makes that almost impossible.
He will track the player up to the very last moment of his strike, sometimes spinning on a dime to do so, you can't fake him out, you can't dodge a millisecond too early, and the sheer size of the weapon means you can't get out of range.
It looks so incredibly stupid to see this giant enemy spin on a top to reach you, or to jerk this massive club in the complete opposite direction it was going just to kill the player.
And that's what this game wants to do, kill you at any cost.
I wasted almost three hours of my precious life fighting this same enemy and came to the conclusion that the game wasn't for me. 
The game looks good, but that is where the praise ends.
Not being allowed to swap the dodge button on a fucking PC is shit.
Having to take ones eyes off the enemy to manage a stamina recovery mini-game is shit.
Being stun-locked by a large, fast, hard hitting enemy isn't fun... it's shit.
What a waste of my fucking time and money, I could have saved up a bit more and gotten something more worth my time than Nioh 2 like sekiro, Elden Ring, MH rise, tetris, pong, or any of the resident evil series (even the bad ones).
Please don't waste your money.

My Nioh 1 review mentioned being "Surprised" by the game, but Nioh 2 was exactly what I expected then. It's brutal, it's unfair, it's grindy, its frustrating but it's too well-made for me to thumbs down it.  Despite many technical advances, I don't actually like this game I'm writing this review to give myself the excuse to just quit and go play something that I'm enjoy.

Up-front, Nioh 2 does ALOT right. Nearly all of the systems found in the original game have been vastly improved and the gameplay is much smoother. Nioh 1 required a college degree to understand, but Nioh 2 is a full-blown PHD program in itself. New tagline: "Prepare to Google." 

I considered the customization, skill trees, ninjutsu and magic systems of the original game to be some of the best I've ever seen in a souls-like. Nioh 2 takes it much further and allows an insane amount of freedom in creating your character even in the base game. More importantly, skill points are gained by using them and this means that you can constantly switch up your tactics without handicapping yourself. (Note to Nioh 1 Players: You don't unlock magic/ninja through the story... you start with them and need to gain a skill point using items.)

The new additions to the gameplay are "Soul Cores" (Abilities dropped from enemies), Yokai-Shift (A needed nerf to the living weapon), "Dark Realms" that drain your ki and can't be purified except by killing a boss, and "Soul Parries" used to deflect specific powerful attacks. Despite a absolutely non-nonsensical control scheme, these systems all feel like natural progression of Nioh 1 and add to the experience.

So why do I hate this game? 

Nioh 1 first-playthrough was a pretty standard action game. It shipped with a single NG+ and it wasn't until DLC and updates that Team Ninja nailed the grind-game. For the base game? You get meaningful rewards like Smithing Sets for completing missions so that you can create the gear wanted as you play through the main game.

Nioh 2 was built for the grind you found in Post-Game Nioh. Smithing Sets have become a <1% rare drop item from bosses, reduced experience and money payouts, skills are tied to usage, soul cores need to be fed other souls ala mobile games. You can ABSOLUTELY win without the grind, but you're at the mercy of the RNG to drop gear you actually want. 

I feel like I'm playing Dark Souls version of Destiny. 

In addition to the grind, much of the balance was restructured to feel more "Balanced". 
- Base damage is MUCH lower. You generally take two to three hits to kill instead of one and normal enemies now take much much more. 
- Finishing blows that used to deal 30-50% health now deal 5-15%. This turns alot of bosses into endurance marathons. 
- Bosses all summon Dark Zones that immediately refill their ki and slow down your attacks until 30+ seconds pass or your break them again.  This doesnt make things harder or more interesting, only slower.
- Percentages were greatly reduced or Where Nioh 1 would offer a "+9% Amrita gain" Nioh 2 would instead add "+0.7% Amrita gain" or maybe "+7% Amrita Gain While Health < 30%".
- Where Nioh 1 every enemy had exploitable frames you could strike to break their ki and stun them, Nioh 2 has exploitable breakable parts or exploit frames that might deal a % of ki damage that don't stun them and can be shrugged off when a boss summons their dark realm. 

This "Balanced" gameplay just makes everything take longer. 90% of the challenge in Nioh 2 is just staying alive long enough to chip away at the bosses health. You make one mistake and you'll get caught in an unblockable combo and be forced to start over.

Bosses are probably the single most important part of a souls-like and it's a mixed bag for me. With the exception of a few gimmick bosses that were borderline garbage, most have been enjoyable. They are far more dynamic than the bosses in the first game. More moves, multiple variations for each combo, and some pretty interesting timings.

I usually really enjoyed the bosses for the first few minutes of a combat, but after the fourth time its fully regen'd its ki without changing up its move set... I just stop caring. There's JUST enough jank that a bosses cheap shot will stun-lock you to death to cross to frustrate me. 

I really haven't felt that "Overcame the challenge" joy you get from these games when I win... but instead end each fight with a final "F you" to the devs.  

Nioh 2 is an extremely well-made game and obviously it has its fanbase. If you like to "Git Gud" and grind for rare loot drops, this is genuinely an amazing game. I'll probably still beat it, but I don't see myself thinking fondly on these hours.

perfect(yeah, i know nothing is perfect and you might enough to critic even here, but in the grand scheme of things and proper context: perfect)part soulslike, part Diablo-looter, part Ninja Gaiden, part eastern adventure ala Ghost Storyeven after hundrets of hours on PS4 pro, i could probably do just as much time on PC.the PC-version comes with everything you'd hope (extensive options, DLSS support, etc.) and in my total runtime i had 1 crash (which happend when loading into a mission, not during gameplay). it looks great, it sounds great, it plays fantastic.there's about one negative, which holds to true ever since the game's original release, which is also a positive (paradox?):there are too many systemsorthere are a lot of systemsdepends on how you want to look at it.there'srandom itemization (with some structure to the randomness), building on what made looters so adictivethere'spokemon/perona like demon collection, fusion, crafting and usage (summon for special attacks, switch forms, etc.)there'sa metric ton of different weapon classes, each with their own combos and move-setsthere'sexp-progression (similiar to Souls)there'slearn by using (use a weapon/attack form, to get skill points to spend on a gigantic talent tree)there'scrafting in all forms and sizes (fusion, transmog, you name it, the game got it)there'snpc-pvp, deaths produce npc-enemy summon for other players, which also have a chance to drop their carried lootthere'snpc-helpers (avatars of other players) to summon; place a sign, others can summon you char, npc-controlledthere'sa paragon-esque-system, offering achievment boni for small, but permanent stat bonithere'sreal co-opkinda pvpthere's a whole fame/faction-systemthere'snot just magic, but also ninjitsu (shurikens, smoke bombs, etc.)and the list goes on and on. it can all feel like to much, but in reality it's your choice to use "yokai-counters", or burst attacks; it's you choice if you want to craft/customize your very own weapon-combo/skill-setup, etc.on the one hand the game feels to crowded with systems, but on the other most are optional and offer just more stuff to do for people who want to engage with the game.it's often called "hard", which holds true: enemies can wreck you in no time; but use just some of the systems the game offers you and you can make it a lot more managble. play a chinese ghost story like spell slinging sword fighter, a slow but bombastic samurai, a nimble ninja, or a street fighter melee build...the options are incredibleall set in a very pretty and very detailed backround. npcs, enviroments, music and art...it's just golden.Nioh 2 is still a very special game, probably one of it's kinda. i doubt any developer will release a game this packed with effort and content anytime soon.

Post Wo Long review:Frankly i didnt have as much of a fun time as i did playing wo long, even only reaching 5 hours i did play this game way more on console and was hoping to maybe find a more better time with it after all the people saying its better than wo long, however i cant much say i did. For example the cons that aren't as good as wo long are the character customization, you have way less options making me feel less motivated to creating unique and awesome cosplay characters. Then youre merely thrusted into the tutorial instead of being put into a well made cutscene or backstory or summary of the first game so the game just suddenly happens and the cutscene that does play just means little to nothing in comparison to story when looking at nioh 1 or wo long which had a far better introduction. The floaty movement compared with the utter stiff camera really didnt match well and i constantly felt like i was walking on skates. The hud is simply too congested and it made it feel more of a mmo than a soulslike. The combat was decent but felt so sponge like and yes like a mmo again, you do so little damage in the beginning it felt like every enemy was a boss battle and hardly fun at all. The systems of regarding ki pulse is completely annoying and just there to make a hard game just frustrating even more with the insane stamina consumption i would find myself throwing one attack just to have to fall back for 5 minutes and wait for stamina to regen. Yes the ki pulse allows you to regen stamina faster but its useless because by the time you do ki pulse the enemy is already attacking you so you have to fall back anyways. The stances merely was to just make a complicated game more so and made it feel like there was merely no purpose into making a stance system worthwhile besides the massive amount of time spent just looking at a skill tree full of moves i felt personally could've been done way better by just making it a single skill tree for the entire weapon youre using. The damage output on enemies is so heavily insane that if i got caught once id be dead, boom, everything gone because i got hit once. I know this game is suppose to be hard but thats worse than dark souls is and dark souls almost never made it to market originally. The graphics arent as good as wo long either, i would constantly catch very blurry textures compared to 4k textures that made it look odd and weird as if they lost budget making a sword look good and instead put all their money on face textures. Omoyo cups are insanely grindy to get and the coop system is timed, so if i was surrounded by enemies the npc could just leave at any moment thus making my cup farming useless. The story isn't as good as either nioh 1 or wo long either, its paired with 2 second cutscenes and then boom youre in a random area with no build up unlike nioh 1 or wo long where it followed the character to that specific area. The only thing good about this game is the fashion, it has a lot of armor options but whats the point in that either when you cant make a good character either? Ultimately id think this game would be average but in the end its slightly below because of my tastes and its systems being poorly done. PS - For those are constantly reply to this review who insult me saying that i have no clue what im talking about and quote ''my inability to understand the game'' clearly never read my review stating that ive already beaten the game before, matter of fact ive beaten the game twice already. Its not my lack of understanding or anything of the sort because like i said ive beaten the game before so clearly i know how the game works. This review (like all reviews) are subjective to my own experience and within comparison to the new game ''Wo Long'', if you dont like my opinion then you may simply not read this because this is for the new people who hasnt played the series yet and may consider getting either nioh or wo long. 4/Cat Clock

Reasons why this is a soulslike: lose amrita (souls) upon death, have to go back get them, has a stamina bar

Reasons why this is NOT a soulslike: everything else

Jokes aside, do not expect to play like souls, combat's entirely different, do not expect exploration or deep lore, game's not about that, main point is fights and levels are there only to create different situations / ambushes

Story is fine, not bad, not excellent, NG (New Game, first playthrough cycle) is only the tutorial of the game, pretty much the presentation of the different enemies you can find in the game for you to fight during the 4 other game cycles, floors of the underworld and underworld depths, each cycle adding not only higher stats, but also new mechanics to enemies, swap places on the map, change enemy types, but also giving you more tools and more customization options for your build, such as higher tier gear, ultimate stats (perks you obtain for completing special missions AND having reached 150 of a specific stat), and set bonuses we call graces

Combat is the absolute best I've ever played, but be warned, it's not beginner friendly, and while one can develop insane technique and land stylish combos, it won't really "click" for most players during first playthrough, for 2 reasons: they'll be busy learning mechanics, and they don't k now the enemies, expertise comes once at the higher cycles, stamina management is key, don't like the "spam dodge and wait for your turn" type of combat that souls brings to the table? NEITHER DOES NIOH, and so you can endlessly combo if you're skilled enough, not gonna go into much detail because I could be here typing for days, but as absolute essentials, enemies have stamina too, out of stamina enemies = stagger with each hit / open for grapples, there's this mechanic called ki pulse (ki is the nioh version of stamina), which lets you recover part of the ki you just used on a combo, with a catch, ammount recovered depends on your timing when you perform it, too soon and you recover less ki, too late and you lose the pulse window and so you need to wait for passive ki recovery to do its job, get hit by an enemy and ki pulse window vanishes AND you receive ki damage, more advanced techniques let you recover even more ki, which is the actual "endless combo" part

Customization is a blast, not only can you customize your character appearance, core stats and weapons but you can also pick many skills and passives to learn for your weapons, some having the same key shortcuts, having to decide whicih one to slot in for your style, additionally, there's 2 root skill trees (shiftling and samurai) which not only provide utility and upgrades to your character, but also unlock special effects for your active skills (that you can customize, so you can have any active weapon skill imbue lightning if you use lightning arcana, although you can only have each skill effect once per weapon) if anything, the biggest downside to this much customization is probably the high ammount of RNG there is for gear / soul core drops, but that's not really a problem until Dream of the Demon / NG+2. There's also ninutsu and omnyo magic skill trees, which you can use with any weapon although they do scale with specific stats, still bring great utility to any build

The game also brings in decent coop in the form of expeditions, 2 or 3 players challenge a level together (don't need to have already completed it but think you do need to have unlocked it) levels change slightly by adding more / tougher enemies, there's a "help bar" which depletes as members die, if it reaches 0 you can continue for less rewards or you can restart, there's another mode, random encounters, which works more similar to souls coop, except you call for help from the shrine (bonfire / checkpoint) by using consumables, up to 2 visitors can be summoned, and they step into your game as it is, do advise heavily AGAINST summoning help, not being elitist, the downside to random encounters is that you don't have a say on who comes to help (you can set it to friends only or password but no filter for random players), and there is no cap on who can come, so you could summon someone from NG+4 at max lvl with min max gear and get your experience ruined because they're one shotting everything

TLDR
pros: AMAZING-COMBAT, post game and customization, actually good coop mode (expeditions)
cons: MMO-like RNG for higher game cycles, random encounters not limited by player state of game

This game took me 20 hours to actually "get good" at. I hated all 20 hours of me trying to learn the basic concepts of this game. I hated it because it was incredibly frustrating to get obliterated for making one little mistake. I uninstalled this game numerous times, only to reinstall a week later and repeat the process. 
But eventually... It clicked. And when it did, it clicked HARD. Now, this is one of my favorite games of all time. Maybe even my favorite.

The replayability of this game is insane for having no actual pvp. The amount of unique playstyles and skills you can get, add onto that a really cool NG+ experience, you've got a game you can play for hundreds of hours. There are content creators on youtube who have a decently sized following just playing this game. Mind you, no PvP.

This game has a skill ceiling that is soaring in the sky. It will annoy you when you first start, you might feel like the game is clunky or that you don't have enough Ki (stamina) to do anything meaningful. Some of that is due to the fact that you're a low level, but one of the key components in this is to swap between stances and regain your Ki so you can continue your attacks and flow between them. One of the best first skills for your "samurai" tree should be the one where you gain a bonus to your Ki gain when timing a ki pulse with a stance swap. That will become muscle memory for you and that's where your flow will really shine. 

Not much else I can think of to say, this isn't a review of pros and cons, it's just me giving you a taste of what your experience might be like if you're brand new to this series. Get into the Nioh community and you won't regret it. Watch some people play the game on YouTube who are just flexing their skills if you feel like you've hit that massive wall. Get inspired. This game has so much to offer!

Nioh 2 is the Good Game you're looking for. A healthy and sizeable main campaign leads into escalating challenges of DLC missions all with new content, new enemies and new strategic encounters that test everything the game taught you over its 30+ hour tutorial. Then you unlock the first of four New Game + difficulties and Start Playing the Real Nioh 2. 

The game is hard and full of walls, but for every extreme difficulty that the developers expect to crush you, there are a multitude of strategies that turn you into a wrecking ball. Encounter wall? Learn how to smash it. The Snake Boss is weak to Fire, and combining Fire with Purity grants Confusion, which lets you deal Double Damage and prevents it from gaining stamina. That's strategy one, and there are better ones for every boss. You don't even have to be perfect, you just have to know what you want to do and do it Hard. 

It's an amazing game, and runs great (now). Multiplayer is easy and consistent, connections may vary, but if you get this from a sale you'll get more than your money's worth before you hit the Final Wall. The only thing that can stop you is not wanting to continue. That came for me after about 400 hours.

The whole game, rather than being an open world, is a mission select screen filled with mini open worlds, which is unique and kind of cool. The loot in this is diablo/borderlands style lootsplosions, and while it has less weapons than others in similar genres, the ones it has shine with rather neat animations and multi stance fighting. Also those damage numbers you see in every inch of content for this game, and were the main reason I personally didn't buy it till now, can be very easily turned off. 10/10 Git Gud

You always hear the second game in a series of games is always the one that‚Äôs the best, well after playing every souls like game I‚Äôve played (not indie games) this game hits all the good points. The character progression/customization is off the charts. It‚Äôs not overly complicated once you get the hang of it but still has an impressive amount of min maxing potential in late game. 

Comparable to the souls series, at first glance the mechanics are very similar although I would argue this game is less clunky in its movement and combat. You will still get overpowered by certain enemies but like the old saying this time it actually is a skill issue. 

Level design is more based on a linear platform design rather than like the souls games where it‚Äôs more open letting you explore for hours. Once you‚Äôve played it long enough though it doesn‚Äôt really feel like a con as it fits better in the faster pace of Nioh. 

The loot is more Diablo based in the sense that the gear drops are in multiples from any given enemy as well as affixes/colored tiers on weapons, gear and items.

Each weapon type has a skill tree that you can progress through by killing enemies. You gain skill points based on what weapons you choose to use, along with magic spells and ninjitsu.

Like souls series, there is a NG+ except for Nioh, the game changes entirely in level design after your first playthrough. It really incentivizes players to continue to play after the first time beating it.

Co-op in this game is legit and straight to the point, you can join up with your friends and play almost all of the levels(some story missions are private). When a buddy goes down you can revive him given there‚Äôs a team health bar that can run out causing everyone to fail the mission, although it can be replenished while playing together. 

Player blood pools are in the form of Revenants, shows how a player died but also will allow you to summon that dead player to a duel where if you win, you have a chance to get their actual equipped gear they had on when they died, players use this to give out gear too. 

All in all pretty amazing game for $40

As a fan of action-packed, challenging games, I was blown away by Nioh 2. From the moment I started playing, I was immersed in a world full of demons, magic, and epic battles. But what really stood out to me was the intricate and deep combat system that kept me engaged for hours on end.

At its core, Nioh 2 is a hack-and-slash game, but the combat goes far beyond mindless button-mashing. Each weapon type has its own moveset and playstyle, with different combos and special attacks that can be chained together for devastating results. And with the ability to switch between two different weapons on the fly, players have an incredible amount of versatility and strategy at their fingertips.

But the combat doesn't stop there. Nioh 2 also features a complex system of stances and Ki management, which add layers of depth to every encounter. Players must constantly monitor their Ki (stamina) levels, using Ki pulses to recover and keep the momentum going. And with the ability to switch between high, mid, and low stances on the fly, each attack and dodge becomes a strategic decision.

What's truly remarkable about Nioh 2's combat system is how it rewards experimentation and mastery. With so many options and techniques available, players can find their own unique playstyle and develop new strategies as they progress through the game. And with multiple difficulty levels and a New Game+ mode, there's always a new challenge waiting for those who want to test their skills even further.

But Nioh 2 isn't just a game for combat enthusiasts. The story is engaging but could have been crafted better, taking players on a journey through feudal Japan filled with mythological creatures and political intrigue. And with a cast of interesting characters and a deep lore to discover, there's always something new to uncover.

All in all, Nioh 2 is an exceptional game that deserves to be enshrined in gaming history!

First of all, I would like to say that I approached Nioh with a really open mind, and I wanted to like this game. But it lacks a lot of what I desire in my "hard video game", even if it is a very good game.

Lets talk about the pros:
1. the game runs flawlessly. From what I have heard the devs prioritized performance over graphics, and it shows in game. the game looks decent, but it runs so well.
2. the combat. Easily the best thing about this game. It is extremely good, as you can unlock moves and customize your moveset, stance swap combos, practically have unlimited stamina if you get the ki pulses down, have multiple systems at place and can pull some montages on the same level of blistering eye candy like devil may cry 5 combo videos. 
3. the cultural aspect of it. This game is historical fiction, therefore a large part of the cast are historical figures or extremely faithful adaptations of japanese mythology, which means that if you have relative knowledge of japanese history it is very interesting to see the game bring up these legends and stories into its world.

Now lets talk about the cons.
1. the artistic vision can be hit or miss. A lot of things like enemy design can be some of the best I have seen considering the mythological aspect of it, but the weapons, armor and a lot of characters just feel like those shitty chinese RPGs that over design their characters with little thought behind it aside from "it looks cool".
2. shitty story. The story of the game is only there to be an excuse for you to go fight things with the insane combat system, unremarkable in every way aside from the historical ties I discussed before.
3. mission based structure and uninteresting level design. The way that this game uses mission based levels, while serviceable, makes the game feel disconnected and cripples your immersion from if they have an interconnected world like souls games do. the level design is subpar, gets the job done and nothing else.
4. loot hell. Easily the worst thing about this game. there is so much loot, and to properly optimize your character you need to minmax down to the random attributes of each weapon. your storage space is also limited, which means at some point you have to sit down properly gauge what you want to keep and what to discard, which is not fun at all.
5. mediocre boss design. ever wondered why people dont fanboy over any nioh bosses the same way they would fanboy over Artorias, Ludwig, Isshin or Gael? yeah. Pretty much all human bosses are bad. Yokai bosses can be decent, but overall forgettable at best. They can be very hard tho, since most can 2 shot you, and their hp bar is massive
6.the terrible balancing in terms of difficulty progression. a Team Ninja classic, nothing strange here. the more you play the game the easier it gets, as they slap 15 different mechanics on you the first level and expects you to have relative mastery of it 10 mins later.
7.the game feels kinda cheap. Flashy colors, floaty animations, enough visual clutter to delete an epileptic person and obscure what the hell you are trying to see, makes for a game that feels cheaper than it should be.

The game is deceptively like a soulslike at first glance, but it is not. The only thing they have in common is the "bonfire" & death mechanics.
This is a action RPG centered around personal skill, your build, crafting and your gear with a combat system more like a dedicated fighting game, say like Bayonetta, Metal Gear: Rising, etc.
It oozes mystical and eerie Japanese atmosphere, the presentation reminds me a lot of some Fatal Frame games in the levels i have done so far, which is a good thing. Always that underlying tension, but no jumpscares. Quiet and creepily silent nighttime locales, i love it.

And of course the booba.
In a time where attractive women with nice features is so illegal the thoughtpolice installs a trojan on your computer if you so much as consider installing CBBE on your trashy little Skyrim modlist, its really nice that you can make some truly stunning characters. Males to if you are into that, i am NOT.

Edit:
Have finished the game now at the final difficulty and gone to around level 20 in the RNG dungeon.
The game unfortunately rapidly becomes a slog once you go into the new game+ difficulties with extreme HP spongy enemies that can oneshot you easily with a quick attack if you are wearing light armor.
The 1st run is by far where the fun lies, unfortunately the good gear and fun builds can only be made in the higher difficulties.

Having said that, this game is still one of my absolute favorites of all time.
In part because of the combat system, but much more so because of the story. I can't remember a game where the story has moved me so and made me feel so many strong emotions.
Certain soundtracks still break my heart when i listen to them so long after experiencing the scene where they played.

I could gush endlessly about the story and probably become less and less coherent, but my final opinion would be:

I think you will enjoy the first difficulty, the first time you experience the story and that alone if worth the price to me. But if you are like me you will start to like it less and less as you progress through the difficulties chasing gear to make fun builds that eventually all feel weak.

If you're looking for a new Souls-like game that isn't Dark Souls or Bloodborne, I heard great things about Nioh 2 but way too involved for me who was just looking for a new video game to play.

A roguelite where you have a chance of winning every run with skill is harder than this where your "skill" gained is spoiling the content and mechanics over and over from the first mission to the last. This is challenging on a surface level only with time investment and memorization disproportionate to gameplay execution and understanding of the mechanics.

Not to say there isn't deep gameplay and theorycrafting here but instead that a player who knows the content already is going to have an easier time winning with an under-geared character than a first-playthrough player with an over-leveled one.

As such, I doubt the replay-value is going to be that high. Sure, there may be great build variety but when most of the skill comes from knowing "where, when and how" over moment-to-moment gameplay, you'll get most of that on your first run.

Were it not for: high price; insane control scheme; console-designed everything and lack of replay-value (in the form of non-linear gameplay or procedural mutators to make each new playthrough fresh and engaging) I might keep Nioh 2 as a great Souls-like to beat at least once (and maybe twice years later) but the price is way too high for that at the moment.

With the current discount at 40% off, I could still buy right now, for the same value, full-price, all of:

- Dead cells
- Grim dawn
- Ziggurat
- Vampire survivor

Each of those games provides me far more intelligent gameplay and depth with actual infinite replay-value - without needing to rely on cheap deaths a dozen times per level so I can pat myself in the back later and say "I must be really good at video games, it only took me a hundred deaths and two hours to beat this one level"!

Meanwhile actually challenging good games will generate a brand new level for you every single time and require you to use reaction time, game knowledge and theorycrafting plus whatever gear you  find during the run rather than dozens of deaths to acquire a little spoiler knowledge with each time LOL and if you die even once, the game is immediatelly over.

I hope that when I finally try Dark Souls the ambience and world design will deliver because this design ethos based on wholly artificial difficutly ain't it!

This game can be... Frustrating to say the least, it can also be tedious, and i have a host of disagreements with some of its game design choices, but even with that said, its still an amazing game. Alot of people compare nioh to darksouls, and while that comparison is fair as they are both 3rd person action rpg's with a punishing death around every corner, nioh is much more rpg than skill based, while there is alot of skill involved, its like how sekiro was different to darksouls and bloodborne, sekiro was less rpg more skill, nioh is the opposite of that. getting better at the game through skill alone will carry you far, but not as far as it might in darksouls, in nioh your going to need good gear and at around level 100, you will need some idea of what build you are gonna be going for, thankfully respecing is easy so your not screwed if you choose to change your build. If your coming from nioh 1 and like me were unsure if you could deal with how unfair this game can be, i assure you, this game is an improvement with the addition of the soul cores and accesability of tempering and rerolls of accessories and various other minor quality of life changes, if is far less draining, but also asks you to manage more, but if you were able to handle the first game this shouldnt be to big a jump. 

If you can, Absolutely play this with a friend using expeditions, it is a superior way to play the game and feels so much more fair.

Disclaimer for anyone who hasn't played the first game, this game throws you in expecting you to already be mildly competent at basic mechanics from the first game, starting here will be a much bigger upfront challenge,  should that be your choice but you sill don't want it to be a nightmare, i would opt for building a tankier character if you don't normally do that and get plenty of heart and courage as those stats will give ki(stamina) and ki regen(stamina regen), also do research on mechanics of the game, it will save you so much headache.

Edit (3/12/2021): 
I've been trying to push through the issues of latest patch (1.27) but I honestly can't condone this game in its current state. Mid-Mission, the game runs fine. Albeit I tend to get a lot of errors with Summoned Spirits names loading incorrectly or something, but nothing affecting gameplay. However when on the World Map, there is a high likelihood of encountering one of two big issues:
1) Menu Text will begin flickering or vanish entirely.
2) Game crashing frequently while trying to navigate menus.

There is no workaround for the first issue besides just restarting the game. The second issue however can strike randomly when going through menus at the Hut, Shrine, Blacksmith, or Teahouse. Essentially anywhere that has Menus within menus has the opportunity to invite a crash. I've begun a process of completing a few things (selling items, disassembling, or combining Soul Cores) then exiting to the World Map to save my game before moving onto the next step. Mainly because I have no idea when the crash will strike and I don't want to lose progress. The [b]Blacksmith[/b] and the [b]Character Directory in the Hut[/b] are the biggest culprits for this crash.

Until these issues get fixed, I can no longer recommend the game in it's current state. I'll gladly reverse my review once they're fixed.

Nioh 2 is my second favorite game after the Monster Hunter series, and it's close. Elden Ring was disappointing after months playing this. 

Nioh 2 has the best feeling combat with the most depth at the same time. They stack systems upon systems without caring if they scare casual players away. 

I normally don't care about following game developers, but Team Ninja really has my respect after Nioh and the Ninja Gaiden games. I'll play anything they release and they deserve to be more successful than From Software.

This is the first Souls-like I've been able to enjoy, partially because it only shares a few things in common with Souls-likes.  Not only am I enjoying it, it's one of the best games I've played in a long time.  Most importantly for me, the combat is remarkable, which is typical of Team Ninja's games (hello Dead or Alive).

Also, it's harder than From's games, but isn't as punishing when you die.  I enjoy all levels of difficulty in games, but I find punishment tiring.  For example, I'm a big fan of fighting games, which have zero punishment and let me immediately dive back in to focus on enjoying the challenge.

Super Meat Boy would be another good example of brutal difficulty but absolutely no punishment.

It's one of the main reasons I never enjoyed From's games, in addition to their simplistic, slow combat.  The punishment in Nioh 2 is mild enough to motivate me, rather than kicking me while I'm down and irritating me.  And OMG THE COMBAT IS SO GUD.

Other reviews have gone into details better than I can, especially since I'm new.  Just had to give this a BIG thumbs up!

This game is incredibly frustrating at first because it tries to throw like thirty different vital mechanics at you all at once. If you stick with it, it's an insanely fun game. 

A few tips to enjoy the game and save yourself a lot of frustration:
-Get in the habit of ki pulsing all the time. It's basically always better than letting your stamina regen naturally.
-Use onmyo and/or ninjutsu items, don't just focus on melee. They become very OP later.
-Use your ranged weapon whenever you get a shot on an enemy that doesn't see you. They're actually good unlike the souls games, and headshots let you run up for a free finisher on many enemies. The rifles and cannons in particular can easily one-shot many enemies.
-Practice burst countering but you can just dodge the moves that are too hard to counter consistently.
-Experiment with the different soul cores. Some seem bad on paper but are pretty useful because they're cheap or have some weird utility. 
-Don't forget to apply the modifiers to your combos via the combo menu (The skills that modify attacks). I played hours and hours of this game without even realizing I could do that. 
-Torii gate lets you do missions co-op, but all the enemies are harder. I'd argue it's actually harder than singleplayer because the enemies get way more ki which is a huge issue for yokai in particular. Get a friend in a voice call if you wanna do co-op because you share a health bar with your partner and you don't want some random running off and dying wasting your collective health. Some bosses feel like they're made for co-op (big snake bastard, for instance) so it's advisable to use the Torii gate if a boss is really kicking your ass.

Nioh 2 is objectively an amazing game. Everything about it from the combat to the armor and weapons to the environment are so well done. I won't lie, the story isn't... amazing? It's there though and I didn't really mind it honestly I thought it was decent enough and that's about my biggest criticism of the game. Many people would describe it as a "souls like" which is a blatant disservice to Nioh 2 because it stands on it's own two legs and honestly is so far from any "soulborne" game. In fact the only commonality between the games is their difficulty. 

Nioh 2 is exactly what I imagine being a ninja/samurai is like. The flow of combat once you get the hang of it isn't something I've experienced until I played Nioh and it's truly it's strongest point. You'll be spinning, twirling, flipping and basically dancing gracefully (or sometimes getting smacked down on your butt) around your opponents and the flow once you're into it [i]feels[/i] REALLY amazing. When you pair combat with the armor/weapon system you can make so many different builds because every piece of armor and weapon is somewhat randomized (think ARPGs Grim Dawn, Diablo, etc gear drops), so you can imagine how much fun you can potentially have trying different sets with different weapon combinations. 

It's an awesome game and the difficulty may turn some people away, but if you take your time to learn there's a real gem to be found here.

A game of many layers. 

At first, for the first 20 hours, it plays like Divekick, with any weapon having a 2 click combos. 

In the midgame, up to 100 hours, acquiring unlocks, it plays like any Dark Souls game, with dodge, parry, and tough but fair way, except with Nioh you can unlock the enemy movesets like pokemon. 

Then in the lategame, new game plus, you really get into the stances, and it plays like a fighting game, optimizing for a build, crafting, combining powers. For any given loadout, at any given moment, you have to access to 35 options = (3 stances * 2 actions) + 8 items + 15 combos + 3 demon moves + 1 demonform + 1 parry + 1 dodge. A lot to sink your teeth into, and a great all around package

Here's a tip for you all getting this game and playing on keyboard.

Set Q for guard.
Try every weapon on first run and stick to what fits. Prioritise the stats related to that weapon.
Fight bosses and large Yokai with Low Stance to avoid getting caught staggered.
Focus on extending your Ki meter, not your regen as in my opinion its pretty troublesome to hit Shift for the Ki Pulse (stamina regen)
Focus on upgrades that effect Ki as well.
Offer gear to the Shrines in the first few hours before you get the Blacksmith. They give free Amrita that you don't have to work for.
Always die somewhere accessible. Don't fight in a tiger's den expecting to win.
Fight one at a time and hit with High Stance after Grapple or when the enemy is on the floor.
The bow is your best friend at the start, but be mindful of the arrows.
