Character creation is very wild and the way they put your custom character in the scenes is amazing. The story has some very noticeable plot holes but it's bearable to a tee. The ending of the main story was amazing. The difficulty is actually way easier compared to Nioh 1 but casual players would still probably find it hard.

The aspects of this game I like are very very good, but there are some huge faults here that can completely sour the experience for people coming from the Souls games. However, overall I would recommend Nioh 2.

The good things... well the game looks pretty great. Enemy design is awesome, and there is a wide variety of enemies too. Levels look diverse and it never gets too boring unless you go through an area multiple times over for side missions. The customization and depth of combat for the weapons and yokai abilities is insane, and allows for lots of versatility for approaching encounters. There is also a LOT of content, from sub missions, to a long main story, to twilight missions, and after the main story there's tons of additional stuff to tackle and the DLC levels are there too.

Now for the bad stuff. First of all, level design just stinks on ice. The "shortcuts" and shrine placement can vary wildly from obscenely far away to unnecessarily close. One mission I was running a freaking marathon of a walk between the first shrine and the next one, and the mission before I rounded a corner and immediately found a door to open right next to the shrine that saved me maybe 15 seconds. Also this game takes the hardcore DS2 approach to enemy placement on steroids. You can bet your ass no fight in this game is mano y mano except boss fights because every single room you enter will ALWAYS have:
-a large enemy
-hidden small enemies
-gunners on top out of your reach

Also enemy design and boss design can be downright atrocious at times. The devs have a really bad habit of giving every single enemy in the game a superarmor grab move they can pull out of nowhere to nearly one shot you (and yes I am not exaggerating EVERY SINGLE ENEMY in the game has this grab, EVERY. SINGLE. ENEMY.). I get boss difficulty wildly varies in a game with this depth of combat, but let me just say this game has an absurdly difficult early game wall with those first two bosses that I'm nearing the end of the game and nothing compares to those two AT ALL.

Overall, combat, customization, how the game looks, and amount of content are all wins. Enemy design, boss design, level design all kinda suck. But hey, if you like killing stuff you'd probably be able to look past that. Overall, I'd slap it with a 6.5/10 or a 7/10. Worth grabbing on sale.

While I never made it to Dream of the Nioh (basically NG+4, the final difficulty) and haven't played Nioh 2 in a long time, maybe a couple years, as the grind got way too much for me. After reaching 3/4 of the way through Dream of the Wise (NG+3) I'd say it's a very fun game has some really unique combat, story isn't anything memorable for me, but the combat, grinding and learning enemies/bosses is what kept me going for so long.

Combos have the potential to be crazy fun with the stance switch specific moves and move assignment in each stance, a little overwhelming at first but learning it is fun once you get the gist of it, weapon types after different enough and all have their own unique feeling.

Yokai mode is pretty fun, never used it as a main combat thing, more of a panic button when I eventually mess up really bad, but it has so much more potential that I never got to fully experience.

Fists, The weapon class, Fist and Feet for the various demons, Crazy Stamina Drain, Multiple hits, big PP damage, My favourite weapon. It has an attack called Beyond Infinity, it has 5(?) Kinda Just Frame inputs, each one increasing my Beyond Infinity's speed is euphoric and a dopamine hit I need during boss fights. The speed increase, the Kinda Just Frames DINGs of success and visual flair of after image punches and kicks make this move so satisfying to pull off. I'd say Fists are a very oppressive and aggressive weapon type and the trade off is its very stamina hungry and it's what I mainly used through all dreams upto Wise, I felt like I never reached the "Git Gud" levels of proficiency but it was still so much fun weaving in all the free form combos I could think of. 

I've dabbled in Tonfa, Odachi and at least reached enough proficiency with every weapon to do their special missions. Tonfa is a pair of spinny bois with fun combo potential, Odachi has a heavy feeling moveset with nice chunky damage and pretty cool attacks.

Oh and you can make a Hot AF Demon Waifu/Husbando as your playable character and I believe you can always change their appearance at nearly all times outside of missions, the character customisation is very nice, one of my favourite character creators of all time, not too complex or simple, just right for me. Game also has a transmog system for the fashion hunters out there, I don't remember how it works but I remember it not being anything too complex or difficult once it's unlocked, I believe you can transmog any gear you've picked up before for a small price.

There is an endgame that I barely touched because I was already burning and burnt out by the time I got there. 

I'd say you'd enjoy this game if you don't mind grinding and min maxing a lot, or just enjoy the combat and escalating difficulty.

After beating the final DLC, I can comfortably give this game a high recommendation. 
  
Mechanically, it's better than Nioh 1 in almost every way. 
  
The level design is more even and less 'bull$hitty' than the first. Though I will say the first has some more memorable level designs...or was it because they were so bull$shitty, I remember them...? 
 
The gameplay has been refined and tuned to an almost perfect degree. You will NEVER get tired of burst countering. 
  
The amount of depth in this game is frankly stunning and will keep dedicated players going long into New Game Plus. 
  
Storywise though...Nioh trumps it. While Nioh 2's story is better presented, so I at least know what the hell's going on, the actual writing is weaker. It doesn't help that you, the protagonist, don't have a speaking role (aside from some anime grunts); which makes no sense since they could have easily added voices for whatever gender your avatar was. Plus, I tend to have a mask on, so hearing my avatar talk was necessary, since his facial expressions are mostly covered. It's just a missed opportunity to really give the protagonist a standout role, instead of just an amorphous plot device to move the story forward. 

As well, it tries to do too much: Being its own game, [spoiler]simultaneously[/spoiler] being a prequel [spoiler]and a stealth sequel, as well as wrapping up plot threads from Nioh 1[/spoiler]; but it can't nail the landing and collapses under the weight of it all. The time jumps are jarring, so it's hard to get attached to characters as they come and go. [spoiler]The resolutions for Nioh 1 feel disappointing and anti-climactic (dare I say, even rushed).[/spoiler] By the time it‚Äôs over, the ending comes off as flat and lacking significant closure. 

As well, Nioh 2's DLC is pretty disappointing and kind of greedy. Compared to Nioh 1, Nioh 2 really relies on its DLC to fill in the plot holes and finish up the story. You could have ended Nioh 1 right then and there and would have been fine. It had closure. And then its DLC CONTINUED the story on its own merits. Yes, it left some plot threads open, but even then, it gave us mostly closure, AND IT PUSHED THE STORY FORWARD. 
 
Nioh 2's DLC story[spoiler], though, is not only a weak time travel plot, but it[/spoiler] feels backwards and doesn't really do anything other than retread ground to explain why certain things happened. The whole opening of Nioh 2 is explained in the final DLC. Why couldn't this have somehow been integrated into Nioh 2 and saved us some money? AND then, continue the story to something fresh and forward. 

But this is like knocking a number off a 10/10 game. So, a 9/10 it is. 
 
It's very worthwhile and one of the best action RPGs in the last few years.

EDIT: With more time to process, this is a solid 8/10 for me. I love the gameplay refinements and moment to moment combat, but the story really did disappoint me both from a narrative standpoint; on top of a weak finish with underwhelming DLC (especially compared to the strong finish of Nioh 1 with amazing DLC).

Nioh 2 a fast souls-like with a vast amount of customization. Not only do you have a pretty in-depth character creator but also smaller PoE like skill trees for every weapon type; 

- 11 melee weapons
- 3 ranged
- 2 magic trees
- 1 transformation tree
- And if i remember correctly, a Samurai skill tree.

These contain both active and passive skills that can be purchased  with skill-points gained by using the relevant weapon/magic in combat. This system is on top of and separate from the classic souls leveling you recognize from other games in the genre.

After unlocking skills in a weapon tree you can use them to customize your attacks to further build your character the way you want. I.E., Maybe put a hand chop as a finisher after light attacks, or perhaps you instead fancy a retreating strike? You choose. 

This freedom is amazing to me. On top of this, all weapons have three different stances; 

- Slow, high power but low evasion
- All-around decent 
- Speedy, low power with high evasion

All three stances can be customized and seamlessly switched between in combat. 

On top of this you can also use your defeated enemies abilities in combat, like in some Castlevania games. On death enemies souls can drop which you can equip on your chosen God and then use their abilities for yourself. There are alot of gods and they all have differing stats and buffs. Just choose the one that seems fun (you can change between levels if you like).
 
I would say this is the hardest souls-like out of the big ones and if you're prone to rage, maybe don't get it? You'll likely break something.
The enemies hit HARD. But gods damn it's satisfying to finally learn the boss pattern and end them after 9 grueling deaths.
 
Add to all this a Diablo-style loot system, co-op with up to 2 friends, and a story you most likely don't care about, and you got Nioh 2.

Combat developed by Team Ninja (creators of Ninja Gaiden) in a Souls-like lens with a Diablo-style ARPG loot system. Tons of enemy variety, extremely unique weapon and varied styles of play.


Incredible amount of content. If you play this game, expect to be able to sink a ton of time into it if you'd like. If you truly want to unlock everything and complete every difficulty, expect multiple hundreds of hours. If you simply want to focus on a couple of specific weapons and blast through the difficulties, you can do that too.


Individuals have spent thousands of hours playing this game on the merits of the combat alone. I myself find almost all of the weapons to be enjoyable enough that I could see myself spending hundreds of hours practicing with the weapons in this game. Unlike Souls-like games, the combat can be lightning-fast much like Team Ninja's previous titles.


The RPG elements of the game are there for fun and optimization, as well as crafting a specialized build based on your tastes, and to scale your weapons to do the highest amount of damage possible or pump HP to live while taking extra hits. Much like Souls games, however, the combat is 100% skill based and you're capable of dodging and blocking every attack, which means that it is not a -requirement- to have an optimized build or hit a level milestone to progress in the game. I personally prefer a more balanced approach to the game and find fulfillment in using my entire arsenal, but the game also supports pumping a few major stats and using just a couple of key skills for each weapon that are extremely strong, which makes it easier, cheesier and more Souls-like which can be fun sometimes and is absolutely a viable way to play the game.


Co-op works flawlessly, and is the best implementation of Co-op in a game like this. On the basic difficulty, I played through the game with a friend of mine the entire way through. Both of us shared the same progression through all main and side missions. You can play 100% of the main story missions co-op and you can play 95% of the side missions in the game co-op


I really only have three very minor gripes with the game:

1. The game is incredibly deep mechanically, and while that is fantastic for increasing the skill ceiling, I don't feel like the game is super explicit in explaining some of the more important stuff to you, it kinda just flashes a pop-up at you once and then you move on. More in-game tutorials here and there might have been more beneficial, because I actually ended up learning a lot by looking up videos. On the same topic, there are SO many mechanics and stats in this game that you just kinda have to mouse over to expand the details because the names of the stats will not tell you the full story, even stats that seem obvious.

2. The story is pretty meh. There are some spectacular cutscenes and there's enough there to keep me engaged, but nothing I'd write home about.

3. I wish there was more options in customizing the look of your character's gear.


All in all, I cannot believe that I just decided to buy this game in 2022, I wish I'd bought it on release.

Nioh 2 is a souls-like game, it shares a lot of similarities to fast paced ninja games like Ninja Gaiden and Onimusha as well. The five main conceits of Nioh 2:

1. The Ki (like stamina) system provides bonuses to playing on a cadence, gives buffs, makes boss encounters feel like MMO phases, and provides a good asymmetry to human and yokai encounters.
2. Most unblockable moves are counter-able via a mechanic called Burst Counter, of which there are three flavors. All unblockables are telegraphed with high clarity on type.
3. Monster Hunter style weapon choices with an activity based (earned through using) skill system that rewards investment but doesn't punish experimentation.
4. A flashy yokai ultimate form that gives the player further control over the encounters.
5. A good blending of Yokai mythology and Sengoku history make this grounded, yet anime, and quirky. For instance there are yokai that you can threaten to leave you alone, others you can stun by shooting them in the eye. Always hit the glowy bits if possible.

Other notable differences:
- Loot system is a bit bonkers like Diablo. Most of the time you get trash, but some have inheritable traits that require you to use the item to allow it to pass.
- Relatively easy access to Respeccing, you do need to beat two bosses, and starting stats are locked in.
- Magic playstyles require you to fight in melee.

Nioh 2 is a 3rd person action game with rpg mechanics. You play as a mysterious warrior with demon powers on a quest around an alternative reality feodal era Japan. You meet and fight various historical figures, who may or may not have demon powers, slaughter thousands of various demonical entitities straight from Japanese folk lore and gather so, so, so many different weapons, armor sets and items.

What separates Nioh from other similar games are the three stances and the ki-burst systems. Each melee weapon can be wielded in a high-powerered stance that drains your stamina greatly, a mixed-powered stance that seems to emphasise blocking and counters, and a nimble stance with a great dodge and fast attacks. You can switch weapons and stances after attacks to replenish your stamina and dispel some adverserial effects. Being good at stance switching means you will be able to keep up the pace of the combat, and do some ridiculous combos on the enemies. It's great fun and a very versatile system. The weapons themselves are very varied, and most feel good to use. There are chains, axes, staves, tonfas, swords a-plenty and even a magical scythe.

The enemies that you smack around with the weapons are tough. Most can 2-4 hit kill you, they can stun you easily if yo aren't careful, they can grapple you through your block and sometimes they ambush you by dropping from trees, or snipe at you from a long distance. They can take a beating too! And the bosses are even worse - with huge health pools, massive attacks and fast recoveries - you will have to battle for you victories. And I think that in the end the bosses and enemies are challenging, but fun to fight. The humanoid bosses are even better, since you can parry their attacks, which leads to a fun dance-around. Unlike Sekiro, the parry isn't the be-all end all of the playstyle, so I like Nioh better.

You don't have to battle alone either! You can leave a mark on the ground and a clone of your character can be summoned by other players to aid their quest, and you will be rewarded for doing this. Dead players will spawn red graves that you can challenge for additional rewards. Good fun, and quite a synergistic system, as the grave-spawned enemies will give resources to summon friendly characters.

There's plenty to do in Nioh 2, as apprantly the New Game+ feature will unlock even more crafting and battling options, along with harder missions. There are hidden skills for all weapon styles, lots of enemy skills to capture, the crafting system is pretty fun and you can have all sorts of weird and synergistic builds. I have spent 70+ hours just diddling around side content, grinding missions and crafting and trying all sorts of weapons and I haven't even seen the final boss.

The game starts in a similar fashion to a Souls game, but it is not one.
The game demands active combat, dodging and Ki (Stamina) management and punishes the more "Stay back and wait for openings" gameplay that is more common in other soulslike games.
The game also dramatically changes after NG, where in later NG cycles (Specifically NG++ onwards) where builds become game altering. The gameplay shifts into a hyper aggressive playstyle where stunlocking an Enemy is necessary to defeat bosses.
It should be noted that NG+ (onwards) adds new mechanics, loot and sets, and changes enemy placements (and later NG+s adds later enemies into earlier stages, including DLC enemies).
Lastly, regarding the DLC - each DLC is quite short, but the quality of the levels, new enemies, new sets and abilities -and- new weapons are on a whole new level. The DLC also add new NG+ cycles as mentioned before.
Fantastic game - but do not go in thinking "I played Dark Souls therefore I know how to play this game" - because this ain't Dark Souls, you will need to be hyper aggressive to succeed, you will need to use Stance Switching and Ki Pulsing (Stam Management mechanic), and the game will punish you severely if you don't.

I have played the game for about 181 hours as of this review.  I have to say that the game is frankly amazing in terms of its depth, game-play, level design, variety of weapons, skills, forging of items, attributes, etc., etc.  It is a very deep and involved game.  The character controls and ability to specialize as well as all of the add-on things that can be done is astounding (e.g., obtaining titles and skill points, tea house, etc.).  It is almost too much.  The play is compelling and the story line is one of the best I have seen - certainly as good or better than Sekiro.  I think this game is much better than sekiro and I thought it was a great game.  The replayability of this game is tremendously better than sekiro in my opinion.

All that said, this game WILL NOT appeal to a vast swath of gamers out there in that the game is difficult to learn.  Similar to From Software titles the documentation is nil and you have to figure everything out yourself or by watching YouTube tutorials.  Given the depth and complexity of the game and the control mechanics learning this game is no small task.  Expect to spend at least 1/3 of your time just trying to figure out the game.  As various players have said that have invested way more time in this game than I have you don't really get access to certain skills, weapons, and armor until new game or new game +.  So think about that for a minute and put it in perspective of a play-through of Elden Ring.   This game is a beast.  I personally think it is one of the greatest game designs of all time for an action RPG given the content and replayabiity.  Seriously, it is that good if you like this type of game.  It is souls like or sekiro like but taken to a totally different level of design, story, and gameplay.  I highly recommend it if you are a fan of those types of games and are willing to invest the time to learn all about it.

This game has a similar feel to the Dark Souls games, but in my honest opinion? way easier and much more fun to get into. You have 13 weapon types to choose from  (you can use 2 different weapons at any given time), with each weapon type having its own skill tree that increases the combo potential. There are 3 stances for the weapons: High stance focuses on pure damage, but it takes up the most Ki (stamina); Mid stance is your blocking stance, blocking in mid stance takes the least amount of Ki out of your bar, and most weapons have a parry skill that can be used in mid stance; Low stance is your dodge stance, dodging in low stance is super fast and fluid, and a lot of the weapons have skills that relate to dodging while in low stance. The weapon types and stances make the game's combat feel much more fleshed out, and even if you fall into the routine of one or two combos, there's still plethora of options to choose from. 

What makes it easier to get into in my opinion, is the guardian spirit/yokai form mechanic. At the start you can choose between one of three guardian spirits, each giving their own stat buffs and other passives. However; the biggest part of the guardian spirit system is the Yokai Form. Each guardian spirit has one of three yokai forms (brute, feral, and phantom), and each form corresponds to your yokai switch (where you briefly turn into a yokai) and your burst counter (a counter move for specific enemy attacks). I always choose the brute form, to which I also recommend to any and all new players, because of its simplicity: the form? Big fuck off kanabo and go crazy. The counter? Hit the mf. But I alsop implore everyone to try out the other forms and pick which is best for you and your playstyle.

Now let's talk about some of the other pluses, starting with character customization. 
OH MY FUCKIN GOD IS IT GOOD, its extremely in depth, you can incrementally change your nose angle if you want, among many other things. Another thing to note hair system, too many times in souls likes you see only two "styles" of afro hair, either an afro, or braids. Not in Nioh, here you can select any hair style you wish, and then choose the curl amount, from stick straight hair to almost coily. I'll be frank, it doesn't look good on every style, but there is such a wide variety of hair styles, and you can make them all your own. Another topic about the hair I like is once you choose a base hairstyle, you can select the parts, whether it be the bun/ponytail, the bangs, as well as the sides of the hair. Its a very in depth system and its also the part I take the longest on. I'm also quite fond of the tattoo and markings in the character customization, the scars don't look fake and you can freely adjust size and placement. The tattoos do seem a bit saturated when you first apply them, but you can turn down their opacity to make them fit better. In addition to all of this, you can directly input character codes so you can upload the appearance of someones character, if you so desire.

My favorite part of this game though, has to be the story.
Don't come into this game expecting a God Of War/Horizon level of depth and detail; because at the base this game is all about the combat. HOWEVER, you can expect way more story than what most other Souls Likes are giving you. This game also takes place during the Unification of Japan, and thus you meet quite a few influential figures from that time. (ie Oda Nobunaga and Hattori Hanzo) Also the "codex" of this game, which you can view by visiting your hut and looking at the illustrations, is extremely well written. For characters, the game tells you about their historical deeds, but also how they have interacted with the protagonist and the story. For the enemies, the first entry will always give you the mythos and folklore about the yokai, whereas the latter entries may give you hints on how to defeat them easier. 

That's enough of a rant from me, but its a VERY good game, and you will drop 70+ hours into this easily

Probably the best of the soulslikes not directly from From Software. A big improvement on Nioh 1, adding to the series' unique entry into the genre with fast paced, combo based combat. There is no pvp in Nioh 2 unlike the small pvp system in 1, but the coop system and other player interactions are fairly well integrated into the game.

Nioh is mission based rather than open world but keeps even reused levels somewhat interesting by changing time of day and blocking/opening paths to make navigation different, even reversed at times. Its story is Japanese mythology laid over a loose take on mid to late Sengoku period, effectively a prequel to the first game with some tie-ins, but largely separated and stands alone. New Game Plus goes up to +4, and each level of NG+ is separately crafted, changing enemy spawns and bringing new mechanics to players and enemies.

The Nioh series has a fairly different form of character progression where gear drops are randomized and plentiful, increasing in level as you progress, and usually more important than character level. This makes the game mildly MMO-like as gear becomes outdated through game progression. There is an upgrade system to update a nice piece of gear to current levels, but it gets pricy to constantly do.

With its different take on stamina with the ki system, combat flows very smoothly when mastered. The defensive options regularly reward mixing up blocking, dodging, countering, and sometimes ki pulses in response to enemies. Ranged weapons are very useful throughout the game, being able to knock down or outright kill weaker enemies from stealth before combat. 11 different types of melee weapons and 3 different ranged weapon types each with fairly distinct abilities brings a lot of options to try out.

While there is a lot of good about the game, it does have its flaws. The English localization is a bit questionable. The story is passable, having a lot of points from Japanese history but handwaving over a lot of details for yellow glowing stones. Most keybinds can be changed, but one specifically can't. There's a bug disabling online trying to connect Epic crossplay. Lastly, aim assist feels minimal on the controller, so I found it typical to move my right hand to the mouse when shooting.

Nioh 2 is Nioh 1 on steroids. An "all you can eat" buffet expansion of the first game. There's more of everything: more levels, move enemies, more weapons, more skills and generally more systems to upgrade your character. You can even collect tea sets. Audiovisuals are just slightly better, but Nioh 2 still is a pretty game. Sadly the main storyline suffers from this avalanche of gameplay options. I'd call it incoherent and that's putting it nicely. Controls are fiddly; it's clearly a game made for gamepad (console). The UI is somewhat cluttered and not all systems are clearly explained. Perhaps I didn't pay attention, but  after 150 hours I discovered how to switch between guardian spirits. Yup, there's a lot going on in this game. Sometimes less is more. Clearly Nioh 2 didn't get that note.

And that's mostly fine actually. After the improved character generation I played Nioh 2 with my regular coop buddy. This was our first Souls experience together. Barring a bit of lag in a few missions the coop experience was flawless. About 99% of the levels can be played in coop, a few arena boss missions being the exception. We had a bloody good time. Coop makes pincer tactics more viable and it's nice to see each other's character and skills grow.

All in all: Nioh 2 isn't perfect, but it *is* an extremely solid Souls and coop game. It's also a big time investement. If you're looking for that type of game, then look no further.

You start out with no skills, weaksauce gear. Weak, afraid, and knowing nothing. You'll end the game a god of war, styling on the bosses and treating enemies like the loot pi√±atas they are. Provided you stick around and learn the game, that is.

Then come on in traveler, stay a while and sink your teeth into 'this souls-like' feels familiar enough to draw you in, but is unique enough to have its own skill tree for numerous weapons along with a whole separate skill system that allows you to not only partake in melee combat using Japanese weapons but fighting alongside the spirits of the slain Yokai that you've vanquished.

Easily one of the best games I've every played. Arguably has the best combat every created. 11 weapons with completely distinct movesets, Yokai/demon transformations, a parrying system called burst counter(which there are 3 different ways to use), a ridiculously deep crafting/upgrading system you don't have to use before NG+, using the abilities of demons etc., this game has a ridiculously deep combat.

This is a huge improvement over Nioh 1, which already was a top tier game. Old enemies have their movesets revamped, new enemies are added which grant the game a ridiculous amount of enemy variety. Both human and yokai bosses are significantly improved over Nioh 1. Returning weapons have new moves added to their moveset alongside 4 new amazing weapons. Skill tree is also revamped and feels slightly better to use now. Magic and Ninjutsu is deeper than the first game with many different abilities added and preparing jutsu is significantly better in this game. Character creator is praised a lot, but I've barely changed the look of my character so I can't really comment on that. Biggest improvement over the first game is, imho, the game's balance. Nioh 1's missions kind of took a nose dive in the endgame with the game just making you fight several bosses at the same time in so many side missions and human enemies spamming living weapon like there's no tomorrow. Both problems are fixed in Nioh 2, and it feels amazing to play thanks to that. Side missions are still fun and innovative by the endgame, and the human boss of DLC2 is one of the best fights in the game.

One flaw(and downgrade from Nioh 1) in the game is the story. Nioh 1 already had a weak story, and this one is somehow even worse. Nobunaga is extremely whitewashed for some reason, which makes him less interesting than his other portrayals in media. DLCs have better story than the main game, and they take you to Heian period which is a time we rarely see in games. I like them a lot because of this.

Long story short, this game is quite definitely a masterpiece, and everyone should definitely play it. It's filled to the brim with content, especially if you're in for new game plusses. It's definitey worth both your money and your time.

[h1]Nioh 2 is one of my top five all-time favorite videogaming titles. If I ever had a list of ten games I wish I had with me if I was stuck on a desert island, Nioh 2 would be one of them.[/h1]
[b][u]Let me start with the flaws, since there aren't that many[/u][/b]:
[olist]
[*][b]The PC port for this game isn't the best[/b]. It's a 7/10 in most regards. You will need a decent rig.¬†
[*][b]Story isn't bad but it isn't as good as it potentially could be[/b]. Don't play this game if you're looking for a rich narrative and fleshed out characters.¬†
[*][b]Drop rates for certain things can be unreasonably low[/b]. Grinding isn't at all necessary to beat all the content the game has to offer. However, if you want perfect gear rolls with perfect passives for your desired playstyle, you will have to do a lot of grinding.
[*][b]The game throws you to the wolves[/b]. It doesn't teach you most of its essential techniques and habits for playing well. Much like with fighting games, if you want to learn important basic techniques or tap into this game's high skill ceiling, you're gonna have to look around on gaming forums and follow specific YouTube channels and social media accounts.¬†
[*][b]Visibility and framerate can both take a huge dip during co-op[/b]. Even in single player, visual clarity can be a problem at times with all the effects going on during battle.¬†
[*][b]Getting skill points early on can be a rather slow process[/b].¬†Be sure to explore levels thoroughly for skill point items to expedite this process!
[*][b]Endgame loot and inventory management can be very tedious[/b]. Especially if you're serious about getting the best gear.¬†
[/olist]
[b][u]Now onto all the great things:[/u][/b]
[olist]
[*][b]An insane amount of content[/b]. There are a total of 28 main missions and 85 side missions, alongside extra dojo missions and hard-mode missions of existing main missions. Then there are also numerous arcade-like enemy rush extra missions, and an endgame dungeon system numbering in at over 100 floors worth of encounters that is only available on the hardest difficulty. You're looking at a game with at least 70 hours of content if all you want to do is solo and beat every single main, side and DLC mission on the game's base difficulty for a first-time playthrough.
[*][b]The most comprehensive New Game Plus system of any Souls-like game to date[/b]. Unlike the From Software games that inspired it, Nioh 2 actually has a robust New Game Plus system that adds numerous changes to the game. Instead of just having New Game Plus be "the exact same game but with enemies doing more damage, having more health and giving you more experience points", Nioh 2 changes up enemy placements, gives most enemies new moves, offers new game modes and unique loot types that you can only get on higher difficulties, in addition to having an actual endgame system. The game's New Game Plus system itself offers immense freedom in the order you pursue each mission.
[*][b]Playstyle variety and viability out the wazoo[/b]. Yes, there are some specific cheesy builds that are more powerful and easy to use than others, but in terms of viability, the sky is the limit. It's virtually impossible to have a "bricked" build in this game that you can pinpoint as the source of blame in case you fail to progress past a difficult challenge. As long as your action gaming fundamentals are solid, then you can make any build work all the way to endgame.¬†Don't listen to the scrubs who tell you that the game "forces" you to play specific lame and cheesy ways, because in 99% of cases, it doesn't.¬†
[*][b]Combat depth out the wazoo[/b]. The amount of dexterity and execution required if you want to play at the highest possible skill level rivals that of the greatest character action games out there like Devil May Cry 3. You want a game that you can spend hundreds of hours labbing just to be able to perform the most stylish tech and combos? Play Nioh 2.
[*][b]Throwing out Pok√©mon to attack during combat[/b]. This game has an Igavania-inspired enemy "soul core" system that allows you to absorb the powers of enemies and use them seamlessly in combat to extend combos, control crowds and pick apart enemies.
[*][b]A co-op system that is easy to get up and running[/b]. That is, unlike the From Software games that inspired Nioh 2. Want to play co-op? Just open up a room and have people join. Or you can join existing rooms.
[*][b]The best videogame soundtrack of 2020[/b]. Even if you read this review and still don't want to play the game, at least go listen to the soundtrack on YouTube. You won't regret it. Be sure to also listen to the DLC boss fight tracks.
[*][b]A robust and easy-to-use character creator[/b]. You can input character codes shared from other Nioh 2 players on the internet to instantly copy their character look if you so desire. Oh, and unlike some other games, you have zero restrictions on how much you can alter the look of your character. You can, at any point in the game, change how your character's face¬†looks. No arbitrary limitations per playthrough (*cough*Dark Souls 3*cough*) and no needing to pay vouchers with real money to change your look (I'm looking at you, Monster Hunter games!).
[*][b]You can actually PAUSE the damn game[/b]. This is unlike the games that inspired Nioh 1 and 2 that insist on not having any kind of pause feature even if you are playing offline. And guess what? Pausing does NOTHING to reduce the difficulty of the game! Shocking, ain't it? How could anyone be dumb enough to think that having a pause feature would trivialize a game's difficulty?
[*][b]Game always gives you free ways to boost damage[/b]. No matter how terrible you think your gear drops are, the game always has universal damage modifiers you always have access to that more than compensate for sub-par gear. Just attacking enemies from behind alone does 50 percent extra damage without having any specific stats or passives on you.¬†
[*][b]The fashion game in Nioh 2 is top tier[/b]. Thanks to the ability to refashion/transmog the look of your gear that is available right from the get-go, you will never have to go around looking like a buffoon wearing a clownsuit.
[*][b]Playing in co-op adds extra enemies in missions and even adds minions to boss fights[/b]. The developers had the foresight to do this so that players people wishing to go through by co-op can have levels designed with co-op in mind for a proper challenge, unlike a certain other famous developer with games that keep enemy counts the same regardless of how many players there are in co-op, which leads to the levels being a cakewalk in those games since they aren't designed to deal with multiple players.
[*][b]Earlier missions never become obsolete in terms of difficulty thanks to the game's "level sync" feature that raises enemy power to match your current character level and gear.[/b] This "level sync" feature is entirely optional. Want to overpower earlier levels? Don't activate it. Want to ensure your revisits of earlier content remain challenging? Activate it.
[*][b]No Bayonetta/God of War-esque gimmick levels[/b]. When you spend an hour playing Nioh 2, you spend an hour mostly doing the combat instead of suffering through mini-games or forced walking sequences or needlessly-obtuse, time-wasting puzzles that have nothing to do with the core gameplay.
[*][b]Very good mouse and keyboard controls and customizability[/b]. Though I honestly don't recommend playing this game with MKB controls since it's a very steep learning curve to a game that already has a very steep learning curve.
[*][b]Nioh 2 and Nioh 1 are the only popular games I know of that actually give you the option to skip cutscenes you have already viewed[/b]. This is huge for a game that gives nearly every boss a unique introductory cutscene. In other games, if you die 10 times to a boss, you'll have to mash through that boss's pre-fight cutscene 10 times. Not in Nioh 2.¬†
[/olist]

Currently on NG+3 and I'd say I'm pretty done with this game.

Would recommend this game SOLELY on combat alone. I think it rivals MH (Monster Hunter) in terms of combat depth. If you want engaging combat with lots of potential and good build crafting get this. But there's a big, big, BIG caveat.

This was a lot harder for me than even Sekiro due to 3 things: bloat values, extreme stamina management, and (IMHO) subpar animations/telegraphs, when compared to FS (From Software) and MH.

1. Bloat values:
This game will 1-shot and 2-shot you a LOT more compared to NG+4 above Souls games, including Sekiro. Early playthroughs can mitigate this with higher defense and toughness (hyper armor), but on higher NG+ cycles you'd better have gotten gud already, because not only will you get stun locked to oblivion if you get hit, but bosses will have very high amounts of health. Expect end game boss battles to take as long as a monster hunt in MH.

2. Extreme stamina management
Stamina is even more of a premium in this game compared to From games. You take health AND stamina damage when you get hit. Every time you get hit, if you fail the hyper armor check, you'll flinch. This doesn't have hyper armor, so if you happened to get grazed by a multi hit combo, you're gonna be eating that whole combo unless you block timely (which also costs a LOT of stamina). Deplete your bar and you enter winded state; at this point you're pretty much stunned and dead, as most enemies will move in for a grapple and 1/2 shot you... Early on this really restricts what combos/movesets you can enjoy. I've heard it gets better on ng+4 onwards once you get better gear, but... idk. Sounds poorly balanced to me if it takes that long.

3. Inferior animations (compared to MH and Souls)
This is probably down to preference. I'd still rate MH at the top in terms of fair combat animations. FromSoft used to be a close tie. While still great, recent experiences with Malekith and other super fast telegraphed bosses in Elden Ring have taken From down a couple notches for me. Everyone seems obsessed with Bloodborne and Sekiro speeds these days, but I digress. Team Ninja is nowhere near that ballpark of animation excellence. You'll see a lot of sliding feet, jerky telegraphs, and most attacks are covered by particle effects and big damage numbers. You can hide the numbers; the effects, not so much. This makes reading your enemies much harder on top of the already mid animation quality.

All in all, I'd still recommend this game. But be VERY wary of the difficulty that awaits you. Personally, after having experienced this game I'm VERY VERY cautious of Team Ninja's upcoming Wild Hearts, and will most likely pass if it ends up being as "balanced" as Nioh 2.

Terrible multiplayer.

Difficult games like Nioh rewards players for being tenacious and undefeated by failure, it's built on the fact that you can try and try again and will succeed if you have the persistence. However in multiplayer gameplay, this changes; the core importance of being able to try again is stripped away. Whenever you die a certain amount, your group is penalized with by halving all amrita earned used to level up your character. To circumvent this, you have to end the session, start a new room, invite them all back in, then restart. I understand that when you die, the enemies don't respawn again, but upon reaching a shrine(checkpoint, new respawn point), the penalty persists, and there is no option to restart without doing it the obviously obtuse method.

I don't recommend this for playing multiplayer.

Excellent Masocore game, well worth the price. Do note the melee combat, while superficially similar to Fromsoftware games, has more options and variations with greater potential complexity. You need not engage in the full breadth of the melee system and it is perfectly viable to play the melee combat in a very simplistic manner, but know that with sufficient experience and knowledge Nioh 2 can be incredibly flashy. 

[b]Positives[/b]
+Excellent soundtrack. Not the absolute best I've heard, as that honor goes to the MonHun series and Nier/Drakengard, but it's very much up there. 

+Very good combat. In my opinion, it's on par with Elden Ring, if not better, due to the greater variety of offense possible. If you like Masocore games, you can't go wrong with Nioh.

+Levels are large and have a lot of exploration to be done. There are side paths, collectibles/loot, and optional objectives to make exploration easier. Do note that almost every level ends in either an enemy rush or miniboss/boss fight. 

+Loot has a lot of variety, and the grace effects can be very fun, offering alternative playstyles. Do note grace effects, whether Divine or Ethereal, will not drop until higher NG+ cycles, with some of the most interesting not being available until the final NG+ cycle of "Dream of the Nioh." 

+Visual design is very good. Environments and colors are vibrant and show the beauty of Japan, its culture, and mythology. You won't see individual pores and skin texture like in MK11, but Nioh 2 still holds up very well in current gen. 

+Content has good breadth and isn't too repetitive. The setting is based on the Sengoku Period of Japanese history, and is fairly accurate in its events. You'll find a decent introduction to the Sengoku Period here, if somewhat dramatized, as game developers and other media creators are wont to do. DLC (note: the DLC is included in the complete edition) does dip into earlier periods of Japanese history, but it is primarily focused on resolving the main conflict within the greater Nioh 2 story. 

+Character creator seems to be able to accommodate various ethnicities decently well, and is quite fun regardless even if representation is not something important to you. [spoiler]There is a bust slider. Need I say more?[/spoiler]

+Short haired yokai-slaying tomboy waifu with beauty mark and giant scythe. With a touch of either a great f*ckin' cosmetic surgeon, or casual immortality from her guardian spirit. Speaking of waifus, there's a lot of waifus. You'll not find any absurd amounts of fanservice (No "I can't believe it's not Hentai!" here), but Nioh is not a prudish childrens' game either. 

[b]Negatives[/b]

-Loot can be incredibly grindy to obtain ones' desired sets. Acquiring better equipment is perhaps the endgame loop, and it can be very dispiriting at times. The loot system absolutely is a double edged sword. Frankly, I hope future Nioh games or successors make it much less grindy, even as much as I love the variety available. 

-Endgame mostly consists of very repetitive 'domains' that players farm to acquire better loot. It may very well appeal to you, but I quite dislike the endgame, once one finishes Dream of the Nioh. 

-Certain gameplay mechanics, especially Curse of the Nioh, feel very unfair. This isn't a major issue and can absolutely be overcome by adapting, as any masocore game should, but it does feel a bit excessive at times with Nioh 2. 

-Magic (and ninjutsu, by extension) deals incredibly poor direct damage to bosses. It might just be my specific build that had issues, but as far as I could tell, it was not simply because of a bad build on my part. I used a heavily magic specialized build, and even then it was only a supplement to my melee weapon at best, only useful on very specific enemies or niche situations. For bosses and most situations, I used magic to buff myself and debuff enemies while I engaged in melee combat. Outside of perhaps a Hand Cannon build, which I have not tried myself and cannot give any anecdotes or guarantees of its effectiveness, pure ranged combat is absolutely unviable. Again, this is a minor issue and does not detract much from Nioh 2 as a whole. but it is a negative nonetheless. I favor casters with reasonably competent melee combat in RPG games, and that sort of playstyle is simply not possible in Nioh 2. The closest equivalent here is perhaps a paladin sort of thing as mentioned above, where magic/ninjutsu is used as support for a melee playstyle. 

[b]Conclusion[/b]
Players interested in masocore games will get a lot of enjoyment out of Nioh 2, and find an extremely deep melee combat system that offers great potential for learning. I highly recommend Nioh 2 to anyone looking for a challenging RPG, and perhaps to look forward to future Koei Tecmo/Team Ninja games of the same type.

Nioh's excellent fast-paced combat and huge weapon movesets set it apart from other games in the genre. The combat honestly feels more like Ninja Gaiden than Dark Souls, other than the part where enemies can kill you in a few hits while you have non-instant heals. I recommend trying out different weapon types as you go rather than using the same 1 or 2 weapon types for the whole game - there are 11 different weapon types and they all play very differently once you learn a few active skills.

I don't love the Diablo-style loot system and think the game would have been better off without it, but it becomes a lot easier to deal with once you realize that special effects don't matter (at least until late NG+ cycles) and that you can get rid of anything you're not actively using because every piece of equipment will become obsolete within a few hours. In the offering/sell/dismantle menus, there's an option to instantly select every item of a specific rarity or lower which helps you clear things out quickly.

Another con to note is that the optional missions egregiously reuse levels and bosses. I like the idea of having shorter levels for a bit of downtime in between the full-size levels, but these just feel really lazy aside from the handful that have unique boss fights. Thankfully this isn't an issue with the story missions, and the enemy variety in general is much improved compared to Nioh 1.

The combat seriously carries the game despite its shortcomings in other areas. It's really, really fun and rewarding once you get the hang of it. If you haven't played either Nioh game I recommend skipping Nioh 1 and going straight to Nioh 2, they're extremely similar games but Nioh 2 is better in pretty much every way.

I have played this somewhere else before steam ones, so my play time may not reflect it. 

A lot of people may compare this to Souls-like, but to newcomers who are considering, let me just tell you it is not. Don't think it as a Souls-like and you won't be disappointed easily. 

[h1]Overview[/h1] 
Nioh 2 doesn't have the a beautiful world like Souls game, so that sense of wonder and curiosity as you explore the world is almost non-existent. The world is delivered in stage format, and unfortunately, the world is ugly. If you have played Elden Ring and was amazed by the vistas, you will not find it here. 
What it has, is a combat system, that is a little similar to Souls in the sense of roll, potion, light & heavy attack, but that's about it. In reality, the combat is much much more deep than Souls-like, you can equip various weapons that have very different style and a skill tree for each weapons, 3 combat stances with every stance customizable, 4 special demon powers, demon transformations, and an array of Ninjutsu and Magic abilities. Dodge roll is weaker in Nioh, you are expected to block fast attacks and dodge slower ones, you can also strengthen your blocks and do block counters. 

The name of the game is practice and grind. You level up, farm gear, beat demons, repeat.

So if you are looking for a satisfying systematic combat that provides a lot of exciting challenges, then this game is for you.

[h1]Pros [/h1]
The combat. The combat system is really really deep. Just as it's world building holds no candle to Souls-like, Souls-like combat holds no candle to Nioh's. While the system is complex and can sound intimidating, the game actually ease you up to the systems very well. The game doesn't let you access all the skills at once, and introduces each mechanic slowly throughout the campaign, so that you are never overwhelmed and forgot the controls. By the end of the campaign, you will have a solid grasp of all the skills that you can employ, and then you realize, it's only the beginning, for it is now time to go into a new mode and become a master. 

With the amount of monsters and bosses, you will never be short of challenges, and the battles are really exciting. You can also coop, which is amazing.

The character models are really great, the amount of customizations and details available is incredible. It allows you to create characters as pretty or handsome as you want, not unlike other game which have hideous character customizations. Getting the right fashion going is half of the game. 

[h1]Cons [/h1]
The world design is ugly, the lighting is ugly, there is not a moment that makes me want to stop and look at the scenery, in fact i kept on looking and thinking "why is it this ugly?". It's like someone who painted only with mud, if i have an analogy, Skyrim looks better than Nioh 2. 
Everything except humanoid characters look ugly, yes even the demons. Stages are reused and repeated all throughout missions. The world feels very "stage" like, it doesn't feel like a world that the characters live in. Only the final area feels slightly different and better, everything else felt the same and bland. The story is also delivered in a very boring way. 

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
The combat is like crack, a deep system you only wish a Souls game could adapt. But if you don't come to Nioh for the combat, then this game has nothing for you.

If you've come here because you've heard this game is like Dark Souls in Japan, then you are in for a surprise. It is a souls-like, but only in the sense that you have a stamina (or rather, ki) bar, you have "bonfires" where you replenish your heath and items, and your health bar will often deplete to zero.

The game operates on a "mission" system, as it consists of a hub area / map from which you can access different facilities, like shop, forging, training, etc. and from where you can embark on missions. Missions are mostly linear with a few detours here and there and only one pbjective: you drop in at one end of the map, you have to get to the other end, survive the final encounter of the mission. Sometimes its a boss or bosses, sometimes waves of enemies. There are unlockable shortcuts during the maps, those will bring you joy.

When you jump in, the game will probably seem convoluted. Read and complete the tutorials, its better to get familiar with the controls during the tutorial. The game has layers upon layers of mechanics, items, skills and equipment. Further layers will be added as you move forward in the game and, eventually, the new game cycles. Your character build will be complex and, in my opinion, it is an absolute joy to fine tune it and see it work in action as you unlock and add more and better stuff to it. It might be important to note that farming for certain pieces of equipment will be an important aspect of the game if you want to have a specific build. The loot system is heavily RNG based, but you can temper your equipment at the forge, changing certain traits and properties of it. It is a necessity to keep your armour and weapons up to date, otherwise your sword will hit like a wet noodle and even the weakest yokai will potentially one-shot you.

You will probably often say "what the hell just happened" as your soul is freed from the mortal coil yet again. The game is challenging but it is fair and straightforward in its difficulty, you can bet your ass that every enemy has a weakness which you can exploit. In my experience, combat rewards two things: agression and picking the right moment to commit to combos. The game heavily punishes turtling, as enemies will have time to regain their ki (stamina) and, on higher difficulties, even their health.
Enemies are diverse and interesting. It feels good every time to flawlessly kill an enemy you have mastered. Bosses are unique, with their own abilities and strategies.

Now, artistic pros and cons.I like the animations and models a lot, the majority of weapons and armours look really good. The story is mostly weak and predictable with the occasional high note, but you are probably not here for the story anway. The soundtrack has many memorable pieces, some of them I listen to regularly. I really like the setting, the time period the game takes place in. I like to read the encyclopedia entries about the yokai, the different guardian spirits and the (mostly) historical figures.

TLDR: Good game, complex, has meaningful endgame content that remains so throughout the new game+ cycles. The sense of progress and improvement is satisfying. Game is hard but fair. Good music, (mostly) cringe dialogues

This is my first ever Steam  review as a 15-year veteran. I have been playing Nioh 2 since Jan 2022 and I am nearing endgame Sep 2022 (Mission 20)
I am also getting old now (~50), but as an old-school gamer (Doom/Quake 1.0), I rely on instincts, practice and  muscle-memory, the last of which is unfortunately fading, along with my biological clock. But this game  - like Sekiro, another Souls-evolved  game -  challenged me to stay young and nimble. Nioh2 has a marginally gentler learning curve, though;  more stretched out, with several 'get ready' missions. 
My review below may be a bit different from the bulleted 'Pro/Con lists' that one normally reads on Steam reviews (and please forgive the ramblings of an old man). 
In my view Nioh 2 teaches the following life lessons for younger gamers: 

- So many choices! at an early stage/ young age - You won't know how to succeed later in the game/life till you try a few things
- (weapons/ninjutsu/magic) and practice/fail. If you can discover what works, then refine, stay focused and build out stats with what works for you. If you can't, persevere, you will find your path in the myriad possibilities. It took me 8 weapons (and 10 hours) before I narrowed down on Kusarigama as my weapon of choice before I got to Episode 2. BTW, It also took me 15 years IRL to find a job i enjoyed. 

- Enemies are life's uncertainties. They come in all forms and keep you on your toes. The secret is to You need to work out timings, combinations of  moves, IRL, enemies are but your friends, they teach you something you didn't know (yet) 

- Dying is ‚ÄòOK‚Äô - The game is (un)forgiving depending on your perspective, i.e., it gives you a second chance - albeit with no amrita aka, earnings. This is food for thought ( ‚Äúold person‚Äù thinking again) ‚Äì if one were to die with a chance of being brought back to life ‚Äì would you want to come back as you were, or have a chance to start from scratch? 

- Perseverance is key. Much has been written about this by people younger and more learned than myself, so keep trying till you can(not) succeed. 

- Enjoy the view. Don‚Äôt keep rushing to the next enemy/life situation. Take a while and twirl your camera around. Look at the artwork, enjoy the music, take a breather, before the next Yokai smashes you down. 

Thank you for indulging me. Enjoy the rest of your life, stay true to your course and the people who matter to you üòä

[h1]This isn‚Äôt a Review, but a Commentary on this Game‚Äôs Context as a ‚ÄúSoulslike‚Äù and how that Tag is both Misleading and Dismissive[/h1]

Well no $hit this game plays like a Souls game. It‚Äôll maybe take a seasoned Souls vet 2-3 hours to gain a firm enough grip on these mechanics to assert themselves in this game‚Äôs world as a worthy threat to all the game‚Äôs bosses. However, the presumption that this game is in any way a Souls alternative, a variation on the Souls genre, a game that has ‚Äúproven itself‚Äù as a Souls contender, or, most disrespectfully, a colorful, anime, arcadey Souls clone, is very dangerous and damaging to Team Ninja‚Äôs hard earned reputation. It is the spreading of straight up misinformation. 

I‚Äôm not sure where this lie began. It makes no sense to me because the Ninja Gaiden games enjoyed immense popularity throughout the PlayStation/PlayStation 2 era. How was it then that once Demon‚Äôs Souls came out, people did not immediately pin it as what it was: a more grim dark, deliberately paced iteration on the Gaiden Series. That From Soft was at least influenced by Team Ninja as they made Demon‚Äôs Souls is not an opinion. It‚Äôs a fact. 

Ninja Gaiden announced itself as an elite take on the fighting RPG genre in 2004. Up until then, there was no game like it that demanded such patience, focus, and dexterity from players. It was hard. The first level alone was a nightmare. The way it introduced players into the world and educated players on how to succeed through throwing players in the pool and not caring if they drowned was somewhat of an innovation. But be clear, Souls did not invent or even reinvent it. In fact, the process was more or less copy, pasted, and adjusted for Demon‚Äôs Souls. 

Demon Soul‚Äôs, being a game that came out in 2009, had arrived after [b] 5[/b] more Gaiden games were released. 

So for Nioh to borrow from elements of From Soft games is of false equivalence to From Soft‚Äôs initial having been directly inspired by Gaiden itself. 

There‚Äôs a funny moment in Nioh where this floating goat is following you around and it notices one of those elevators that you step on the square on the center in order to trigger (just like there is in every souls game). Thing is, this contraption has been in every Team Ninja game since 2004. The goat then says 
[/i]a wooden platform that is able to transport people by merely being stepped on? Who could have thought of something so ingenious?‚Äù[i]

[h1]Possibly the best action-RPG ever created.[/h1]
This is a combination of Diablo 2's loot system with better crafting, an obvious Souls inspiration and an out-of-this-world robust combat system.

If you think Dark Souls' combat is just a rhythm game, then this is the game for you, because the combat system has a lot of depth to it. Lot's of special moves, stances, yokai abilities, ninjutsu, onmyo (japanese paper-talisman) magic etc. master all of this with weapon- and even guardian spirit switching mid-combo and you get combat that almost resembles DMC sometimes.

Add the sheer amount of build variety to that and you get a game that's easily not just THE best souls game in existence but also the best aRPG. Only thing it lacks is probably online PvP, because multiplayer is pretty much just coop.

Graphics are pretty, hair looks like it had 3 shampoos and 5 balms applied, a nice ultra-realism artstyle. It's set in 16th century feudal fantasy-Japan, so you get the history and it also gives you the mythology. Don't worry, the story isn't as convoluted and difficult to understand as in Nioh 1 anymore, and the 2 games are only sort-of connected in the epilogue through Nioh 1's player character, William.

It's a good bang for your buck too: 1st playthrough with all side missions completed took me about 100 hours. It had some issues at launch (kb/m button prompts, some performance issues), but they're all resolved and it's a proper PC game now.

The maps are interesting and have an old school feel to them, things move in a semi-linear path. The enemies are difficult, even the little ones can kill you if you make a mistake. This game is likely not going to be fun for more casual gamers or people who want to be able to pick something up and play it easily. There is a very steep learning curve and it is unforgiving even early on. Overall I think it's a good game in it's design, but it's demographic is aimed at very hardcore combat enthusiasts and not for the average person. If you are looking for a challenge, this is it. I honestly think it may be the hardest game I've played.

It's really good. 

It takes the dark souls combat and improves and expands on it in many ways.
It also takes the diablo-style exciting but random loot-casino and fixes it with the ability to adjust all aspects of items at the exactly right pace towards the end of the game, completely eradicating the typical issue with that loot-system.

The devs are aware of the strengths and weaknesses of their game. Obviously the story is just some random samurai-demon basic fantasy and they keep that to a skipable minimum, to get right back to the good part: the combat.

Only real negative thing is, how easy it is to break the game when using the less player skill dependent combat styles like magic or ninjutsu. While initially not as easy as in Nioh 1, it allows for even more ridiculous combinations. The saving grace here is the fact, that it's easy to avoid and still possible to have a perfectly fine and challenging experience.

All in all a fantastic balance between supplying weaboos with their anime and monstergirl cutscenes etc., unskilled players with crutches like magic to avoid actually having to play and gamers with rewarding and challenging melee combat.

[h1]1. description[/h1]
Game is pretty challenging but rewarding. With beautiful graphics, lots types of weapons and good looking characters, it is really enjoy.

Default settings for character creation is pretty nice. I was so please about my character. Also there are lots of spirit waifu, yokai waifu, human waifu, community waifu(waifu code), which make your journey even more enjoyable.

Controller is definitely recommended since developers kinda don't know how keyboard-mouse works and default key setting is clunky as hell.

There are plenty of stuffs like "how certain perks works", "what is means of main weapon", "what are use of mortal soul cores" that game didn't explain well. So players need do find some guides from internet.

New game plus is too grindy. When player finally reach the "Dream of the Wise" level, ethereal item will start to drop randomly. The problem with the ethereal item is that player can't forge with materials. So the only way to get ethereal item is to farm. To get ethereal items with decent effects is like totally gambling.

Also some boss design is so cheap that I was get so frustrated.
Here is how they make game hard:
A). make enemy health 10 times of player's
B). make enemy attack damage 10 times of player's
C). make enemy almost never run of stamina(Ki) and also pretty aggressive
D). make enemy almost never get stun
With these game settings, players have to learn enemy's move patterns with little room for mistakes.After beating these kind of boss, I feel like I am wasting my time because its actually take no skill to do but patience and time. And everyone can do it if they know the boss move pattern.

Nioh 2 boasts an incredible amount of depth in its combat system.  With stellar character customization, varied approaches to every enemy through its mixture of weapons, stances, equipment, and magic, further modified by customizable movesets, Nioh 2 is a joy to complete the main campaign for.  The icing on the cake is its unique approach to its New Game + cycle, allowing for deeper exploration of systems the first romp through only alludes to.  Nioh 2 is easily a top 3 for me when it comes to combat in games, and if you approach this "Souls-like" like its often slower, more methodical contemporaries you will be disappointed. Instead, embrace this is as the spiritual successor to Ninja Gaiden that it aims to be.  Easily worth full price, getting this on sale is an absolute no-brainer.

[h1]THE GOOD[/h1]
+Improves upon Nioh 1's combat, which was already the smoothest and deepest of any Soulslike game. Now there's a system where you can collect the abilities of demons and equip up to 3 of them at a time. There are 75 of these in total, and collecting them all is a lot of fun. 
+Every weapon is not only cool, but viable. They come with a heavy, medium, and light stance that can be switched between at any time, and each stance completely changes a weapon's set of moves. While I have my favorites, I felt the need to master every weapon because of how great all of them are to play.
+Tons of character customization. Every piece of equipment can be made to look like anything you've already found. You also have the option to transform into many of the characters that appear throughout the story, in case you don't feel like worrying about your look.
+Significantly better level design than the first game. Missions can last for hours depending on how much time you spend exploring their numerous hidden / optional areas.
+Features the only New Game + mode I've ever taken seriously. There are 4 NG+ playthroughs to unlock, and each add entirely new mechanics, remixed enemy placements, and some enemies even get new attacks.
+Generally good soundtrack and sound design.
+A fun way to learn about Japanese folklore.
+Great overall art direction.

[h1]THE BAD[/h1]
-The story is somehow even more of an afterthought than in the first game.
-While the game is challenging, it is easy to become way too powerful for it to keep up with you.

[h1]FINAL SCORE: 95%[/h1]

This is not so much a "souls-like", beyond the very surface. It's closer to a Ninja Gaiden game, combined with Diablo's loot systems, with brutally punishing difficulty, even compared to From Soft games. Nioh 2 has more systems and subsystems and loot mechanics than almost any other RPG out there, so unlike Dark Souls, you're actually going to have to put in some work with comparing your equipment, and developing a build that's somewhat unique to you. Play this game if you want more mechanical complexity than From Soft's games are giving you, and more compelling combat than Path of Exile or Diablo are giving you.

Then you get to bosses designed to counter your strengths. That methodology doesn't work for you though. Not until much later in the game. Your weapons are pathetically weak. Every boss is a dance where you better perform your steps exactly in time. While the boss can swing and accidentally kill you. You have to balance your resources. Pay attention to the environment etc etc. The boss only has to outlast you and they never get tired. 

I will commend Team Ninja on trying to improve on the genre.

Nioh 2 is an odd game to recommend. A little backstory, I played the first Nioh when it released and loved it! To me it's the only "souls-like" (üôÑ) game that was not released from FromSoft that I felt unique in the genre and not a ripoff. So coming into Nioh 2 I was extremely looking forward to it. 

First off, if you didn't like the first game, there is nothing here that will change your mind or get you into the series. Improvements to the combat are the main improvements. With that said I enjoyed the first game quite a bit so any improvements are great! This plays more like a huge expansion rather than a full fledged sequel. 

I think my biggest issue is the level design. The levels can get a little repetive after a while. They all have the same structure. The first game also had this problem, and I wish it was addressed here. 

All and all, I would recommend this game to fans of the first game for sure! I'd also say if you liked Souls games or are fans of character action games like Bayonetta or Devil May Cry, give it a try!

Great game once you fully understand all the mechanics of the game. I did have to take some time understanding each weapon and what they do before sticking to the two weapons for my first gameplay... so my advice for everyone is to truly play with each weapon before dedicating to one.

In short - this game is overcomplicated and grindy. And the more you play the more grindy it becomes to the point where it's just too boring to play.

Most enemies, except for the few low level ones have to be grind killed. This is incredibly boring. You are supposedly playing as some kind of half-spirit warrior. Except that warrior is probably ill with tuberculosis or some other severe respiratory disease, otherwise there is no explanation why it near-suffocates after swinging a weapon for a few times or performing several dodges. You have a demon-form. Except it invariably has to be saved for end stages of boss fights because form activation gauge builds incredibly slowly. Basically everywhere the lore implies abundance of power, your character can only demonstrate weakness. The only abundance you can really have in this game is grinding.

There is a huge fighting system with multiple types of martial weapons that each can be used in three stances. Each stance comes with different moves, paces, stamina consumption, damage output etc... Who the f... had an idea that fighting happens this way must be living in some kind of alternate reality and has never practiced any kind of real world martial art. Generally you will end up choosing two weapons and one or two stances and throw all the other complexity away, because there will be no time looking up key sequences when you have to doge and grind the enemy.

There is also a manual lock-on system that has to be used to land more than a few hits. Fails in epic fashion when you get jumped by a group of enemies that start hammering you all at the same time. You have locked on enemy A, oh look enemy B is attacking you now. You have dodged and relocked  on B, oh look C is here. You are trying to concentrate on A and just doge the rest? Not happening because you are circling the locked enemy and cant maneuver in a normal fashion.

As an added bonus, there are high ledges (instant death on fall) and deep water (instant drowning) everywhere. Packed with enemies you have to doge. And no borders to prevent you from dodging from the ledge or into the water. Why? Because....

Honestly I see another game marked "dark souls like" i'm just throwing it into a ban-list instantly. Why waste time grinding arbitrary nonsense when there are far better things to do.

plays smoothly even on my potato-top, my only issue is enemy scaling and the way to do co-op, you have to constantly refresh it rather than be in a waiting lobby, other than that the game is almost perfect, great variety of weapons, armor and the likes, you can customize your character almost whenever you wan't, you can transmogrify any weapons and armor to ones you have acquired previously and the weapons include your projectile based ones as well, such as bows, rifles, and hand cannons. In my personal opinion, this game is harder than dark souls 3 in certain areas, such as certain bosses don't have a massive move-set, they all do disgusting amounts of damage, but once you find your groove, your load-out, and favorite weapon combo, the game is rewarding like none other, sure you'r the "main character" but its cool how you don't have "plot armor" in a sense, you constant effort to become better at the game, stronger, and smarter, means that you build the foundation of your plot armor through trial and error, skill building, and mental fortitude not to give up. here are some pros and cons that aren't very in depth but get to the point.
CONS 
~co-op issues and difficulties when not working properly
~occasional responsiveness issues such as when using items, or items showing the use animation and not being consumed
~occasional online stability can be wack but can smooth out, honestly isn't to bad as long as you have decent wifi
~the stun locks are real so don't get to aggressive lmao
~there is no open world but*
PROS
~there is plenty of exploration to be had in most missions, roughly 80% of the missions have some kind of exploration to be had*
~great smooth gameplay
~beautiful atmosphere and visuals (if your pc and or laptop isn't slow like mine, still pretty tho)
~dark and gloomy areas perfect for a souls-like
~great boss variety
~great enemy variety
~endless amounts of replay-ability due to the huge amounts of weapons and different play styles they give you
~ really everything else is great about the game, if your bad you can grind, but you definitely don't have to grind a lot like in the souls games, and once you get good enough the game becomes a boss rush game just like the souls games 

Bonus info: every weapon type has a skill tree to add combos and other benefits such as extra damage on certain skills obtained from the different weapon types. You play as a Yokai Shiftling (half human half demon) and in term you get Yokai abilities and a whole skill tree on your Yokai shiftling part. There are crazy amounts of enemies going from human to giant bosses, all the way to a weird turtle boi that wanna smack em cheeks. The stance system offers many different ways to play, high stance = damage and low mobility, mid stance = medium damage with decent mobility, and you guessed it, low stance = low damage but extreme mobility.

there is plenty more to be said about this game, but this is a rough gist of it all, if you wanna be some bada** samurai with a story that is amazing cover to cover, and a great challenge that makes success feel truly rewarding rather than playing a game on easy mode your whole life, then this is the game for you, worth every penny.

While I'm putting a thumbs up for this game and definitely remains in my favorites list on Steam, I cannot fully recommend this entry over the first. 

This game IS good, especially combat-wise, and does a lot of things better than the first, but it also does a lot extremely wrong. Having more options isn't always better, especially when the main problems are with the main STORY, overall BOSS design, and no longer 100%-ing skill trees which is contrary to the first game, in my opinion. 
Yes, the first game's story did suffer from bein' fairly disjointed at times, but comparing how this game continues along you'd think it had never read a finished sentence in its life. 
Also having extremely dull boss fights with yokai which made it a chore to push through, especially now that draining its stamina is the only real viable strategy on whether or not you're able to actually interrupt them and do any kind of damage or not. 
Lastly you can no longer 100% a weapon tree as it apparently favors decisive decision making over all else leading to only half of it being available when maxed out. This weird decision severely hinders experimentation, even though you are able to respec later on and have multiple versions of a character's skill list to choose from, which is not the optimal option.
 
I'm at least glad that character customization is fantastic and is definitely an extreme highlight with the 'Ninja Team flare', but I gotta be honest, you really can't do better than the chad, William Adams, from the first game.

Again, it's a good game, a GREAT one even, but I would recommend the first 10 outta 10 game to newcomers and if after finishing THAT one maybe get this 7 on 10 sequel whenever it's on sale.
