I was having fun most of the game but as you play more the game degrades more and more as it tries to ramp up its difficulty. You start off weak, getting 2-3 shot by enemies and taking a while to kill bosses in terms of damage. By the end of the game, with you all leveled and geared up, you are now getting one shot by the half-second instakill grab attacks from bosses, and your kill times have gotten significantly worse. (I was following a meta build, by the way. LOL!) Enemy stat inflation is way worse than Elden Ring for example. Games where leveling up is just to tread water, like Nioh, instead of getting stronger, like in most games with leveling, shouldn't have leveling in the first place.

The gameplay got repetitive around 60% through the game. There aren't enough moves for the weapon I chose (Katana), and a lot of the moves are either not good, or you can't use them because you need to use certain moves to break through enemy ki inflation. (For example, I was stuck using Kick the entire game because of the ridiculous ki system in the game meaning you can't damage enemies for more than chip damage until you break their ki bar, except they have a bigger ki bar than you, that regenerates faster than yours (which you need to deplete to drain theirs), and can attack with no ki (you can't). See the problem? Also unlocking different abilities is really not good, with arbitrary xp and mission gates that only make you grind longer, instead of anything meaningful like improving your skills through beating a challenging boss.

Every single level feels the same and the environments suck. Looter games where you get a billion different pieces of gear that all suck are very tiresome, too. Once you've played through the first level, you've played through the entire game, essentially.

The game would have been much better if the player character was able to do any amount of damage greater than chip level to most enemies, and/or not get 2 shot by every enemy the entire game following the appropriate level curve, and/or do anything close to the cheap stuff enemies do (the best I got for you is lightning talisman + sloth to make enemies pretty slow. woohoo...) Also either let the player demon counter all the bullshit moves (such as the ridiculous late game grab attacks, or various boss moves like the golden armor spear guy who hits you 100 times which will simultaneously deplete your ki and kill you in under a quarter of a second with no counter besides dodging in a very specific way which is not fun nor gives the player any gameplay choice.)

I thought the game had potential at the start, and don't want to play it again after finishing my first playthrough. It starts at 7 or 8/10 and ends at a solid 3/10. Destroying a game in terms of its design and gameplay for the sole sake of making it challenging (the game actively fucking you over just to waste your time through dying after a 10 minute long perfectly executed boss fight with a single mistake isn't fun or engaging, Team Ninja.) is a horrible thing to do.

What a waste of a potentially good game.

Sincerely,

This is a review of someone who is very passionate about video games, but not necessarily very good at them.
Let's get some things out of the way:
- I've only played New Game, not NG+(+++) or DLC, so my opinion is based on that.
- This game is "difficult" as the tags suggest, yes, mainly the first 3 or 4 levels, but the rest I felt like a curve going up and down. First boss took me 71 tries, but most bosses took me around 20-5 tries, some first try, and some just a couple.
- Concerning the "Souls-like", it is souls-like in regard of: 
*How levels work, you got your shrines (bonfire/lamp), if you die you wake up in the last shrine, enemies respawn (except mini bosses).
*You get "Amrita" from defeating enemies, and when you die you lose them, until you go back and touch your grave.
*Levels have shortcuts you can open.
That is how I feel having played Demon's Souls and BloodBorne previously.

Apart from that, it has a very different feel, with how combat works, equipment and items. People have likened it to Diablo, but I have personally not played that.
I think of this as Ninja Gaiden, but with stamina bar and less chaotic overall (it can get chaotic at some points), and lots of loot!

This is a martial art action game with many styles and weapons to master, you'll feel strong and you'll have many tricks up your sleeves as you progress. But yes the first 3 bosses especially kicked my butt lol

Character creation is really good with many options, and more you unlock later on. You can change your look anytime and save and load or upload your customization, and download other people's creations. One of the main points I decided to give this a try.

I also feel I have to mention, this game has a really good Photo Mode, it has both an in-game Photo Mode and Nvidia Ansel, if you're into virtual photography like myself, this is a great pick!

My two main gripes about this game are:
- Training Mode is limited to a few enemy types. I wished to practice against all enemies.
- Shrines/checkpoints being a bit far from boss encounters, it adds nothing to the challenge, just wasting time, as each time you die, you have to again run across a bridge or climb a few ladders and evade a few small enemies.
Just put the shrine next to the boss's door *shrug*

Really good game, worth being a sequel (or prequel?). Everything good in the first game they make it better in this one. This game starts off strong, with an interesting twist on the souls formula, which is great.
However, it squanders all this good will by simply being punishing for the sake of it.
Aside from the camera employing snap points, making the game overly clunky, you would be hard pressed to find an enemy in the game (no matter your level) that can't two shot you.
That's not necessarily a bad thing in general. On the other hand, many enemies have tough movesets to master. Moreover, this developer has a fetish for unavoidable ambushes and spam. I can't overstress how spammy this game is.
Combine absurd levels of spam with the complex movesets to grasp with the ridiculous damage and you just get the definition of artificial difficulty. Bloating stats and numbers doesn't really equate to mechanical difficulty/depth, and that's a shame because the game actually does have mechanical depth, which is already hard enough to master without the stupid design decisions i outlined.
Hard for hard's sake.

For all the character customization fanatics out there:  You create a character at the start of the game and you can update it in any way you see fit once you start the game, right off the bat in the tutorial you can change it.

The meat and bones of the game though are just an absolute masterpiece. Crisp, clean and responsive controls and combat that is also fast and fluid while still maintaining weight with each swing with each weapon. Many different styles and many different weapons means many different ways to play.

The combat on its own is easy enough to understand and the game can be played through with just the fundamental understandings of combat, but there is just absolutely thick and juicy meat in terms of depth of combat from parries to counters to iframes, it's all there.

Excellent visuals. Dark and dreary landscapes, war-torn lands and ravaged villages painted in dark, depressing and drab palette all juxtapose besides the colorful oni and visual effects that come with clashing with them.

The challenge, the Japanese mythology, they're all there if you're familiar with Nioh, but it is improved upon by bundles and bundles. An absolute masterpiece of a game that proves Team Ninja's development maturity dating all the way back to Ninja Gaiden. Excellent, excellent, excellent. This whole game is just on another level.

After taking 61 hours to beat the game, all i can say is yes you should buy Nioh 2. It's got all you could want from a looter type game, not making old items entirely useless, while making sure you're rewarded for investing into newer items, it's got super fun combat with a large skill try, different play styles for every weapon and Yoki form, fast, fun, and difficult combat with a boatload of bosses (~63 bosses from what I've seen), and a NG+ that still thinks about what the player would like to go back to. Say you beat a really really fun mid game boss, and in games like Dark Souls, you'd have to beat the game, and get to that point to fight them again (in no way a game breaker for the DS series, but sometimes you wish you could just fight the boss just *one* more time). In Nioh 2, old missions are still doable on the same save, even if you beat it. And if you think you'd be too strong for that mission, making it boring, you can opt to drop your level to enjoy the difficulty while not being *too* broken.

Overall I'm very happy with Nioh 2, its got a very unique identity in the "souls like" genre of games, and I think if you like games in that genre, you'll absolutely enjoy Nioh 2.

Arbitrary is the key word to this game.

The difficulty spikes in places that have no reason for it. Especially some bosses tend to punish mistakes hard, leaving you very little room between respawns to really get to learn them. This, after a hard level that, in the very least, was beaten methodically, to a satisfying degree. Thankfully the Nioh series has a hard-on for that DS1 interconnectivity, meaning that usually you're a sprint away from trying a boss again. Sadly, they still like to include a few enemies in your route. And sometimes, those enemies are frustrating and will nip at your health right before the boss gate. That never feels good, especially when the shortcut is obviously designed to put you in sprinting distance from the boss.

Some skills are blatantly better than others in their class, to the point that the enemies start punishing you for trying to use the bad ones, while all of them sound good in their description. You're quite punished for not finding the meta before you commit to a skill point, because you can only respec those points outside of a mission.

Some weapons downright get shafted unless you're a God-tier player who compensates for all their serious shortcomings. Axe and Odachi definitely feel like they need some help, as enemies only get faster as the game goes on, and slow weapons require actual foresight to land good hits.

The biggest difference with the DS series is how you face a challenge. In DS, you learn and observe the enemies, routes and tactics. In Nioh, you can start with that, but ultimately you'll need to rely on Cheese to make encounters less painful. Cheese and overleveling are the only solid, consistent answers to any problem, which cheapens every victory where you had to rely on them. Magic to slow down a boss to the point that their moveset is irrelevant, pluck at their health using DoT's whenever possible, heavily overpowered weapon skills that can easily dominate. There's not one answer for every problem, but rather an array of solutions to which a few can usually solve any problem. In short, personal skill is far less relevant than cheese. And if the only answer to a boss is cheese, then that boss is inherently designed poorly.

This could all have gone over better if the opponents were written better. Sadly, the story muddles along and those hard-won bosses have a history or monologueing where there's no satisfaction in victory. Either you're supposed to feel bad or you just don't care. No satisfying villain take-down that makes for a satisfying reward after a gruelling set of hours fighting them. Everyone's a victim, everything blows, and you're a mute with a one-tone reactionary personality who has guardian spirits talk, argue and bicker for them. Exhilerating.

Yet, in some sparse moments, this game feels good. From the aesthetic to the level design. Especially when trying to get through a level, every death feels earned. You slipped up, forgot or ignored this aspect of this grunt or common enemy, and pay the price. Respect every common enemy appropriately, and the level becomes a wash. Especially when trying out new skills against them. That, I can respect. Bosses don't play by this rule, as mentioned above, and rarely leave you satisfied. Only frustrated.

I leave you with the following to ponder on:
When a game is painful or punishing to play, there ought be a reward or quality to compensate for it.
Nioh 2 has these qualities, but not enough to compensate for the ramped up difficulty it boasts about.
The stick is there, but the carrot is measly and small.

If you're stubborn and have the skills to match, this game might be for you. Otherwise, prepare to be frustrated by choices you committed to and had no idea could be bad ones, and bosses that don't respect your time.

I wonder if afterall, instead of soulslikes, we shouldn't call tough exploration-based action adventure games Niohlikes. Dark Souls codified the genre and brought it to a more general public, perhaps. And Fromsoft's collective work is of the highest aesthetic brilliance, no doubt about it.

But Nioh boasts a more impressive lineage in the Ninja Gaiden games, Team Ninja pioneered many of the same mechanics long before Fromsoft did and the visuals and aesthetic of the Nioh series are at least equally brilliant. Not to mention that the combo and weapon systems allow for greater complexity and improved itemization allows for greater strategic depth.

Overall, highly recommended, especially if you liked the first game

[h1]A game that has surpassed the Souls formula [/h1]
[b]Nioh 2 delivers an insane amount of content in a single package with an excellent and addictive combat system. A clear 10/10 for me. [/b]

[b]Intro[/b]
Well, this game is so good that I just bought it again now on PC. I platinumed it on my base PS4 back in 2020, bought the DLCs and here I am again, playing it on PC with better graphics and resolution, and it was worth it every penny.
Nioh 2 delivers a state of the art combat system that is even better than the previous game, improving every single aspect and adding new Yokai skills and weapons. The gameplay is incredibly addicting, rewarding to those who explore and make full use of the skills while also punishing every single decision or input error heavily.

[b]Story[/b]
The story in Nioh takes place before the events of Nioh 1 and you get to play as a character that you can create. The character creator is very deep and has a lot of customization options.
One of the best parts of Nioh is that it references a lot of samurai and important people that really existed in the history of Japan and represents them quite accurately in it's story. Every single Yokai and spirits are actually creatures that appear in Japanese folklore. Even the name of the swords and a few armor are equipment that existed in the past.
The story itself is focused on the history of Hideyoshi and the spiritual stones. You will notice a lot of references from the previous game, including the parents of the characters that appeared in Nioh 1 or even a younger version of the same characters.

[b]Gameplay[/b]
The gameplay is the best part of the game. It's excellent combat is high risk and high reward. Nioh 2 is a game that knows how to punish a wrong move, but also rewards the player greatly when the correct decision is made. It's high risk and high reward.
Difficulty is perfect in my opinion. It's always perfectly leveled, always delivering the right amount of challenge while being very fair. I never felt the game is unfair. Every single time that I died, I knew it was because I made a mistake and there's a way to overcome the difficult part.
Equipment management, upgradability, leveling attributes, selecting spirits and soulcores... It has a lot of depth that can change the gameplay style quite dramatically depending on which build you're aiming at. The gameplay possibilities are endless. It's a game with a lot of replay value. The story itself takes around 50 hours to beat, depending on how good you're at the game, and the DLCs probably takes about 20 hours more.

[b]Graphics & Sound[/b]
The graphics are really good in this game with a detailed models and environments. It does not match most of the story focused AAA games' graphics, but it still looks absolutely beautiful, especially because of it's excellent and creative character and monster designs. The game was clearly designed with gameplay and 60fps in mind, so a small sacrifice in image quality was needed.
Sound in this game is excellent. Both the soundtrack and the sound effects. Everything is really epic and properly selected by the developers. The SFX when hitting enemies and doing a high damage attack is very satisfying and the soundtrack that plays during missions and the map are great.

[b]PC Port[/b]
The PC Port is really good. I can run this game with a RTX 2060S at 4K DLSS Quality, Maximum settings at 60fps comfortably without any dips. The game is super stable and runs incredibly well.
It has never crashed and I never encountered any bugs during my entire playthrough.
The graphics menu has quite a good number of options to customize. It's a good port, considering that it's a KT game.

[b]Conclusion[/b]
I consider Nioh 2 a perfect game. It has everything done right, from the excellent character creator, combat system, replay value, length to finish, graphics, soundtrack and PC port quality.
Nioh 2 is definitely one of my favorite games of all time. I think it's safe to say that it is the best game I have ever played.
Nioh 1 was already a game that I considered perfect, but Nioh 2 managed to make it even better.
The series is so good that I double dipped both games on PS4 and PC, bought all the DLCs, and finished them multiple times.
I can't wait to play Wo Long when it comes out.

Alright, it's largley like the first game. I'd heard that they'd "fixed" some stuff like item spam you constantly sort through and other like repetitive levels or maps... But no, they haven't really. Minor tweaks a few for the better but that's it. Overall it's still largley the same game with a few new additions that while interesting, don't solve the core issues.
Core issues are still I'd say controls, they are still somewhat functionally broken at times. Input queueing is mostly not a thing, but sometimes, after thourough testing, the cases it works are slightly inconsistent, not good. Learning to only provide inputs once animations finish is not too bad if animations are clear in when they finish, but plenty aren't. Swinging a blad, stopping, breathing a second or too in that idle post attack pose and only after two and a half breaths or so does the move consider as ending, sure you'll eventually learn that exact timing but it's frankly just a big pain in the ass. The game to put it lightley makes you work for everything, you want fun, work for it, you want to learn how to attack, work for it... ok. But you want to be able to do something as simple as dodge a predictable attack you know exactly when it's coming? Hot damn if you recently put in any other actions you better work for it, or rely on luck. You want to clear items out of your inventory? Better spend time working on that. Want to progress the game, you gotta work for it. Not enjoy it, grind it. A good souls game may have some leveling moments of grinding, but I can enjoy. This one...  Way to repetitive. Overall, harsh but fair is key for these and this one just doesn't seem fair.

Now that said, you can play in a way where you avoid mixing timings or uncertainties for the most part. Only for the most part. You'll still every so often even if just standing there with full stamina not having done anything else input dodge or an action and get nothing out of it for some reason (after just playing elden ring for 300+ hours I'd know if it was my controller, no it's not that). But these completely random ones are semi rare. So the key is to always do one attack, evade back. Control distance, wait for obvious opening... one attack...
But to put it simply that takes absolutely insane amounts of time. Play the entire game safe like that, and it'd probably be a 400 hours long game, complete slog. Most enemies have plenty of health, and or habits of blocking that if you don't stack on attacks to break stamina/ki will not do any lasting effect.
Now, the occasional failure or inconsistency in controls, issues learning exact timings, etc... might not be so bad if the game was more forgiving, but it's not. Most enemies can kill you in one or two hits unless you spend time power leveling befor reaching new areas. If you are in mid stand (stance to block) and blocking, most random enemies can break it in two or three hits. Some in basically one. When broken, or running out of ki in general, you become staggered, and can't do anything for a few seconds while also being vulnerable and taking bonus damage when hit it seems.
So if you try to block an enemy, you'll often just get staggered and die from them. If you attack you expend Ki. And if you get hit you lose ki. So if you ever do more than one or two attacks many enemies could if they hit you once clear out your remaining ki, leaving you open to kill you. So for this reason you can't play actively enough imo. To play safe, is to play insanely slowly. The controls, input queue or lack there of, and other issues (not to mention overly complex control scheme) just makes it a pain to actually try to play reliably without arguably hundreds of hours of play and familiarity with everything. Some enemies you learn you can stagger spam yourself letting you deal with them quickly, but any you can't become a gamble. You'll often make it through not being staggered and dying... but some times you will, and that means one seeming random failure on inputs or anything kills you and sends you back. That's not fun in a souls game. I love me DS1, DS3, Bloodborne, Sekiro, Elden Ring, Little Witch Nobbeta, Hollow Knight, and plenty others. Not new to the general formula of high risk high reward. But this game still doesn't have it ballanced.

On the other note, the control scheme is busy, very busy. Every button has two or more things it's responsible for. And no button ever only has one thing it will do when just pressed on it's own. There's always states something else can affect it to do instead. So especially early on you'll keep trying to hit a button to do X only for Y to happen instead. Since you're in the wrong stance have the wrong item bag up, or so on. Making it worse is, stance/bag,etc... 

It's a shame, I thought with the first one they had some really good core ideas and interesting setting, and it really had potential but they kept failing with key things like ballance, enemy design, repetitive enviornments/instanced levels, and the item and UI spam. And contrary to what I'd heard, the second game doesn't really seem to have fixed any of these. A few occasional improvements but only minor things, never large or core enough to solve the underlying issues. So the result it's a game I can play, but one I feel frusterated playing quite often, and even when not getting screwed by the controls or some questionably designed enemy encounters I'm just not honestly feeling like I enjoy it too much. I'll probably finish it like always unless it gets really bad, but my thoughts are I wont recommend it unless you've played all the others and don't have anything better to do with your time and can accept possibly wasting some money.
I'm sure this type of game is a better fit for some people, like those that prefer JRPGs with the instanced world levels and item spam they often have, for a JRPG it'd be decent imo... but for a souls game per se it's quite... lacking, though definintely still better than some of the other bad attempts out there.

EDIT after another 18 hours. Ya, enemies are more and more often insane damage sponges, taking quite awhile to wittle down and kill, often have attacks that can one shot you if you get hit by them. And love chaining random attacks together at random so a move that normally you think you could attack after they use it as an opening, might instead get chained into some other big attack that could kill you. Lots of these things that mean playing it safe takes absolue ages mixed with the crap tons of raw health the enemies have, all while easily killing you if you have a mistake, or failed inputs happening. And more and more I get the rage that I sum up as this. The camera controls my life, and the enemy controls my camera. Some enemies are just highly mobile, and in rooms that are really tiny with solid vertical walls so you're camera can get stuck at bag angles where you can't see really easily why you can't dodge or move (they also have the opacity thing where stuff close to the camera fades out so you can't see it). Ya, still feels like they were close in some areas, but just... failed on lots of details. The buggy inputs not being the least.

Edit: 60 hours in, and it's just worse. I'm done... can't take this shit anymore. First game I'm not playing fully through in years that I made it more than the first hour or two into.

The psuedo last boss, lore ish wise, broke tons of major rules. Large numbers of enemies in the same fight, that don't stagger their attacks or anything. Each one can launch a variety of attacks from across the map, or up close that deal very high damage. We're talking up to eight or so at once sometimes. Ranged attacks that you might get spammed with faster than you can dodge don't even all have clear audio queues so you know when to dodge when attacked by one of the many off screen. I beat him, got into bonus content... it's just not fun, it's painful. Not rewarding, just punishing and frusterating.

Nioh 2 is all about combat, and it's the best for 3rd person action, the developer coined the term masocore, why? 
Because the game is intend to be hard, so if you are not willing to spend some time to deep dive into the combat mechanic you won't have a good time here, but if you are willing to explore what the games provide you with, it's one of the most rewarding gaming experience ever.

Nioh is an amazing experience if a bit on the grindy side towards late game. Its drastically different from any soulslike I have played especially coming from elden ring which I finished 3 playthroughs of, but it isn't a massive evolution of the first game which was a new IP. 

The story is a fictional retelling of historical events with a spiritual spin on it.While people don't play this game for the story, whats there is bare bones, adequate and gets the job done. Other than Tokichiro , none of the chars are really fleshed out, events and storylines happen out of sequence and its kinda hard to follow who is who. But I digress. 

The real meat and potatoes is the combat here, which is stunning once you master all the mechanics. Its built in such a way to counteract the souls way of dodge roll spam and baiting moves out of enemies. Instead it favours aggression, blocking and ability/skill spam which makes the combat feel more engaging and visceral. Add in the sheer number of weapon types, and active skills you can augment, omniyo/ninjutsu talismans and scrolls, you just have so many options to go for and master. 

That being said the mechanics can be a bit daunting for a newbie as they have to manage stance switching, Ki pulsing(regen of stamina), the anima bar and so much more stuff like yokai abilities/burst counters. But once you get a hang of it, it just clicks. They even generalised the use of Yokai weapons(effective against humans) and purity weapons(effective against yokai and gives ki on blocking), to make for smooth sailing in the early game. 

Bosses are kinda hit and miss. The early game has some really challenging fights like yatsu-no-kami and enenra, the late game kinda peels of with bosses who are thematically very good,but offer very little challenge. Especially the humanold bosses fall flat once you abuse the ki system and drain them of their stamina.  You will also fight various versions of these bosses in gauntlet style modes later on multiple times anyway, so I guess familiarity helps. 

Now we come to the RPG mechanics and loot-game. Nioh 2 has a diablo-esque /PoE style lootgame attached to it. Your first playthrough wont be really affected by this much but there are some OP builds like the ninja builds/Iai stance builds which kinda trivialise the game when its at its most challenging. The game really starts once you get into NG+ and get access to divine gear. From here on out the game becomes a looter where you try to min-max to a T, trying to get the right modifiers to suit your play style. However, you will need the help of other players via revenant trading from the nioh 2 discord, very helpful community btw. The worst part is you have to repeat this process for ethereal gear when you unlock the two hardest difficulties. Late-game enemies and bosses have inflated health bars, which you will need really optimised gear to even scratch them especially in co-op. Then you have the underworld, scrolls and so much more grinding to reach your most optimal build. 

Here is wherein the problem lies, the only builds viable late game are grapple builds and/or builds which stack debuffs and rely on percent modifiers.  That kinda shoehorns you into a specific playstyle, where early-mid-late game was mostly about mastering your weapon with active skills and stances. Set bonuses scale terribly late game and percent modifiers take a long time to grind out. 

All-in-all despite my few gripes this is an amazing game. I hope Team Ninja stays away from the pitfalls of loot/skewed RPG progression and stick to designing mechanical combat systems players can flesh out with gear and stat spreads not based on RNG.

As of reviewing this, I only have a base hour of 42 in total for Nioh 2, whilst having more hours from playing Nioh 1 before Nioh 2. This review is solely based on my personal views on the game and is not influenced by anyone or anything else, nor a paid advertisement.

[h1] My review of Nioh 2 [/h1]

[b]Gameplay:[/b] 8/10
It felt like Playing Nioh 1, but with more improvements to the original systems in place for combat and abilities. A lot of problems with the keybinding made the experience pretty bad from the get-go and having to manually tweak them again was a long painful road. It feels wacky still, but I'm managing with what I have and I hope I'll get back into how I experienced the gameplay in Nioh 1.
[hr][/hr]

[b]Weapons:[/b] 9/10
It got more weapon additions than it had in Nioh 1, and it has actual Melee weapons now (aka fists). Sadly, as a weeb, the way it works instantly made me feel in love, as it feels nostalgic whenever I combo with it. I have not got the chance to try out the others, but I hear a lot of late-game builds run Rage and Axe combo, which seems a bit OP. But, right now I am just loving how much KI management you'll need to have to use the Fists and not instantly die.
[hr][/hr]

[b]Menu + In-game UI:[/b] 8/10
Not much has changed, it is still the plain old map and quest interaction as ever. UI has to some extent changed, but at least for the better. It is better and more straightforward now. Having to look for an option is easier in this game than it was in Nioh 1.
[hr][/hr]

[b]Skill tree:[/b] 10/10
For once they managed to make something that fits perfectly with the game. It looks a bit messy to start with, but in comparison to its predecessor, this version of the game has nailed it. Though it still feels new to me what invokes to get a specific skill in said tree.
[hr][/hr]

[b]New Weapon Elements:[/b] 8/10
The new addition of Purity and Corruption elements that will invoke this element after building it up is amazing and it also fits the theme, Purity for Yokai and Corruption for Humans. Whilst most of the story is probably more the player fighting against Yokai, Corruption is still viable, though probably mostly useless depending on what build you need it for. But compared to Nioh 1, where this was not available I find it a great addition to the game, it allows more Elements to be applied and also at random... Which the ladder I'm not too fond of tbf.
[hr][/hr]

[b]Yokai Ability / Anima:[/b] 10/10
Unlike Nioh 1 where this was not even remotely a thing nor mentioned, I do find it confusing why having such a feature before Nioh 1's story was even possible to implement into the game. But, the reality isn't always needed, as this feature still hits home with what it does, having Humans/Yokai drop Soul Cores was a good addition and Soul Fusing? Man, another reason to spend years grinding again is to get the right traits and create the most epic build. It's an intriguing feature and a genius idea.
[hr][/hr]

[b]Yokai/Dark Realm + No instant restart on death:[/b] 10/10
Having played Nioh 1, knowing how hard some Enemies were, having an additional Realm on top of that which by no surprise disrupts the KI flow... Why am I not surprised that these evil developers want us to suffer so? At the very least, it allows us to regain some bar when playing CO-OP online, which was not a thing in Nioh 1. Furthermore, on the ladder of the title, you no longer restart the instant your CO-OP partner dies, which is a huge improvement, as it can sometimes be hard to carry your friend or be carried, and just it all ends because the boss just wanted to see your friend/yourself dead no matter what and let you go back to the title screen. Honestly, it's a blessing that these evil developers aren't that evil, still not gonna forgive them for all the hours spent dying and restarting entire maps because of a bad teammate or myself dying over and over to some trash lowlife Yokai scum.
[hr][/hr]

[b]My overall game score:[/b] 9/10
It doesn't feel worse than Nioh 1,  but rather the opposite. It took everything that Nioh 1 did wrong, improved, made it even more confusing, but still has a static storyline where only difficulty and monsters change and item drops rarity. Sadly, it feels like Nioh 1 gameplay-wise, except for the new weapons, abilities, and items added though and that Story is so short you can speedrun it within half a day if you are tryharding it or skip every enemy. But regardless, my friend made me fall in love with this game, so I might as well stick to continue playing it, despite my lack of being good at these sorts of games.

I just wish it got over the finish line compared to the gameplay of the 'souls' genre. I'll explain below.

- Loot to die for, lots of slots and rarities / sets
- Endless builds
- Endless playstyles
- Great grind / replayability
- IMMENSE amount of content

Game just rocks. It's hard at first, but one you rhythm it becomes one of those games that you look back on your first few hours in it with fondness - you *enjoy* that it was difficult to get into, because it's so satisfying when you get good. 

A few important mechanics that you can miss, I'd recommend YT tutorials like from FightinCowboy. 

The downside on Nioh:

My only gripe is the artificial difficulty that is constant throughout every level/playthrough. This is a minor point, but you recover slightly slower than the enemy, even when you've snuck up on them or dropped onto them. A few deaths are because of this, especially on higher difficulties. You drop onto the enemy, they recover really quick and 1 shot drains your ki (stamina)(because you've partially spent it attacking) and then another shot kills you while you're winded.

I feel like if there is ever going to be a Nioh 3 there just needs to be a slight tightening up on artificial difficulty like this. This game, whether it is *actually* in the souls genre or not, it IS a competitor. 

By artificial difficulty I mean:

- Inflating healthbars to ridiculous proportion
- Enemies tracking input (I KNOW it tracks when you use yokai abilities and they KNOW you're out of anima to burst counter)(tracking input is also in use when you sneak attack an enemy and go to hold block to use a L1 + x move, and the enemy immediately has set up a grapple attack (grey cloud)).
- As stated above with the recovery is too fast compared to the players in some instances, makes it so people rather just barge in there and go ham instead of utilise other methods like sneak, drop, and shoot.
- There isn't a great diversity of enemies, truly even with DLC included. 'Cursed' enemies are a cool mechanic but honestly there isn't enough types of mobs. LOTS of long-neck yokai dudes, LOTS of gaki, enki everywhere and then in the DLC just more reskinned enki. "oh we should make the human warriors more difficult here? No sweat, put in a long-neck yokai dude." Some levels feel nice but it's a lot of the same (the lure is definitely the loot and getting to the point where you just stomp bosses).

I would want Nioh 3 to be a huge blockbuster. Adding a bit more variety in all, including more story *in-level* (no one gives a fuck about your pre-mission blurbs and the no-context cutscenes bro sorry), and streamlining difficulty so that it scales while FEELING FAIR would be amazing.

[h1]TL;DR[/h1]
[list]
[*]Three player co-op, main story and most side missions can be played with other players
[*]Custom character creation (male or female)
[*]Challenging but rewarding combat
[*]Good music overall, sound effects are spot on
[*]Story is a fantasy retelling of real events in 16th century Japan
[*]Recommend playing with controller[/list]

[h1]General Overview[/h1]

Take two scoops of Devil May Cry, a scoop of Ninja Gaiden, and a handful of Dark Souls and blend it up.  You'll get something close to, but not quite like, a Nioh 2 smoothie.  If, like me, you're coming from other souls-like games into Nioh you'll learn quickly the combat is faster but fluid.  Unlike Dark Souls / Elden Ring or other games like them there is less emphasis on dodging - in fact, dodging is often not your best option.  Instead there is a focus on carefully timed blocking and counter attacking.  Fights against strong enemies and bosses are only partly solved by learning the pattern and when you can punish them.  You also need to see what you can interrupt to create your own openings for flowing combo and chain attacks.

[h1]Good[/h1]

Three player co-op - easy to setup and jump straight into missions without any weird systems restricting your play.  Some duel side missions are solo only but the main story and most side missions can be played with up to two other players.
Graphics are solid, although some environments can feel overly busy.  The character creator is superb and you can create a male or female character, which should be standard by now, but is welcome here.  You will have a hard time making a character who isn't handsome / pretty, as Team Ninja is behind this one.  The cut-scenes are in-engine so your custom character and the gear you have on are reflected in the cut-scenes which is awesome.  The armor and weapon designs range from realistic to leaning deep into fantasy.  All are well modeled with beautiful textures.
Music is great, some of the tracks are so epic they'll keep your blood pumping fast as you feel the pressure to move, attack, counter, and destroy.  Sound effects have plenty of clanging metal, weapon into armor crunch, and solid hit effects.
Controls are tight and belie their fighting-game roots at times.  Learning the ki pulse, stance switching, and counter system - with slight variations for each weapon type - will take time but is incredibly rewarding once you get into the groove.  Speaking of weapon types, there is a nice variety of weapons on offer for different play styles.  As you unlock the ability and skill tree for each one they develop their own character and feel.  Once the trees are about half unlocked or more the weapons will feel very different.
The story takes place in 16th century Japan with some hefty liberties taken with real events to fit in the fantasy elements and your character's role in the alternate history presented.  Keeping track of all the characters can be difficult but fortunately there is a character guide in-game you can consult to keep up with the story as it plays out.
The game can be modded.

[h1]Neutral[/h1]

The game is difficult and makes no apologies for it.  Some of the duel side-missions are harder than anything the main story will throw at you but the main missions are no slouch, either.  The flip side of the difficulty is the satisfaction you will get as your skills improve and you conquer a challenging enemy or boss.  Be warned, however, the difficulty is no joke and there is no easy option.  The game plays best on a controller, keyboard and mouse not so much.

[h1]Bad[/h1]

This is a well polished game and most of "the bad" would resolve to nit picks.  With that said, the game wastes no time throwing complex systems at you with barely a tutorial.  It took me some time to wrap my head around the controls as this game will utilize every button on a controller and then some.  The twilight missions use a red filter / lighting system that hides the beauty of the levels they take place in.  I wish you could tone down the effect as they are SO RED.  Some of the music is short repeating loops that can grate after awhile, even though for the most part the music is great.  The aforementioned twilight missions are also the only content that gets level synced, so if you are teaming up with a low level friend on a high level character you will eliminate a huge chunk of the challenge for them and stomp the lower level missions.  With all of the special effects in combat your screen can get cluttered in flashes, sparkles, hit indicators, and more at times.  There are mods to tone this down but the default game can be overwhelming visually at times.

[h1]Conclusion[/h1] 

Nioh 2 is a solid game.  Expertly designed combat takes some getting used to but is very satisfying once you begin to learn and eventually master it.  Three player co-op with custom characters is fantastic.  Even at full price this game is a worthwhile purchase but it sometimes goes on sale and I enthusiastically recommend snagging it at a good price.

Nioh 2 is an action game first and foremost, a prequel to Nioh 1. It is also a spiritual successor to Ninja Gaiden.
I easily can call it my favourite game of all times due to many reasons.

+ Complex, fast paced combat system. There are 11 weapons with unique movesets which are also customisable. You can assign moves to different stances, put arcanas on them that add different properties and such. Also, every weapon has unique mechanic. For example, Splitstaff allows you to extend combos, dealing more hits per attack at a greater range.

+ Customisation. You can customise everything. Your weapon moves, your appearance, your build, your special effects. There is so much variety. Also, character creation is super good.

+ Loot. There is a lot of it. And it's useful. You can mix and match item sets, you get starred effects, which only can be randomly found on gear at higher difficulties, you can get divine and ethereal graces which have unique effects. And if you don't want an item, you can break it down for parts for crafting, so nothing goes to waste.

+ Yokai abilities. You can collect soul cores and use abilities of your enemies against them. They are super fun and most of them look awesome. Kasha, Ryomen Sukuna, Oni-bi - these are some of my favourite.

+ Endgame underworld arena, twilight missions and demon parade scrolls. There are 3 endgame activities that you can do, each of them is full of challenging enemies.

+ Coop. This is always a plus in my book. You can play with 2 of your friends or just random guys and experience some real mayhem.

+ Visuals and aesthetics. Game is aesthetically consistent and beautiful. Armour, weapons, monsters, levels - everything is just amazing. Artists really outdid themselves this time around.

+ Enemy variety. Amount of enemies you have to fight is also great. They easily doubled the amount of foes you meet compared to Nioh 1.

+ Soundtrack is superb.

Nioh2 is good, fast paced and gorgeous. Character creator is one for the books and the bosses are unique and lively. One thing I do not see much, when it comes to praise, is the music. The OST has got to be one of my favorites. Helping to convey every type mood just right in a lot of cases. Is it Witcher3? Not to be rude, but no. But still, for me, it is up there. Level design is fun and some even come with my favorite... shortcuts! I always appreciate them and stumbling upon one when needed instantly brings a rush if done proper (I'm not hard to please). 

However, I think criticism is good. 
1. Parrying. I'm not the biggest fan when multiple weapon types have multiple button prompts for the same result. Using my controller as an example. On one weapon, parry is RB+X. On another weapon, RB+Y...... Why? This will only bring confusion. Although I hate to assume (starts with ass for a reason), characters can have up to two melee weapons at once. So the percentage is high someone ends up mixing the parry between the two. Especially if you're like me. I try and play with EVERYTHING (Except the hatchets and short swords. Too weak, imo) and in this type of game, that truly is life or death sometimes. If it were up to me, I would consolidate the prompts. Matching them the best you can. With the way it is, I feel this layers for the sake of being "layers". 

2. Reusing locations. When it comes to side missions, each region has them. My issue is some side missions take place at a location one, maybe even two regions ago. While the story takes place across Japan. So either your character travels ALL the way back to these locals, or people hired the same temple designer and no one has caught on yet. All jokes aside, from repetitiveness to illogical it becomes a little tiresome to fight in the same forest / temple time and time again. This is not to say all side missions take place in the same two locations. Sometimes they too get a new local. But to drive my point home, I am currently in the third region but I am doing a side mission at a location in the first region. Just saying. It would be nice if they were unique as the main missions are. I know it would be a lot of work, but it could go a long way for the player traveling through it. 

3. Crafting. I do not mind it. The game is based around RNG (at least I think it is) when it comes to picking up weapons off the floor. Crafting is a way to circumvent your weapons becoming stale. Or at least it should. So far in 55hrs, crafting hasn't helped. I tried crafting a few times but it wasn't even close to what I wanted / looking for. Especially when it comes to the attributes. Bare bones compared to what you find in the missions. Nowhere near a deal breaker but I find it funny it is here. Maybe an end game thing? Time will tell. But for now, I just do not see it being useful. This is not to say the blacksmith isn't useful overall. She does a load of other things you will use throughout your journey. Though, most likely crafting isn't one of them. 

4. Speechless! Main character is custom and in this case, that means not a peep outta them. No matter what happens, nothing. I am just not a fan of this approach. I get why devs do it, it isn't cheap getting multiple people do the same lines. Especially if there is multiple male / female voices to choose from. Hopefully, if there is a Nioh3, they can have at least one male / female voice actor for your character. Like the unique missions, it goes a long way imo. Keep in mind, most of the time it comes down to world ending stuff! Meanwhile your character is just standing there.... staring... confused? No. Determined! Hungry? Or maybe they just have to let out a far... I don't know! Because they don't say.

5. What am I covered in?? There is multiple types of counters in Nioh2. I can appreciate them all honestly. Granted maybe one can be removed. Burst Counter. A special type of counter for special enemy attacks. I was OK with this until I started to notice some cases, if you're character isn't not lined up just right, you will slide to the enemy left, or right. Not only missing, but taking damage too. It can be infuriating honestly. Especially when you realize how hard these attacks hit. Either give some leeway, or remove imo. Also, word of advice, if you do slide to the right or left, don't chase the enemy down, spamming Burst Counter. Just let it go.. Trust me.  

As you can see, there isn't much wrong with Nioh2 in my eyes. Which is funny because I played at release and stopped while in the second region. I was playing the forest level for the 2nd, or 3rd time. Became bored honestly. Glad I played Mortal Shell, got me in the mood again for more Souls-Like and here I am. It is a fun, fast paced melee game. I usually rate Souls-like with a great for beginners, intermediate or give me SoulsBorne level. Nioh2 is defiantly intermediate. You may want Lords of the Fallen, Surge1, Code Vein or Ashen under your belt before jumping in. This one comes at you fast! Give it a go!

Nioh 2 starts out excellent but gets worse and worse with every NG+ cycle as enemies turn more and more into giant damage sponges with excessively damaging attacks. That wouldn't necessarily be bad in and of itself, but it exacerbates other problems; these are so numerous that I've decided to list them:

- Bad hitboxes on both your and enemy attacks and especially on counters. This of course heavily favors the AI, since it only needs to get lucky once. This also includes attacks sometimes harmlessly passing through their target, enemy attacks sometimes doing two ticks of damage rather than just one, countered attacks dealing damage anyway, lingering hitboxes still dealing damage even when the enemy that produced them is already dead, etc.
- Tracking issues. Tracking is generally very sluggish for both you and enemies, with both your character and an enemy wildly flailing in the wrong directions at the same time being a common sight, but enemies sometimes track perfectly with no warning. Like the previous point, this is also a much bigger problem for the fragile, lonesome you than for the tanky and numerous enemies.
- There is a bug where your stamina starts regenerating after being reduced to zero due to an enemy hit, then after a second gets reduced to zero again, this time for no apparent reason. This delays your recovery considerably and often leads to death.
- No friendly fire among enemies. Ranged enemies will happily shoot you through their buddies, a fact the developers shamelessly exploit in abusive encounter design throughout the entire game.
- Multiple bosses in the same fight. N2 has evidently not learned the lessons of N1 and repeats the same mistake of putting multiple bosses designed to be fought individually into the same fight, which is especially bad in combination with the preceding point, as these bosses can and do attack through each other with wide, sweeping attacks that become impossible to avoid when coming in at twice the normal frequency.
- Blatantly cheating enemy NPCs with ridiculous stats, including being able to cancel animations in ways that the player can't, being able attack faster and farther than the player, having faster projectiles, using better versions of spells than the player gets (e.g. their spell projectiles are homing, yours are not), and being able to sprint faster and without using up stamina.
- Hyperarmor, which means the enemy becomes immune to stagger during their attack. This is a bad gameplay mechanic in general, since it means you can start an attack against a vulnerable enemy that would stagger them, except they decide to launch an attack of their own before yours lands, don't get staggered as a result, and hit you despite being hit first. Giving the AI the ability to retroactively make what was a safe opening for attack into a deathtrap once the player has committed is poor design in any game, doubly so in one as unforgiving as this.
- Input-reading enemies. Since the computer has instant reaction time, the fact that some enemies can dodge means that your attacks effectively have an X% chance of doing nothing other than making you vulnerable, and there's not a damn thing you can do about it. Some enemies abuse this to a monstrously excessive degree, obviously designed to be obnoxious rather than challenging.
- Camera issues. Given the quick pace of combat and constant movement, the camera freaking out is a frustratingly common occurrence, especially near walls. This is exacerbated by enemies that are able to break lock-on, forcing you to try to wrangle the camera in their vague direction and reestablish lock-on, and by enemies who attack by zooming across the room at warp speed in erratic patterns, forcing you to either break lock-on yourself or do your best not to puke as the camera sways around wildly. This issue is also exploited in abusive encounter design, e.g. placing a boss that is able to push you around into a tight arena so that you get pushed into a wall and die because you can't see what's going on, levels with narrow ledges along cliff faces so that you literally cannot avoid being near a wall, etc.
- Enemy projectiles can pass through some solid objects. Unless you memorize the entire game through trial and error, you will sometimes get hit when you absolutely shouldn't, since what looks like perfectly good cover might well not be.
- Enemies get invincibility during their grapple attacks but you don't during (most of) yours. Some even get invincibility during some of their longer wind-ups.
- Mix-ups, where enemies pretend to have ended their combo only to resume attacking and get you when you try to punish. This wouldn't be too bad if it was used sparingly and consistently, but some enemies can do it several times during a single combo, or they might decide not to, it's random, and you can never tell whether an opening is real or a trap. These unlearnable attack patterns are especially bad in combination with:
- Unreactable attacks. Sometimes there's absolutely nothing you can do to avoid being hit, especially by grabs, since for some the hitbox is active from the moment their telegraph animation starts (rather than from the moment the telegraph ends and the attack itself begins).
- Enemies can shoot straight up and down, whereas you are limited to about 45 degrees. This means that in some situations, enemies are free to shoot you, but you have no way to retaliate.
- Anti-player bias. With a handful of exceptions, enemies who should be hostile to each other team up against the player for no apparent reason (e.g. demons and demon hunters).

These issues start out minor, but the longer you play, the more they come to the forefront of the experience. They're no big deal when 99 of your deaths result from your own mistakes and only 1 from one of these issues; when the ratio is reversed, they suddenly seem far more serious. As you progress through the game and improve your skill, you get to a point where your deaths almost exclusively result from these issues, and that is the point where the game ceases to be fair and therefore fun. Can you learn to play around them? Absolutely. Should you have to? Absolutely not. The fact that these issues can be worked around does not negate the fact that they are issues.

As a general principle, the less forgiving a game's difficulty is, the more solid its gameplay mechanics need to be, and Nioh 2's gameplay mechanics unfortunately do not adequately support the level of difficulty the game eventually builds up to. As a result, players who stick it out until endgame almost invariably go for stamina-depleting builds so that they can stunlock bosses and don't have to deal with any of their attacks (as shown in numerous, easily googled videos).

To sum up, Nioh 2 unfortunately spends far too much effort on flashy and self-indulgent window dressing and far too little on gameplay fundamentals. The game's alright for a casual playthrough, I guess, but I can't in good conscience recommend it for the kind of serious commitment that its numerous NG+ cycles and randomized endgame zones seem to expect.

Positives

Small Brain - "This game is Soulslike cause it has dodges"

HUGE Brain - "This game is Soulslike because it has fair challenges, multiple playstyles and you get to create your own character."

NIOH 2 is the latter.

If you enjoy Souls games, there is a good chance you will enjoy this; basically Sekiro before Sekiro (and in my opinion, I would prefer this to Sekiro). Otherwise, if you enjoy difficult games, you will love this.

Some things to note for those who haven't played the first one:
Character Customizer, 3-mode combat called stances, Massive perk tree akin to older RPGs (each weapon is a branch, as well as Onmyo Magic and Ninjutsu Arts), mechanic driven combat, Boss fights that'll take your teeth out, TONS of content

To keep it brief-ish, this game is easily in my top 10. These titles play akin to a souls game, and so I was able to pick up NIOH 1 pretty quick, and had a lot of fun with that. NIOH 2 then adjusted the dial, giving us the character creator and a new Oni form that allows you to also use enemy abilities in a sort of "collect the soul - use it's signature attack" method. Some new weapon types also pop-up here like the Switchglaive, making for a super diverse path for you to take on your way through missions, as your Oni form also comes in 3 flavors of offensive capability (very, moderately, and defensive); which can also be paired with any of the enemy attack souls (but there is benefit for understanding what to mix and match).

Combat is also very risk vs reward, and more-so than in Souls titles imo. When you run out of stamina and get hit, you probably are dying if you didn't already, as you get the wind knocked out of you. Simultaneously, enemies flinch less, but when you break their stamina, you can slap them like you just guest starred in the three stooges. Otherwise, you unlock combos as you fight and slowly work up into just comboing bosses out until you eventually see a notice pop-up and you just perfected one.

Lastly, this game does not demand you learn too much about the elements and mixing and matching status ailments/buffs, but without them you will slowly stagnate at a point and hit one hell of a wall. Bosses are not just the Souls style "Remember the moves", but they are meaty beasts that come in many flavors, both man and demon. One boss may just be some NPC guy where you need to fight more passively using one element for added damage, but then the next one may be fire personified and you need to leverage the arena to get him weaker, to then just going mano-a-mano with your friendly neighborhood Toad-demon.

[h1] A mechanically brilliant game that deserves far more recognition than it has.[/h1] 

Despite looking graphically and technically similar to its predecessor, Nioh 2 masterfully improves the formula all-round, delivering on its promise. The game‚Äôs plot is a prequel to the previous title, so you don‚Äôt have to play it first to experience this gem. The storyline and lore focus on Japanese historical events mixed with folklore. 

[b]Nioh 2 is not a FromSoftware clone[/b], both do share many similarities, the review will be focusing on what distinguishes them and Nioh 2‚Äôs catch-all mechanics.

[h1] A page is taken out of:[/h1] 
‚Üí [b]Diablo‚Äôs[/b] focus on loot, colour-coded gear, variables, stats, and build variety.
‚Üí [b]Monster Hunter‚Äôs[/b] focus on combat, crafting, characters, and re-playability.
‚Üí [b]Dark Soul‚Äôs[/b] mechanics such as bonfires, bloodstains, consumable items, stamina management, exploration, ecstatic clashes, and various other intricacies.

[h1] Mechanically the best Soulsborne ever made:[/h1] 
Using Dark Souls syntax I‚Äôll focus on why Nioh 2 goes beyond adding reason and purpose to many established souls like mechanics.

[b]A nexus-styled map:[/b] Akin to what you‚Äôd see in Demon Souls where you choose where to go next. Although maps are isolated areas, each is masterfully crafted and can take an hour or longer depending on your skill. They are graced with well-thought-out shortcuts that loop back and forth to your bonfires. This model allows them to fine-tune main and side quests with different changes when you revisit each area, even adding unique missions such as a boss rush.

[b]Invisible walls and others:[/b] Not invisible in Nioh, they are alive and they can pack a pack-a-punch if you annoy them, luckily they can be friendly if you pose for them with the right gesture, the same applies to mimics that can be cooperative or fiendish.

[b]Bloodstains:[/b] No longer just a time capsule or snippet of some unlucky fellow‚Äôs darkest hour, you can interact with them and summon an AI version of a player, fight and loot them. On the other side of the spectrum, there are benevolent graves to aid you when you need them most.

[b]Bonfires:[/b] Provide the same type of solace and vast array of mechanics like leveling, and attuning magic, they also grant you with a few other options like being able to donate loot in exchange for rice, a currency that only allows you to buy local items and fine-tune the difficulty of an area with increasing the amount of healing items (They have a hard cap).

[b]Leveling:[/b] Works the same as in Dark Souls or Elden Ring, except for basic skills and each weapon type has its sphere grid tree with multiple skills you can choose from and bind to different keystrokes to further enhance your build. The game has various other options like fame, a tea house, and more to further tweak and optimise everything about your character.

[b]Proper NG+ content:[/b] Rewards you with each subsequent play-through, vastly changing the way the game plays. Like the addition of new enemies, gear tiers, stats, and even a brand new game mode.

[b]Stamina:[/b] Isn‚Äôt just a simple stat, it‚Äôs Nioh‚Äôs bloodline, far more important than it ever has been in most games, it works half similarly to Dark Souls, except in the way you recover it, you regain it far faster if you time your ‚ÄúKi pulses‚Äù, rewarding players with mechanical expertise. 

[b]‚ÄúYokai realms‚Äù:[/b] Tie to stamina as these dimensions halve how fast you regen it until you find the host and kill them. But like all in Nioh for every disadvantage, there‚Äôs a counter, ‚ÄúYokai realms‚Äù which provide you with stronger ‚ÄúAnima‚Äù skills (Magic).

[b]Parrying:[/b] Has a yin and yang effect, providing an exceptional counter to enemies and bosses, when they try to land a critical strike on you, you have three ways you can parry, depending on the guardian spirit you equip.

[b]Guardian spirits:[/b] Provide passive bonuses and stats that enhance your skills whilst also providing you with a mechanism that you can use once energised as a special mode where you‚Äôll deal way more damage for a brief period. When you die you have to collect your guardian spirit to recover your souls or recall it and lose everything being able to use ‚ÄúYokai skills‚Äù once more.

[b]Soul cores:[/b] Are tied to guardian spirits, you can mimic attacks or buffs from all enemies and bosses in the game and use them like you‚Äôd use magic, with its mana pool called ‚ÄúAnima‚Äù.

[b]Other types of magic:[/b] Provided are omnyo magic and ninjutsu skills, which are not tied to any mana and instead are a consumable item you use and that replenishes once you rest at a bonfire, allowing you to enhance your stealth abilities, damage enemies with different ailments, buff or debuff them to your heart‚Äôs desire.

[b]Gear wise:[/b] The game is a tinkerer's dream, with so many tangible stats, set bonuses, and different synergies for the ultimate build. You attain them by finding decent loot or crafting and mixing items until you get the desired outcome. Familiarity comes to play too as it helps with inheriting stats between gear and increasing your defence or damage output with some spells centred around it.

[b]S tier musical album:[/b] Displaying very high quality all around.

[b]Controls:[/b] Ingeniously assigned and work well in tandem with the myriad amount of options the game provides.

The achilles heel of Nioh 2 is the GUI‚Äôs clutter and the lack of PVP.  It does support co-op though.

[h1] Describing the combat:[/h1] 
What makes this gem glimmer, putting every other souls-like/borne to shame. You have three stances, low, med, and high, see them as your light and heavy attack, except that each one of them has its strengths, weaknesses, their attacks, and skills that you can combo with.

The game encourages you to experiment and play with more than a single weapon type and to use two types of ranged weapons as they are viable and very useful in dealing with enemies. 

You can‚Äôt wield a shield so you‚Äôll be sidestepping, rolling, and evading in a game that has some of the best hit-boxes ever conceived, there‚Äôs stealth incorporated as well, with your usual suspects such as backstabs. 

[h1] Miscellaneous:[/h1] 
‚Üí [b]Item descriptions exist[/b]
‚Üí [b]Stat numbers can be disabled[/b]
‚Üí [b]You can‚Äôt jump[/b]
‚Üí [b]Cursed weapons that can talk to you.[/b]
‚Üí [b]Items you find on dead bodies carry memories with them.[/b]

[h1] Conclusion:[/h1] 
Nioh 2 is a hell of a gem, deserving every bit of love and attention, a game that keeps on giving amazingly crafted all round and that you can come back any time after a long while and be addicted again, if you enjoy it you‚Äôll be indulged with one of the most satisfying combat systems ever made.

I had been wanting to play Elden Ring co-op, but you basically can't. You get constantly invaded in that game, you get locked out of doing co-op if you've already beaten the boss of an area. Nioh 2 is exactly the opposite, the co-op experience is amazing. You never get involved in PVP and you are encouraged to finish the level and then help others do the same, or you can play a mode called Expeditions where you and someone else do a level together for the first time and both get credit towards completing in single player if you win. The only drawback is that in Expeditions they double the health of the enemies and you can't collect your lost "souls" if you die. So, it's actually a better experience I've found to just have one person beat a level and then they can join you and help you through it. 
Besides co-op the game is tricky to learn the mechanics. It is more complex by far than a Dark Souls game. The Ki Pulse, Flux and Burst Counter are very important mechanics to doing well and they are not explained all that well in the tutorial and are hard to master. I recommend watching some Youtube videos on how to play before diving in so that you get to know these mechanics early on so they become natural. Also, the control scheme is very different from Dark Souls games so I had to reconfigure it a lot as my muscle memory was getting very confused. I mostly figured out a good balance except you can't configure dodge to B it will always be A. I can live with that. I'm just happy to be able to play a souls like game with friends without worrying about being killed in PVP constantly.

If your here for the gameplay then its just as solid, if not BETTER than Nioh 1.  New weapons and a fleshed out skill tree mean theres a playstyle for almost anyone out there, and if your that dedicated you can do some wacky shit like mid stance parry over an enemy while slicing them into a low stance combo just to finish it off with a high stance heavy attack or something even more wacky. granted I haven't finished the story of Nioh 2 yet but to me I don't feel like theres a 'point' in doing that. Your mom gets killed by a strange yokai man and you basically live on your own till yokai start popping up around your crib, then some monkey man finds you and you just follow him around? Right now I'm helping nobunaga on his quest to reunite all of japan but I don't see why my character really cares? Another little gripe is how tanky normal enemies are. Big fan of this franchise

TL;DR + Edited Review at the end

The things that I will admit about this game is that it looks very good, the combat is incredibly responsive, the level layouts are actually very well done with shortcuts and shrines, and it is as difficult as people have advertised... at the start.

I'm not too far in I don't think, but this game struggles in a couple of aspects. One is enemy variety, which leads to combat staleness pretty quickly, and another is the same issue that I had with the DLC of the first game... fights take way too long with very little room for error to get one-shot. There are a couple of weapons that are a little better at doing "critical" hits to some enemies, but for the ones that can't, the fights take even longer. The bigger issues  is that due to the nature of the larger enemies, your fight will often just be swing three times and wait for the literally exact same attack they just did rinse repeat for a long time. This leads to a desire to when you inevitably do die to a random enemy that grabs you and kills you or pushes you off a cliff that you just want to run to your spirit to get your experience back instead of fighting your way throw. Fights are much more interesting and worth doing if you only have to avoid the same 2 or 3 moves 2 or 3 times instead of 10-20 because every single enemy has super armor to worry about.

Now I did mention "At the start" for a reason... once you find a good weapon, the game starts to get pretty trivial with no incentive to really do much else. I started with the fists weapon because I wanted to use a quick relentless punching weapon. Fists require you to invest in a stat that almost exclusively ups damage, and no defensive abilities. I decided to switch my route to a switchglaive weapon which allowed me to invest into a defensive stat while also increasing its damage... Not only am I more tanky and I do more damage, but the switchglaive's moveset also is able to land these critical hits I referred to earlier on the bigger enemies. It went from overbearing where the first and second boss would take me 10 minutes to beat and I had to worry about being hit once to literally just swinging away like a madlad.

The bosses are also just.... not that interesting... They do too much damage to properly reward proper aggressive gameplay due to how much HP they have, and can be lured into doing the same 2 attacks over and over for a couple of hits until they die. Yeah, it's not that interesting... could probably do it more interestingly, but I would much rather learn the bosses moves on my first try, and kill it in the second instead of spending many many many hours trying to have more fun being more aggressive just to die in one hit and have to start a long boss fight over...


TL;DR version, I'm likely going to play through the whole game anyway, but fights are just too damn long for how punishing a single mistake is. It is not nearly as fun as it could be to have so many tools at my disposal but feel the best route to victory being "poke - poke - dodge - wait" with the occasional rifle/arrow shots.

The bosses became much more enjoyable, but I don't know what actually caused it as the first couple of bosses were definitely killing me in one hit, while the later bosses would take 3-4, which is what I would expect from a game like this. Game became much more enjoyable, and will likely be playing through the DLC and NG+'s like I did in Nioh 1 for the better gear and getting other weapons skill trees up.

Wow, everybody is saying "Oh Nioh 2 is even harder than Dark Souls or Elden Ring" and well yes it might be true because some enemies two shot you. 

But then again you need to read the rules. If you see a big text on the screen saying "You don't need to fight every enemy" maybe don't try to fight that  big creepy horse boss right now but later when you levelled up. The game is much different than Elden Ring and to be honest, it's a lot of fun as it is very loot based. You find tons of loot and it's really cool to search for new items. The combat is very engaging and hits good.

I also like the mechanic of summoning help very easily (blue swords on the ground) and also summon enemies to fight (red swords). Sometimes I just stay in an area and fight many red guys because like I said the combat is really fun. 

I also really like the weapons. Usually I am a sword and shield guy but oh well there is no shield so suddenly I am using this big ass sword called uhm Odaki I think and then suddenly I find some gleves or however they are called and they are also a lot of fun.

But you need to realize: This game is hard and it has waaaaay more buttons to press than Elden Ring or Dark Souls. Oh and of course you  shouldn't play this game on mouse and keyboard, that would just be silly.

[h1]Review as of patch 1.27.01[/h1]

Nioh 2 had a fairly rough launch on PC, and the game still has issues, but as of the latest patch I can safely recommend the game.
Nioh is often described as a "Souls-like", and while there're many elements that it adopted from that genre, you realize that it's more its own thing the deeper you dive into the game.
Like the first game, the game combines excellent melee combat while also doubling down on RPG aspects.

[b]Positive aspects:[/b]
[list]
[*]11 weapon types, each featuring a huge movelist
[*]Stance system and Ki management feel very rewarding
[*]Excellent character creator
[*]Huge amount of build variety
[*]Much better human bosses compared to the first game
[*]Tons of content, on average people take around 100 + hours to finish the first playthrough
[*]Yokai Skills (allows you to momentarily transform into an enemy Yokai and use one of their attacks)
[*]Better enemy variety than the first game
[*]DLSS support (decently implemented)
[/list]

While the game is filled with content, this sometimes works against it.
You'll be busy managing your items and equipment very frequently. 
This combined with the grindy, RNG driven aspects of the loot can be a huge turn off for some players.
Additionally, the PC port of the game still suffers from a few issues.

[b]Negative aspects:[/b]
[list]

Overall a difficult but great game. Graphics are good, the story is decent, but where this game really shines is both the combat and the character customization. The use of four different stances (high, mid, low and sheathed) which have their own unique attacks as well as the ki pulse mechanic which helps you recover your stamina once you get a hang of the timing is pretty unique. The weapon variety and the plentiful options for where to spend your skill points for weapons, magic, ninjutsu and upgrades to your demon form as well as the samurai tree which primarily deals with ki and base stats, is very nice. Combine all that with the myriad of randomized bonuses you get from your weapons and armor that drop quite often from enemies, it all makes for seemingly endless ways for you to build your character. The main story isnt bad, even the side missions have some interesting lore especially in the dlcs. The dlc stories and zones were even better than the main story i feel. The few things i have against this game though are, one, im not a huge fan of the diablo-style loot system, having to check over every piece of gear you pick up early on in the game to make sure its not an upgrade can get tedious, not a game killer for me though, gets better as you find more pieces for your build, you can just sell most of your stuff with out having to look at it at that point. The other thing and this is the biggest negative in my book. This game has new game plus modes available which is fine. That being said i was greatly discouraged from moving onto them because of how much the difficulty increases which each one and with this game making your character very dependant on having the right bonuses for your build from weapons and armor, theres a problem... the RNG of getting the specific bonuses you need for said build can be a very very boring grind late game. I only went to the end of new game and stopped because finding the three bonuses i needed for each armor piece was taking waaaaay too long and costing me waaaaay too much in game money using the temper option at the blacksmith. You can temper your gear by using money and materials and it will reroll bonus stats but with there being soo many stats in that pool its incredibly tough to get what you need. I ended up settling for one or two of my stats i need for each piece cause getting a third was insane. For that reason i believe that for poeple like myself that dont want to grind out those stats i would still highly suggest getting this game but only beating it on new game then going with another character instead of new game plus. Aside from that reroll feature i give this game a solid 9/10.

I came to Nioh 2 after playing the FromSoftware trio of difficult games for PC (Sekiro, Elden Ring, and DS3) hearing it described as a "more difficult Sekiro." After putting over 20 hours into the game I've taken the view that, while it combines some of the elements of Sekiro and DS3, it's really just a worse version of both. 

My opinion is that when you pick up this kind of game the single most important element is the combat. If you come into Nioh 2 with a complete understanding of all the combat mechanics, I could imagine it feels excellent. However, this is a tall ask considering the combat drowns you in endless tutorials which barely scratch the surface including weapons, stances, combos, and special moves. While having some diversity in how you approach combat can feel good, for me this game was dialed up to the extreme where I was completely overwhelmed. I ended up spending a good amount of time reading/ watching basic combat guides (not my favorite thing to do when I first start a game) and still felt like I had the bare minimum understanding to scrape by. The level of detail reminded me of Monster Hunter (except maybe even more complex) but Monster Hunter is nowhere near as difficult allowing you a bit more freedom to figure things out as you go.

In terms of mechanical difficulty, I found most of the game to be fairly difficult, as you might expect of this type of game, although nothing terrible and probably slightly easier than Sekiro or DS3. While it can feel a bit tedious at times to clear out mobs, which is often times required to face mini-bosses that are directly inserted into the level with no private arena, the use of ranged weapons feels really good and makes this far more trivial. The thing that made this game's difficulty feel weird were the absurd difficulty spikes surrounding some of the major bosses. While I might dispatch all the enemies and minibosses in a level/region with ease, I would find myself facing the main story boss that might require hours of attempts to finish. This in itself wasn't a deal-breaker as a difficult boss fight can feel rewarding, but the absurdity of the spikes definitely were frustrating and interrupted the flow of the game.

I can't recommend this game as I feel like there are many others in this genre that just do things better. Unexpectedly, the high point of this game for me was the story which does a neat job of incorporating historical characters and events into a more fantastical world. It's not a terrible game, and if you've exhausted your supply of other Souls-type games and are prepared to embark on the massive learning curve surrounding the combat, you may enjoy this game, but if not, just go play Sekiro.
