Nioh 2 is a fun game that's, in a way, too complex for its own good.

It takes the basic gameplay loop of the soulsborne genre, and layers technical action game combat and loot showers on top of all of that. All of this together both makes the game great and overwhelming at the same time.

The more technical combat on top of the Souls formula creates a barrier to entry even to veterans of the genre. On top of light and heavy attacks, you've got a bunch of special offensive and defensive moves that you'll want to make good use of to succeed. 

There's also the youkai abilities you have as a shiftling (half-human, half-youkai). These are a pretty simple matter of having an "anima" (basically mana) bar that you build by hitting enemies. Then you just press a simple button combination to throw out an ability.

So far so good.

Then we get into the fact that there's three different stances for each weapon, which basically are a matter of how fast or powerful you want your swings to be. Each of these not only have different attack animations, but also have their own set of special attacks, so you need to remember different sets of attacks for each of them. You also carry around two weapons, so you've pretty much got 6 different sets of attacks to keep track of, plus your aforementioned youkai abilities. 

To make things more complicated, a lot of heavy unblockable attacks are stopped with the "burst counter" mechanic, where you momentarily shift into youkai form and do one of three different type of defenses (parry, dodge, strike) to counter and stagger the enemy. This is based on which guardian spirit you have active, and you can carry around two spirits, which may have different counters, so you need to be mindful of that to know how to use the counter correctly in the moment. Furthermore, burst counter is used with a button combination involving the youkai ability button (which is fine), [i]but doesn't involve the defend button[/i], which is used in normal counterattacks that you can unlock for your weapon styles.

Your ki (stamina) also notably regens pretty slowly (even with a relatively light weight class), and to get it back rapidly you'll have to make use of the "ki pulse" mechanic (where you tap a button to recover a much faster regenerating bar). Honestly, I don't know that this really adds much to the game, other than adding some mental overhead. Though, sometimes you might want to forgo the pulse, or use it at a time where you won't get full recovery because you need to stay on the move, so it does add [i]something[/i]. I just don't know that it really adds all that much, and there's already a lot of things to keep track of in this game.

There's honestly just [i]too much[/i] stuff going on, and it makes the difficulty curve of the game incredibly steep in the beginning, as you try to hammer in all the button combinations and controls into your head. I died [i]a lot[/i] in the beginning to the fact that I kept pressing the wrong button combination to try to get burst counter out, since I intuitively thought it involved the defend button, which it does not. Overall, I died slightly over 300 times in my first play through of the main storyline, which took some 80 to 90 hours. [i]Well[/i] over 200 of those deaths are from the first 50 hours. By the last two main story chapters of the game, I was sight reading the bosses more often than not.

On top of all this is managing your stats, which you're used to in a soulsborne game, [i]and also[/i] your loot that you're constantly showered in. You'll be sifting through pieces of armor to balance your toughness (poise) and agility (weight class that impacts ki use and regen), among other bonus stats, then selling/dismantling literally dozens of pieces of equipment between missions.

The gear curve also seems like it's a little rough in the first play. Unless you know how to build already (which you probably won't if you're a newcomer), bosses will hit super hard and be super hard to hurt. They seem much more difficult than they are later in the game. This may be because I figured out a build by later in the game (and you have more tools at that point), but I'm also pretty sure it's because the gear you get ramps up rapidly toward the end of the storyline. The last main storyline level is recommended for level 114 characters. By that time I had gear that was over level 130, and I didn't do [i]any[/i] farming of any kind for it. Thus, I'm pretty sure I was overgeared without even trying to intentionally get gear above the level of the levels I was playing. I'm fairly certain this contributed heavily to my ability to sight read many of the later storyline bosses.

Nioh 2 is overwhelming. It was honestly too much for me. I actually burned out 50-60 hours in, and only picked up the game again recently (a year later), picking up where I left off. It's not that the game was too hard, I was beating a level or two every night after work, but it was just too much. One night I just didn't fire up the game to keep going, because I felt I wanted to relax, and this game doesn't fit that bill. That was the end of my run up until recently.

There's a lot of things to keep track of in Nioh 2, and it all can make the enemies and levels kind of become pains in the ass. Still, it's all this stuff that [i]also[/i] makes Nioh 2 incredibly rewarding. All the tools and options you have at your disposal allows you to come up with a huge number of ways to build you character and approach each situation. Enemies that smashed your face in over and over and over will be common fodder to you later, and you'll face them more and more the further you get (which also contributes to them being a pain, if I'm being honest).

Nioh 2 is a hard game. It's not for everyone; not even for all fans of the soulsborne genre. It's incredibly well-crafted and beautiful. It's a lot of fun. Just don't go in thinking this [i]just[/i] another soulsborne, because it's not. It's much more than that, and that will be [i]absolutely fantastic[/i] for some people, overwhelming for others, or if you're like me, both fantastic and overwhelming at the same time.

Got severely obliterated as advertised, not disappointed in that field. What I didn't expect was the 100+ hour campaign, with about 80 bosses and a billion ways to defeat them. With the amount of variety and depth you can dive into, and for how brutally challenging it all is, I'm surprised Nioh 2 doesn't have more attention nowadays.

Let me put it this way: Nioh 2 is like endurance training at the gym. It only gets heavier and more unbearable as it goes on, testing your resolve and will to go the extra mile. At any point, you could stop. You could give up, say "I did enough, that's my limit", and move on. Or, you could climb that metaphorical mountain, taking all the weight you can, working your way to the third expansion, and the final boss.

And if you beat that final boss, the absolute bringer of nightmares that has awaited you for the entire game, it'll feel like the weight of a planet has been lifted off your shoulders. And that's the fun of Nioh 2; the journey, the uphill battle, and that payoff. Now, is the story and world-building that amazing? Objectively, no, but I didn't mind it though. Felt like a Sengoku period Johnny Mnemonic or something, and as someone who actually likes that film for some reason, the story had it's own janky charm.

tl;dr: Good, buy it if you want.

[b] Introduction: [/b] Probably the next best "Souls-like" game after the Souls series. It has incredible combat(better than Dark Souls) and the level of character customization is very high. One of the best games I've played this year. It still has flaws which I will elaborate, but overall highly recommended.

[h1] Review Score:  9/10[/h1]

[u] Pros: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Incredible combat with three fighting styles for 11 weapons with Ninjutsu & Onmyo Magic. Then there are 3 Shiftling(Oni) transformations and even barehanded play-style. Each of them of their own skill tree system you can unlock as you play. There is also several stats for you to raise as you level up! There is no "bad" play style, just your own. Fists + Dual Swords are my favorite!

    [*]Being able to play co-op for majority of the game while everyone gets progression together. Too many co-op games don't do this and it ruins the entire experience. I am glad Nioh 2 isn't one of them. Wish there was PvP among friends only, but the Revenant System works fine as is. I always wanted a full co-op Souls like game for long while(Remnants from the ashes is close but not quite the same). Does make the game super easy until you hit Dream of the Wise, that's where the real fun is at with co-op.

    [*]A huge load of content for you to go through, spent hours upon hours playing and still haven't reached the end-game yet. Easy 100 hours to put into the game. NG+ are worth doing since they unlock more content for you to do.

    [*]Extremely high levels of player customization. You can create your own character looks similar to how the Samurai Warriors Empires would do it, but with more control. You can Refashion armor and weapons if something suit your taste. You can make a pretty unique looking samurai/ninja. There is even a sub-reddit on Nioh fashion, that's how good it is.

    [*]Pretty great design on the onis and world. It's feudal japan with demonic influence to it. Majority of weapons & armors look great. Character designs are recognizable if you ever played a Samurai Warriors game. Nothing wrong can really go there. 
[/list]

[u] Cons: [/u]
[list]
    [*]Very weak story-telling. It requires you to have some prior knowledge on Feudal Japan's and Nioh 1's history. It loosely follows the Sengoku Period; VERY loosely. It has it's own spin on history which is interesting, but the lack of bridges between story gaps makes any reader confused. Major events in history are just told in pieces with little to no motivations explained with majority of characters. This creates a dissonance with the player and the story. By the end you only care about like 1 - 4 characters, the rest you don't remember existing at all. Another case of "show don't tell" scenario in this game. (The game's weakest aspect)

    [*]The voice acting for the most-part is great as well as the sound design. Though I would have loved more cutscenes and voice acting rather than texts to tell the story. The music is a bit weaker side, there is only a lot of strong music pieces though many of them aren't very memorable. And for those handful ones, they were very outstanding. They are mostly there to set the tone of the scene. Just turn on Samurai Warriors music if you are going to spend all day grinding.

    [*]Extremely grindy to the point of absurdity. The first two NG settings are too easy while the third NG+ is where the true meat of the game is. Every NG+ sort of makes the previous gear weaker and useless in comparison(to an extent). Forging becomes somewhat useless after NG+++, with Divine Weapons being uncraftable. I can understand the first difficulty for beginners but NG+(DOTS) was sort of pointless and just felt like padding... should have skipped to NG++(DOTD). It gets extremely tedious going through the same maps and missions to the point where you get burned out... I highly recommend getting a buddy and trying your best to blast through the first NG+. Doesn't help some enemies has some cheap one hit kill moves, but that's just how this genre works~

    [*]No way to customize armor colors or decals on them... This is the most confusing aspect of the game. With how much this game loves to let you customize your character, it has zero customization for armors. This prevents players from deviating from armor sets preset designs. Doesn't help how certain armors have hidden cosmetic when paired together and ridiculous amounts of silly helmets(yes I know actual samurai had some crazy helmet designs). A very HUGE missed opportunity! 

[/list]

[h1]Recommendation:[/h1]

Full Price? Yes. Definitely worth your money and one of the better "Souls-like" games you can find in the market.
On Sale? 100% Yes. High value.
Peer Pressure? YES. While this game is fun solo-play. It's a lot of fun with friends(try to reach Dream of Wise together, that's where the real co-op fun starts).

Everything the first Nioh had, plus character creation, youkai powers, new weapon types with their own move sets and skill trees, lots of new locations, enemies and bosses, new game mechanics like a slow-charging demon form for you and mini-boss enemies who generate a whole region of darkness until defeated... in summary, it's better in every way. If it has a fault, it's that by the time you've done all of the things there are to do (which is a lot unless you skip every optional mission), you will probably be a bit tired of it. Still, there's enough variety here to make it enjoyable for the most part.

Some content from the first game returns, but it feels more like occasional nostalgia than excessive recycling - basic enemies whose absence would be odd, freshened up with updated move sets, for instance, or revamped maps from Nioh 1 appearing for minor side missions.

The core gameplay is the same moderately fast-paced Souls-like action and exploration, coupled with Diablo-esque looting of heaps and heaps of helmets, pants and weapons, all in a vast array of types and a range of qualities. Your spare pants can be sold for cash, offered at a shrine for experience, disassembled at the smithy for parts used to make other kinds of pants... your choices are many, and whatever you want to do, odds are you'll figure out a way to make it work. You pick your play style, your weapon preferences, your magic and ninjutsu abilities, your support items, and of course there's plenty of room to experiment. Dying happens fairly regularly unless you're overpowered for your current mission or just seriously "in the zone", but that's Soulsy games for you.

Genre advice: Try to maintain a mentality of "What did that death teach me?" and you should be fine. Even if you lose a heap of experience to an unfortunate double death, you can earn it again. With a single death, you can recover your semi-lost experience directly. There's a rare but not unobtainable item that can summon your experience back after death, and some guardian spirits can give you a chance to reclaim it upon death without having to visit the spot where you fell. The game is challenging, difficult, perhaps unfair at times, but overall it does give the player opportunities to survive and enjoy the experience. You'll get better and better at timing and use of your weapons as you play, which can also be a lot of fun.

Overall, highly recommended to anyone who enjoys Soulsy gameplay, Japanese settings and mythology.

[b]A very tough hack-and-slash like the first game.[/b] It plays almost exactly like it, and whatever story the game has takes place both before, during, and after that.

As a PC port, it's fine for something that came out of Koei Tecmo who aren't really known for great PC ports.
While it doesn't officially support Windows 7, it can run on it pretty nicely after some file tweaking.

Like the previous game, there's a story going on, but it's not really all that engaging.

The main attraction, of course, is its gameplay. It plays exactly the same as the previous game, with more control options & gameplay mechanics, like the different types of Burst Counters and Yokai Abilities, in case you were already overwhelmed last time by the sheer amount of buttons you were able to press. Though they're not all necessary to get through the game, learning & mastering them does lead to an extremely rewarding & satisfying experience.

The replay value here is just as high‚Äîif not moreso‚Äîthan the previous game, with the higher difficulty NG+ modes making a return‚Äîalong with all the postgame features‚Äîas well some new features to make the game even harder, but slightly more rewarding for yourself, if you're feeling up to it.
The side missions and even in-game achievements aren't as B.S. as before, and there are some fun new weapons to try out in addition to every weapon making a return from the last game.

Compared to the first game, it's not as difficult, but at least it's for very appropriate reasons.
My only real problem with the game is how its level designs constantly try to be Dark Souls in an almost tongue-in-cheek manner, like blocking off a shortcut or parts of a level behind fragile looking doors or tiny gates, or being unable to get loot that's over a 2 ft. ledge.

Strongly recommended if you're looking for a fun, rewarding, and very challenging hack-and-slash, especially if you got into the previous game.

The game is deceptively difficult early on, mostly due to the lack of equipment, skills, mechanical knowledge, and overall build synergy which requires you to play much more slowly and carefully than you need to later. However, this also leads to one of my favorite progression curves of any game I've played. Your options open up tremendously as you progress, as does your understanding of how to use them (so long as you put in the effort and pay attention to what the game is trying to teach you). This is a game that absolutely rewards you for everything you put into it. The combat is high risk and very punishing, but also provides many methods and opportunities for you to turn the tide in your favor and dominate fights.

Definitely my favorite game in souls-like ARPG medium. Some people compare it to dark souls but is fundamentally very different than that. The combat is intricate but flows incredibly well when mastered. I have over 500 hours and there are still a bunch of mechanics and play styles I have not mastered yet. The complexity of the game may very well be daunting at first but it gets very rewarding once you slowly start to get used to the close knitted combat systems. 

The story serves well as both a standalone and a prequel to Nioh 1 through its implementation of real Japanese figures viewed through fictional lens and their reappearances in Nioh 1, which brings about a feeling of nostalgia. The story is a joy ride and I highly recommend not skipping them because it offers a narrative that augments what your motives are at different parts of the game. You could be playing a mission through pure joy or through pure spite, it's all about the narrative. 

The combat is very VERY convoluted but in a way that gets more and more rewarding the more you understand its systems. There are 9 different unique weapons that have their own skill trees. Transitioning from one weapon to another feels daunting but oddly familiar at the same time. Weapons have similar movement inputs which makes the combat feel easier to adapt to. There are also things like yokai abilities, yokai shift, and hidden boss skills you can get to get more out of your weapons. There is honestly too much to talk about and you can really only see it for yourself.

TL;DR: Dark Souls X Diablo X Ninja Gaiden

Borrows a LOT from Sekiro, Dark Souls, and Bloodborne, but adds a lot of its own ingredients as well. I will never love this as much as I love those games, but it's far from a cheap knock-off.

The gameplay is DEEP, almost to a fault. A lot of players will be turned off by this game, because it has all the difficulty of a FromSoftware title and more than twice the complexity. Right from the beginning, you are managing two primary weapons with three stances each. That's already six distinct movesets to worry about, not including ranged weapons and a huge variety of Yokai shift abilities. This complexity only grows as you level up, with new active skills adding variations to each moveset. It's a lot to memorize very early on. From a game design perspective, it would've been better to start players off with a much simpler experience, and let them unlock stances, secondary weapons, and Yokai shift abilities as they progress through the game. Starting Nioh 2 as a new player, especially with DLCs, feels more like NG+ than a fresh start. My guess is that the developers originally planned for these mechanics to be unlocked later in the game, but had trouble balancing the early-game progression.

Level design is decent, albeit underwhelming. There's plenty of ladder-kicking and "door does not open from this side" to keep the genre enthusiasts interested, but each area feels more like an instanced dungeon than part of a contiguous world. There is nothing that connects the different areas together. Instead, you have the arcade-like experience of teleporting to each mission site for a quick linear excursion full of monster-slaying and loot-collecting, and then returning back to home base to take inventory and level up. It is not quite that banal in reality, but that is the overarching gameplay loop. Somehow, Team Ninja and Tecmo still haven't quite escaped their roots in the video arcades of the 80's and 90's.

Remarkably, despite its shortcomings, this game works. The depth of gameplay, once you get familiar with it, results in a very high skill ceiling and plenty to look forward to as you progress. For every aspect that deserved more attention, there is another that received a surplus of attention. There's a lot to admire here that I hope other developers will borrow, which is ironic given that this game is mostly derivative. It's a good game. It will only appeal to a niche audience, but if you're part of that audience, you might find yourself right at home.

Honestly, this is my favorite take on the "Souls-like" formula, and it improves upon the original Nioh in nearly every way.

You can jump into this without having played Nioh 1, as this is technically a prequel. While it does have a very light tie-in to Nioh 1, it doesn't really spoil anything about the events of Nioh 1.

What separates this from other "Souls-like" games for me is:

1) Enemies have a ki (stamina) meter that you can meaningfully use to pivot the fight in your favor. You can deliberately dodge around them and let them tire out, block their attacks, and even use specific weapons or skills to do more ki damage at specific times. Once someone's ki is completely drained, they drop into a vulnerable state where you can do a lot of damage. Having this ki bar always visible on enemies - even on bosses - is so useful.

2) You have way more tools at your disposal for approaching combat. 

      The first of which is that every single weapon has three different move sets -- one for each "stance". There's a low, mid, and high stance which you switch between by pressing RB + A, X, or Y. Mid stance is kind of the default with standard speed and ki consumption, but blocking in Mid stance consumes a lot less ki. And the mid stance is the only stance that allows a parry move.

      Low stance has faster attacks, faster dodges, and everything generally uses less ki consumption. All of your attacks, however do less damage.

      High stance has slower attacks and slower dodges, and everything uses more ki. But your attacks do more damage.

      So you can start in mid stance and use blocks to carefully read your opponents moves and attacks, switch to low to dodge around them, and then switch to high to do more damage. Then switch to a different stance depending on the needs of the situation. But the combat can get much more involved as the different moves in different stances can have different functions. Using an odachi specifically gives you access to moves that allow you switch stances mid combo, which can allow for some interesting displays.

      Each weapon also has a skill tree that will enable multiple active use skills for each stance and weapon, and also low grade passive buffs to your weapons or weapon skills. There's even a skill that will allow you to perform a special attack while switching between one of your two melee weapons. You're also allowed to carry two different ranged weapons with limited ammo for each.

      You also have a hype as fuck Yokai Shift (replacing the overpowered Living Weapon from Nioh 1) which lets you temporarily transform into a demon and deal more damaged and stagger. While transformed, damage doesn't reduce your health -- only the amount of time you can stay transformed. So it can be used strategically to deal max damage during a bosses weak point or as a panic button to save yourself right before you're about to die. There's even three different Yokai forms to choose from - one emphasizing damage, one emphasizing speed, and one emphasizing range. And whichever one you pick also dictates how you use your burst counter.

      Burst counter is a special move you perform using RT + B that will interrupt an enemy's burst attack. An incoming burst attack has a distinctive audio cue and a visual cue in the form of a red haze around the enemy's head. Burst counter it successfully, and you'll stop their attack and temporarily stun them, opening them up to be combo'd or giving you a moment to use an item. The yokai shift emphasizing damage gives you a SHOULDER TACKLE burst counter so you can literally interrupt them mid-attack. The yokai shifts emphasizing speed and range give you a parry burst counter, so timing is much more important with those.

      But burst counters cost 1 anima, and the anima gauge is something you charge slowly through attacking and receiving damage. Other than enabling your burst counter, anima is also consumed upon using other yokai abilities that you'll naturally find, test, and equip as you play through the game. There's tons of stuff here -- grab attacks, boulder hurling, fire yoyos, a paralyzing attack -- and each boss even drops a unique yokai ability for you to try.

      And I haven't even gotten into the different armors. or the passive buffs you can roll or reroll on each armor and weapon, or any of the new game+ stuff.

     Essentially, if you found yourself feeling pretty limited on options in Dark Souls - you'll definitely find plenty to sink your teeth into here.

I was pleasantly surprised by this entry. Great music, fun coop, great combat, immersive setting, quite pretty in its own way, and overall a pleasure to play. 
The story felt lacking initially, in-fact I was almost completely lost. My friend helped explain things as we progressed together. As I became more familiar with the characters, lore, and real-world history, things began to get far more compelling. I was able to appreciate the narrative more in subsequent playthroughs. 
Narrative gripes aside, Nioh 2 has one of the most robust character creations I have ever encountered; quite impressive indeed.
Combat feels great and rewarding for those who take the time to become familiar with it. I never felt forced to use any particular weapon, and could always switch at anytime. I recommend at least sampling every weapon in the game, they are all lots of fun.
The music is really nice and quite immersive. I actually had some of the tracks saved in my music playlist before I ever even played the game. When I stumbled across the music in-game I was pleasantly surprised and had an "Oh! I know this music!" moment or three. The music really is great... though I will admit that I think Nioh (1) had a more memorable OST in terms of music that I would frequent even outside of the game. Notable exceptions being Elegy and Lullaby; I quite enjoy them.
The setting and theme is great and really played a large role in why I enjoyed the game so much. Environments range from quite beautiful to very eerie. The grand assortment of armour and weapon designs was quite cool to see and experience.

I am glad I had the opportunity experience what this game had to offer. I highly recommend the game to those with patience and fortitude.

I really hoped to like this game, and there's a lot they do that's neat. New weapons like the switchglaive (basically a modal scythe) and the fist/claw weapons ("unarmed" is my favorite combat style), the fact you can make your own character instead of playing a pre-generated white guy running around Japan, etc. However, the shit I hated most about NiOh1 is here in full swing, with some really annoying friends.

The super obtuse level design, full of invisible walls and hidden critical paths, the 2D minimap that shows almost literally nothing (it can't even do the terrain for the part of the map you're ON; it's completely featureless, except for nondescript blobs that are meant to indicate fog areas where monsters spawn), save for a beam at one point that means "go vaguely in this direction", except there's always some dumbshit roundabout path that actually LEADS anywhere, so you still spend a lot of time running around samey environments, covering the same ground repeatedly and looking for the one prescribed path you're supposed to take that they took really bizarre glee in hiding from you.

Once again, 85% of the time you're fighting Yokai, and Yokai are less than half as much fun to fight as dudes. Dudes actually react to your blows and you can actually get combos off on them. Yokai just no-sell your attacks for as long as their little stamina bar isn't empty, and when it is, you CAN stun-lock them, briefly, most of them anyway, until they do an unstoppable attack that usually hits for insane damage, restores their (super-armor) stamina gauge over halfway and sets it about restoring itself. You can disperse those little realms they open, sure, but the fact they get 65% of their stamina  back in a single frame and you're back to the usual wait-attack-wait-attack pattern that you'll use on literally every Yokai. And the same pattern you used on literally every Yokai in the previous game.
Not only that, but, once again, some half of the moves you can unlock in whatever fighting style you're using tend to be throws, grabs, launchers, or other "cinematic" attacks. A personal favorite of mine in this game is Battering Ram with the fists, which punches a dude in the solar plexus and launches him fifteen feet in the air. There's a BUNCH of moves like that for each fighting style, and they're all sick-awesome. Guess what? Best get the most out of them in the first quarter/third of the game cuz they don't work on Yokai! Someone had the bright idea to make shitloads of spectacular, awesome, bone-crunching attacks and then decided they should do nothing against ~80% of your enemy base. About as bright an idea as a hydrogen airship, and my enthusiasm to play this went up in about as much flame.
Finally, they switched out the Living Weapon in favor of a Yokai transformation, which WOULD be cool, but for the fact it's weak as shit. Living Weapon was an awesome, excellent desperation attack (or a mode you could swap into if you wanted to just FLEX on fools); Yokai mode is.... Not that. You can upgrade it, certainly, but it levels much more slowly than the rest of your character does (you can't put Amurita into it), and even maxing out damage in minimizing stamina consumption in the mode, you're not gonna be able to kill more than a couple basic enemies (even dudes) or do maybe 7% of a boss' health, on average before you switch back? "Pathetic" is the word that kept coming back to me.

Nioh 2 is a hidden gem and should be a household name for any gamer. It is a masterfully crafted action/fighting game, and the game is criminally underhyped. YES, it IS hard - but unlike other games Nioh 2 gives you the tools to handle these challenges, rather than purposefully gimping the player character and using a LACK OF TOOLS to artificially increase the difficulty.

Brief background:
I found the game on my own after moving on from the MMORPG scene (WoW veteran for 15 years) and I was craving something new. I had recently played and enjoyed story driven RPG titles such as The Witcher 3 and Skyrim. The Nioh series is set in feudal Japan, with raging warlords and horrifying demons from Japanese folklore coming together for an interesting take on real historical events.

I suppose technically Nioh is considered a ‚ÄúSoulslike‚Äù game as it has no adjustable difficulty setting, the primary focus of the game is on the combat, which in turn is heavily defined by stamina management, blocking/parrying/dodging. However, upon playing over 300 hours combined between Nioh 1 and 2, I don‚Äôt necessarily agree with this comparison. 

Nioh 2 is definitely a hack-n-slash action title, with Diablo-like RPG elements, and *SOME* Dark Souls inspired gameplay. The game is very hard but has a deep progression system that allows the player to grow into the challenges presented and has extremely fast combat in comparison to Dark Souls or other action titles.

Overall, the game is a worthwhile pickup at full price (and a steal on sale) even if you only intend on playing it one time through. On the upside that you fall in love with it, the game will reward you with countless hours of blissful gaming and will become one your watermark experiences that you compare all other games to.

Overall rating - 9/10 
World design/Aesthetic - 7/10
Combat/Gameplay - 11/10**
Music - 6/10
Replayability - 10/10 
Story/Lore - 5/10

Here are some expanded commentaries on scores, for those interested:

World design/Aesthetic ‚Äì 8/10
Sengoku period Japan is a fun setting with a medieval feel, mixing archetypical Japanese architecture and culture with dark fantasy. It seems like the Japanese equivalent to Arthurian England or Tolkienesque mythology. As a lover of open world RPGs, or even themepark style RPGs, I was admittedly disappointed with the central map graphic and mission style layout for the in-game world. This did not end up being something that I really cared about, the depth of the gameplay easily overshadows this shortcoming.

Combat/Gameplay ‚Äì 11/10
This game has a fast-paced combat design with many different tools at the players disposal to deal with any threat encountered in game as they see fit. A near infinite number of strategies can be developed by the player to cater to their unique play style. Nioh 2 has deep and engaging controls and a thorough progression system. There is an extremely rewarding gameplay loop with an absurdly high skill ceiling (search for PooferLLama on Youtube and you‚Äôll see what I mean). Weapon combos, magic, ninja skills, demon skills, practically all combinations are viable. 

Want to use a broadsword (slow 2H) with magic and light armor? Go for it! Want to be a tanky, heavy armor wearing ninja? Absolutely! How about fighting barehanded while naked? You‚Äôre nuts, but OK! The game has been designed to give you these options and they all work. 

Encounter design is also top notch. Basic thug mobs have interactive mechanics and bosses have an exceptional balance between being challenging but also manageable with the right strategy and preparation. 

Replayability ‚Äì 10/10
Nioh is actually 2 different games in one. Your first playthrough and NG+ is has access to basic armors weapons and features, but in NG++ and beyond there is continued progression through your favorite fighting styles, along with more powerful armors and weapons with bonus perks that significantly affect the way you play the game.  

The more you play the more systems unlock to take on entirely new enemies with increasingly difficult movesets and damage output. This is not a game that simply adds HP and damage to the enemies/bosses and/or neuters the player character to achieve difficulty (see: Elder Scrolls games, GoW4, etc).
The game can get grindy towards the end playthroughs (NG+++++/Underworld), in terms of acquiring resources and specific armor sets for the bonuses you are looking for. But if you have gotten that far, you probably don‚Äôt mind because you‚Äôve already crossed the 100 hour mark in the game.

Music ‚Äì 6/10
Not too much to say here. The music adds to the experiences, but it isn‚Äôt something to rave about.

Story/Lore ‚Äì 5/10
The story is light and doesn't take itself too seriously, the focus on the game is the action. The player character is basically devoid of any real traits, they are simply a vehicle to experience the setting. It is inoffensive and sometimes fun, but lacks depth (This is NOT the Witcher 3 or God of War 4). If you have a specific interest in Sengoku period Japan, samurai and ninjas, or Japanese folklore, the game can be fun as it draws on the actual historical record in regard to events and people of that time, as well as incredibly accurate representations of Japanese demons and other mythological creatures in regards to classical and contemporary renditions in art.

Bonus - Character Creator - 10/10
Absolutely fantastic customization options and beautiful models.

I've played a lot of this and my affection for it has gone up and down over the course of my playthrough. The first Nioh was often described as Dark Souls for weebs, but then Sekiro came out and did it much better. One may ask if Nioh 2 manages to do better than Sekiro did - it doesn't, but that's fine because it only looks like the same kind of game. If you are a Souls fan and think of this as anime Dark Souls, you will be annoyed and disappointed. 

The combat is kinda loose - enemies are over-reliant on hyperarmor and attacks that, depending on circumstances, are both unblockable and can be pretty much undodgeable. The active skills range from useless to gamebreaking and often efficient use of them feels a bit more like cheese than skill. When the AI uses them, it cheats, animation-cancelling into an unblockable hyperarmor iaijutsu that takes off 80% of your health bar. The warts show when the game tries too hard to be difficult, like it's in some weird pissing contest with From Software, but From didn't know about it and went off to do something more interesting.

The key to liking Nioh 2 is understanding that its true heart is not Dark Souls, but instead Diablo. The real core mechanic of the game is coming up with a build, min-maxing your gear around that build, picking all the appropriate buff jutsu, and then polishing your gear into the best possible version. The souls-like stuff is the loop you go through to get the gear, and the reward for better gear is more efficiently getting better gear. I think this actually works because I find the soulslike gameplay more stimulating than diablo-style gameplay.

Ultimately I recommend this game, but specifically that you shamelessly push your way through NG as fast as possible. You have those ochoko cups - use them. Summon constantly, take advantage of the buff items, don't get too attached to any one piece of gear. It'll all be useless the moment you hit NG+, which is where the real game starts.

Nioh 2 is a fantastic game. At this point, I think I can reasonably conclude that the Dark Souls-esque genre of games is my favourite out of any genre, and Nioh 2 is one of the games that I can place in the top region of that pantheon without much trouble. 

However, though Nioh 2 has many elements of a Souls-like and is extremely well-made, in a sense it is not a game for me. One of the pillars of this game (unlike other Souls-likes) is the eternal loot grind, and getting to the "true" endpoint of the gameplay would presumably take over 150 or even over 200 hours. At the time of writing this review, Steam says that I have 63 hours played, but in reality I probably have at least 20 more while in offline mode. At this point, I have completed all the story missions and submissions of the most basic difficulty, as well as the first DLC. But after about 85 hours, I have run out of steam, and will stop playing here. 

Many players would tell me that is unfortunate, because "Nioh 2 only really starts here." The ultimate goal of the game is a Diablo-like loot grind, where you get ever more fancifully-coloured gear to get even more effective at killing enemies which also never stop getting stronger. In theory, there are apparently four more playthroughs of this game waiting for me if I wanted to take it to its real, grindfest of a conclusion. But that's not what I come to these games for, to be honest. 

If I had to make a mental representation of the Souls-like Pantheon, I would place Dark Souls I (along with Bloodborne), Sekiro, and Nioh 2 at the top. DS I and Bloodborne have in spades what I look for in these games: truly amazing worlds that you want to explore and feel lonely and oppressed in, which spur you forward to face amazing and horrifying creatures just by the sheer strength of the world building. Sekiro, on the other hand, has less of the worldbuilding and exploration, but it has a highly unique and satisfying combat system that is easily my favourite in the whole constellation of Souls-likes. And then there's Nioh itself.

Nioh 2 has a great combat system in its own right, that finds a balance between the methodical aspects of Dark Souls and the frantic and satisfying action of Ninja Gaiden, which was made by the same developer. As someone who likes the aesthetics of Japanese history and folklore, Nioh's environments for me were also interesting and enjoyable to explore. But it never quite reaches the heights of Dark Souls in terms of sheer joy of exploration, and is also not quite as groundbreaking in terms of combat as Sekiro. Instead, Nioh brings the loot grinding element to the table as something that sets it apart, and unfortunately for me the grind for its own sake does not keep me coming back. 

I died a total of 175 times over about 85 hours. Not too bad: I am a patient player, and find that I click well with the methodical style of the combat in these games, where picking off individual enemies and goading them into more favourable positions is rewarded, as opposed to highly aggressive play. However, just like with the original Nioh, which I also played to completion on the first difficulty level (on PS4), after 85 hours my patience to keep playing well ran out. I felt like I was fighting the same enemies over and over again. This caused me to get impatient (and perhaps overconfident), which led to me running into a wall when the enemies started to hit twice as hard in the transition to the second difficulty playthrough. Maybe the following difficulty levels change their behaviours or movesets significantly, but I have to admit that even by the end of my first playthrough I felt like I was going through the motions with some of the encounters, and the idea of doing that for another 150 hours just to watch the damage numbers of my spear go up does not appeal much to me. I find it hard to imagine how that experience would not feel rote very quickly, and simply making the enemies hit harder, having more of them, and having the game be more punishing in general to me does not sound like an exciting evolution of the gameplay.

Even without being a fan of grinding for loot, this game nonetheless had a lot to offer me. The level design is good, the Japanese temples and castles are evoked to great effect, the combat is excellent, and the story is serviceable. I very much enjoyed going through the game on the base difficulty, which was already plenty challenging. However, the loot aspect ultimately was not for me, and so my journey with this excellent game ends here. I still find it a very easy game to recommend, however.

Very strategic in the application of stance swapping, countering, and skill combinations or combos than a typical soulslike or combat style game. Tons of cool lore building and elements even in each weapon or item. High replay value and even higher challenge and opportunity for fun. High potential for fun CO-OP with friends or singleplayer replayability.

This game saved my life.

I am 27.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiraling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Nioh 1 but on steroids. Bigger, more varied, in most of aspects better. 

New mechanics - Yokai abilities and burst counters were brilliant design. Yokai abilities are fun combo extenders and animation cancelling Ki-melting moves and burst counters are satysfying countermoves which also have additional functionalities depending of which type You've choosen - I've picked up fast type which serves as long evasive dash move which can be cancelled from any action. Those two mechanics takes up combat mechanics on another level. Oh and new ''out of ki'' grapple system vs demons is satysfying as hell. 
Gear management got expanded too because new Yokai stuff, more enemy types than in Nioh1 and because that enemy placement became much more varied. Returning enemies got additional movesets.
Dark realm mechanic is nice addition too which makes exploration and boss fights more interesting.
Music is really good, sound design with satysfying meaty hit effects (especially grapples) is great.
Redesigned skill tree needs time to get familiar with it but after a while it became ok.
Specific Nioh atmosphere is still here.
Difficulty is fair - yes, demons got buffed compared to NIoh1, there is Dark realm system which affects difficulty too but player character got so many new powerfull tools so game balances itself in favor of player.

Story and characters are ok, nothing groundbreaking.
While demon bosses are damn well designed (rich movesets, detailed design and animations) the human bosses and standard human enemies are huuuge dissapointment - primitive poor movesets, they aren't designed with new Yokai mechanics in mind. In short - human enemies are boring pushovers and just downgrade compared to Nioh1. Even Hayabusa got butchered and he is just pathetic disgrace to his clan name here.
Pre-abyss equipment sets bonuses are meh, they don't enocourage You to mix-match bonuses like Nioh1 did.
Another sad thing that there is no pvp :/

I don't care about new living weapon system aka yokai shift cuz like in Nioh 1 I don't like those types of ''godmode'' power-ups systems so I've didn't used them. 

Can't write anything about ng+ modes (which were huge game changers in Nioh1) because didn't played them - only finished game once so far.

After all 9/10, great game.

This game is not soul-like.
I have about 200 hours on PS, buying this because of... *cough*... culture content... *cough*. To be clear, I play this game and enjoy playing this game as a Masocore no sarcasm, no pun, no joke. Except not as a journey to "git gud" but as a never-ending journey of getting my arse kicked no matter how long I play it. Because reaching the peak and have to create challenges by themselves like challenge run or speedrun is when one would getting bored of a game. Such is also why I'm not recommend people getting into this game because of the "soul-like" tag.
People will tell you to "git gud" but there is only so much "gud" you can get. The game have so much artificial difficulty that after spending hours learning a boss fight, you still have to try once and again waiting for the perfect pattern like a speed runner.
Kid you not, after you kill a boss, try that again, you will still get whooped when the pattern is not right. No need to look too far, try peeking in the stream of veterans players when they do "depths". It's just a glorified level-normalized boss rush, If you can actually "git gud" to a level where gear doesn't matter, these people wouldn't die left and right to bosses they already fought literally hundreds of time. Keep in mind they still have advantage of all the tool from their build (stamina and health recovery being the main part) and moves you unlock as you playing the game.
To name some of the "difficulty":
- In mission, at "recommended level" and gear, everything can two-shot you, grab attack from bosses one shot you.
- Snipers that are not even visible on your radar can two shot you if you engage with one enemy far away in their "pack" (the one-wing bird boss mission, that guy on watch tower), while other time they don't even care if you blast the head of a guy sitting 3 steps away from them (that two Sohaya in the cat finding mission of Hanzo).
- Big wind up attack is not indication to "get out of the way" but "prepare to hit a perfect iframe", because the hit box will be on top of you no matter which direction you running, and if you block (which you can) you will most likely run out of stamina after the first hit of that big wind up flurry and get kill by the next one or follow-up.
- Hyper armor everywhere, no matter what or who you fight, even after you get them out of stamina human can still just break out of your string and punish with hyper armor while yokai can just enter dark realm to fully replenish their stamina. It is not "a window during specific attack the enemy have hyper armor", it's "a window during specific condition you can flinch enemy".
- Enemy have infinite consumable (spell, ninja tool, guardian talisman)
- When you transform, each attack take away portion of your transform meter, not just getting hit, so does dodge, block and even just staying in transform. Enemy can stay indefinitely until you deplete their stamina (I'm staring at you Saito).
- Some human enemy can still use healing item despite them already have loads of health.
- Say if you are facing a human enemy, if they attack you and you block, you will run out of stamina. If you hit them and they block you will run out of stamina. Yes, it is not a typo.
- Sometimes enemy will instantly facing you when you pull the trigger of range weapon, which result in moving their weakpoint away from where you aim.
- This is speculation, but to me, more often than not the enemy have chance to perform single-frame-reaction time for block, retaliate during your string and ranged attack to cancel your item (very obvious in Saika fight).
- When you apply elemental to your weapon, you do about sub 100 elemental damage and have to build up elemental status through multiple attack in quick succession. Enemy can deal thousands depend on the move (staring at you, Shiba Inu guy).
- Human bosses have their signature moves that involve them summoning their guardian spirit, they will do elemental damage which pierce your block, and yes, it can one/two shot you.
- Bosses sometime have very gimmick strategy, and when using correct cheese, they are a joke, for example: Switch Glaive/ Gust talisman for Saika to deflect bullet/ bombs, Kusa low stance for Saito, non-lock-on hugging the side of Gyuki and ignore its "weakpoints".

And some other minor detail that may tickle most people the wrong way:
- Every time you die, it's not a "reset", your consumable are still consumed, and if you out of "health potion" stock you will find yourself in a situation where you have to face the same challenge at higher difficulty. You can't just buy potion with money, even though you have loads of them.
- A lot of important mechanic are not explained to the player up-front. To name some: weapon buff stack like Fist's and Switch Glaive's, boss's mechanic like the Gong in Uminyudo fight, the bell in the boar mission, the mimic/ Nurikabe gesture, breakable walls, gear weight, confusion, etc.
- You can't jump and can't swim. water is deadly to Kappa and cliff is deadly to Tengu. You can't step over a 2 foot high fallen tree and have to go around, fighting 5 enemies at mini-boss level to get to the other side. You see a collectible through a human-size gap of a wall of a rotten wooden house that on the verge of collapse and have to climb on top of the house and drop down other side to pick it up.
- Playing without a slot dedicated to Enemy sensor is inviting one-shot from literal "fall from the sky" enemies.
- There are no "retry" option to restart the fight immediately, you have to do the "walk of shame". And if you are learning the game, the walk will most likely longer than the fight.
- Some move have very strict timing and if input at wrong time another move will be performed instead. Twin Blade's God of Wind 3 for example.
- When having FPS issue, the game will not look laggy but it will literally slow down to compensate, thus messing up with your input timing. This and the point above make it hard to play when you have inconsistent FPS.
- Feathers/ Magic are insanely overpowered, if you try the game before and after using feathers, you would feel guilty for using them if this game is not a one-off for you. Bragging with feather builds will most likely discredit what ever you are saying.
An improvement over Nioh in every aspect.

[h1]‚ÄúAzrael? Are you dead?‚Äù
~[i]Gargamel[/i][/h1]

I must admit ‚Äì I was looking forward for [b]Nioh 2[/b]. Sure, the first one was pretty much yet another [b]Souls[/b]-like game and we sure had a lot of those lately, but... there was something in it. [b]KOEI TECMO[/b] added their signature touch to our usual formula and, let's just admit it, [b]Souls[/b]-like game in fictionalized Sengoku jidai setting? With all the ayakashi and [b]Guardian Spirits[/b]? It was a very charming experience. The atmosphere, the scale of the story, historical touch, design... Sure, gameplay-wise [b]Nioh[/b] wasn't that special, but like I said, there was something in it. So, even though I rarely look forward for [b]Souls[/b]-like games (not because I don't like them or something, it's just those are not the games you play every day, while, like I already said, there's quite a lot of those around when you need them), I did look forward for this one. Now, here it is and... I must say I'm disappointed.

The first thing you'll notice when you'll start with [b]Nioh 2[/b] is a character creation screen. That's right, no more [b]William Adams[/b] as the main character. We're playing as our own silent avatar called [b]Hide[/b] now. It's not like it's a bad thing by itself and the way our character is written into the story is actually very clever (especially if you know Japanese culture good enough to fully understand it), but... See, the original [b]Nioh[/b] was all about Sengoku jidai. It showed us the end of Azuchi‚ÄìMomoyama jidai and the beginning of Tokugawa jidai. And it had everything that makes Sengoku jidai so interesting. It had signature civil war atmosphere, it had intrigues, it had samurai, honor and all of that awesome stuff everybody loves. Now, in [b]Nioh 2[/b]... well...

I can't say that the story here is bad, or something. And it's still following the same time period (the game takes place both before and after the original [b]Nioh[/b]). It's just... it's way too generic and lost most of what used to make the original so impressive. Our hero is half-ayakashi who'll hunt evil and end up playing an important role in Toyotomi Hideyoshi's rise and fall. Quite a lot of historical figures are presented (from [b]Oda Nobunaga[/b] to [b]Abe no Seimei[/b] in one of the [b]DLC[/b]s, don't ask me how's that possible, though), but it won't feel like a fictionalized slice of history. Instead, it'll feel like our usual ‚Äúhalf-demon hunting demons‚Äù thingy. Which is, like, one of the most common motifs in Japanese media. Even if you don't like Japanese stories much, you sure know at least one of those. From [b]Hideyuki Kikuchi[/b]'s [b]Vampire Hunter D[/b] to [b]Devil May Cry[/b] video game series. Such stories are [i]everywhere[/i]. And that's exactly what we've got here.

Sure, [b]Nioh 2[/b] looks pretty neat. Monster design is superb and if you have one of those [b]OLED[/b] TVs with the real [b]HDR[/b], make sure to enable it in this game, because honestly, I've never seen such beautiful [b]HDR[/b] colors in video games before. This game looks like an art and [b]HDR[/b] colors just bring it on the whole new level. But with such a generic story... it's hard not to feel like something's missing. Especially since it'll be impossible not to compare [b]Nioh 2[/b] with its predecessor, which did way better in that matter. Talking about the first [b]Nioh[/b], by the way. In my review I've made a joke about [b]Yuki Midorikawa[/b]'s [b]Natsume Y≈´jin-ch≈ç[/b] ([b]Natsume's Book of Friends[/b]). And guess what? It's time to mention it again. Because, while still being divided by mission, this game works exactly like that. You go through the level, you meet a big and scary enemy, you defeat them and then you listen to their tragic story. Repeat until credits will start rolling. So... yeah. Far from being the best thing you can imagine. Stylish. But that's it. [b]Yuki Midorikawa[/b] turned such an approach into something absolutely fantastic. [b]Nioh 2[/b]? [b]Nioh 2[/b] just turned it into repetitive mess that doesn't give you enough motivation to keep going.

But enough about that. Let's talk about the most important thing ‚Äì the gameplay. Is [b]Nioh 2[/b] good? Well... yeah. But again, it's a huge disappointment. Just because... the game didn't really change that much. I mean, it's not like there won't be any changes at all, it's just in [b]Nioh 2[/b] [b]KOEI TECMO[/b] decided to take [b]CAPCOM[/b] approach. You probably know 'bout that tiny little series called [b]Monster Hunter[/b], right? You know, the one that can consume your whole freakin' life? Well, that's pretty much what we've got here. I don't mean that [b]KOEI TECMO[/b] turned their game into a monster slaying thing (you can always call for help online, though), it's just, like in [b]Monster Hunter[/b] games, they've decided that introducing a couple of new mechanics is more than enough for the next game. In other words, [b]Nioh 2[/b] is pretty much the same exact [b]Nioh 1[/b]. Just with a couple of minor changes.

The biggest difference between the first and second [b]Nioh[/b] is so-called [b]Anima[/b]. A secondary stat that will let you use your ayakashi (y≈çkai) abilities. Which you'll unlock by collecting so-called [b]Soul Cores[/b]. Technically, those are pretty cool, since you'll purify them, fuse them, turn them into fragments and attune them with your [b]Guardian Spirits[/b], but... * sigh * Yeah, it's another disappointment. Because [b]Soul Cores[/b] are way more boring in reality than they look on paper. Long story short ‚Äì you defeat some fat enemies, you get [b]Soul Cores[/b] that drop from 'em and you bring those to nearby shrine to ‚Äúpurify‚Äù them (just a way to prevent you from using them right away, nothing more). Then you either put those on one of your [b]Guardian Spirits[/b] (attunement), fuse them to improve their stats, or break them for shifting skill points. That's it. Not as fun as the one may expect, right?

Talking about shifting, by the way. Again, it looks way better on paper than it does in reality. On paper your character gets possessed by his (or her, since finally, we can make ourselves female avatar in [b]Nioh[/b]) [b]Guardian Spirit[/b] and get access to corresponding abilities. In reality, though, you just press two buttons and turn into one of those generic powerful forms that we've seen in many other games before. Sure, in [b]Nioh 2[/b] it's a bit more tricky thanks to how we can customize and level up that form (see above), but still, it's not really that exciting and fresh as you may hope or expect. And the worst thing? The worst thing is that... that's it. That's pretty much all big changes in [b]Nioh 2[/b]. There's nothing else. Like I said, it's the same exact game with just a couple of new mechanics.

It looks the same, it feels the same and, well, it [i]is[/i] the same. [b]UI[/b] didn't change at all, we've got the same exact stances / shooting mechanics, the straightforward levels are still pretty dumb by [b]Souls[/b]-like standards (the only level that actually feels somewhat like a real deal is the final level from the final [b]DLC[/b] called [b]The First Samurai[/b]) and so on. So, in the end, it's close to impossible not to feel disappointed. Sure, I can't say that [b]Nioh 2[/b] is bad. Because it isn't. It's quite good and the new mechanics totally work. There's no way I can give this game a thumb down and people who don't mind [b]Monster Hunter[/b]-like approach won't even see my problem with this title. Also, like with previous game, [b]Steam[/b] got the complete set. A full game with all three story [b]DLC[/b]s and even some exclusive gear that you can retrieve through the shrine menu. In other words, it's a solid product and [b]Souls[/b] fans would totally enjoy it. And yet, it's a big disappointment. Just because it was hard not to expect more than just a generic story and a couple of new mechanics. Dixi.

As a long-time Souls fan, I was VERY surprised at the quality of this game. I went into this game expecting a mediocre ripoff of From's formula, as so many others have done in the past. I was so, SO wrong. This game goes above and beyond all expectations, and simply calling it a souls-like would be a disservice to the game as a whole.

This game is top-notch from head to toe! Every animation, every spell effect, every pixel is just DRIPPING with quality. You can tell a LOT of passion went into this game's world, characters, and story - even for side missions & DLC! So much so that I might actually prefer this game to anything from the Souls series, and that's saying a LOT.

Every quality of life feature you wish From had included in their games, Team Ninja has gone ahead and implemented. But they didn't stop there - they went above and beyond and absolutely crushed expectations. 

Above all else, this game has immense replayability. I'm over 100 hours in my current playthrough and have yet to make the transition to NG+ because of just how much content there is, builds to try, and gear to farm (if you want to). I have never been particularly excited for the NG+ experience in a Souls game, but Nioh 2 makes it incredibly appealing and they handle the whole process far better.

The right person can easily dump 500-1000 hours in this game and not even realize it. Fans of Diablo, Destiny, Borderlands, and the Souls series should all give this a try. Highly, highly recommend!

Some games suffer from their complexity, bogged down by erroneous features to pad their run time.  Luckily, Nioh 2 isn't one of those games.  While it's no stranger to extra features you'll find in many AAA titles, the core game is tightly polished, neatly balanced and a blast to play.  If, then, you decide to keep playing you'll continue to unlock more gameplay progression options through the various NG+ difficulty modes and organically start to interact with crafting and collectibles.  It's a rare game like that: the normal experience is weighty, but it knows what it is.  If you want to plow through the basic game and story, all the extraneous features won't get in the way of that.  In fact, many of them aren't even available.  This allows Nioh to keep tight control over the intended experience while also allowing it to continue on for devoted players.

As a small disclaimer, this is a game that feels like it was built specifically for me: it's a skill-based Samurai action game with tight controls and great character customization.  It has a story, mostly a period character drama spanning decades, but it's largely incoherent and easy to ignore.  Basically, it is the opposite of a game like Ghost of Tsushima, a game I wanted to like but telegraphs the ending about fifteen minutes in and then fails to expand from there.  Nioh 2 is not for ghost train ride players, it's expertly paced, wonderfully balanced, and full of interesting and diverse enemies, levels, equipment and skills.  This is a great game.

I originally planned to write this review after just completing 100% of this game. But my friend grew tired before we could, and frankly, so did I. Nevertheless, after investing ~250 hours into the game, I can say without a shadow of a doubt: [b]Nioh 2 is the best souls-like game currently available on the market.[/b]
Is it perfect? - No, there are no such games. Does it hold in every major game design aspect, delivering quality varying from ‚Äúdecent‚Äù to ‚Äúamazing?‚Äù - Hell yes. 
[list]
[*]Story
Prequel to the original Nioh, Nioh 2 is also set in feudal Japan with a fair pinch of it‚Äôs mythology; mixing the real, historical events with fantasy. This time around, we get to create our (mute) protagonist; a half-man, half-demon [i](did someone say ‚ÄúDMC‚Äù?)[/i]. The overall story is good; it‚Äôs even [i]occasionally[/i]  better than Nioh 1, but in most cases I would say that the first Nioh had a more coherent narrative. Nioh 2‚Äôs story has some badass moments, but overall it is hindered by budget limitations, using ‚Äúfast-forward‚Äù way too often and skipping moments of the story that —Åould‚Äôve been pretty interesting. On the brighter side, it gives the first game a logical conclusion and answers all questions that were left. The DLCs, though‚Ä¶ While I get what the devs wanted to show, [spoiler]time-travel[/spoiler] is still one of the laziest narrative tricks one can use. And ALL three DLCs revolve around it -_-
All in all, the story is of decent quality, especially when compared with most other souls-like games. You know who you are, what you need to do, why you‚Äôre so powerful, who the bad guys are, why exactly they are ‚Äúbad guys‚Äù and all of that without any ‚Äúindirect narrative‚Äù bullshit involved. The main storyline has some nice, memorable characters and even some nice twists.
[*]Gameplay
Nioh 1 on steroids, essentially. More weapons, moves, skills - everything. The devs learned quite a few lessons from the first game: improved economy, simplified and expanded co-op a bit, as well as significantly improved progression and replayability. The only drawback is the removal of PvP, which I suppose was simply too complicated to balance.
For more info you can check out my Nioh 1 review, since the basis remains unchanged - just improved in almost all aspects. Major innovations worth mentioning separately:
-co-op up to three players; this time around you CAN revive from the nearest checkpoint, although you‚Äôll have to sacrifice all the souls you‚Äôve gained during the mission
-Living Weapon is replaced with [strike]Devil Trigger[/strike] temporarily turning into Yokai. There are three classes of Yokai available, based on your Guardian Spirit. It also affects another new mechanic - Yokai Counter; the enemies now have attacks that can only be parried with those counters.
-Overall economy and replayability were improved significantly. You can reroll gear stats much easier and earlier, there are far more ways to replay the old missions in a new, fresh way (backtracking was reduced, as well)
-Proper tooltips for M&K controls, hallelujah!
[*]Graphics
Just like the predecessor, Nioh 2 looks amazing. The level design is awesome (and reuses the same levels for side missions much rarer), the enemy design is superb for both old and new monsters, and all the old/new gear looks just as badass.
Once again I‚Äôll highlight the amazing ability to apply skins of one gear to another; as simple as it sounds, it is an ingenious and for whatever reason - rare sight in modern RPGs with standard looter-shooter/diabloid progression. Found a sword with great stats, that looks bleak and unappealing? - fret not, since you can easily swap it‚Äôs appearance to any sword you‚Äôve found so far. Same goes for armor.
Another credit where credit is due - the game isn‚Äôt hardlocked on 60 FPS anymore! The PC version now supports up to 120 FPS. While it was released with certain issues related to it, most of them did get fixed in the first two months.
[*]Sound
Not much to add here - the sound quality is still great. IMO, the soundtrack even got more badass. What did change, however, is the voice acting. While first Nioh had both Japanese and English-speaking characters, explaining how they understand each-other via lore, Nioh 2 has all characters speaking English. Did it affect the atmosphere? - Personally, I don‚Äôt think so; especially since the quality of the VA is spot on.
[/list]

[h1] Conclusion[/h1]
9/10. Best souls-like game currently available on the market, simple as. Most complex and diverse combat system, proper story, great visuals and sound, replayability and proper multiplayer without stupid gimmicks. What more is there to ask? The only reasons for me to [b]not[/b] recommend you Nioh 2 are:
1) If you, for whatever reason, absolutely despise the setting of Feudal Japan and/or it‚Äôs mythology
2) You just don‚Äôt like souls-like games, which is totally fine. Keep in mind that even if you hate complex combat and prefer the incredibly simplistic ‚Äúroll-roll-roll-basic two hit combo-roll-roll-roll‚Äù formula - you CAN play like that in Nioh
3) You hate the rarity loot system in its entirety. I understand this hatred and partially share it, although I have to point out that Nioh 2‚Äôs system is arguably one of the most lenient and least infuriating, safe for the grind at the latest difficulty levels.

This is the most rewarding game for your persistence. 

The game seems impossible early on, but once the systems and combat clicks, its one of the most enjoyable combat systems in the genre by a long way. 

If you are are new to it (like myself) please persist with it and watch some videos, you won't regret giving it that extra time. 

On a side note, there are a lot of comparisons to Dark Souls - I think that undersells this title, there is far more depth, creativity and complexity in combat in Nioh 2, and this is coming from a veteran Dark Souls player (Finished 1, 2 and 3, multiple times)

LEARNING AND OBSERVATION :D
something of a little advice first :) learn and ultimately "master" how the mechanics of combat work (the second enemy you face is good practice), KI PULSE is a feckin must on where to start, if you don't know when to ki pulse you are gonna run out of stamina/KI QUICK and then die muchly.
Timing and knowing when to attack/dodge is too a good thing to learn in this game, it's trial and error sometimes but you get it eventually and after the game becomes much more fun.

STANCES
 You can use 4 'stances' for all weapons which do different roles in combat, you got Low, mid and high stances learn these also and their functions.

1. LOW stance uses very little ki and is for quick attacks, dodges and for taking out weak enemies or just getting in some damage without messing with the enemies KI/stamina. <---(i'll get to why later)
2. MID stance is (in my experience) a damage dealing stance for doling out the hits when an enemies ki is depleted.
3. HIGH stance is for breaking guard and dishing out heavy KI damage but uses much of your own KI to do so.
4. SHEATHED... your weapon is sheathed, you can unlock special attacks for the Sheath Stance.

LEVELLING + SKILL POINTS
As you kill enemies or just using the desired weapon you main you'll get skill points to unlock and access to more advanced combos and moves.
(my advice about weapons...)Pick and test every type out on the first area and get a feel for which one you're gonna stick with because most weapons behave and feel different... an Odachii is a far cry from the splitstaff.

For normal levelling up you'll gain AMRITA of which to spend on various attributes. this nets you increased stats like health, KI and damage with specific weapon types depending on which attribute you'll favour.

KI or STAMINA
ah the joys and pains of enemy/boss KI.

Regular sized enemies (e.g humans, Gaki) have only one bar of KI, when it's drained you'll be able to pull of a "finisher" usually killing them in the process.
 Larger enemies have two bars of KI, as you drain the first bar of KI out of larger enemies you'll be able to stagger them as you attack which in turn interrupts their attacks, if you drain the next bar (shown red) you'll drop them and thy'll be vulnerable to a "finisher" move that will drain much of their health. if you do not kill the said enemy with the finisher chances are it will regain all it's KI, spawn a dark-realm pool and get enraged.

BOSS KI... same applies to bosses HOWEVER sometimes you DON'T want to drain the KI of bosses cos they can become a massive pain in the ass, gaining VERY annoying/high damaging attacks that it's best avoided as much as you can because it will drain eventually and when it does they'll drag you into the YOKAI REALM where you'll get mildly stunted stamina/KI also special effects and move-sets in favour of the boss will occur. (still fun tho...kinda cool too).

EQUIPMENT + ITEMS
There's tons... like a lot of items you'll just not end up using or remember existed. 

There is a lot Weapon variety in terms of looks and what special effect it places on the table, like lightning, fire, water elements but mostly just stat increases.
As you use weapons you gain "familiarity" which increases it's damage and given stats.

Armour is Plentiful and very "of the era" looking which is totally fine, light armour will allow your KI to regen much quicker and allow further dodges but offers low toughness which affcts how much damage you take. Heavy armour is cumbersome and your KI won't regen much but allows a bunch more toughness whilst medium armour is a nice balance between both light and heavy, 

KODAMA + SUDAMA
Around every area/level you'll find Kodama hidden (usually well hidden) that you can collect for the shrines in that particular zone which will net you bonus healing drops, certain items, amrita or ammo so long as you activate these buffs at a shrine. 
you'll get a flat percentage increase to drops for the buff you choose at the shrine. there are 5 different kodama to find that are identified by the bowls they wear on their head.

Sudama are little dark realm types of kodama that act as an item exchange, so if you drop say... a blue rarity class weapon, you'll get a diffrent blue class weapon as an exchange and perhaps some extra items with it.
don't attack sudama hehehe...

CHARACTERS+STORY (no spoilers)
For the love of all that is holy who put in charge of the voice acting for the english voice overs?
play in Japanese voices cos the english is kinda bad (especially the part where that guy sings and it sounds nothing like the english voice actor. you'll know what i'm on about...) dont get me wrong, the voice actors do hard work but it just didn't fit here really. Japanese is really top notch though.
anyway...
The game is set in the Sengoku period or "warring states period" of japan as war is bungling out and peeps are angry-nasty civil war making. oh and there's yokai... yes.
You are a halfbreed human/yokai and you are pulled into all that excellent historical shite meeting big names in that era i'll not mention.
Characters are cool, i'd look up the history of the era or somert if you're interested in a particular event that happens. 9/10 could use more shrooms.

Art AND DESIGN
Enemies and Yokai look fucking stellar 10/10 (i want a scampuss plushie)
Bosses are FUCKING MOST BODACIOUS 10/10 could use more magic shrooms.
Environments are kinda Here and There... some cool, some not really interesting. 6/10
Characters look Really elegant and flashy and i like it!! 8/10
Armours and weapons are cool in places, basic stuff looks... well...basic but that's fine, the more rare weapons look amazing and sometimes have special visuals to them. 9/10

THE PROTAGONIST!!!!
Silent and Deadly...                            mute...                                 they're mute...
The character creator is actually really good, you can make SO many different looks to your Dude or Lass however you wish and you can change it any time throughout your play-through too so that's cool.

Overall i love this game and i give it a solid 9/10

One of my most favorite games of all time, and that says a lot. 

Up front, the flaws are that there are a lot of loot that most people don't know what to do with; and also that enemies can be cruel in placement, ambushes, grouping up on you with no sense to give you any wiggle room. 

However, this game is more forgiving on the aspect of loot/stats than most people give it. While you do need to have a mild idea of what you're going with, there's no need to min/max or optimize to get through your first three (of five) playthroughs. Seriously, just take this for what it is: a vaguely Souls-esque action RPG that mixed detailed and intricate combat with a most striking and colorful style that makes every encounter feel like art at hour 1 or hour 500. 

There are obscene amounts of end game, easy to co-op, lots of lore if you want to dive into it, and plenty of customization in both character and gear. If any of this interests you, then trust me: you won't be left wanting.
