"Dark Souls difficulty with a heck of a lot more combos and weapons."

The Souls-like genre gets a lot of hate for being extremely difficult and requiring a lot of skill to play. I myself did not vibe with Dark Souls 3 due to it's more grounded combat and emphasis on stamina/mana economy with precision strikes. Added on with the enemies and bosses difficulty, the game wasn't satisfying enough for me to keep going.

Nioh 2 fixes those issues with an insane amount of weapons, 14 to be exact, each with it's own fully fleshed out skill tree. Additionally, you can choose to invest in Omyouji Magic, Ninjutsu Techniques, and even choose to fight enemies bare-handed. With just how much content this game throws at you, you can keep playing forever. Bored of one weapon? Just reset your stats and choose another one! The combinations of weapons, skills, stats, and techniques can either make the game easier or harder, and you can gauge how hard you want your play through to be. And don't worry, there are super flashy anime-leveled moves and combos that you can pull off. Plus, the game has 4 tiers of difficulty, acting as its own version of NG+, NG++, and so on going from level 1 to level 750! Also, the amazing character customization is the cherry on top for this game.

I cannot recommend this game enough. There is a reason it won the Steam Awards' "Best Game You Suck At" Award.

I'm going to point out, what this game features in addition to its prequel. NIOH 2 feels exactly like the prequel, with some additional interesting gameplay mechanics. This game offers a refreshing fast and dynamic [b]combat system[/b], with three three different stances which feel significantly different to each other. Moreover, more [b]weapon categories[/b] have been added to the excising ones know from NIOH 1. William, the [b]protagonist[/b] in NIOH 1 was replaced by a nameless half human half Yokai being, and its appearance can be designed in a nice [b]character editor[/b], offering many details. With your nature as a half-Yokai, [b]new abilities[/b] can be added to your attack repertoire. Your Yokai foes randomly will drop a soul core, which can be attuned to your selected guardian spirit and these soul cores represent the attack of the Yokai, which dropped the soul core [i]( ... haha, reminds me kinda to MEGAMAN XD... )[/i]. Major changes have been carried out to the [b]perksystem[/b]. Each weapon category, magic, ninja, samurai and Yokai comes with its own [b]perktree[/b], which can be evolved starting from the middle towards more developed skills in each direction. [b]Story[/b] ... to be honest ... I didn't pay much attention, sorry XD. There are several more additional gameplay mechanics, however, I think I just pointed out the most important ones. New equipment you acquire in your adventures are thrown in too high quantities at you in my opinion, thus it feels not so good to find new armour and weapons. 
Overall: A must have for every gamer enjoying souls like games.

The reason I bought this game is mainly because it was tagged as Souls-like. I am an huge fan of Darksouls 3 and Sekiro, with a few hundred hours gameplay and 100% achievement on both games. However, this game is a huge disappointment, as it is nothing "Souls-like". My frustration is mainly on:
- Everything is so colorful, which is huge distraction to the gameplay. Most of the time I have no idea what is going on since both the enemies and my attacks have such robust colors. It is as if the game developers threw in the whole color palette, treating the game like a children coloring book. 
- You can't start the game in offline mode (unless you turn off your internet). As a result, the whole game is desecrated with red and blue graves, which is an eye sore to me.
- Weapon and skill sets are overly complicated. Most of those fancy gimmicks are pointless because you will eventually stick to the same combo or weapon sets which you are comfortable with. 
- All enemies, even the ones at the beginning of the game has hyper-armor when attacking. You need to play that game super defensively in order to minimize the damage taken. 
- The default key bindings for mouse and keyboard is garbage. To add to my frustration, most of the well timed actions required hitting more than 2 keys at once which is absurd. 
- Boss fight is not interesting, tedious, and not satisfying at all. Gozuki boss fight was like one of the most boring fight I had in all the action games I have played. Spammed dodge, attack, and spirit animal for the win. 
- You can't jump in the game. Despite being a Samurai, Ninja, Plumber, Engineer, Astronaut.. You. Cant. Freaking. Jump. Navigating through the map is a pain in the ass. Also, that mini-map is useless as hell. 

Conclusion: 
- Just because a game has the "Souls-like" tag does not means the gameplay is similar to DarkSouls. In short, Nioh 2 is an action RPG with a bunch of artificial difficulties to mess with the players. Enemies and bosses has unnecessary high health and damage; weapon and skills are unnecessarily complicated to make the players think that the learning curve is deep. If you want a game that is hard but yet enjoyable, go for Darksouls series or Sekiro instead.

Just going to dive into things, since you know what this game is already about most likely. 

Overview:
- This is a soulsborne. You will die a lot until you get the hang of things. Once you do, like most soulsbornes you will feel quite accomplished and powerful.
- The game is essentially Dark Souls which had a baby with Ninja Gaiden and the new kid inherited the Diablo loot system on top of it.
- Your first playthrough will probably take 40-60 hours depending on your previous Nioh experience (for me it was none) and depending on how completionist you are.
- You do not need to play the first Nioh to understand & perform well in this game, but having played soulsbornes before helps.

The Good:
- 8/10 Combat. Combat is aggressive. Stealth aspects exists, but the game really rewards players for hacking and slashing. ranging down enemies really helps simplify areas.
- 10/10 Loot system. Diablo loot system, with tons of options and rarities. 
- 8/10 Replayability. You would need to NG+, but at least things change. New weapons and enemies etc. A lot to do.
- 7/10 Multiplayer. No shared loot, so thats a plus. You can play with friends, but would like to have seen forced online invasions while you play to add to the pain.
- 9/10 Player customization. Surprisingly abundant choices here.
- 9/10 well made/optimized game. Only experienced 1 minor glitch so far. No lags. 

The Bad:
- 5/10 Story. At least a story exists, but its nothing compelling. I never quite care about characters in the end.
- 6/10 Level design. This is a game heavily focused on combat and RPG elements. Some areas are well designed and nice to look at, but most are basic, and linear. Still wide enough levels to explore and get lost in, but not interconnected. Not an open world game, as other soulsbornes are.
- 5/10 Death penalty. No real penalty for death other than losing the currency you require to level up, and that is only permanently lost when dying again before you retrieve your 'soul'. Another minor inconvenience is losing the consumables used (healing, ranged, etc) and needing to repurchase those.
- 3/10 Yokai shift. Although very cool looking with tons of benefits, it is far too overpowered. You can 'super saiyan' once a gauge is full and it can really make a moderately tough fight trivial, even with the buff being temporary.
- 5/10 Build variation. You are really either a fighter, a mage, or a ninja who uses tons of items. For instance, you can not easily be a ninja and utilize the ninjitsu tree without having to invest into the magic skill to increase your attunement slots. There are ways to blend these to add variations, but not in a noticeably varied way. Katanas are always for builds with the heart skill, glaive for magic skill, etc. Scaling unfortunately does not vary in significant ways within weapon classes and among the plethora of weapons. 

Final Thought:
- Overall, a very satisfying game to play if you are into soulsbornes, and one that I highly recommend. I have not had this much fun with a soulsborne since the actual souls games. Nioh 2 takes the difficulty up on notch and brings it on par with Bloodbourne. Could be more difficult if not for Yokai shifting. Veteran Soulsborne players will find this game moderately difficult, with a few bosses that pose a real challenge. The games length is nice too and there is a lot to do if you wish to keep playing.

TL;DR: NIOH VERY GOOD, FEELS DISTINCT. COMBAT BEST IN GENRE, EXPLORATION WORSE THAN SOULS, CO-OP WAY BETTER THAN SOULS, LOTS OF MENU MANAGEMENT, LOOT SYSTEM LIKE DIABLO/PATH OF EXILE. NG+ CHANGES THE GAME AND ADDS TONS OF CONTENT ALL THE WAY UP TO NG++++. EXPECT SOMETHING BETWEEN AN ACTION GAME AND A SOULS GAME. FEELS REALLY, REALLY WEIRD IF YOU DON'T CHOOSE JAPANESE AUDIO IMO.

NOTE: YOU DO NOT NEED TO PLAY NIOH 1 TO ENJOY NIOH 2. with this said, if you decide to play nioh 2 before nioh 1, there is very little reason to go back to nioh 1 (it's nioh 1, but better and with more stuff).
nioh 1 and 2 get probably the best praise that i could give a soulslike, which is that they actually feels distinct from the souls series. this review will essentially be for both nioh 1 and 2.
approaching this review under the assumption that you're experienced with FROMsoft's games,

>the nioh games have a far, far more in-depth combat system - to the point that it is probably best approached as being a hybrid between action games and souls-clones. there are fewer classes of weapons, and each weapon in each class is almost completely identical to the others outside of statistics, but every single weapon class has over triple the amount of moves compared to souls games. in addition, the core mechanics of combat have been expanded far beyond that which can be found in dark souls (e.g. the importance of ki damage, enemy weakpoints, ki recovery via ki-pulsing and switching stances, yokai shift, and yokai soul cores), leading to a far higher skill ceiling, reward for skillful play, and variety in combat styles. NIOH HAS THE BEST COMBAT OF ANY SOULS-LIKE BY FAR IF YOU ENJOY ACTION GAMES.

>the nioh games are far more lethally punishing of mistakes in combat than the souls games. while not as prevalent in nioh 2 as nioh 1 (due to a very specific enemy not being as common in the early game), it is safe to assume that you will die far, far more quickly from unskillful play in nioh than in the souls games. with that said, you will be pleased to hear that your bloodstain is automatically picked up the moment you enter a boss arena in nioh 2, and there exists a consumable item to remotely pick up your bloodstain.

>THE ITEM SYSTEM OF NIOH IS MORE AKIN TO DIABLO OR BORDERLANDS THAN DARK SOULS. this is EXTREMELY important to state. in addition, nioh has a staggering amount of menu-management that can easily scare off new players. i would recommend exploring the menus at your own pace and not letting yourself get bogged down by these extra systems. most of them can safely be set aside for at least your first NG cycle without impacting your playthrough. in addition, there exist options for loot filtering and displaying items and all that stuff in the options menu that i HIGHLY suggest you take a look at once you have a few hours under your belt and start feeling comfortable with the basics.

>every single weapon class in nioh scales off of 3 different stats, and have some overlap with other weapons. while the stat system can seem daunting and confusing at first, i can safely state that any build would appreciate having 30 in the health stat, the ki regen stat, and both magic stats, as well as however many stats you need to wield most armors, and the rest into damage-affecting stats for your chosen weapons. with this said, i would advise that you experiment often with different weapon classes to find a playstyle that feels right for you. also, note that consumables to respec your stats can be bought in infinite number from multiple shops, with the teahouse being perhaps the most reliable.

>magic in nioh is implemented as automatically-restocking items, and are (unless specialized into heavily) primarily extremely useful as buffing and debuffing tools. while this lends itself to melee playstyles in expected and unexpected (item canceling for combos) ways, a pure magic playstyle is not as engaging in nioh as it is in souls. on the topic of items, you can have up to 4 available for easy-access at any given time, via the D-pad, and can switch between sets of 4 at a moment's notice.

>CO-OP is supported far better in nioh than in the souls games, but there is NO PVP in nioh 2, and only a seldom-used duel system in nioh 1. in addition to the standard souls-style co-op of summoning phantoms at a checkpoint, you can also set up multiplayer lobbies to run through certain missions completely in co-op, which will give full rewards and mission completion status for all players involved. these allow for reviving downed allies (with the mission failing if the team dies too often or all dies at once), and actually scale the enemy composition and toughness to account for the presence of more players. while these features are not available for all missions, the VAST majority of the game can be played entirely in online co-op, without the clunkiness of repeated runs through the same mission with summon co-ordination like in the souls games.

>the level design in the nioh games, while strong at times and poor at others, is not on the same level as dark souls. there is no open-world navigation or connectivity, as every single mission is contained within its own closed instance, and side missions usually take place on maps that you have already seen before (oftentimes ones that you have just fully explored in a main mission). side missions themselves can vary in quality, from things like "go through this area with different enemies" to "pick a side in a race war between humans and yokai", to "1v1 duel versus a ridiculous opponent, no backup", to "DMC bloody palace".

>the nioh games are LONG. if you do all of the side missions (i recommend that you attempt to do as many as you can stomach, to keep pace on levels for your first new game cycle), you will probably be spending about as much time going through your first NG cycle as you would spend in a dark souls 2 playthrough.

>NG+ CYCLES ADD AN IMMENSE AMOUNT OF MECHANICS AND CONTENT TO THE GAME, to the point that i would say that your first playthrough on NG is only the tip of the iceberg. entirely new items, an extra item slot (scrolls), stat limits, item effects, tiers of item rarity, set bonuses, enemy composition in main missions, ENEMY MOVESETS, AND AN EXTRA FUCKING GAMEMODE are all added from NG+ to NG++++. you also unlock missions at an accelerated rate on subsequent NG cycles, meaning that you aren't stuck slogging away at a lower NG cycle if what you want to play around with is locked behind something further on. with the addition of a system to save your build's stats and equipment, and the prevalence of respec consumables, there is very little reason to start a new playthrough rather than continuing on to higher new game cycles.

the last thing i'll say is that, if you were put off by nioh 1's extremely noob-stompy first act, or its downright bullshit human bosses in the DLCs, nioh 2 will be far, far more palatable. just don't expect to go into the "Chinese Bellflower Dagger" side-mission and have a fun time.

When I played the original Nioh, I played it very similarly to a Dark Souls game. I.e. I played it in a very slow paced manner where I would block/doge the enemy's attack, attack once myself, and then repeat. After all, I picked a fairly slow weapon (Odachi) to use. In Nioh 2, I decided to try a faster weapon: the fists. I enjoyed using this weapon WAY more, and there was a point where I thought Nioh 2 was a 10/10 game as far as gameplay is concerned. It felt like the game combined the challenging bosses of Dark Souls and the fast gameplay of Devil May Cry beautifully. However, as I kept playing the game, I realized that combining both Dark Souls and Devil May Cry had introduced cons as well as pros.

In my opinion, there's two extremes of Hack and Slash type combat: Dark Souls and Devil May Cry. Dark Souls type combat is where the enemies can do a lot of cool shit and are very difficult, but you as the player can't do all that much. Devil May Cry type combat is where you as the player can do a lot of cool shit, but the enemies can't do all that much (or at the very least don't get much opportunity to because you'll destroy them in seconds). I've always thought that the perfect game would involve merging both Dark Souls and Devil May Cry combat. For a while, it seemed like Nioh 2 was this perfect game.

Fundamentally, Nioh 2 has Dark Souls type combat where you can block, dodge, run, parry, and attack. Everything costs stamina so you have to be careful in balancing being offensive and defensive (i.e. if you use too much stamina attacking, you won't have enough stamina to dodge/block). At the same time, pretty much every enemy can kill you in like 2-3 hits (sometimes 1 hit). All of this causes combat to be very methodical, as you have to find the best way to kill enemies while trying to make sure you take as little damage as possible. This causes the gameplay to feel very rewarding, as you can totally feel yourself mastering the enemies you face as you beat them without being hit once.

What sets Nioh 2 apart from Dark Souls and other typical souls-like games is that in addition to your quick and strong attacks, you have access to a variety of attack skills, similar to Devil May Cry. To be clear, you're not exactly going to be doing infinite combos on enemies, since you have a limited amount of stamina and you'll invariably run out after a few attacks. However, having access to different types of attacks gives you different ways to approach/deal with enemies. For example, you might want to use an attack that closes a large distance between you and the enemy. Or you might want to use an attack that does a lot of ki damage. You even have the option of parrying almost any attack! (certain weapons only). This means that the skill ceiling on the offense side of Nioh 2 is a lot higher than something like Dark Souls. I think I was using around 10 different skills while playing Nioh 2, which was absolutely fantastic.

There are also multiple improvements that Nioh 2 makes from its predecessors. Not only does the skill tree in Nioh 2 simply look better, but it also introduces passives that you can equip onto active skills to change their behavior. For example, you can have certain skills do more damage or cost less ki. You can also augment them to do elemental damage like poison or lightning! This system is very cool and I spent a good amount of time thinking how best I should augment all of my skills.

Another major improvement is the loot system. In Nioh, the problem with the loot system was that while there was a lot of QUANTITY of loot, there was very little quality. You pretty much didn't care about "exotic" gear (the highest level of rarity up till beating the game) because there were so many trash special effects, it was very unlikely you would ever get a worthwhile exotic. It almost always made more sense to simply equip a higher level weapon since that way you did more damage. In regards to the armor, you didn't care about the rarity but the set bonus. Once you got the set pieces you wanted, you pretty much didn't care about the armor you would get. So basically, you wouldn't REALLY get into the loot system until you finished the game, which is a huge problem. Nioh 2 improves upon this a lot by allowing you to re-roll special effects since the very beginning of the game. This means that you do in fact care about the rarity of gear since higher rarity gear can have a higher number of special effects. It's OK if the special effects are mediocre since you can re-roll and craft a piece of gear to your liking. Within 10-20 hours into the game, I was very regularly re-rolling my weapons and armor in order to get the special effects I wanted. 

In addition to improving upon the loot system that existed in Nioh 1, Nioh 2 also introduces an entire new type of equipment: Yokai Souls. Taking inspiration from Castlevania, each Yokai enemy can drop souls which your character can equip up to 3 of. Each soul provides passive benefits AND allows you to use a unique attack. These unique attacks often do a lot of damage and can cover a wide area, provide unique effects, etc‚Ä¶ As a consequence, these abilities cost "Anima", another introduction to the Nioh series. Anima is basically mana, which increases by attacking enemies. So the game essentially encourages you to both be involved in melee combat AND use these new yokai abilities, which is great. For a long time I was looking forward to getting a new soul, finding out what it does, and thinking of the best way to use them against enemies.

While at one point I thought this was a 10/10 game, it seems like this was only the honeymoon phase as my enjoyment from the game eventually started dropping. Fundamentally, this is because the "Devil May Cry" aspect of the game simply started taking away too much of the difficulty. At a point, you figure out how best to deal with enemies and you barely ever get scared of dying. I was even facing new enemies and not even caring that I didn't know their moveset. I almost always beat the new enemies on my first try. Hell, I even faced BOSSES and could kill them on the 1st or 2nd try. 

The main reason for this is that all enemies, including bosses, have a type of stamina (ki) bar. Once you deplete it, they will stop what they're doing and be vulnerable to major damage. In Nioh 1, enemies and bosses also had stamina bars. However, apart from a select few instances, it was very difficult to get this stamina bar down to 0. Sure it was possible and a way to approach to dealing with certain enemies, but by no means did this always happen during a boss fight. In Nioh 2, it almost always does. This is because your yokai skills can do some major ki damage, and they don't cost stamina (they cost anima). Therefore, you can chain together regular hits and then use a yokai skill at the end to deplete like 30-50% of a boss's ki gauge. I was regularly facing bosses and they would only get out like 2-3 attacks before their ki gauge was depleted. This meant that I was almost stun-locking bosses, which is insane.

I guess this is the risk of what can happen when you mix Dark Souls with Devil May Cry. At some point, the Devil May Cry can take over and sap too much of the difficulty out of the game. Hell, I can also imagine the reverse happening where the Dark Souls makes it so difficult that you can no longer do cool combos. To be fair, Nioh 2 kept a great balance going for 20-30 hours of the game. That's the length of most games!

Overall, Nioh 2 is a fantastic game. It's not just samurai Dark Souls. This game has a lot of depth thanks to its stances, different attacks, magic skills, ninjutsu skills, yokai abilities, etc‚Ä¶ The list goes on and on. You could spend weeks playing this game and still not have mastered it.

This might be the best Samurai game, next to the "Way of the Samurai" series, you will ever find. 

Good: 
- Its combat system is more complex yet more forgiving than Dark Souls' combat system. 
- The PC version might be the best "PC port" of a souls like game I've ever seen, as it allows to play with and use keyboard & mouse properly. The player can choose between the said keyboard & mouse controls or an X-Box or Playstation gamepad. The keys/buttons are always displayed properly, which is not the case in the original Dark Souls games. 
- Tons of loot and costumization options. You can change your characters face, hair, gender etc. any time in your "hut".
- Not needed loot can be "offered to the gods" (sold/exchanged for useful items such as health potions).
- It has a minimap/radar and a big map in which the player selects his/her next level.
- The more you fight with a weapon the better your character handles it boosting your damage, its passive effects and - as far as I understood - boosting your experience/granting skill points for said weapon. 
- No health penalty after dying. Only the typical loss of money/"souls" which can be reaquired by interacting with one's point of death/"grave". 

Neutral:
- The game has not that many options in the graphics menu. Your computer should roughly match the recommanded specs to have a 60 fps performance. I personally had no problems after lowering the shadow's quality and turning of some pretty yet unnecessary graphical options (anti aliasing etc.). 

Bad:
- nothing so far. How could anyone complain about a souls like game with a mixture of historical japanese armor and japanese magic/religion/fantasy?

To make it short: if you like Dark Souls, the "souls like genre" in general or Samurai games this might be the game for you. I totally recommand it, esepcially when it is on sale.

Nioh 2 is the refinement of an already great game, if you liked the first game you will like this. For people looking to pick up this game, keep in mind that while there are definite parallels to the favorite line of hack Game Journalists the world over "Its like Dark Souls but X"; there are just as many areas that it differs. 
Character creator is orders of magnitude better, and while the weapon system means you have less unique weapons than in a Souls game, the weapons' combat capabilities that are here are far more fully fleshed out than anything on offer from Dark Souls or Bloodbourne. 
One area of i'd say weakness is that the game is split into hub based missions, rather than a fully interconnected world; this is a must because of the nature of the story being told, but it also means easier access to co-op and multiplayer options.
One of the Main sticking points for people picking up this game or Nioh 1, is the gear and loot system; Namely that you have the ARPG/Diablo style loot with randomized properties. Nioh was one of my favorite games of all time. It took the ideas of the emerging Souls-like genre and blended them loot-grinding and spectacle fighter combat. The result was a game that felt unique and interesting. Nioh 2 is an improvement over the predecessor in pretty much every single way. 

Right off the bat, there's a character creator, so you can create your perfect OC. There are more weapons, so you have even more variety in your character builds, as if Nioh wasn't already generous. The depths in which you can customize your character, aesthetically to gameplay is staggering. 

The combat is even more impressive. Nioh already had a fantastic combat system. Nioh 2 further deepens the combat by giving the player even more options. Its almost overwhelming at times. The skill ceiling with this game is astronomical, and its up to the player to decide how far they want to take it. In fact, the level of depth in combat could be a negative for some players who want a simpler, more streamlined experience. I'm not one of those people, however. 

There are two main complaints for Nioh 2. First is the difficulty. As much as Nioh 2 gives you options, it matches that with punishing enemies. Even regular enemies will destroy you if you're not careful. Bosses in this game are severely challenging - far surpassing most bosses from Soulsborne games. Personally, I didn't mind that difficulty, I'm just pointing that out for people wanting to buy this game. 

The second complaint - one I agree with - is the story. Team Ninja are terrible storytellers; I don't think they've made a single game with a decent narrative. Nioh 2's story is nonsensical. One moment you're a random dude, the next you're a high-ranking samurai under Nobunaga, then your best friend is betraying you. Between levels you'll time-skip 10 years. Characters randomly appear with no introduction and less screentime, then die and you receive exposition afterwards. If you're playing Nioh, you're here for the gameplay, not the compelling lore. That's for sure.

Regardless of complaints, Nioh 2 is easily one of my favorite games of all time. Its a unique compelling experience and I enjoyed it immensely, even as I cussed it out for dying at a boss for the 30th time.

I really wanted to like this game. The fights can be fun as hell, fluid combat sequences, tons of gear and skills to experiment with and a rather interesting story based on events during the Sengoku period in Japan but ultimately it's a simple case of the cons outweigh the pros. If there ever was a contest for bad boss fight designs I will definitely mention Nioh 2; it started out alright, got better towards mid-game but after that.. I have never experiencedmore rage-inducing boss fights ever, not even in Sekiro. Some of the mechanics are just downright unnecessarily annoying to deal with, not that it is hard to learn the move sets but the design is just cheap and lame. Defeating these bosses just feels like a huge chore to get out of the way, hardly satisfying. Then there's the level designs; half of it is just so... poorly thought out. Bear in mind there is no vaulting over stuff or jumping in Nioh 2 so the "path" is basically quite linear. Certain doors cannot be opened from one side to gate your progression using... a thin plank leaning against the door. Certain pathways that connect back for convenience is either simply a large step away or slightly elevated. These things are just so lazily implemented I lost count of how many times I just stopped whatever I was doing and just stared at the spot in bewilderment. I guess I'm writing this review to say, if you're deciding between this or Sekiro, give this a miss first and experience in Sekiro what a top quality game should feel like especially at this price. Nioh 2 is hardly worth $68 here. Maybe get it on a discount, but otherwise it is probably best for your mental health to skip this.
Edit: I need to mention, more often than not the idea of "increasing difficulty" = faster enemies that hit harder and putting more of them together in confined spaces. Towards the end of the game you get sent back to the grave by trash mobs more often than bosses. Nothing special to learn about the moves, you fight them almost all the time. Like I said earlier, lazy and cheap.

How do you tell a good souls-like from a bad?  I'll tell you what I've come up with.  Just about every time I die in Nioh 2 I say "that was dumb".  Instead of "gotta git good", it is more how this dumb game was designed.
This game is very tedious.  Everything about it is tedious.  Recycled the same environments and enemies so you are fighting the same bad guys in the same places over and over and over... but in a slightly different order so the devs can say "it is new content!".
Most games design a world and set up rules that run that world.  This game designed a world, and breaks their own rules whenever.  It is the most annoying way to make difficulty, and a super lazy game design.
Game has no plot.  No characters.  No development or progression.  Complete nonsense (like the first but made worse by the main character now being a mute who just stares blankly at cut-scenes going on around him/her).
If you have beaten all souls-likes and are desperate for a game (like me) I still wouldn't recommend this one.  It rewards lazy game design.

Just to clarify - I finished Nioh 1 on steam and Nioh 2 on ps5, finished all dark souls/demon souls (ps3 and ps5)/bloodborne/Sekiro games etc.)
I enjoyed Nioh 2 (to a point) but whole game design for me is flawed in many ways, when compared to "From Software" game's.
Let me try to explain:
-After 3-4 region's Im physically exhausted with overused assets and grind. This is not Sekiro, where You had temples/caves/villages/castles/mountains etc. that each looked different and had own feel to it. Nioh 2 is  copy paste, and Sub missions are basically same missions with a little different enemy setup.
- Mission system unfortunatelly kills progression, world building and half of "fun" of exploration. Each mission start's and end's just like the one before. 
- You'll use same weapon type for most of the game (Due to skill and attribute lock). 
- Way to many cheap "traps" in every single map - I got more cheap death's in Nioh2 then in whole DS trilogy. Canon's and archer's agro from 1 km, 
- Difficulty progression is BAD. Game gets easier after each region', not harder. Bosses are unbalanced and some are way to easy, and some way to hard (snake). Boss "Dark realm phase"  is "kite for 2 min" phase tbh. 
I dont feel any kind of DS satisfaction after killing a boss in Nioh. Also, there are no Boss Armour's, weapons or other unique rewards. Only RNG on top of RNG.
- Cyberpunk2077 like equipment RNG...There are more drops than in Diablo 2, and it says alot - You are flooded with boring drops, hundreds of RNG armour's and weapon's You wont ever use and insta sell etc. Also gear is "inflated" with levels (attack/defense) so You need to swap everything every couple level's to keep up. 
- Story - It's fragmented to a point I dont know why im doing half of those thing's. In DS we had mistery, in Nioh we got confusion and loads of forgettable characters.

I put countless hours into the PlayStation version, and will likely do the same for this. As someone who plays basically every soulslike she can get her hands on, I can say without a doubt that this is far and away the best one. At least until Elden Ring comes out, Team Ninja has beaten FROMSOFT at their own game. The game looks and feels amazing. I'm honestly at a loss for words to describe how amazing this game is. The weapons have distinct movesets and playstyles, the skill trees and the unusual way weapons scale allow for huge build variety, and the game is gorgeous with HDR. The game expands on the traditional soulslike formula in every way. It's one of the few soulslikes built to allow a full co-op playthrough.

My only major complaint about the game is how complicated it is. I actually love complicated systems, but for newer players it's more than a little overwhelming. The sheer volume of stuff a new player needs to learn is absurd, but so, so satisfying to master. I would not recommend this as someone's [i]first[/i] soulslike, but if you're already a veteran to the genre, you simply have to play this. This is easily my favorite game of all time, and I don't see that changing anytime soon.

Team Ninja does some questionable things with their other games, but whoever their internal Nioh dev team is seems to be very autonomous-- in a good way. When you play this game you can feel and see the love, thought, and care that went into it. The Nioh 2 dev team absolutely nailed it, did a great job, and listened to fan feedback every step of the way.

The combat is among the best you will find in video games and the spirit of the GOOD Ninja Gaiden games is present in Nioh 2--that is some of the highest praise I can bestow on it. When playing Nioh 2 and seeing the animations, camera angles, how the weapons function etc, it becomes clear that some members of the old Ninja Gaiden crew worked on this or that Team Ninja analyzed and successfully replicated the parts of combat that worked in NG.

The amount of detail, depth of combat, huge replay potential, and fully fleshed out weapon types is incredible. BUY THIS GAME.

I went into Nioh expecting souls-like RPG and combat with a Japanese setting. Nioh is this, partly, but it becomes exceedingly clear after the initial surprises that this game is simply Diablo III in 3rd person view. The game is grindy, arcadey, and has the illusion of depth more than any meaningful progression systems like that of Dark Souls. RNG based loot and extremely repetitive "hit enemy first" gameplay loops get very very tedious and old after a few hours. 

Yes, you can be a shinobi, but grinding the same identical copy of shinobi gear except with a different level and random stat boosts is an absolute buzzkill. 

This game might be great for hack and slash, MMO, or other such grind-based time waster fans. For me, someone who wants methodical and interesting encounters, uniqueness, and agency, a game based on RNG, gameplay loops, and random drops just does not satisfy. Perhaps I was foolish to expect Dark Souls in a game that is decidedly a hack and slash loot grinder, but that is basically where I stand. 

Nioh is not bad, but it becomes extremely boring after you get over the initial sense of novelty. Sure, the weapons have a ton of moves, but no weapons are truly unique and you will basically run around spamming attacks for hours and hours. By comparison, Dark Souls combat, which has fewer attacks, has a different approach that makes each encounter feel unique. It is more about timing and execution in Dark Souls, whereas Nioh 2 expects giganerd levels of muscle memory in the form of combos, stance shifting, and timing a stamina bar reload (similar to gears of war's reload mechanic). It just feels like a FIGHTING game where you explore meaningless areas. 

No real depth, shallow gameplay, and needlessly complicated features. If the grinding and smithing system is considered "depth" by some, I can only say wow. If anything, these features are glorified inventory management minigames.

Nioh 2 is very Difficult and challenging game. Same you would expect from a Dark Souls game but Nioh 2 adds a different flavor to the mix. Supporting different formulas making it a completely different and unique experience. There are a few minor and some major differences compared to Darksouls. 
1) Blocking is alot more valuable and effective. Blocking in Darksouls felt pointless to me, mainly cause you burn through so much stamina. Even if you could block most or all attacks in Darksouls I barely had any Stamina to attack afterwards.  

2) Bosses health in Nioh 2 can be a bit much. The one thing I always loved about Darksoul games. Is no matter what weapon you used or how low grade it was. It would still do fairy decent damage. Seemed like no boss in Darksouls would take more the 15 to 20 hits to die. Nioh 2 bosses alot hits, depending  how you utilize skills and weapons. 

3) Being Flexibility and versatile is what Nioh 2 shines in the most. It does share weight limits like Darksouls, that hinder speed. But you never have to switch gear for casting or range builds. It's pretty much in all in one package. You Will gradually learn how everything in your arsenal works. 

4) Range with bows is probably the most that stood at to me. It is almost kind of silly on how OP the bows are compared to Darksouls. For one most enemies don't see you from a mile away like in Soul games. Which gives ample time to line up head shots. Which alot times will actually kill enemies out right. In Darksouls I always generally used Bows to pull enemies. In Nioh 2 Ammo is also limited but still felt completely different. In terms of actually being useful.

5) Darksouls games the original ones, actually handicapped you for dying. When you died in Darkouls it would slowly lower a cap to your health as far as -50% health decrease. Nioh 2 can give you a little bit of a leg up. It could randemly let you keep the souls Dropped and also fully charge your oni demon form.  Which can be a huge power up if used right. 

6) Character customization is probably another area I felt Nioh Shined in, same for Code Vein. Darksouls is horrible and always has been when came to that. Nioh 2 is alot more polished in that department There was very little I could find disappointing about it.  The overall quality is beautiful.  

Anyhow I am enjoying the game so far, even if sometimes feel like I want to put my fist through my wall. But hey! what's a Souls game without feeling a little rage from time to time.

One of my favourite games of all time despite my relatively small playtime. While the loot system is basically Diablo-esque and thus not particularly thrilling and heavily RNG-gated, the actual storyline- being so intrinsically about /you/ while also about a historical figure weaved in with other historical figures and fantastical characters, and the fact that the story is its own sequel, prequel twice, and back to itself again, it remains interesting and entertaining and somehow more grabbing than William's story in Nioh 1. 

The gameplay is clean, slick, and fun, the boss battles are satisfying, the combat is surprisingly deep and the movement feels slick, swift, and effortless. And there's a TON of content. I see a lot of comments warning not to compare Dark Souls 3 to Nioh 2 because they are "completely different games." This is a lie. Dark Souls 3 and The Sims are completely different games. Aside from both being Action RPGs, Souls and Nioh have a lot in common:

-Almost identical death system. Lose your experience unless you can touch your grave, keep your items.
-Cruel level design full of mostly stationary enemies, traps, and ambushes that encourage luring enemies to you to avoid extra trouble
-Clever donut-shaped level design that use one-way doors and ladders to open shortcuts
-Dark yet eerily beautiful atmosphere.
-Limited healing potion use reset by bonfire/shrine
-Armor encumbrance system that determines speed and stamina regeneration
-Single stat improvement as a leveling system
-Inventory screen does not pause the game
-Useful items that can be bound to the d-pad

...to name a few. Nioh differs in several major areas.

Levels are divided into missions, but they are not linear. Each mission is roughly the size of a unique location in Dark Souls. Many side missions re-shuffle and redecorate existing areas for better or for worse. The story and lore are also more forward, with a monster encyclopedia, cut  scenes, and the like.

Also, where the Nioh series truly shines, is the combat, which is very different and can drive many comfortable Souls veterans away after being punished for trying to dodge-roll away all of their problems. Nioh is not dodge-roll and attack, in fact dodging is a risky maneuver with a larger vulnerability window than invulnerability window. Instead, overwhelming at first, it is a flow of guard, parry, dodging heavy attacks, burst counters, ki-bursts, and grapples. Each encounter feels partially like a fighting game as you react to your enemy. On top of that, ranged weapons are for more than pulling and can eliminate many enemies with  a head-shot, magic and ninjustu are very useful for weakening, healing, and disabling enemies. The blood and gore is also top notch, with a visceral satisfaction to each small victory over your enemies.

The loot system is a randomized Diablo-like, but with more options to control specific stat boosts on equipment. There are a lot of opportunities to have it your way.

Improved over Nioh:

Character creation is top-notch, with all of the sliders to make whoever you want. You can also change the appearance of any armor or weapon to another one that you have discovered, the the fashion options are completely free. You can also recustomize your character entirely at any time from the mission selection area.

Nioh 2 also did away with the horribly fight-two-hard-bosses-at-once side missions, with more measured yet challenging encounters that don't require you to run around in circles waiting for an opening.

The burst counter system and yokai shift system are also new. The burst counter system is essential and adds a lot of flow to yokai combat - in fact the game will be very hard until you develop the burst counter reflex. The yokai shift system is essential to complete the first mission but its power levels out significantly later.

Everything simply ties together for an amazing action RPG experience, which I almost missed because the first two missions are a little too hard. I almost gave up after chipping away at the second boss (until I found something in my inventory). Don't forget to use your tools.

It's too easy to call it a souls-like, because it kind of isn't: It has more similarities to Diablo, or other ARPG's, than it does to any of From Software's games, so forget any of that for now.

Get this game if:
- You want to spend a few hours on character creation (totally optional, but rad),
- You want an extremely in-depth combat system which rivals some fighting games.
- You want balls to the wall character customization, both in looks and mechanically.

The game's combat shines. There's 10 weapons, each with 3 stances, each with a dozen or two moves (most of which you unlock through skill trees), all of which can be combo'd together in various ways. It sounds more intimidating than it actually is: It's not complexity for complexity's sake, even though it might seem to be at first glance. Everything meshes together more and more as the game progresses.

The game's loot is also highly customizable, however this might be seen as a negative to some. There's a LOT of loot to go through in this game - I personally see it as a plus in this context, but some may see it as a negative.

The character customization is ace, offering exactly the right amount of options to let you do what you want without overwhelming you with details which don't make sense. It's incredibly satisfying to see your custom character in the cutscenes in this game, where even facial animation just looks great on any abomination you can come up with. It's a rather underrated feature in my opinion, on a technical level. 

Don't get this game if:
- You strongly dislike inventory management,
- You want an open and interconnected world to explore.

Inventory management and lootsplosions are a thing. While the cap is at 600 items, which will take a while to fill, you do want to either melt down or sell some items, craft others, upgrade these and modify those: It can get overwhelming if you just want to smash demon face. Personally i don't mind, as it feeds into the customization, but some people may find this very frustrating to deal with.

This game does *not* feature an open world: Prepare for lots of loading screens and menus. Don't go into this expecting a leisurely stroll through a large interconnected world to explore as you see fit. The level design of individual levels is great however, though some parts get reused a few times for smaller side missions.

Otherwise: Graphics are technically not the best, but they're very well done (especially NPC faces are quite believable or even realistic), and the art direction is top notch: Everything looks extremely consistent. Aside from some isolated areas in some levels (heavy grass popin or very bland outer boundaries) it's really well done.

Sound is simply great. You learn to appreciate the many audio cues for combat by ear, and the game has some very subtle audio design to help you be aware of your surroundings. The music can be an earwurm: The first two hub areas have an extremely soothing ambience which can easily get stuck in your ears.

For the rest: Well, prepare to die, a lot. But weirdly, dying in this game never feels frustrating, at least not after you've figured out some of its nuances, which can admittedly be frustratingly hard to figure out when you go in blind.

Oh, and unlike some other games in the soulslike genre (but just like other ARPG's) you can co-op this game with up to two friends from start to finish, no need for cumbersome summoning systems :)

I've got hundreds of hours in Nioh 1 and Nioh 2.  I ended up buying both games on PS and PC.  I have done this despite continually getting annoyed at how much bullshit these games can throw at you.  As a new player you'll find the game just absurdly punishing. You'll find enemies in every level that kill you in one hit.  You'll find bosses that drain your ki and kill you because they never stop attacking.  You'll be killed by ridiculous enemy placements, absurd ambushes and gank squads.

After this happens you'll inevitably find yourself asking, "Why?  Why is it needed to have a bunch of one hit kills?"  And, if you keep going, you'll eventually figure out the answer to that question.  The truth is Nioh gives you such a ridiculous amount of tools that it's impossible to imagine the game having any challenge at all if it played it straight.  In fact your ONLY deaths will be to unfair shit.  And then you'll figure out you have to nuke those enemies with any number of ridiculously OP shit the game gives to you.

About mid way through your first play through you'll have mastered ki pulsing, flux pulsing and the stance system.  You'll have acquired magic and ninjitsu.  And at that moment nothing can kill you fairly.   Instead team Ninja will need to lock you in a room with 7 stun locking enemies to have any chance.

The loot is kind of annoying. The game is deliberately designed to be unfair. The performance is pretty weak.  But the combat is so good none of that really matters.  You just have to let go of the idea that Nioh 2 should be fair.  Instead you have to realize that you and the enemies are both stupidly OP and whichever one cheeses the other wins.

Dont mind the hours played on here, Ive played this on ps4 before at about close to 600 hours. For anyone curious as to what this game is about, i will try to go in as much depth as possible with NO SPOILERS

BEFORE I START, if you have not played Nioh 1, I still recommend playing this over the first. Also i need to clarify that although everyone compares this to dark souls because of the stamina, quick death if punished and "bonfire" like death mechanic, the combat and overall game is structured very differently. The game does not try to be Dark souls except use some mechanics from it. Instead of an open world, it is broken down into levels and the general idea of the game is mostly loot and combat focused as opposed to adventuring through an immersive world. Looking through youtube would have you think the game is purely build focus killing things as quick as possible but this is only one way of seeing and playing the game. 

PROS--------------------------------------------

- [b] Difficulty [/b] is a perfect mix of punishing but very rewarding. Like Dark Souls, you die a lot early on but once you get further, you survive longer and longer. Difficulty can easily be tweeked by the gear you wear. You can make it extremely easy with certain builds or extremely hard BUT your personal skill and understanding of the combat will outweigh your build any day. You are never stuck having to farm or make a certain build to progress

-[b] Combat [/b] can be approached in any way you want. You are able to equip 2 weapons then can be switched on the fly, 3 stances per weapon with their own moves, Magic, tools, 2 ranged weapons, yokai abilities and transformations ALL at the SAME TIME. Want to play it like Dark souls? Sure! Want to play like a ninja with multiple spells and items? Sure! Want to be aggressive and constantly attack while bob and weaving through theirs for a non stop offense making it seem like youre playing devil may cry?!? Sure! The game has the tools for complexity but does not FORCE you to use it!

-[b] Customization [/b] Not only is the character creator great and character creations can be shared via code but transmog allows you to look exactly how you want with 100s of armor pieces. Visual aside, armor effects allows you to tune your character to your playstyle with a limitless amount of builds plus equipped moves that makes your character completely unique.

-[b] COOP [/b] THE ENTIRE GAME CAN BE PLAYED WITH UP TO 2 OTHER PLAYERS! You can also join random games to help others. As of now, i can find a game easily in less than 10 seconds.

-[b] Enemy [/b] The enemies can be weird, creepy, badass, disgusting or all of thee above. Aside from a few enemies, every enemy seems fair but deadly. Boss fights vary from a gigantic yokai to a human with moves that will test your patience.

-[b] Replayability [/b] The game initially advances from you doing key missions to progress. Side missions are optional but helps leveling up or unlocking unique armors or weapons. When the game is done, you unlock a new difficulty and the ability to get even more rare and stronger weapons. Once you unlock "Dream of the Nioh" Difficulty, you gain access to The Underworld, 108 floors that are static levels and 30 randomly generated floors called The Depths. After your first playthrough, they give you the ability to skip pass some missions after progress is done to quickly pick and choose which mission you prefer redoing. Enemies are tougher, some have different moves and new enemies show up in missions.
When it comes to the grind, the game follows a similar diablo/borderlands loot system for weapons, armors, stats and scrolls. Scrolls being small missions where finishing them unlocks extra effects/stats that can be equipped to your character

CONS------------------------------------------

[b] Story [/b] Very unfortunate that it does not deliver. The cutscenes alone can offer an ok story but you will mostly be lost when asking too much questions. Most of the story is told in writing before or after a mission and reading up on the characters in the glossary. There is a great story there but you have to dig for it.

[b] Repetitive?? [/b] Putting this here because i can see how some people may find it repetitive since side missions have you going back to previous areas and people who focus purely on grinding out builds may find the rng annoying since the pool of items is huge. This is why i think you should see this as more of an action game focused on combat than an adventure game similar to dark souls. I came in for the combat and variety of play styles so it never felt repetitive to me

[b] Starting up [/b] The game easily overwhelms people in the beginning with the loads of mechanics it introduces. If that's the case for you, You can go through your first play through ignoring most stats and just equipping whatever has higher defense and attack. Even playing with one stance until your comfortable is fine but the game throws a lot at you in the beginning.

That is all. Hopefully from this review you got a clear understanding of whether or not this game is for you

If you are into the Soulsborne series, then it'd be my pleasure to recommend you this game. Tho it still has it's pros and cons, but i'm a bit lazy to break it down each so, i'll explain it in a nutshell

Firstly, Nioh 2 is that Souls-like game, it's as if, FromSoft was too stressed to make Elden Ring, so they force marriage Diablo and Dark Souls. It has the Souls-like gameplay but the loot of Diablo, so every weapon you find will never have the same stats as the one you previously found, which make loot hoarders (such as myself) end up with a full inventory with the same weapon but different effects and stats. It's kinda intuitive but at the same time inconsistent, so sometimes you end up using the sword you previously found when you were lvl 10 than the sword you recently found.

In addition, unlike dark souls, when you play this game, you don't just start somewhere, you have to take it up on ''Quests'', and these ''Quests'' have rewards when you complete it like most ARPGs.

Finally, this is the topic i always wanted to talk about, the combat system. HO-LY SHIT, it's so fucking good, better than dark souls even. In Nioh, Stamina or ''Ki'' can be recovered quickly with the form of ''Ki Pulse'' in which you either change your stance or pressing the RB (for XBOX Controllers or R2 for PS Controllers)  at the right time or with a perk that can make your perfect timed dodge to also recover Ki Pulse. This is a total game changer, because you (almost) can not run out of stamina, after you deplete an enemy's stamina you can punish them with 5-6 hits depending on your Ki or maybe even more, in dark souls you can't do this, you already have a fixed amount of times on how many attacks can you release, after that you either wait for it to recover or get hit. It's very very useful, even parrying and countering could also recover your ki pulse. Speaking of parry, this game has a very unique skill to which you can not parry at very beginning of the game, you have to learn the skill for it, even backstabbing too. Oh and i forgot to mention, this game has something called ''Burst counter'', in which you can counter an enemy when they flash red with your yokai counter, it depends on the enemies tho. Some range burst attacks can not be countered by Feral Counter, so you end up dodging rather than countering, and sometimes the Burst counter does not trigger because of the hitbox idk i'm not a fucking game developer (or maybe i'm just that bad idk) either way you end up taking a bit of damage (sometimes more) so be careful when you try to do this, you could end up killing yourself.

TL;DR: Game's pretty cool, i like the setting of the Game, exploration is also rewarding just like dark souls, though the combat system needs a bit of tweaking, just a teeny tiny bit, i think it's a couple of inches closer to being perfect so good job Koei Tecmo.

Update: Okay, I'm re-recommending the game, but with this caveat: It's Nioh, and it needs to be played like a Nioh game.  I wasn't playing this the right way when I wrote my frustrated review below, but I'm leaving it up, and changing it to a thumbs up.  Why?  Because while I love the game now, I also think a lot of people will be able to relate to the frustration I was experiencing *back then.*   

If you liked Nioh 1, and remember how to play the game, pick this up.  If you didn't like Nioh 1, or the frustrations I outlined below sound like things you would say, then DON'T get the game.  
  
-----

I originally wrote a recommendation for Nioh 2, but now that I'm further into the game I feel that I have to take that recommendation back.  
  
Look, hard but fair games are fun, learning from one's mistakes and getting good is a very rewarding experience.  Nioh 1 was one of the most fun games I've ever played, I put more than five hundred hours into the first game, I played through the campaign three times (NG, NG+, NG++) and while it was absolutely hard as hell, it was also fair, and that fairness made the difficulty and the gameplay much more enjoyable; Nioh 1 is one of my favorite games of all time, bar none.  

Nioh 2 is not Nioh 1.  
  
Where Nioh 1 was fair, Nioh 2 is cheap.  
  
Stun-locks abound, one hit kills are frequent, getting tricked into four dead end death traps in a row isn't uncommon, sometimes the enemies seem like they aren't constrained by the game's mechanics, cheap, unrewarding deaths are the status quo.  "Oh, you just killed nine mobs in a row, you've got 5hp left, and you're five inches from the shrine (bonfire)?  Sure would be a shame if there was a sniper with a canon just out of view (but within firing range) to blast an atomically accurate canon ball into the middle of your face."  
  
So how do you overcome this genuinely unfair level of difficulty?  Why with cheese and jank, of course!  

The enemy is staggering you with every hit and you can't win?  Well that's easy, use the High Stance Axe skill, which can't be staggered, and just spam it for the entire fight!  
  
Getting overwhelmed by so many enemies you actually can't target them all?  The solution's simple, summon an NPC visitor and use them as a meat shield!  

Sick and tired of fighting your way to the boss after dying for the thirty seventh time?  Use a speed run scroll and just skip the whole portion of the level leading to the boss!  
  
Yes, with liberal application of jank, cheese, and exploits, you too can ploddingly progress through this unfair, stun-locking, one-shotting, head-sniping, mechanic-ignoring slog of a game!  
  
That's the thing: In a good souls-like deaths teach the player how to play better; in Nioh 1 deaths taught the player how to play better; in Nioh 2 deaths teach the player how to exploit game mechanics to fight against enemies that are also exploiting the game mechanics.   
  
I loved Nioh 1, it's one of the best games I've ever played, and I had five hundred hours of fun playing it.  Nioh 2 is not Nioh 1.

Full disclaimer, I am 'not gud' by any stretch of the imagination at Soulsborne/Souls-like games and Nioh 2 isn't any exception to this. I have not and was not able to advance to Dream of the Nioh. You can disregard any of the below on the basis that I need to 'git gud'.

+ Best combat out of any Souls-like game created, with a ton of weapon options and move-sets.
+ Fantastic fashion souls (complete with cape/cloth physics!)
+ Great graphics
+ Best character creation out of any Souls-like/Soulsborne game. (IMO Code Vein comes in as a close second, but it's obviously very Anime styled in its look, so it's apples and oranges) It isn't difficult to create a character that doesn't look like an alien. (Looking at you Dark Souls III) Plenty of preset options that look great and can be tweaked. Can even save and share character creation codes so you don't have to stuff around pausing/un-pausing and alt tabbing a youtube guide with sliders. (Again, looking at you Dark Souls III)

- Story and lore can be difficult to follow for those not familiar with the Warring States period.
- ARPG-like gear system. This of course will be personal preference, you might be the type of player that likes ARPG games and/or really enjoys this gearing system. Fortunately for me, this doesn't really matter too much in the base NG cycle, so for your first run through the game and it's three DLC's you can focus on enjoying the other aspects of the game. 

For those who want to advance through all the NG+ cycles right through to the final DotN (Dream of the Nioh) game cycle, you'll likely need to use a meta build and certainly grind for gear drops that give you the set bonuses and sub-stats that you want. It's a fairly intricate system and I would advise that [b]after [/b] you complete the game and it's DLC's on NG to look up one of the detailed guides explaining the forge in detail if this is what you want to do.

Overall, while I prefer the Soulsborne games I still thought Nioh 2 was a fantastic game and well worth playing even at full price. I think it makes for an interesting middle ground for fans of Soulsborne and other Souls-like games to dip their toes in ARPG gearing systems and vice versa.

Nioh 2 is an incredible game and almost certainly the best Souls-like on the market.

Though Nioh has many differences from From Software's series, the comparisons to Dark Souls are unavoidable.  It has the same exp system, it has a similar stamina system, the combat has a similarly methodical feel to it, and bosses are similarly devastating to the unprepared.  However, it's clear that Koei's game had a much larger budget, and it generally compares favourably against Souls in almost every way, particularly in terms of content and polish.  

One of the biggest differences between the two games lies in terms of progression.  Dark Souls presents the player with an interconnected world that they can explore at their own leisure, while Nioh is instead divided up into distinct stages that are selected from a menu, more akin to the earlier Demon's Souls.  These stages are still generally very large and there are also an absolute ton of them, but it does change the overall feel of the game to some degree.  Nioh also generally has more systems than Dark Souls, it has a much more complex loot system that bares some resemblance to games like Diablo, and there are also complex skill and magic trees that are unlike anything from the Souls series.  Generally speaking, Nioh feels a bit closer to a traditional Action RPG than Souls does.

As mentioned before, Nioh also generally has a lot more content and polish.  It's a much longer game than Dark Souls, with a single playthrough clocking in at somewhere around 100 hours, and it also features an extremely fleshed out new game plus mode where you gain access to new types of equipment and bonus dungeons, again somewhat akin to the difficulty levels in games like Diablo.  It also has far better multiplayer systems.  In Dark Souls, if you want to play muliplayer, you have to go through a clunky process of putting your sign down, fiddling with the password settings so only your friend can see it, summoning them into your world, then keeping the host alive until the next checkpoint, then going back and doing it for the other person.  Although Nioh also allows for this type of play, it also has "proper" multiplayer where you can do missions as a team and everyone gets credit for it.  It's also much better balanced than it is in Dark Souls, as Nioh's multiplayer significantly increases the number of enemies and their HP and damage, while also forcing the mission to be completed in one go without the use of checkpoints to balance out the fact that you can revive each other a few times.  Similarly, fighting other players is handled in a far more sensible way where when players die, they leave revenant graves in the game that players can challenge for bonus exp and items, but the phantoms are controlled by the AI, so all of the griefing associated with Souls' invasion system is avoided.  The game also generally does a far better job of explaining how its stats and systems work, with well integrated context help menus and a much better UI.

So far, all of these comments apply equally to Nioh 1 and 2, and indeed, they are fairly similar games for the most part.  Nioh 2 mainly just refines on Nioh 1 and smooths out some of its rough points.  One of the biggest issues with Nioh 1 was that the start was extremely tough, for the first two missions you are unable to level up or access multiplayer, and the boss of the second mission is quite tough for new players.   This is no longer the case in Nioh 2, the starting mission is still challenging, but feels more fair, and levelling and multiplayer are available right from the get-go.  Nioh 2 also adds two new systems related to the half-Yokai nature of the protagonist, the ability to use Soul Cores and to perform Burst Counters.  Soul Cores are items dropped by Yokai that allow you to use one of their special attacks, for example, if you use the Soul Core of Mezuki, the first boss, you can perform a big swing with its saw, while something more simple like Toxic Slime lets you fire a poisonous ball at the enemy.  These are pretty neat and give you a lot more ways to tailor your build to your liking.  Burst Counters are maybe a bit more of a mixed bag, most enemies in the game can now perform a special attack where they flash red, and if you press a specific button combination at the right time, you can counter the attack, avoiding damage and also damaging them a little bit.  This is not totally mandatory, as you can still block or dodge these attacks as normal, and it doesn't occur so frequently as to dominate combat, but it feels slightly superflous and I don't think anyone would miss it if it didn't come back in Nioh 3.  There's also simply a lot more of everything compared to Nioh 1.  The game is longer, there's more weapon types and spells, and so on.

One last area where I have to commend Nioh 2 is its overall value and technical polish.  Many AAA games receive fairly lazy ports to PC that are poorly optimized, loaded up with intrusive DRM, and release long after the console version at a premium price and with a ton of DLC.  Nioh 2 instead launched with all of its DLC included, for a discounted price, completely DRM free, and it's an extremely well-optimized port that looks great, runs great, and isn't overly demanding in terms of computer specs.  It simply feels like Koei respects the PC market a lot more than most of their competitors.  I would normally advise waiting for a sale on most big games, but this is one where you got great value even if you bought it at launch.

Nioh 2 a blend of Dark Souls, Diablo 2 looting, ninja Gaiden fluid combat and the raging that you would expect from the souls like genre. Nioh 2 is one of if not the best Souls Like gaming experience you will ever have. From the deep complexity of builds, to the fun story set in the Sengoku Era of Japan in the early 1500s  that sets you asa half-yokai named hide who befriends many different characters along the way during the upheaval and warlodism in Japan.

 Nioh 2 takes real dates of the Sengoku Era and characters based on the real life historical figures like;  Kinoshita Toukichirou who later became Toyotomi Hideyoshi. The mixing of fiction and non-fiction is very neat to see and going through the civil war era of Japan and incorporating with Japanese folklore of Yokai (demons) is very fun and interesting spin-off  a real-life era. 

With  over 400 hours in and lots of raging, I want to share my review. 

Combat:

If you have played any Team Ninja (Ninja Gaiden, Nioh 1, Hyrule Warriors) then you know you are already in for a treat when it comes to combat. Like most dark souls the combat is unforgiving to those who don't make time to learn the mechanics of the game. But very rewarding to those who put the time into learn the mechanics, the combos the ins outs of how the game functions during its combat and that's about 90% of the game.

If you played Ninja Gaiden then you already know about the combos, the jutsu/magic and the over top slicing and dicig of your enemies. The combat is probably the best feature in Nioh and makes some of the other Soul like games look like a snore fest.

To say the combat is slow is like saying an airplane doesn't break the sound barrier. It is extremely fast combat, the combos are brutal and coupling it with magic and ninjutsu it can get pretty insane and once you get into New Game + collecting divine gear and start making you build it will get even faster. If done right you can drop big boys in a only a few hits. The combat is a huge step up from the normal souls play and tons of fun if you are into fast paced over the top in your face and melt bodies combos. (I wanted more descriptions but lost em)

With the Nioh Combat you have multiple weapons you can choose from all with their own animations, combos, look feel and play style and as you get better swap between them and pull off some sick combos.

Story:

Nioh 2 is a prequel to Nioh 1 and no you don‚Äôt need to play Nioh 1 to play Nioh 2. It all ties together and fills you in. While I payed somewhat attention to the story, it is actually decent. As you are a half human, half yokai AKA as a shiftling and as you go through you meet and befriend Kinoshita Toukichirou who wants to make his mark in the world by selling sprit stones(Amrita). 

You meet many other interesting characters along the way while fighting back Yokai and evil warlords to gain control of the different regions. The story actually has some really good twists and leaves you with your jaw dropped as you don't expect certain things to happen. For an Souls like ARPG with a story it‚Äôs a decent 7/10 and worth learning about and delving into the lore of the Japan era and the folk lore around the Yokai as it makes it pretty fun to slice Yokai in half knowing what the story around the Yokai are.

Over World Map:

Unlike Darksouls where the game is open and you can traverse the world in any direction (I do prefer this) Nioh 2 kind of does a "lobby" style. The lobby is the over map and you move from mission area to mission area from the over world map. While its cool and there are hidden items you can find on the map, I do prefer free roaming the world and exploring. The mission concept is cool and keeps the game moving and but at times can feel disconnected. An example of this is Warfame, your lobby is your ship, the mission ares are the planets you can select and you can too. But Team Ninja's mission are blast and moving from mission to mission is painless and easy and really keeps the game flowing. Some missions are great for items while others are great for farming.

Leveling Up:

This is where Nioh and other Souls games differ and I kind of like it. In Nioh series you get Amrita (Souls) and gold for buying items, crafting, respeccing etc‚Ä¶ Where Amrita is ONLY for leveling your character up. Like souls games, if you die you have chance to get your Amrita and if you die along the way you lose it for good. They do make it so you can find Summoner Candles and Summon your spirit Guardian back to you and all your Amirta.  

Like most soul games, each stat ties to armor and weapons' as well as your magic and ninjutsu. Scaling and leveling up is a whole separate video, but I really like the way Team Ninja took the approach of separating Gold and XP to ensure you can have one resource for leveling up and another resource for crafting, buying items and components. 

Crafting:

After you beat the mission The Beast Born of Smoke and Flames  you then unlock the black smith. From here you can buy, sell, forge equipment, soul forge (make your equipment stronger), you can use soul forging to over write inheritance or add new ones, you can also temper, change move specials effects from gear and armor to compliment your build as well as remodel which lets you change your equipment to scale off of familiarity, your main weapon stat or if you are using a sword which scales via heart, but want a to make a DualBlade + Sword build and want Skill to be your primary stat so you can us the BS have your sword scale off of Skill instead. 

The crafting system is fun unique, and you will spend a lot of your time here praying to RNGesus as you role for certain tempers or forging new weapons etc. As you use  the blacksmith services more you will get patronage points which can be used to reduce costs, increase rare finds, and use patronage points to soul forge instead of gold. Careful soul forging, its expensive and the way you need to upgrade divine gear, you'll go broke fast! (more on crafting and upgrading divine gear at a later time)

To craft new weapons & armor you will be farming for smiting texts. These will come from missions rewards, boss drops and some enemies so you can craft that weapon you want and then role for the stats you want it to perfect your build.

Builds:

Builds are the bread and butter of Nioh 2 and well usually the bread and butter of any ARPG that has stats, loots and an endless grind to obtain the ULTIMATE POWER OF THE GODS! But to be real, builds are everything and almost anything is workable, 

 So don‚Äôt let a subjective build video that says OMG THE BEST 1MIL DMG SWORD BUILD EVERRRRRR! Sway you into playing that way, as some builds are cheesy and while its cool to fart (Tesso) and kill a boss, you lose a lot of what makes Nioh 2 great. That‚Äôs the combat and fun, maybe farting on a boss gets you going, but my point is to just experiment. 

Nioh 2 offers so much from beginning all the way to end game, either at full price or on sale, 34.99 at the time of this review.. get it!

TL;DR: I really enjoyed the game. As a person who enjoys souls-like games I feel as though it is a must-buy. The combat was fantastic, each weapon type having their own unique play-style and the story was good enough to keep me interested. I was able to play through the game rocking a solid 60 frames 95% of the time with an RTX 2080 at 4k, though I have definitely heard that others haven't been so lucky. Based on comments from the developer, hopefully that issue will be resolved. Other than that, I found the game to be great.

Deeper look:
The combat is smooth, enjoyable and cinematic with the wide variety of both skills and weapons completely changing the way in which you may play. And trust me when I say there is a LOT of skills to choose from, for every melee weapon, onmyo, ninjitsu and the like. For those coming back to the game you may recognize some skills, but additional skills to weapons that had existed prior have also been introduced, which was a pleasant surprise.

Going off of the first Nioh game, the inclusion of the Yokai Shift adds a lot more variety to the combat, and I found it to be far more interesting than that of the previous Living Weapon system. The addition of Yokai Cores also adds some fun elements in how you may approach defeating foes.

Character creation was good, and allowed for a real decent amount of customization.

Enemy variety was definitely improved, as was boss variety. Definitely a big improvement in comparison to the first Nioh game at least. If you've played the first Nioh game, you'll definitely be running into some familiar faces, but their attack patterns are far more varied than before.

The only negative I had was, as with the first Nioh game, the story was alright. It was decent enough to keep me interested, but I wouldn't exactly buy this game for the story.

Very good game, though there's a bit of a learning curve. If you've played Dark Souls, don't go in expecting it to be like Dark Souls. There's going to be similarities to Dark Souls like the stamina combat and difficulty, but this game will punish you if you play it like Dark Souls. Here's some advice: 
- Learn to block instead of dodge through attacks as the invulnerability frames for dodging are a lot tighter in this game.
- Learn to swap stances as needed based on the kind of enemy you are fighting.
- Time your ki pulses to help manage ki after attacks.
- Use your omnyo to buff up and use ninjutsu as appropriate.
- When fighting Yokai, focusing on damaging their ki effectively will go a long way to beating the tougher encounters.
- Keep your gear up to date, as that makes a big difference in power and survival when tackling new missions.
- Bring a friend sometimes, you can summon them like Dark Souls or use expedition mode.
