Holy crap, what a great game; it is in the truest sense of the word, a sequel that expands, streamlines, and improves on its predecessor.  For those who maybe bounced off Nioh1 (understandable, since its difficulty curve was at times BONKERS) will maybe find Nioh 2 smoother to ease into.  And for those unfamiliar with its predecessor, but craving metroidvanias or Dark Souls-likes, the Nioh series is easily among the best of them since not only does it scratch that specific itch, but it also gives you upfront information in its menus/stats, much needed qol, and so much more that Fromsoft could stand to take a few notes on for their own future iterations.

Nioh's whole stance system and skills are just as customizable as they were in one, but now we also get Yokai abilities, which are essentially just attacks that we can copy from *any* demon enemy or boss, which not only further fleshout your moveset, but said abilities come with their own meter, passives, and bonuses that compliment different loadouts too!  The guardian spirit skills from 1 are less overpowered now, but your general gameplay without that limited-god mode are elevated such that it more than makes up for it by being more engaging.

Also, multiplayer in this game is just an actual blast?  Not only does Nioh cut out DS's bullshit where you summon me, we beat the boss, AND THEN I have to summon you and then we do it again, progress is maintained for the both of us so we're not repeating levels twice over.  Unlike DS's humanity, which CAN be expended almost completely in the early parts of the game and thus deny you out of coop, kicking you while you're already down...Nioh just lets you play with people.  What an alien concept.

Not only is the use of expeditions (coop) just more sensical, it also adds fun stipulations.  Enemies are *slightly* remixed around in their multiplayer versions of the map, compared to the single player ones, keeping veterans on their toes.  Furthermore, the heals and other consumables which typically replenish themselves become limited, only replenishing ONCE at every checkpoint you reach, so while, yes you have twice as much dps, and can do satsifying combos where you and your friend just jump unsuspecting dudes, you can't just faceroll the level with your friend (unless one of you is drastically overleveled).
(Minor note, it does cost a specific resource to summon people MID single player missions, but said resource is incredibly easy to come by and is essentially unlimited.)

There's also just an insane amount of content in this game?  Similar to multiplayer, NG+ and NG++ not only upscales the enemies but slightly remixes their placements and swaps around what types of enemies are where.  And to keep things fresh on these NG+ cycles, you're given ample opppurtunity to just respec your stats, your skills, your character's looks, like, basically whenever.  Skills and stats cost resources but like, short of being the most indecisive person who respecs 10 times over, it's a non issue and encourages you to experiment.

If you like Dark Souls, you will probably enjoy Nioh 2. It takes the typical action approach of Dark Souls and twists it to be more open towards an RPG rather than simple combat.
Pros:
+ Random Loot makes it more interesting to go through more runs in missions
+ Custom moveset allows a more personal kit beyond simple choices like weapon.
+ slow OR faster progressions are taken into consideration, as the game allows you to either go through the game with no replaying, or to farm a mission till you are comfortable,
+ OST is amazing and fitting.
+ New Game + genuinely feels like a new experience with certain parts
+ Multiplayer that is actually more than Dark souls' "pleas take me to boss and kill for me :("
+ A smithing text system to decrease the grind or make it easier to obtain a weapon/armor that is favored.

Neutrals:
/Doesn't have PVP *at all*. Though this means that players who never liked invasions or PVP don't have to be forced.
/ Mission system changes the flow entirely, whether it be for the good or bad.
/ No "real" quests per say for NPCs besides "do this mission then this mission. speak to my ghost in some weird limbo world now."

Cons:
- Falls in similar shortcomings DS games do
- Story feels too short, even with DLC
- Clan system is extremely flawed, with no anti-cheat to prevent clans from inflating their score, and having unbalanced buffs leading to one clan absolutely dominating every time.
- Due to randomized drops, it may take ages before the player can find what they're looking for.

Final thoughts:
While I did prefer certain aspects of Nioh 1, like their spirit system MUCH more and the extra elements, Nioh 2 is a welcomed game, and it should be tried by anyone who likes RPG's and also enjoys Dark Souls.

I find it hard to describe this game differently then as extremely exhausting. Of course I understand that this game "tries" to be souls-like, but in contrast to games by From Software, I mostly feel tired even after short sessions with Nioh 2. And after defeating harder bosses, instead of feeling joy of accomplishment I rather feel sort of relief that I'm done with them and I can finally take a break from the game. 

The game looks good, the combat system is leagues ahead of Dark Souls, but like I said before, this game still feels like a slog. You can't relax even for a moment or you will be dead in a seconds. There are some tutorials but they barely scratch a surface of more in-depth mechanics.

What makes this game even worse is the system of side missions. All of them take place in just slightly modified locations from the main missions. All of them are boring and I really don't see the point of making already long game even longer.

Bosses also seem inconsistent. How many tries took me to defeat the first one? 4 or 5. The second one? Between 15 and 20. The third, fourth and fifth one? One try. Tbh, I don't feel like I'm getting better. They just seemed too easy. There were many more mini bosses that posed bigger threat than them. Because of that, the game progression suffers a lot. I really don't think that I'm getting any better or stronger. It just seems that enemies are pre-defined to be either weak or strong and no amount of character's levels will change that.

Also, due to this difficulty RPG elements suffer as well. If I don't wear anything, how much hits does it take for the bossed to kill me? One. If I wear top class heavy armors? Two or three. Like I said before, not feeling any sense of progression. Ok, maybe my character looks cooler in better armors but that's it.

Locations seem needlessly convoluted. Some of them are really terrible. Good example is Yoshitatsu's Castle. It consists of undeground, some sort of tower with multiple floors, outside area, outer castle gates and inside of the castle. Obviously, there is no map, most of the paths are blocked completely and there is a lot of minibosses around. After that level I decided to stop playing, because I noticed that there is literally no reason to continue. Levels are extremely boring, they can be describe in one word, like village, forest, castle or combinations of few like caves and camp. They are designed awfully and remind me more of The Surge (huge labirynths) than Dark Souls.

Inventory is extremely limited. You may think that 600 slots is a lot, but the game has sort of h'n's loot type, so you will probably fill it all in 5-6 missions. Then you will spend a lot of time selling/scraping or sacrificing it to free some space. There is also a storage, but you still need to browse through every single thing.

All things considered, I can't really recommend this game. It isn't THAT bad, it just seems more like a chore than an entertainment.

PS: I managed to clear Dark Souls III with DLCs in less than 40 hours. Here, after 30 hours, I have cleared 6 main missions from 19 or 20 (not even counting missions from DLC). Another terrible idea to make exhausting game (which begins to feel repetitive really quick) this long.

I absolutely love the customization. However, I hate Dark Souls style combat systems. They aren't fluid and they feel out of date. I'm just not interested in those style of games anymore. Everything in this is better than the first game though, so if you are looking for that type of game, I definitely prefer this to Dark Souls. Don't base it solely off my experience. It just isn't what I'm looking for.

Don't even really know where to begin with this one, besides saying that this game is amazing. Played it quite a bit, obviously and it just gets better. There is a staggering amount of content in this game, and a large portion of it doesn't unlock until you unlock Dream of the Nioh (NG+4) and it is a wild ride the whole time. Total blast, combat is amazing. Every weapon is fantastic! and by the end of the game you will be able to transform what the weapon scales with, so  you will be able to use any weapon you want potentially. 

So I guess I will start with possible cons. It is very difficult, not cheap but difficult. I don't consider this a con, but some people seem to. The sound cuts out annoyingly sometimes for a few seconds, but nothing too crazy. It is pretty well optimized now, but could be better. Another thing that might disappoint the Dark Souls fans is that its not a branching world from one zone to the other, its set up in levels on an overworld. Which was a bit of a bummer at first when I played the first Nioh, but it makes co op way more accessible.

Not many cons but I might think of some later. So Pros I guess now. Jeez, the combat for starters. Combos, upgrades, so many fantastic weapons in this game and they all level separately and have their own skill trees which is amazing, there are a few boring skills on the skill tree but they are huge enough to where it doesn't matter. Just in comparison to the first Nioh, the skill trees a HUGELY improved, in my humble opinion. So many reasons to play this game my goodness. So, enemy variety okay? Huge, its amazing. Yokai from Japanese mythology, its fascinating and their depiction in this game is incredible. So well designed. One of the big things that drew me to the first one, its even better here, more enemy variety. Bosses are awesome! different maps are awesome. Going back to how the  game is set up in levels instead of a giant branching world, a pro to this is that it makes co op a lot better cause you can choose specific missions, difficulties, if you want to play with a friend you can search either by friends on your friends list or by using a secret word. You can co op any mission in the entire game no matter where you are in the game, assuming you have beat the mission at least. But there is quick match co op or expedition. Expedition is more for a co op buddy and you both go through the game together, and you dont have to beat the mission first to be able to play it in expedition but you do need it unlocked of course. 

So here I will talk  about differences between this game and the original Nioh, at least that I remember. Dark realms. Okay, so Nioh 1 had Yokai realms, you know, the little circles that the Yokai put down that nerf your stamina regain. Dark realms are whole areas that are similar but not as punishing as standing in a yokai realm in the first game cause you at least still regain SOME stamina. New weapons, Fists, (my favorite my god) Splitstaff, Switch glave, hatchets, I think thats it thats new? If you didnt get the dlc for the  first game then you can add Odachi and tonfa to that list too.
Also, 2 of the new weapons scale with the magic stat, so if you are hardcore mage you have dedicated weapons which I found as being a HUGE improvement and in hindsight, a big missed opportunity in the first game but great that its here.

Nioh 2 is a challenging game, as to be expected from a "Souls Like" title.
The combat system builds very much on the original, but has added and changed enough features to make it feel fresh and rewarding.
The core mechanics of stance based combat, and various weapon skills has remained unchanged, meaning that anyone who played the first one can jump into this one fairly easily. 
Don't assume this makes this one easy though. A brand new "Burst" mechanic has been added to the game giving every enemy special attacks, dealing significant damage, if not countered using the new Burst counter mechanic. 
Additionally, a new resource of Amina was introduced, which is similar to the Ki used for standard attacks.
Anima is used to carry out burst counters and the new Yokai abilities. Unlike Ki, Amina is build up via attacking the enemies and only depletes when using associated skills.

All skill trees have had a fairly substantial overhaul, and have become a lot more manageable. Using weapons/ninjutsu/omnyo will now gain proficiency levels for that particular skill only and allows you to unlock skills for relevant trees quickly. All trees enjoy more skills/passives to choose from. A new Samurai tree now allows the unlocking of skill modifiers, such as stat based damage boosts or imbuing elemental effects.
The living weapon mode has been replaced in favour of a new shiftling mode, allowing the player to temporarily transform into a Yokai. This comes with its own skill tree and unique abilities.

Overall Nioh 2 is a welcomed addition to the franchise, telling an interesting story preceding William's Adventure's of Nioh 1, acting as a form of prequel. 
A number of characters and enemies make a return, though a plethora of new ones also make their introductions. The new weapons allow for even greater variety of combat, with some allowing for near infinite combos if carried out correctly.
If you are a fan of Nioh 1, or enjoy challenging games, give Nioh 2 a try. It is rewarding when you manage to beat the various levels and provides a high replay value through its various NG+ cycles.

Great game. This isn't a "souls like", it doesnt deserve to be called that. The amount of work and care put into this game is so evident in the gameplay that you cant call it a souls clone because it is so far beyond copying a formula. Team Ninja didn't even copy Nioh 1's formula, I'm not getting bored of playing the same game I just beat because Nioh 2 is different. They reworked quite a few systems and introduced some new ones and it makes for the most enjoyable, challenging, fair, balanced and variety filled combat I have ever experienced.

There is no META in this game, you get a huge variety of options and you chose what you like and it will be VIABLE. You dont have to be afraid you're playing wrong because if you can always beat a boss if you hone your skills with what you have. You dont need to grind, but you can and its an enjoyable experience. You dont need to use every tactic, because getting really good at the core few is all you need; then you can branch out and build what you use to your sense of style. Few games give you this much freedom while still being captivating.

You might wonder if you should play Nioh 1 first, and you can. The graphics hold up and the gameplay is just as good. But tbh it doesn't matter, these are two different games and you should play both, but if you want to play the more modern, developed and fully realized version; play this first, i havent even noticed any spoilers in this game for Nioh 1.

TLDR: If you want a challenging, fair and in depth game with amazing combat; look no further.

While infuriatingly difficult because Team Ninja, I love this game. The character creator is great (though the presets... could use some tweaking...), graphics are great, the new weapons are fun, and the story is entertaining. If I were to only be able to play one souls-like for the rest of my life, this would be it. And the game is LONG. I've gotten achievements for "finishing" the game and getting all collectables, and it still has more story missions for me to go through. Best $40 I've spent.

For those concerned about PVP, this isn't Dark Souls. There are no invasions. Closest thing is that you can touch player graves to summon them (red = duel with CPU, blue = team with CPU). There is an enemy type that is present in both Nioh games that is capable of summoning player CPUs from their graves, but you can prevent this by rushing the enemy before they can spawn the CPU in.

For framerate optimization concerns: the issues this game had at launch, from my experience and the experience of people with more outdated hardware than me, the framerate issues seem to be at least 90% fixed, as I don't recall running into stuttering or framerate spikes or drops.

-- Buyer's Guide Notes ---
Nioh 2 is a game you can spend a ton of time on. The whole package can last you many many hours with challenging main and side missions, new game+ adds, and a whole bevy of play styles to try out. If you're looking for a challenging game that can last you a ton of hours, Nioh 2 might be something you're looking for. 

My current play time is me doing most, if not all, the side missions up to my current point in the story. I think I'm near the end.

--- Content Review ---
Nioh 2 is a tough-ass game that is wholeheartedly taking pages from stuff like the Souls series, a touch of Diablo, and Ninja Gaiden, the last of which the team behind Nioh created. What I find spectacular is that it manages to scratch those gameplay itches in different ways while building off of the first Nioh to create something of its own. It's fast, deadly, and flashy. 

The yokai abilities are a great addition to the game, creating another piece of the combat that I enjoyed. When you find your window to do a yokai counter, you get to have some fun.  The individual yokai active abilities can be fun additions to your kit, whether for applying effects, giving you a strong option for different engagement ranges, or having a powerful move up your sleeve for when it's time to go for the kill.

There is a ton of customizing of your character and play style. There's plenty of weapon types to try, special moves for each weapon, three different yokai forms, a cadre of guardian spirits to pick, more gear than you could ever properly parse through, a wide selection of yokai abilities to equip, modifiers for special attacks, the list goes on. If you have fun just stacking up abilities, making your numbers huge, and having a ridiculous amount of options this game has that level of depth that you can choose to engage in.

The game looks largely the same as the first Nioh, but they've sharpened some stuff up, added some crazy looking new enemies and dialed up the supernatural flair. The aesthetics of the game are unified and work well. Graphically speaking, saying "its looks good" doesn't feel useful to write, but I like how the game looks. The game has run pretty well on my rig and I've run into very very minimal issues technically speaking.

Story-wise it generally feels a little more understandable than the first Nioh but it's still largely rooted in knowing stuff about the Sengoku period and that whole conflict, which I don't so I can feel some of it flying over my head sometimes. At the core of it is your character meeting some weirdos like you and growing your notoriety as warriors, dealing with a supernatural threat while fighting on the front lines of a war across Japan. It works well enough. It's serviceable with some neat things here and there. 

Overall, I'm into this game for its blistering fast and tough gameplay and I wholeheartedly recommend it on those merits. It's a fun game if you like to sweat a little for it. The character creator is cool, which honestly is more of a high point than I initially thought it would be.

Extremely underrated. I got the first Nioh on Epic Game Store for free recently and if it weren't for that, I likely wouldn't have ever played this game. As a huge Dark Souls/From Software fan, this game is basically Dark Souls mixed with Ninja Gaiden and Shadow of Mordor. It has way more depth and many more gameplay mechanics than any Dark Souls game.

-Atmostsphere/Story: The atmosphere, in general, is not as good as From Software games (still very good), but the story is actually coherent comparatively and it doesn't require you to do mental gymnastics in order to understand it. Nioh 1's story is practically non-existent, but Nioh 2's is much better and actually enjoyable for what it is.

-Gameplay: The gameplay is what this game does best. It is probably one of, if not, the best combat system I have ever used in a game like this. It's difficult, but rewarding and has so much depth and replayability that it is kinda crazy. Splitstaff is amazing

-Graphics: The game doesn't look amazing compared to other recent titles, but it still looks good and runs at over 100 fps for me. I like the art design. Lots of particle effects on screen at once can tank your FPS and make your game go into slow mo though which can be annoying.

-Sound: Nothing special or anything that I remember specifically. It's just your average game's sound. I do have issues with hearing static near certain objects/areas and I'm positive it's from the game. That is the only notable issue I have with it.

-Overall: Buy this game. It can take time to learn all the mechanics and get good at the game, but it is a very rewarding experience if you choose to stick with it. There is also a ridiculous amount of content (at the time of this review, I haven't even finished the first NG cycle)

I really wanted to like this game. I really did. I wanted to get into another souls like game. But I hate it. I really do. I hate it so much. Its dark souls in the worst way, its all the worst parts of dark souls 2 and all its unfair and cheap difficulty.
Before this just becomes a rant let me just say some positives: The game has incredible complexity like the kind you could get lost in for hours, every weapon has three stances to them and an entire skill tree. However that skill tree all seems to be blocked till you pass one mission which I didn't get to so the more fun parts of the skill tree were locked away. The melee combat is fun and very fluid and I especially love the punching gloves weapon. It has a really good character creator and that's it for the positives.
Firstly the story: I couldn't follow any of it. Maybe you need to play the first game but it was just a mess of terms I did not understand and proper nouns that just went over my head. I gave up trying to follow it almost immediately. Second is that the game starts in default Japanese audio. Sekiro did this too and it pisses me off because I'm dyslexic! Subtitles just do not work for me unless I'm pausing the thing constantly in order to make sure I read it right before continuing.
The passing is also really bad. The various sub-missions are all re-used from the main missions with a different starting point and some paths blocked off. Un-creative at best and lazy at worst and I don't even get the point for doing them beyond the extra loot and XP. Speaking off!
This game is so complex and has no idea how to properly convey that to the play beyond text walling them to death. Now, as said before, I'm dyslexic so just slapping me with walls and walls of text is beyond annoying but even then no one likes learning stuff like this. Front loading your game with information is a way to turn people off quickly. And the thing is you can have both. You can have a complex game with a good tutorial, its not impossible. But Nioh doesn't even try. It just throws you into the first level and says to skip the first enemy you see because its harder then the boss of that area. Which feels both lazy and a slap to new player who maybe aren't familiar with souls born type experiences.
Going off about that let me complain about the stupid little things the game does that annoys me. Why the ever loving FUCK! did you decide to call it ki instead of stamina? I was leveling up my stamina star for 5 hours wondering why I wasn't seeing any change only to realize it wasn't the right thing. Yeah that was probably explained at some point but since any menu at all brings out so much text and stats that you won't find what you're looking for on the first look. Also an important thing that you will need to know is a ki pulse to stop these things that stop your not stamina from recharging. Which I didn't, because it was in one of the many text pop ups in the first level that I was ignoring because who the fuck thought that was a good idea? Speaking of that! There is a whole thing about countering red flash attacks that I also missed because it was in another text pop up in the middle of the first boss fight! God damn it!
But one the biggest thing in this fucking game is that the level layouts are just beyond shit. Like I said at the beginning it is dark souls 2's worst qualities. Hidden traps, enemy placement that just feels unfair a lot of the time and long treks between checkpoints. Some of the early levels had locked doors or ladders that were pulled up that you could use for shortcuts but in the soaring region it felt like it had none. Which was compounded by the fact the levels were very confusing and I often got lost. But I can forgive the occasional "Oh look an item in the open, better grab it. Oops! Looks like we hid an enemy where they can jump down and grab you!" but I swear it was every fucking item by the Soaring region. There's a part before fighting a strong mini-boss enemy with a stronger then normal enemy close by and they hid a little fucking enemy up top that jumps down on you if you forget to take them out before getting close. Which you are bound to forget doing the segment over. All of this wouldn't be AS bad if it wasn't for the worst part of the fucking game:
Healing items are a limited consumable. You can just up and run out of them. And in a game this trial and error that is a death sentence. The only way I found to reliably get more healing items is to make an offering of all the equipment you're not using at the shrine and hope that it blesses you with healing items. There is probably a better way but as stated before the text wall tutorials did not help me learn anything!

Since everyone loves mentioning Dark Souls in those reviews, I'll start off by saying I don't like anything about Dark Souls, from the murky aesthetic of the game(s), to some of the clunky combat and the storyline that's just doom and gloom for everyone involved. That being said, I think the game has enough elements that differentiates it and puts it on an entirely new level to Dark Souls.
[b]PROS[/b]: 
[list]
[*]Nioh 2 feels like a title that encourages co-op, so it's fun to play with your significant other or with a couple of buddies, if a multiplayer experience is what you're looking for. There are thankfully no PvP modes, so you don't have to worry about that (and if you wanted one, too bad, I guess).
[*]The customization in this game is amazing and you are allowed to modify the appearance of your character whenever you want, as long as you have access to your hut. As well, you can refashion weapons and armor. So if there's anything you're not a fan of visually but you really like the stats of, you can always change its appearance with another piece of armor that you own.
[*]A lot of weapons to choose from and a lot of abilities to adapt your playstyle to be whatever you want it to be. You can walk the path of the ninja or become an onmyoji. Or both. After you've done enough grinding, of course.
[*]Tutorials that you can revisit. The combat is difficult at first, but you can get the hang of it with enough practice. Personally, it took me a while to get used to the yokai shifting (transformation) mechanic and its respective combos, specifically countering and grappling at the perfect moment.
[/list]
[b]CONS[/b]: 
[list]
[*]The camera tracking/adjusting can be annoying during some battles (e.g. Kamaitachi) where the enemy blitzes from one side to the other or straight up flies out of your range.
[*]The combined combat elements might be too much to take in at once.
[/list]
_____
Over all, if you go into the game expecting it to be challenging, visually appealing, with compelling characters and a compelling storyline with some comedy sprinkled on top, then you will not be disappointed.

Nioh 2 is a clear improvement over the first game in most ways. Combat is more fun and varied overall (Devil trigger >>> shiny sword), and this applies to levels and bosses as well which are generally quite a bit better than previously. This applies to the story also, they actually managed to make that more compelling through a more personal connection with the main cast. This is quite ironic, considering the 1st game had a named character who spoke while this time around you make your own little silent samurai. The last few missions offer something that I don't think Nioh 1 ever fully achieved, battles where both gameplay and narrative come together to form a really satisfying whole (especially the final boss, which is a highlight for this series). 

It also feels like the game has more than 3 music tracks now, unlike in the last game. I was actually a bit surprised by the soundtrack being so solid overall, because the music in the 1st really wasn't that memorable to me. There are a few standouts here that really elevate the scenes in which they're used. 

On a somewhat similar note, the 1st game felt really front-loaded, and started to get stale during the 2nd half, while in this game I'd argue that the opposite might be the case. There are still some low points, but I felt that the more varied levels kept things fresh enough. Nioh 2 is also pretty massive regarding content. An argument can be made that there might even be too much content, because a good chunk of it feels REALLY samey, but that's up for debate. I'm personally still not a big fan of the loot system, but I'll doubt that changes any time soon. At least the new weapons are fun, but I can see the loot an inventory management push some people away from this game. 

If you enjoy Soulslike-games, you should definitely give this a go. However,  If you played the first Nioh and didn't enjoy it, I have a hard time seeing this game change your mind. Still, I'd say that it's easily among the better Soulslikes, especially if you don't count the ones made by Fromsoft themselves.
It's a Souls-like game that's actually difficult with a lot of depth to combat and gearing.

EDIT: Added thoughts after clearing the game once.

Although Nioh 2 is a Soulslike at its core, rehashing many mechanics familiar to players of the genre, Nioh 2 innovates and manages successfully to breathe new life into the field. 

Set in feudal Japan, Nioh 2 starts the protagonist off as a warrior-for-hire, banking on their half-human-half-yokai skills to make a living on the edge of society. A coincidental meeting with an unassuming client throws the protagonist head-first into the war effort, and sets the stage for an unlikely tale of an mercenary-turned-samurai, fighting for the future of Japan, and of the human and yokai that live within it.

Nioh 2's story and stages are set within the caricature of the struggle to unify Japan, battles and all. This backdrop gave the development team the opportunity to design a variety of stages, from midday fortress sieges to late-night village infiltrations, all part of the overarching tale. Many real historical figures and battles are re-enacted, but there is a distinct mystical twist, with the incorporation of many yokai of folklore into the setting, lending the story a flourish all its own.

The gameplay very much resembles a Soulslike. For the uninitiated, Soulslikes are games borne out of the success of the Dark Souls series of games developed by From Software. Infamous for their steep learning curve and punishing gameplay, Soulslikes expect you to die, and to die a lot. But Soulslikes also expect you to learn from mistakes and overcome the challenges that they present to you. After all, Soulslikes trade in the rush from overcoming adversity, and overcome you shall, if you put in the effort. That doesn't mean that the
game is unfair, or excessively hard; far from it. Nioh 2 sets the expectation that you're willing to learn from defeat and experiment. When you get how the game is meant to be played, everything clicks, and the game becomes a challenge that you can grapple with and work to solve. The hard part is getting past the initial
steep curve.

Nioh 2, while sticking to the core of what makes a game a Soulslike, adds its own set of twists to the format. Ki pulses that can be performed after attacks at the right times to regain stamina add a defined rhythm and deepen swordplay. Would you Ki pulse at the right time to regain the maximum amount of stamina in order to maintain tip-top condition for the assault to come, or Ki pulse early in anticipation of an upcoming quick jab? The interplay between safety and greed is a welcome addition that adds depth to the stamina-based gameplay of a Soulslike. Furthermore, as a half-yokai, you get the ability to use the abilities of the yokai you befriend, ranging from simple dodges and parries to the signature ability of yokais, and even full-body transformations and assorted techniques. The yokai abilities flip the traditional dynamic of a Soulslike game, offering powerful abilities (tied to a resource meter of its own) that you can use to beat down enemies in an all-new yokai fashion.

In conclusion, Nioh 2 is a familiar-yet-unique package that is definitely worth getting into, if you're already a fan of the Soulslike genre, or if you like Japanese history and folklore.

Edit: Update, at between 590-600 hours, I have completed all 30 floors of depths. This game is indeed a masterpiece.

[i]As of this review, I have clocked over 350 hours* and just completed ALL achievements for this game on steam.
*This was made possible as part of my unemployment break in May and June, and I have not grind myself to death in underworld nor the depths.[/i]

Nioh 2 is a souls-like game (but not actually souls) 3rd person action game taking place in Feudal Japan (Sengoku Period, 1550-1620) where players are basically assured death for bad decisions, bad mistakes, bad techniques, and... well, bad luck*. 
*See Fuki, Hellish Hags, skeleton warrior memes, and slippery cliff edges in laggy multiplayer games.

[u][b]The goal of this game is to make the manliest or prettiest hero and kill hostile demons while figuring out the best approach and available equipment to killing them.[/b][/u]

Game Play:
The best part of this game is character customization. No, seriously, it's the best I have ever seen from a console based game and r/glamurai has enough threads to prove it.


There is a variety of weapons to choose from ranging from the iconic katana to the exotic ninja kusarigama, each with 3 stances (High, Mid Low) with the weapon's innate strength and weaknesses.

On top of the complicated weapons and combat styles, there are also 3 types of armor (Light, Medium, and Heavy) with possibly their own hidden stats* and vaguely defined letter grades (from C to AAA)**.

[i]*SUPPOSEDLY, according to an old thread on reddit, Full light armor offers 8% damage reduction, full medium offers 15%, and full heavy offers a whopping 25% BEFORE the raw defense is used to calculate damage taken by the player.[/i]

[i]*Levels play a huge hidden role in my own experience. If you are getting wrecked in normal mode on certain missions, go back to it later when you are at least 20 levels over the recommended level - you will notice you stagger a lot less and the enemies are more easily staggered (first fight against Honda Tadakatsu and Yasuke the obsidian samurai).[/i]

[i]**Nioh 2 does not clearly specify what stats stacks nor how damage is calculated... So you end up with a good number of autistic players and tryhards trying to "proof" something (thankfully, because I can't do that and I cherry pick what fits how I play from their guides).[/i]

Armor weight is a thing in this game, and it is best to keep armor weight no worse than "B" agility (< 70%) otherwise dodging and running will be painfully difficult for the player.

Unlike souls game, blocking (and deciding when to block) is a valid defense technique, however, this is further made complicated by a stat called "Toughness" (again, ranging from letters AA to F, anything worse than "B" means blocking an attack will take away far more stamina).

Suffice to say, the combat stats calculation is opaque and deep enough to keep people guessing and experiment a variety of character builds*.

[i]*This game allows you to respec your character after advancing enough, so don't worry about creating new characters.[/i]

tl;dr

1. Make waifu. 
2. ? (git gud, get gear)
3a. Slay demons. 
3b. If slaying demon fails, git gud and try again.

The co-op is much better than Nioh 1, can play with 2 other people through the entire game and don't have to start all over when you die. (shrine checkpoints work like they do in single player). The character customization was a nice thing to add. The skill tree is more polished with better navigation, new enemies, new abilities to existing yokai. 10/10.

This game might be great, for all I know, but it is absolutely not ready for steam release. First I open the game and find the settings menu is all in Japanese (even thought the main menu is in English. I managed after some googling to find out which was the correct option to change this, but not a great start (4th option starting from bottom on mine, in case you have the same issue).

Then on to the main problem so far. The controls are an abomination. 'Interact' is mapped to 'B' on XBOX controller, and dodge is on 'A' - the exact opposite to what you would expect for a western release. This would be fine, but despite the fact you can customise most other controls, this one is greyed out and you aren't allowed to change it for... no reason at all? It's bonkers.

I manged to use a program called ReWasd to create a virtual controller which rebinds buttons to something sane, and it just about works, apart from in certain text based menus during play. So I still have to swap to mouse to click anything in a text menu. I can't figure out if this is because the game actually mixes up which button is for which sometimes or what, but it's a total mess.

And in the 45 minutes it took to get this working it had already crashed once. 

I haven't even got far enough yet to see if I'll have the same graphical and other crashing issues others here have had.

I'm going to stick with it for now, having put so much effort into making the controls work, but I ought to refund it. if you're in any doubt I strongly recommend you wait until these issues are patched or it's on a steep sale. 

The game might well be fantastic, but from a technical point of view this steam release is absolute garbage so far.

UPDATE: I've managed to get the controls working in a way that lets me play this without fighting a decade of muscle memory. I used a third party program to set up one virtual controller profile that has normal controller input, a second profile that swaps A and B, and a keyboard button to swap between them. I use the normal profile for interacting with menus, and then the 'swapped' profile for playing the game. It sounds complicated but is actually very simple to use and makes it playable for me.

Has a solid combat system, but is otherwise either shallow or cheaply designed in numerous parts.


This really isn't Nioh Two because a significant amount of the game is just Nioh One being resold. Players can create their own monotonously silent protagonist with a relatively decent character creator, but that protagonist is basically a reskin of the one from the previous game. All their basic animations seem to be the same, all the weapons from the previous game reappear with the exact same combat animations and relatively identical skill trees. There's a couple new weapons at least, but Magic and Ninjustu are also largely the same too. Several bosses and areas from the first game are reused, many if not most of the regular enemies are recycled as well. 

They even ripped bosses from the first game into the DLC for this one. When that DLC was released it was sold for ten dollars, and maybe half the bosses in each ten dollar DLC in Nioh Two are literally just bosses from Nioh One being reused.

The combat is mostly the same as it was before. Mainly since this looks to be the exact same code. It's a solid combat system with emphasis on punishing players for being too reckless, rewarding stamina management and strategically targeting enemy weaknesses. Until players reach the point where they've figured out how to juggle most enemies with the same effortless attack sequence over and over; at which point this turns into a thoughtless button masher. Then after awhile the game introduces new enemies which seemingly can't be juggled and the combat becomes divided between enemies that players actually have to fight; and enemies players can just button mash.

Although a fair amount of the bosses aren't very interesting they do manage to present a distinct threat. But the greatest threat to players is generally just grapple attacks. The game desperately depends on grapple attacks to defeat the player or at least rip off large chunks of their health. Literally every enemy has a grapple attack just about, some have multiple. Most enemy grapples will lock onto the player exactly, requiring players to dodge at the absolute last second to avoid losing two thirds or all of their health to said grapple. Almost every enemy has a grapple, players cannot avoid the grapple without dodging at the exact right moment and each grapple has a completely different timing that must be learned. 

So players are relentlessly punished throughout the entire course of this game by losing large chunks or all of their health to grapples that require several instances of getting grappled to learn the timing to maybe avoid it. Players must go through this process with almost every enemy and boss, some of which are only a threat because of their grapple. Especially when they can lunge across a room, run in circles around the player until they finally get the grab, or can seamlessly integrate the grapple into their attack combinations.

The story in this game is an incoherent mess of disjointed cutscenes, bland characters, conflicts that beg no investment from the player, story events that make no sense, pointless backstory dumps and the introduction of new story entities with absolutely no explanation at all. The story is based around a fictitious distortion of human history because the writers were too uncreative to come up with their own story. Pathetic and grotesque to use actual human wars that resulted in countless instances of death and suffering as the plot for your wretched piece of entertainment you call a video game. 

Yet worse still is the propagandic way the story depicts certain human groups in those wars as being the reprehensible antagonists who were corrupted by demon crystals, while other human groups are presented as the protagonists trying to stop this fictitious corruption. The writing practically trips over itself trying to glorify certain humans in particular and the protagonist spends a significant portion of the story basically being the personal tool for a murderous dictator.

Consequently the entire game is bent around trying to stay within the confines of its pseudo human history basis. Players relentlessly travel through similar looking villages, woods and battlefields fighting the same generic human and demon enemies for no particularly coherent reason. It's only in the DLC where the game locations actually start to become somewhat interesting and unique, right around the time where they introduce [spoiler]time travel[/spoiler] to the plot and now it's actually just about impossible to tell what the story is about anymore.

Much of the player's time is otherwise spent picking up useless items, the game is cluttered with numerous consumables that players will likely never use and perpetual loot drops that need to be dealt with. Between Magic, Ninjutsu and generic items the game probably has over sixty types of consumables yet players only have eight default quick slots. Several of which will already be used up for vital items like the basic healing consumable. There are a ridiculous amount of micro statistics attached to every piece of gear too; making later game optimization tedious while various important elements of those statistics aren't even properly explained to the player at all.

Even the multiplayer is an atrocious mess on its own. The game hasn't been balanced around it at all. There's so many particle effects and moving shapes at a given time that combat becomes incoherent button spamming, which is reinforced by how easily players can stunlock and mash down enemies together. Enemy models randomly desync causing them to teleport around, status effects desync and don't show the proper amount left which makes keeping track of status application on enemies basically impossible. Half the time the game won't even let players enter a lobby and sometimes the game will become hardlocked post mission.


Boring locations, intensely recycled content, atrocious story, overbearing loot system, terrible multiplayer implementation and much of the difficulty actually just stems from all the grapple attacks. Otherwise the combat is decent if players want absolutely nothing else from the game besides a decent combat system; although it is mostly recycled from the previous one.

Veteran Dark Souls player here. Because you have to be to write reviews on games like these right?

Anyways I am two hours in at the time of writing this so there's no getting that $50.00 back now... 
So here are the important things I know [so far]:

*Great character creation. Yes. You can make those milk missiles as big and as anime as you want.
*Combat is more action oriented then Dark Souls. You use stamina for your actions but everything replenishes fast. Attacks are also fast. You WONT be asking yourself "Is now a good time to swing?" too much.
*The world is not open. You pick a place on the map and start your mission.

I will edit this as time goes by lord willing. And also as I check out the co-op.

UPDATE:

Alright. I'm currently 16 hours in and well...... The game is pretty badass! Again, as a Dark Souls main with +1000 hours in just DS3 alone; this review is mainly for fellow undead.

So, if you like the genre go ahead and buy it. You may be cringing for the first few hours but once you get into things trust me, You'll be ok until Elden Ring.

FEATURES:

‚Ä¢ You enter levels by selecting them on the overworld map. But these levels are NOT small, and are NOT empty by any means. You will enjoy your time exploring and fighting and looting. Which more than makes up for the lack of "true" open-world gameplay.

‚Ä¢ There are plenty of skill trees to customize your play-style. An example would be unlocking a guard breaking kick after a quick attack, OR unlocking a back-step slash after your quick attack. Leap over your foes with your spear, OR stab them in the gut and re-position them. And yes, there are plenty of ways to parry.

‚Ä¢ Co-op is fine. You go to the shrine (bonfire) and use sake cups to open your current mission to any players who might be standing by. There are NO invasions. If you die, then it will be a CPU killing you. This, in my opinion, is the ONLY thing missing from this experience.

‚Ä¢ Appearance, Skills, Weapons, and Powers can all be reallocated with ease. So no multiple saves and characters required.

All in all: It's a good, well worked on game. Play it and try for yourself.

This game sits directly in between Diablo 3 and Dark Souls, and is as high quality as either of them. If you like these games, you would likely enjoy Nioh 2. If you do not like these games, you might not like Nioh 2.

It has one of the best melee combat systems of any game period. The weapons vary in difficulty and skill cap so there is a little something for everyone. The magic and ninjutsu can stand on its own or complement any build. 

It is a direct imrpovement over nioh 1, with excellent character customization that lets you make a beautiful PC or a hilarious abomination. 

Additionally, this is one of the best optimized games released in the last few years. I have a fairly old PC that struggles to run things like RDR2 or Fallout 4, but I have had no issues running this game and have been surprised at how fast its loads and exits. 

The ONE complaint I have is that I wish there was over-world exploration like Dark Souls. The levels are complex and amazing to explore, secret paths and hidden shortcuts are abundant. But you have to enter from a level selector which is ~fine~ but I wish it could be something more. Basically a non-issue. 

You should definitely play this game, insta-buy if it goes on sale.

+ Lots of loot

- Like many ARPGs, the sense of tension and danger quickly disappears once your build comes online and you start blowing through all but the toughest enemies.

[h1]Nioh 2 might be one of the worst and most frustrating games I've ever played.[/h1]

Beneath some great gameplay mechanics is a slew of issues. Terrible game-balance, a very lacking storyline, dull and uninspired levels, ugly armor and weapon pieces, countless glitches and bugs, flickering on menus that make the game unplayable, frame drops out of nowhere that tank it from a smooth 60 to unplayable 20, pathing issues, idiotic AI issues, inconsistent and poorly designed menus, auto lock issues that sometimes prevent you from locking onto distant enemies or moving enemies and sometimes auto locks to the wrong one, horrendous camera especially when backed into a wall, unbalanced boss designs that swing gameplay from laughably easy to frustratingly difficult, slippery movement, incomplete keyboard prompts, inconsistent and quirky menu and setting navigations, inconsistent grappling/final blow prompts which don't register, tracking issues from the enemies that make their move timing arbitrary and inconsistent, inconsistent enemy detection, invisible walls that block ranged attacks, incessant farming and veiled "variety", the list goes on and on.

Noticing a trend here in criticism? The name is [b]INCONSISTENCY[/b]. With this kind of combat, especially at NG+ cycles, you should not be dealing with game breaking issues that make deaths unfair and unbalanced. Imagine reducing someone to zero ki and they just keep on swinging as if they're at full energy, laughable. At the core is a good game in concept, but the execution is just utterly sloppy and awful. The developers have no idea how to create a balanced and sensible game.

When the NG+ cycles increase in difficulty, the gameplay just becomes a loop of "farm rare items", "break enemy ki", and "don't get hit or you'll die in 1 or 2 hits". It's not satisfying or interesting, it's dull and frustrating. Artificial difficulty that doesn't challenge the player but instead find ways to cheese the mechanics and exploit the game.

If Team Ninja thinks this is a well done completed project, then they should be ashamed. People say this game is "underrated". It's not underrated, it has far too many issues to deserve the praise that others keep giving it. Unless you want an incomplete and buggy mess,

This is the best of the Souls-like genre... 
with a caveat. 
The highly complex sophisticated combat system is both the game's greatest strength and greatest weakness. If you absolutely despise the fighting mechanics found in the Ninja Gaiden series then this game is not for you. While it is possible to exploit enemy patterns to a limited extent, the AI is far more aggressive as well as adaptive; so unlike other Souls-like games,  "cheesing" a battle here will always end in failure. You have to learn and use all available options in order to be successful, especially in later areas where mistakes are brutally (and often fatally) punished.
With that out of the way, let's dive in.
While Code Vein and the Surge series come very close with their enjoyable gameplay mechanics, Nioh 2 simply adds so much refinement as well as polish that it is a superior game even to Nioh 1.
The fighting system is vastly improved with additional mechanics such as the Yokai Shift, new weapons to experiment with and a greatly expanded ability system.
The immensely-expanded character skill tree means no two characters will be the same. Do you want to be a specialist or be versatile in several disciplines? The choice is yours and that's certainly a positive improvement.
You are now finally able to customize accessory items (highly requested from fans) along with the sheer amount of customization options (weapons, armor, equipment) is mind-boggling.
That "carrot-on-the-stick" cycle is alive and well. Players will be spending many enjoyable hours finding equipment with just that "right" trait to suit your ensemble.
Do you need to play Nioh 1 to enjoy Nioh 2? 
Not really. 
You'll actually be spoilt by the new gameplay mechanics as well as the polished refinement compared to Nioh 1.
In conclusion, arguments can be made as to why The Surge 2 or Code Vein could be the best Souls-like but to me with its incredible addictive gameplay along with numerous positive improvements, Nioh 2 "Benevolently Rules"  the genre.

[h1]Shorter: [/h1]
Nioh 2 is an action RPG looter with a stamina-based melee-focused combat system set in a historical fantasy setting.

[h2]Frequently Asked Questions or Concerns[/h2]
[list][*]You can co-op with two other players through nearly every mission, though some scenes you may have to play/watch solo, then rejoin your friends after. 
[*]Nioh 2 story-wise is about 95% prequel to Nioh 1, and 5% sequel, so you can play this without Nioh 1. Though story is not this game's strong point.
[*]In my opinion, the control scheme may have a short learning curve with a gamepad. You can play with keyboard and mouse, but you'll probably need to change the controls to your liking instead of using the defaults. 
[*]The game difficulty is punishing. Co-op can DRAMATICALLY make the game easier. (i.e. clearing a mission or boss on the 1st or 2nd try instead of 10~20 tries)
[*]No official PvP and does not appear to be plans to add at the time of this review
[*]Backup your save and/or if your save doesn't load, try to rename your BACKUP.BIN to SAVEDATA.bin in the Documents \ KoeiTecmo \ Nioh2 \ SaveData \ xx \ SaveData00 folder (or the location of your save file)
[*]Turning off DLSS may resolve some crashing and graphic issues at the time of this review
[/list]

[h1]Longer:[/h1]
[h2]What I Liked[/h2]
[list][*] Character creation's facial options being complex enough to make Hiroyuki Sanada, Emilia Clarke, that Geralt fella from that there Witcher game, and even Kanye West
[*] Historical feudal fantasy setting in Japan and unlocking lore for various characters and monsters
[*] Beautiful and fitting atmospheric music - with the second boss track making you bust into that old Xmen cartoon title theme
[*] A very deep stamina-based rhythmic combat system filled with counters, re-positioning, parries, stance switching, weapon switching, timed guards, dodges, status effects, combos, environmental hazards, projectiles, ninjutsu, and magic talismans (magic)
[*] The myriad of build possibilities as you progress deeper into the game from the guardian spirit that determines one of three burst counters and transformations you can do, to enemy abilities that you can equip and use, to the randomized gear you might find with different gear sets with a great deal of passives you can modify at the blacksmith, to the multiplayer clan you choose for bonuses, to your stat point allocations, and others - time consuming, but possibilities are there
[/list]

[h2]What I Didn't Like As Much[/h2]
[list][*]The protagonist motivation, a few holes in the story, and story pacing were not as good for me. I'm not sure what it would be like if someone weren't as familiar with events of the Sengoku Jidai or story of Japan's Three Unifiers, but I suspect it would be harder to follow
[*]A large amount of the game's possibilities do not open up until you have completed the game several times to unlock Dream of the Nioh or sometimes referred to as NG+4 / New Game +4
[*]Some technical issues that I haven't revisited since uninstalling the game such as text disappearing at the map screen, infinite loading screens, a stage with light and fog being exceptionally difficult to see unless some graphic settings are turned off, game crashes that sometimes corrupted the Steam download manifest or a save
[*]Never knowing what a legitimate leaderboard looks like and in populated clans, never being able to access the clan-unique tea set that comes with being among the top contributing clan members (this is a 5th / extra tea set that may increase luck on loot drops, money gained, and/or chance to find more tea sets)[/list]

And probably some other things that I can't think of at the moment.

Side Note: You may hear the real game doesn't start until the Depths (beat the game four times, traverse through 100+ floors) or endgame Scrolls. Or you may hear that the first playthrough is just a tutorial for the real game and to keep playing to get to the fun stuff. IF you are not enjoying yourself by the time you complete New Game or by the time of the third region, I honestly cannot recommend continuing to play the game further.

This game is fantastic. The combat is rich and complex, and extremely customizable. There are 8 different melee weapon types that all perform uniquely from one another. Every melee weapon has three stances (Low, Mid, High), and also light and heavy attacks.
The story is engaging and interesting, with characters from real-world history.
The amount of content is sure to last you a long time. Take me for example: at the time of writing this review, I have 317 hours played. I just yesterday unlocked a new feature that I did not have access to before. Because of this, the replayability factor is high. New game difficulties (think NG+ from Dark Souls) each give you something new, either a new rarity level of gear, or new missions, or an entirely new challenge.
This game is 100% worth your money if you want a (semi) historically accurate, Dark Souls-ish, Mortal Kombat-like combat system, just plain fun game.

Well with me exposing that I'm trash, I really like this game. There's co-op available, AI co-op if you have the materials, you can call for back-up and see if any players will respond do your request, or create a lobby for a friend to join up to 3 people maximum including yourself. The combat mechanics is awesome, you get cool ability trees into many different weapon types. There's this thing you could do to gain back a portion of your stamina by timing a stance change (upper, middle, lower stances) allowing you to extend your combo more or to back when an enemy is about to attack. You also have access to up to 3 amazing yokai transformations.

Some small details I really liked is that your weapon could get bloodied and when you sheath it your character shakes the blood off then sheath the weapon.

A few big negative is weapon loot management; it's all over the place. The controls for PC is a bit unsatisfying.

Overall a 9/10 game, even though it's difficult for me to actually get anywhere near NG+ where the game truly starts.

Holy SHIT this game is good.  The first thing I want to draw attention to is the customization.  This game takes the term "Fashion Souls" to a whole new level, the amount of outfits that look amazing, even mix-and-matched are unreal.  The character creation is great too, although one gripe that I had was that most armors in the game make any changes to the Bust slider on female characters effectively useless, as the bust is almost always hidden.

Now, onto the gameplay, it's fuckin' hard.  That being said, it justifies it's difficulty by departing from the enemy-filled open world that most Souls-like games include, and instead turning to shorter levels with a fixed length.  The combat is smooth and feels amazing, though it requires constant usage of the Ki Pulse mechanic, which can get somewhat annoying as you start to progress further into the game, but it's more of a minor annoyance in the back of your head than a game-breaking annoyance you can't get past.  Speaking of Combat, the amount of weapons in the game is pretty good, you've got Katanas, you've got Nodachis, you've got Tonfas, you've got Spears, all sorts of weapons to choose from, each with their own unique moveset and fighting style.

There are certain gripes that I have, such as the Ogre's Parry being the best out of all the Yokai Form parries, the stupidity of the AI summons and the inability to "mimic check" chests (i.e. hit them with your sword) as the mimic that appears in the later levels is somehow immune to any and all damage until you attempt to open the chest, at which point YOU take damage and the mimic becomes an exact copy of you with your moveset and abilities, which you then have to fight in order to receive it's loot.  However, in my opinion, the pros far outweigh the cons, and I definitely see myself playing this for quite some time.

Oh, and you can play it in Coop mode, like, full-on hosted lobbies for coop play.

So, all in all, if you are someone who relishes a challenge, and who lives for the thrill of a difficult fight, pick this game up, I HIGHLY doubt you'll regret it.  Oh, and bring a friend, it just makes the game that much more fun~

Picked up during Steam Sale for my wife and myself, though the game supports online co-op for up to 3 players. 

Personally, I have played demon souls as well as dark souls 1-3 (finished 1-3). I have also played nioh 1.   While the difficulty to newcomers to these types of games may seem similar, Nioh's combat is different under the hood vs Dark souls.  Blocking serves a purpose, as does knowing when to switch stances, dodge, or counter.  

This may sound obvious but anyone who has played both nioh and dark souls will be able to tell you that there are differences which affect the feel of how combat flows.  People looking to dodge/iframe through everything may initially be in for more pain at the start, as there are certain habits you may have to break in order to prevent needless deaths.

As for my wife's experience/background?  She has never touched a souls-like.  She likes games like the Witcher 2 & 3 (on normal).
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Below are excerpts of us during first 10 hours of coop and plenty of deaths

*after getting wrecked on first level*

Me: "...Damn the combat mechanics  sure are a lot to take in at the start."

Wife:  "Holy  ****ing sh**?!"  and "...What? What!? ......WHAT!???? OH F*** THAT BULL SH**" and "WHY WOULD ANYONE DO THIS TO THEMSELVES?" and "WHO THE HELL LIKES FEELING LIKE THIS?"  

(Despite initial frustrations she did not give up)

~~~~~Skip ahead to 40+ hours~~~~~~

Me: *Gets downed*  "Ugh pushed ahead too far and had no Ki to block..."

Wife:  I've noticed you tend to get one, two, or three shot more than me...Maybe try hanging back near/behind me.

Me:  *laughs & smiles*


~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
Personal Opinions + Closing Remarks
~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Graphics:  (Ran on 1080) Great if not outright excellent.  Recommend turning visual effects to low to aid in seeing red flashes (burst counter indicator) or white/black clouds indicating incoming non-block-able grab.

Sound: Above average (audio queues are reliable enough to hear when you should counter or dodge).  If you move cautiously through new levels, certain enemies will give themselves away through ambient noises they make before you engage them.  That being said, some enemies are quiet.  If panning to jump in, I strongly advise that you do not forget to check the ceilings/look up.

Music:  Thematically appropriate.  Forgettable a majority of the time but occasionally great during boss fights and cinematic cut-scenes.

Story:  Average**  There is a narrative but the base game is made for a demographic that has a basic understanding of Japanese history as it applies to the japanese civil warring states period (Sengoku Jidai).  

While the significant characters are historically based, the 'world' of nioh combines historical events and locations with Japanese folklore & mysticism.  A casual gamer jumping in will likely not be able to follow the story or understand major events without reading bio-blurbs in between missions acessable via menus.  A story is there but it will not be spoon fed to you.

Game Loop/Type:  Diablos/Borderlands loot, Souls-like mechanic of die/learn/retry with 2 consecutive death = losing collected exp, Monster Hunter World weapon depth depending on weapon (as well as ability to prep tactically for situations with a plethora of items you can custom bind to up to 8 shortcuts), and Devil May Cry-esque twitch action combat (no direct way to jump however). The games depth and skills become apparent especially mid to late game after you unlock combos, skills, and even hidden weapon skills for more on the fly tactical combat options. 

Online co-op functions differently than single-player.  In pre made groups of 2 or 3, you play in 'expedition' mode.  Your group has shared life gauge.  Party members can revive downed members to avoid penalties or the downed player can choose to self rez.  If bar is depleted then mission ends BUT while party loses the experience accrued up to that point, you can choose to continue from last checkpoint.  Another heads up, Expedition tends to have more enemies than single-player and have higher pools of HP and feel like they do slightly more damage.  

Biggest key difference from single player  is that use of shrines (checkpoints) saves progress and enemies DON'T respawn BUT your consumables are NOT replenished for any use of the shrine after its initial use.  For certain Levels this can make the difference for a boss fight being easy or hard for the group depending on shrine placement.  Don't be afraid to use items/spells in co-op but don't spam them either.  

**NOTE:  If looking to play co-op from the beginning, use the item 'Divine branch' to exit the first level and access the world map.  Have other friendly players do the same.  Have host/leader access the starting point >> Tori Gate >> expedition >> create room WITHOUT conditions and set criteria to 'friends' and choose number of open slots.  Make sure your friends have been added to steam.  Have them go to starting point >> tori gate>> search for rooms using friends criteria and join the host room. 
 

Highly replay value for those interested.  Recommend doing new game + at least once if you are the type who likes to theory craft about builds.

Bugs:  Collectively experienced 1 or 2 over first 80 hours co-op (Both experienced by my wife).  1 was a crash to desktop.  The other was a glitch in a cut-scene and perma-blackscreen requiring forced restart and repeating the mission (for her).



Overall:  Fun single-player/ Online coop distraction during the crazy times we currently live in.

If you decide through baggy, sunken Souls-veteran eyes that this is something you want to try, a couple of helpful tips:
1. This game *is* hard. I know that's to be expected, but sometimes you get a game that says "Souls-like" and all they mean is the respawn system, etc. is in play.
2. This game is not hard like Dark Souls hard. Yes, you'll want to fight a single enemy at a time if you can help it. But this game is more about stamina management and building up an arsenal of useful items in your bag of tricks. This can include special moves that you unlock (THROUGH MANDATORY TUTORIALS, FUCK WHOEVER THOUGHT OF THAT), items and combo moves. Be aggressive, be kind of cheap (shoot people in the head with a gun, then fight them) - the game encourages it.
3. Its an overwhelming system. Every weapon style (fists, magic staves, kurangiamgiaigndjnadj, little sword, big sword, axe, hatchets, anime scythe, double swords, spear, etc.) has like 50 elements you can unlock, and come with three separate stances with different moves, combos, etc. Your stats directly impact the class of weapons, so your build is married to a kind of weapon. I highly recommend the regular old katana with middle stance. You can do literally everything this way, but key to this - high stance does the most damage but uses up the most ki (stamina), low stance uses the least ki but is the weakest, you can guess on middle.
4. Ki (aka Stamina for the rest of the gaming universe) is the single most important thing in the game. You need Ki to attack, if you run out you can't move and can be hit with an attack that will likely immediately kill you (vice versa, you can do a powerful attack against enemies), and without ki your enemies get stunlocked.

So yup

Obviously inspired by the Souls series in the relatively sedate but high-stakes combat pacing and soul retrieval mechanics, Nioh 2 is its own worthy title with what it brings to the table.

This is, first and foremost, a single player game. Without a dedicated PvP arena, balance decisions are primarily driven by PvE considerations. That frees a HECK of a lot of design space and allows things to be fun which players would complain about if they were allowed to use them on each-other. Don't get me wrong -- I love PvP games, but including PvP in a game like this is a huge decision for that reason. It means playing a completely different balance game, frequently at the expense of the PvE crowd. But I digress. Nioh 2 didn't.

Nioh 2 has a huge number of maps, some of which are recycled for use for sidequests. This is mostly fine. The world is not one huge interconnected space as you see in the FromSoft games, but the total space is still quite large. It's mature, but it's not unrepentantly bleak and existentially dreadful. It's a hodge-podge of Japanese folklore and history. The story is passable.

There is a large set of very developed weapons (think the Monster Hunter series) rather than an absolutely huge set of relatively simple weapons (Dark Souls). Weapon crafting and builds are much more developed than Dark Souls. Think ARPG level. It is possible to make your toon absolutely busted in the endgame. Ki-pulsing lends combat an interesting rhythm I haven't seen in other games.

Altogether, this is a great intersection of fun and challenging which defines itself enough from its predecessors to stand on its own. The story is somewhat superficial, but you're playing for the mechanics and action, which are stellar. It doesn't have PvP (and wouldn't be as good if it did) so if that's what you want, look elsewhere. If you want a great monster-slaying adventure, this is a fantastic option and worth your time.

This game is such a good evolution of the outside souls-like games genre and a fantastic game overall. Where the previous game set the foundation, world and engine technicalities for KOEI TECMOS (same people that did Ninja Gaiden btw) take on the souls genre, this sequel is one of those examples of what a sequel should be. Boasting a fantastic character creator, a combat system that rivals the best ones out there, a long albeit mediocre story, retelling of history in Japan in the Sengoku period. Don't expect fantastic story-telling in this regard, but expect to be able to learn so much from this time period in Japan with an abundance of written sources in the game through character histories, places, yokai myths, and map diagrams.

So this presentation is already great with an inspired art direction blending fantasy and realism into the Sengoku feudal periods, having both authentic recreations of Samurai weapons and armor that exist still today, to wilder creatures inspired from Japansese yokai folklore. The UI is heavily stylised as well with big indicators that might look jarring at first like with many Japanese games, something about their UI design philosophies pollute alot of information on screen all the time. But like I said that's only jarring at first, with alot of it being very customizable and sizeable to your liking. Without a surprise, the Japanese voice dub is expertly voiced given the story being a backseat, but please lord do not change to the english dub, why would you? This game is set in Japan, embrace your weeb.  

Back to the combat, it's really just phenomenal and nothing that lives up to it. Fast paced weapon combat with 11 types of weaponry each with their own huge expansive moveset, and three different stances[b] for each of these weapons.[/b] Not including any of the ranged weapons and magic options that scale differently with your build. However with this games expansive content, with multiple increasingly difficult NG+ cycles called "Way of the Samurai, Strong, Demon, Wise, Nioh." Magic becomes a very needed necessity in the later difficulties and the higher tier content you will be faced with. Aiding in your survivability, damage output, or even slowing down your enemy to a snails pace. 

If you're a fan of Souls-like games or even desire a new challenge to your finessed gamer skills, pick up Nioh 2 and be enveloped into it for hours on end with more content than you probably paid for, and never be satisfied with another combat system in any other game. This game fucking slaps.

TLDR: if you like the first game, there's no reason not to like this one either. Its more of the same with some added features, which i'm sure nioh fans in general will appreciate.

Nioh 2 is a very difficult game to master. It has quite a bit of complexity in nearly everything it does. I very much like the challenge, although I am far from being a good player. I very much appreciate that there are many ways to tackle the difficult challenges and you are not stuck with a single winning strategy. When I die, an often occurrence, I know what I did wrong. Every death is a learning experience and an opportunity to build skill with your weapon. 

I love the depth and the variety of enemies. I like the intricacies and the complexity, although it can be quite a bit to learn. 

The downside to this game is that it is difficult to learn all of the intricacies of the game. There is a steep learning curve, but the curve at least has a slope. The enemies punish you. Tackling more than one at a time is risky. If you love casting magic, be warned that you should be prepared to swing a weapon for quite a while before your skills advance. The nice thing is that there are basically two magic trees, one that scales with a Magic statistic, and another with Dexterity. Both have benefits and you often use both.

I found using a controller (PS4) works best for me. I did not try mouse and keyboard, although I have played other games without a controller. 

I enjoy the game, but be warned. You need to pay attention and have your wits and reflexes to do well. Dying often can be frustrating at first, very much so. 

If you want a game that challenges you, I recommend it. However, you must have a level of patience or you risk breaking something out of frustration!

TLDR: This game is based on artificial difficulty inflation and really flawed, but still worthwhile.

God I really want to like this game. I love the souls-like genre, and I usually like these big(ish) budget games which take their inspiration from the Fromsoft games, but damn Nioh 2 is flawed to all hell.

Rather than having primarily tough but rewarding gameplay, the game is wildly unfair and downright frustrating with really forgiving mechanics (more healing, faster pace, faster stamina regen, etc.) but disproportionally dramatic increase in arbitrary elements of enemy difficulty (more health/damage) to overcompensate. That having been said, there are enough redeeming qualities that if you're a glutton for punishment like me, and you really like souls-likes, you'll find a lot to enjoy.

The core gameplay (general combat, combos, variety of weapon types, etc.) is decent, and human enemies are fun. The general aesthetic, level design, and mission structure is all solid. Also, the multiplayer elements are pretty unique and excellently implemented.

However Yokai enemies generally kind of suck imo, and unfortunately they make up about 70% of enemies in the game. Most enemies and bosses feel difficult, not because they mechanically present a challenge, but because of arbitrarily unbalanced/un-tuned elements: most enemies have one shot/one kill combos (even with the highest armour, enemies will absolutely destroy you, and virtually every hit you take will force an immediate heal); enemy health is often obscenely high; levels are absolutely littered with copious ambushes and cheap enemy positioning; the game severely caps your access to ranged ammunition, preventing it from being a core combat mechanic (usually you just use them to level the playing field against otherwise bs elements like picking off a mob hiding in a tree, etc. to ambush you).

The character/inventory management is extremely un-intuitive, but serviceable I suppose once you get used to it.

In addition, the story is pretty mediocre, despite the amazing setting and art direction. Plays out like bad historical fan-fiction littered with tired/mediocre tropes and pretty awful dialogue. However, the near encyclopedic lists of enemies, allies, characters, etc. and their stories/histories are pretty cool, and make for a welcome addition to the genre (can take a break if you want and just read about the lore of certain enemies, etc.).

Overall, if you're itching for another souls-like game, go for it. But go in knowing this game feels like only partially successful imitation of better mechanics and games, and relies heavily on arbitrary factors to artificially inflate the difficulty.
