Nioh 2 is a perfect blend of the soul like gameplay and difficulty with added superb combat system and RNG system (similar to Diablo). 
This review is going to be focused on 5 areas of the game: Combat System and Gameplay, Story Telling, Difficulty, End Game Grind, and lastly Graphic and Animation.

----------Combat System and Gameplay - 9/10----------

The fluid combat mechanism is where this game shines. There are 12 different weapon classes in this game and each weapon offers their unique attack pattern and attributes. There is no clear Meta or build that you have to follow if you are playing through the game the first time (end game is different, more on this later). Each weapon has 3 stances (upper, mid, lower) which changes the weapon attach pattern depending on which stance you are in; this offers each weapon a lot of flexibility and allowing players to quickly adjust depend on the situation. On top of that, each weapon class also has many unique skills (the skill proficiency can be acquired the more you use that weapon class). Making it quite enjoyable to experiment between different weapon classes and playstyles.
 
----------Story Telling - 6/10----------
The Story telling is good but not great. This is where the game is lacking in my opinion. 
The story is a blend of Japanese folklore, history and with some mystic twist added to it. The storyline itself is okay, but the story telling is very mediocre. It lacks the necessary character development to make player invested in the story and the fate of each character. The story transitions also does not feel cleanly executed; It feels rushed and not well explained. I can see it can be a struggle, for many players, to understand what is happening sometime, if you are not well-versed in Japanese history.  
The protagonist also does not speak a word for the entirety of the story, which really make the story felt disjointed. And also due to that very reason, the action of the protagonist sometime seems illogical and we as players don‚Äôt really have a clear understanding of his/her motives and thoughts even though we are actively controlling and playing as the main character. 

----------Difficulty 8/10----------
The difficulty can be vastly different dependent on if you play alone without any help, or online with Friends. 
The first playthrough can be very frustrating if you choose to play alone without help. The mini boss can kill you in one or two hits or you can get ganked by multiple enemies, and the environment can also add a bit challenge.  But the game does offer a lot of help if you are struggling; you can summon blues to help you clear an area, or you can summon player at the shrine. And if you are really struggling at a mission, you can even play together with a friend/online player. 

----------End Game Grind - 8/10----------
The Game consists of 5 difficulties: Dream of Samurai, Dream of Strong, Dream of Demon, Dream of Wise and Dream of Nioh. 
The end game grind is essentially consist of 108 level of underworld and 30 level of depth once you reached Dream of Nioh. The 108 levels of underworld are fairly flexible, you can make pretty much any build work. With the luck drop introduced, its fairly easy to get the gear and graces that you desire. However, once you go pass 108 levels and the first 10 level of depth. The content can be very challenging, you build is likely maxed out at this point and the bosses can still kill you in a few hits. On top of that your spells do not reset after each boss encounter (for the same level) and the boss also heals a lot fast. But hi its okay, this is very last bit of the end game content, and it was not supposed to be easy.
I didn‚Äôt find the end game grind crazily overbearing and provides a lot of freedom to experiment with different builds. 

----------Graphic and Animation - 8/10----------
Graphic and Animation are pretty good. The texture and environment looked nice, and animation is pretty smooth.  

Overall, I really enjoyed this game. Would highly recommend it to players who enjoy soul like game play, great combat system and the RNG grind.

[h1]Gameplay Summary[/h1]

The second installment in the Nioh franchise, the game is a hack-and-slash game that incorporates magical abilities of Japanese demons called "Yokai". Similarly to the Dark Souls franchise, this game requires high level of skills and hand-eye coordination due to the fact you may easily be overwhelmed by enemy units in the game. Enemies are overall difficult due to their relentless powerful attacks that can easily kill the player early on in the game.

The game, very much like the Dark Souls franchise, also requires the player to increase in levels and farm better loot to move on against more powerful enemies. Another game that can be compared to this game is "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice" (also from the creators of the "Dark Souls" franchise) as it is set in feudal japan.

This game also allows PvE mode, where we can request assistance from other players within a mission. Slightly disappointed that the game is not fully open-world as players will return to the "map" after each quest.

Not much details during the tutorial phase, again, like "Dark Souls" franchise. This causes the player to experiment and learn the game mechanics themselves without hand-holding.

A very big fan of the brutal dismemberment within this game that is not available within the "Dark Souls" franchise or "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice".

[h1]Controls[/h1]
As a player whom prefer using keyboards, the controls are rather complicated. Overall had to change and customize the controls accordingly to play properly.

For the PC, using Keyboard and Mouse, there seems to be some delays in commands, specifically blocking and dodging.

Example 1: Blocking on-point, but the commands do not register, and enemy attacks go through the block. Had tested on other games like "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice" and other games with no issues. Had tested against enemy bosses and in the dojo multiple times and used different mouse, seems inconsistent.

Example 2: Had tested against bosses and in the dojo to dodge enemy attacks. Same case with blocking, the command input seems delayed for a few milliseconds, and this can cause you to die in a fight.

[h1]Mechanics[/h1]
With the complex controls, the mechanics of the game is over-complicated compared to "Dark Souls" franchise or "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice". Players require to manage their stamina called "Ki" a lot to perform both offensive and defensive maneuvers. How well players manage their "Ki" will define their survivability throughout a playthrough.

Forging or Tempering (upgrading your weapon/armor stats) in this game heavily relies on RNG. You will be doing a lot of Forging/Tempering to get specific builds you need. Most cases, just use existing items from drops until New Game+.

Enemy AI is not too bad as they will randomize attacks on the player, making it a challenge for the player. Even the low level enemies are damage sponges which causes the game to become tedious and dull altogether. Pure utter garbage boss designs, they basically cheese you in most cases.

Your character is a [b]half-yokai with "powers" but having a stamina of a decrepit old man[/b]. You can barely block or dodge enemy attacks that it's not even funny.

Blocking and dodging is not even worth it in this game due to the fact it has extremely little I-frames and consumes too much "Ki", making you unable to perform combos after dodging or blocking. Had even tested parrying on multiple occasions and found that its is high risk with low rewards, hence, not worth doing. Might as well not even try to block or dodge as it consumes so much "Ki" and requires extreme amount of recovery time that is beyond stupid. Enemies are not restricted to these issues, they are basically damage sponges (both HP and Ki), doing large AOE attacks that can stun lock you if you are in a bad position within the environment you are fighting in. You will not be able to do "flashy" attacks in this game, like in "Devil May Cry" franchise as it is basically not worth it to perform continuous attacks on enemy bosses due to the lack of damage and high "Ki" usage to block/dodge enemy bosses continuous attacks.

To actually defeat enemies, all you need to do is dodge/run far away (running consumes less "Ki" compared to dodging) and attack them bit by bit until they die or punishing them when they finish performing an attack with long recovery time, since you cannot perform combos due to the "Ki" draining out too fast (even with Ki Pulse used). These mechanics make the fights tedious, unfulfilling and downright boring in comparison to games like "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice". You do extremely mediocre damage whilst enemies can two shot you with insanely large hit-box attacks. Enemy projectiles also has superb tracking, combined with them attacking at the same time, you can instantly die if overwhelmed (You will need to take out enemies one-by-one, unless you are focusing in playing AOE Magic/Ninjutsu). Overall, the game makes the player handicapped and this removes the enjoyment factor.

Another issue is when the camera gets stuck on the wall during fights in confined spaces (where many bosses fight in). As the camera makes the environment transparent, this causes you to get stuck during a fight especially when there are obstacles. This causes enemies to stun-lock you until you die.

[h1]Audio/Video[/h1]
Overall audio and video quality are very nice and superbly optimized for PC. However, there are lack of animations when interacting with the side characters or when you are in "map" mode. It would be great if all interactions with NPCs are fully animated.

[h1]Bugs/Issues[/h1]
1. So far, no FPS drops when running the game at maximum graphics with RTX2080
2. There seems to be a bug with the boss "Erenra", one time, when he goes "Dark Realm", he becomes completely invisible with exception to the orange part of his chest. When the "Dark Realm" finishes, he is still invisible. I've checked multiple videos on this fight, and it seems to be a bug.

[h1]Cosmetics/Customization[/h1]
You may create and customize your main character's appearance similarly to "Dark Souls" franchise along with selecting multiple types of weapons. Your demon (Yokai) form is also customizable to some extent which is quite nice.

The character customization option is quite in-depth, which most games do not have (most have preset characters and limited editing).

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
This game requires time to learn the mechanics and how to overcome the various archetypes of enemies. For hardcore players, this game is quite nice, but can be improved. Not for casual players, as you will die a lot until you've learned all the mechanics.

The game levels are quite dull, your character being a powerful "Yokai" can't even jump or swim which doesn't make sense. With that said, this game overall is decent in terms of graphics, but difficulty-wise feels more handicapped rather than fair as you have multiple skill-sets, but can barely use any of them consistently due to high "Ki" consumption even for basic actions like blocking or dodging, coupled with "Ki" reduction in the "Yokai" realm. As mentioned, enemies also take very little damage and can 1 or 2-shot the player with large hitbox attacks.

All these factors combined takes away the satisfaction of defeating enemies as eventually you will have to resort to hit-and-run method rather than performing punishing combos like you can do in games like "MHW: Iceborn", "Devil May Cry franchise", "Dark Souls franchise", "The Witcher franchise" and "Sekiro: Shadows Die Twice".

For hardcore players, this game is tolerable. For those still interested in this game, purchase only when on sale. It is not worth the full price when compared to the games already highlighted.

This kills the pacing as you have to inch your way forward with the block button taped down walking over small bridges, through tiny doorways, across fallen narrow trees, and rooftop edges ‚Äì unless you want to be grabbed and instantly killed by Yokai or kicked off a cliff. Doubly so when the edges are concave and are very slippery. Even further when you have to pull three, four, five, or even six Yokai, one by one, across these gaps into what could be passably described as a 'fairly open area' by this game's standards - the size of the elevator itself from Firelink Shrine to New Londo Ruins.

All fights with trash mobs feel like cheap shots, while only [i]some[/i] of the boss fights in this game are genuinely enjoyable, and all of them are battles with Yokai.

Before I start, I must say that I absolutely loved Nioh 1, and the reason I start off with that is simple. This game is basically Nioh 1 but improved in so many ways that Nioh 1 is made irrelevant by comparison. Nioh 1 suffered from a few main problems.

1. The enemies moved way too fast for you (boss wise really and some Yokai) to react to in a reasonable way. Nioh 1 suffered a lot from enemies zipping and zooming across the screen and doing near chunks of your health bar if you dared run low armor builds. Nioh 2 adds Burst Counters, which while not perfect at registering, (I've had times where I did do the move and it didn't register and instead acted like I moved to left or right for no reason) still allow you to react much more readily and even punish the high speed enemies with quick reflexes and rewarding you with a good chunk of ki damage, removing curse status for longer than a grapple (Curse of the Demon+) and even regular HP damage. All in all, huge improvement!

2. There weren't really that many choices for builds. This might be on me, so I'll say that in advance, but it really did feel like Spear became the only real great choice the later on you got. I never went insanely far into Nioh 1 due to the 3rd point so I do get that it might just me as a player, but it felt like the option for builds were limited due to the speed issue I mentioned in the first point alongside the damage issue mentioned there too. Given the fixes to the first point and the addition of Switchglaive and Fists, Nioh 2 boasts a much better range of weapon builds due to balancing of the skill tree and expanding how it was before.

3. The damage was insane for how little you could react too. Again, this might be on me, but it felt like I was almost always getting one shot by the enemies in Nioh 1 given how it would be from a really fast attack that I had nothing I could react with.

And those aren't even the only improvements that were made, many more such as expanding the story before and past where Nioh 1 stepped down as well as just making the stages more fun to get through makes playing through the higher difficulties a lot more fun to me. If you liked Nioh 1, or wanted to while not being able to get over some of the faults the game had, I highly recommend giving Nioh 2 a shot; it's a lot of fun and I bet you'll enjoy it.

Nioh can essentially be boiled down to an intersection of three genres.
[list]
[*] It is a Soulslike, similar to e.g. Dark Souls and Bloodborne;
[*] It is a technical action game, similar to e.g. Devil May Cry and Ninja Gaiden;
[*] It is a looter game, similar to e.g. Diablo and Borderlands.
[/list] 
More precisely, it starts with the basic combat and level design formula from Soulslikes. It then layers a ton of advanced mechanics and obscure tech on top, letting skilled players speed up the game to a point where it doesn't really look like Souls anymore; the game is complex enough to have people making dedicated combo videos. Finally, it uses an ARPG-like random loot system that even keeps evolving through four New game plus -levels, providing a long grindy postgame.

Whether this game is for you depends on how many of the listed three core genres you like. If you like just one, it may be a risky pick, as the other genres may detract from the experience: for example a pure soulslike fan might find the combat middling in the genre if they don't focus on the technical aspects, a pure stylish action fan might find the RPG mechanics and a lack of scoring systems off-putting, or a pure ARPG fan might be turned back by the less forgiving difficulty curve of Soulslikes. Liking two of the three genres is however already a good sign that the game has a decent chance of become one of your favorites; people who get absorbed into it can spend a long time with it.


Nioh 2 is the second game in the series; it feels very similar to the first, but with more polish. Many of the less liked parts of the first game have been addressed: the previously low enemy variety has been improved, there are less "annoying" instances of challenge, and the game is better balanced. Hence, especially the postgame experience of Nioh 2 is far superior to Nioh 1, and the remaining reasons to play the first one are now mainly the story and its levels/bossfights. In terms of story, Nioh 2 is a prequel, and the story of Nioh 1 is mostly irrelevant throughout it; however, there is one short part which heavily ties into the story of Nioh 1.

Amazing game with fantastically fun combat, character creation, and a really interesting setting and story in the Sengoku era. Every character and interaction is rooted deep in Japanese history and Shinto lore, and a believable world is something I love. If you get serious about end-game content, there's a lot of mechanics to make your perfect build and whatnot. Everything hits like a truck and beating enemies after they rinse you feels great; I gave out a victory roar after defeating Ren Hayabusa for the first time. That happens often. The other major attraction is that the game has very solid co-op for up to three players with the "Expeditions" mechanic, unlike Soulsborne games (it does have a separate Soulsborne-like "summon help" mechanic, however.)

Despite that, I cannot recommend it at this time. Why? Because the game STILL has stability issues, almost 6 months after launch for a major subset of users, and it's a serious issue for me and my friends. Personally, my own game is stable with patch 1.27.02 and runs great (Ryzen 5600X/RTX 2080). My buddy who I play with also has a stable game (Ryzen 3600X/AMD Radeon) as of 1.27.02.

But our third friend, who loves Souls games, and who we wanted to be our third player in Expeditions is playing with Intel Xe graphics (i7-1165g7 laptop) and absolutely CAN NOT get the game to run in a stable manner. It crashes within 10 minutes of gameplay at various points, every single time. The graphical capabilities of the laptop are fine; it runs at a smooth FPS when it works, and Xe is a huge step up over Intel UHD graphics. But again, it always crashes without fail. He cannot complete the first mission. This is completely unacceptable; Expeditions and three player co-op is a major attraction that elevates this game above Soulsborne games, but the fact our friend can't play after we harangued him into buying it is extremely, extremely disappointing.

Games like this are challenging and incredible with co-op, but it MUST be rock solid in terms of stability for that to pan out. It HAS to work, ALL THE TIME. Beyond that, 70% of steam users are on integrated graphics, often worse than my friends laptop, and many users report similar problems even after 1.27.02 on the forums. This isn't acceptable. It not acceptable for this game to only work for people who can spend $2000 USD on a gaming rig, especially now that GPUs alone cost $1000 USD.

Modern AAA games are complex; I get it. Koei seems committed to maintaining this game, and I suspect more patches will come. I will continue to play. I hope they continue fixing it. But I won't change my review to positive until my third friend can actually run this game without it crashing and join us in Expeditions, because frankly the disappointment that he can't join us is immense. Maybe it's a graphics driver bug, maybe it's a game engine bug; it doesn't really matter at the end of the day. Koei needs to find the solution and help get it fixed.

I'm a huge Soulsborne fanatic. I have over 10k combined hours in Dark Souls 1/2/3 and Bloodborne. It's by far my favorite series. Now there are A LOT! I mean A LOT of games that claim to be "Souls-like" and aren't, they basically just use the tag to sell games. I'll be completely honest, I did not like the first Nioh, I bought it the day it came out after playing the demo, and I enjoyed the demo but after getting a few bosses in it started to get very stale and repetitive. There was a huge lack of weapons, and a huge staple in most Souls-like games is the character creation which Nioh 1 lacked. Couple that with a very low verity of weapons and it just didn't do it for me. 
So on to Nioh 2, For me Nioh 2 checked all the boxes that Nioh 1 missed and then some. Nioh 2 has an incredibly detailed character creation (Honestly it's more in depth than any of the souls games and that is saying a lot!) The combat feels so much better than the first, they added a ton of weapon archetypes my fav being the Switchblade which is basically a great scythe! The summoning a friend system works a ton better than in the first, and there is usually 1 or 2 NPC summons outside every boss fog so if you're having trouble with a boss you can summon help. Nioh 2 also added way more build verity than the first making the replayability value through the roof. 
So all in all if you're a fan of the Soulsborne series and were maybe a little weary on this game because of not liking the first I would say def give this a try it feels soo much better than the original. Hope this helps :-)

[h1]My Opinion[/h1]

 I haven't paid full price for a game in a very long time. I feel like I didn't pay enough for how awesome and intense this game is in it's delivery of challenging and visually pleasing action gameplay. In summary, I highly recommend this game for anyone who has played and loved Nioh, Dark Souls, or Ninja Gaiden. For everyone else, this game may or may not be for you depending on how you feel about its component game mechanics. Personally I enjoyed my whole time with the game and it is the only game I've cleared 100% in a long, long time. A+ 10/10 from me.

[h1]General Assessment[/h1]

For people who may not match 100% with this game I will talk about what this game includes so you can make up your own decision on whether you want to play the game or not.

Some people say the [b]Story[/b] isn't very good and I cannot help but agree with that. It is essentially a generic adventure story with a few rather obvious and overly foreshadowed twists. However, I will say that the story is just a narrative excuse to having you take on the well constructed levels, enemies, and bosses. In true ARPG style, the Story doesn't matter all that much.

Some people say that the Nioh 2 has a ton of [b]grind[/b] baked into the game. I would again say that I agree, but only to some extent. This game operates in the classic Diablo 2 formula of ascending difficulties. So you will start the game in the Dream of the Samurai (Normal Difficulty) and you can only play harder levels and reach higher levels once you clear the game and the subsequent NG+ modes. This segment of gameplay is not a grind for the most part as, and it is counterintuitive, but you can clear all the difficulties through to Dream of the Nioh (the Final Difficulty) just with what you naturally find in levels and not having to do all the side missions.

The grind lives once you reach Dream of the NIoh because there is a rather astounding difficulty spike. This increase in difficulty may require you to finally spend some time farming the right equipment to put together a durable and damaging build in order to tackle the endgame. The only way you survive at this point without trying to maximize the benefits of your equipment, soul cores, and weapon skills is if you are just perfect mechanically, which is almost no one alive. I personally like this because it forces you, in the final challenge, to think about your build and maximize your play style. This game has itemization that is comparable to games like Diablo 2, Last Epoch, and loosely like Path of Exile. There are equipment sets, crafting, and magic find here, so if you don't like numbers and getting BIG damage, this may be the time you hop off the game. Which for me, reaching the endgame, was about 80 hours into my playthrough.

This game has a ton of content and challenge. If you understand the role of ARPG stories, don't mind some grinding, and love fast paced, high skill action combat, then get this game [b]RIGHT NOW[/b] at literally any price. It's one of the best games ever made in the souls-lke environment.

If you're like me and hated Nioh 1, 2 is definitely worth checking out. While still difficult, it doesn't have the insane, random difficulty spikes that 1 had, and the experience is much smoother overall. Armour actually matters in 2, and best of all, you're not required to grind out side missions just to keep your level even with the content. And there's a lot of content. At almost 200 hours, I'm still bouncing between NG+ missions and the DLC (which I'm now hugely over-leveled for, but some of the bosses are still a big challenge for me). 

I am a huge fan of Dark Souls 1-3, and after despising Nioh, Nioh 2 really fills the void, but don't take that to mean it's anything like DS. While there's some surface similarities, Nioh is a different game altogether, and I find Nioh 2 on one hand less difficult than any DS game (YMMV), I also find it also has deeper, more satisfying combat, but less interesting level design and world building.

It also has a feature where you can summon an NPC version of another player to help out for a while. While the AI is *truly awful* a lot of the time, they can still help by taking some hits before they die while you figure out what's going on.

TL;DR, if you like the DemonSouls genre but didn't like Nioh 1, this is worth checking out, because it improved pretty much every aspect of 1.

This game is good in many ways and has been fun (as one can see from the hours played) but I don't recommend it for most people. 

If you belong to the psychotic (yes literally) "git gud crowd", whose self-esteem hinges on being able to brag about stuff you did in a video game, then sure; This game may be for you (just don't hurt anyone when you are tossing furniture around because pretty much any of the bosses wrecked you unfairly again) but for anyone else, give this game a pass. 

Team Ninja are known for "hard games" but the thing is, this game isn't hard. It's actually fairly easy most of the time. The problem is that the game is unfair. This mainly concerns the bosses and a few "generic" enemies. 

Even fans who proclaim their love for this game with heartfelt song admit this (the sane ones at least). 

Now, some bosses are optional (and they are by FAR the worst offenders) but when I'm forced to smell the bull**** in varying degrees, literally every single session, that sort of grinds me down (I imagine it's just like the aforementioned crack cocaine in that regard. It may have felt good at some point but it keeps getting less and less interesting every time and you know it hurts you and that you should stop before your controller breakes). 

I can't go into details without spoiling but lets just say bosses never cease to surprise you with how much bull**** they can toss your way and how much the next boss can trumph the one before in this single regard. I'd say I'm generally a pretty calm dude but this game has me raging almost every session (sometimes multiple times), sometimes I get so flabbergasted by the amount of **** this game takes right in my face that I just ALT+F4 without even reacting to it further and I pretend I did not just waste the last hours of my life doing something that made me feel horrible... willingly. 

The one-hit-kills with insane tracking, speed and range, in cluttered small arenas. All enemies (not just the bosses though ofc they are the worst offenders) have too much life (I'd say most have more than the player. By that I mean even the grubbiest of ronins and the most pathetic of Yokais). Some of them heal themselves, others can spam magic that is harder, better, faster, stronger than dedicated mage-builds, while still being able to "poise" (tank) massive hits from heavy weapons. Some have instant-kill grab-attacks that they like to do when they are low on life.

I'm all down with the type of gaming formula where we are all (both players and enemies) made of wet tissuepaper and have to use skill, reflexes and smarts to progress. I'm also a fan of more laid back games where it's more of a forgiving grind, enemies take unrealistic hits but so can the player. 
I am not a fan of the formula that says I have to hit a boss around 253 times in a row while he/she/it can one-shot me at anytime and under very unfair circumstances. 

I am not sure it was always true when people proclaimed "Dark souls is hard but fair" but everyone understood what that meant. I can tell you that "Nioh 2 is (often) easy but very unfair". 

So, I guess the reason I don't recommend this game is that it actually makes me angry, frustrated and stressed. Which is pretty much the opposite of what a videogame exists to do (even the punishing ones are at least meant to give you kicks of happiness and accomplishment in between the suffering to make it worth your while).

I would only recommend this game to players that don't give up after dying many times in a single mission. It's difficult to progress in this game when it's so easy to die. The developers test your might by giving you the option to fight a giant two-legged machete wielding horse demon in the beginning of the 1st mission. YOU WILL DIE. Just run away. Run away from anything other than soldiers and zombies. If you die within a mission, you have to retrieve your soul where you died. Otherwise, you lose all your exp and soul cores (demon souls you can summon as a battle action). Now imagine doing this over and over again because you died many times. So why do I still enjoy playing this game? I've never played a game before that had so many weapon types. Each weapon type has their own attack moves too. You like ax? The game has ax. What about giant scythe? It has giant scythe too. My personal favorite is the gauntlets. I enjoy using the dual swords too. In the beginning, you have the option to choose two weapon types out of the rest. I had thought I would be stuck with those weapons throughout the game. But the weapons you choose just dictates which of your player attributes gets a bonus point in the beginning. In this game, it doesn't matter how high of a level you are, YOU WILL STILL DIE EASILY. To fight in this game, you need ki. Ki is basically your stamina bar. I would highly suggest leveling up attributes that give you more ki. This is not a hack and slash game. Every move you make during a fight takes ki. Use your ki wisely. Otherwise, you'll be wondering why your attack button isn't working and then SLASH! An enemy just cut you down! This game has a lot of enemy loot drops. You can hold up to 600 items. So, choose what you decide to keep wisely. So far, I've been collecting as many cool weapons and armor I can possibly carry. Be aware that your equipment weight is only affected by what you are wearing. I had previously thought it was affected by my entire inventory and so I dumped a bunch of loot. That was early in the game so I didn't lose out on anything special. This game has a lot of attack variations (skill sets) that can be unlocked with skill points. However, if you want to expand your skill sets, you have to train at the dojo. I didn't know this and so I was just using BASIC ASS MOVES for so long. Training at the dojo is also how you unlock "magic" and "ninja" attack moves. There is a lot of cool things you can do in this game. It's too much for me to continue writing about. If you can just deal with dying so much, you will enjoy this game for the rest it has to offer. I do have one gripe about this game. The voice! Why allow me to change my character's voice in the character creation when SHE DOESN'T EVEN TALK THROUGHOUT THE ENTIRE GAME. I just thought that was weird. Anyways, if you do buy this game have fun creating your character. It's the most enjoyable thing you can do before the game throws a GIANT HORSE DEMON to slaughter you!

If you are coming from a background in Dark Souls then I highly recommend this game.  I think it is objectively a bit harder as the combat system is quite a bit more complex than just managing a stamina bar or FP.  For example you have 3 stances that all affect your combat style (dps focused, blocking focused, dodging focused) plus a wide variety of special demon moves to use as well as different weapon builds and demon builds.  Its a lot, but it works so damn well. 

Edit: Maybe I purchased the game at a lucky time, but I have not had any of the technical issues people have listed in reviews.  0 crashes, high FPS outside of cut scenes, and no FPS spikes on max settings.  I have a 3070 which runs hot while playing, but never stutters.

Combat:
Nioh holds you much more accountable than dark souls as you have to actively retain stances to regenerate your stamina, and generally speaking enemy types feel much tankier even when using a strength build.  Overall though, once you get a feel regaining posture and using your demon counter to break the 0 stamina penalty state (which is far more punishing than anything in dark souls), the combat hits a level of satisfaction that I find to be far superior to dark souls.  

Other features:
Exploration is much more linear than souls games and you have to select a location through missions that can be replayed to grind for loot, but honestly its a nice change of pace. There is also more of a focus on optional grinding for gear and great black smithing option which appears to be far more complex than it really is.  

Final thoughts: 
While souls games begin to feel trivial after a handful of runs, Nioh feels like the next step of evolution for the skill based aspect of this genre.  I highly recommend to anyone who craves souls like action and wants to truly test themselves with a new system that is not only a mile wide, but also miles deeper than Fromsofts current offerings.  Fingers crossed Elden Ring can share some of this complexity!

One of the best games I have ever played and definitely one of the best if not the best Soulslike game apart from Sekiro. Nioh 2 is a great game for those craving a more fast paced Soulslike game.

Nioh 2 hits it out of the park in most if not all aspects I find fun in a videogame.
- A story that is mainly based on Japanese history and puts that demon twist to things, if you know learnt Japanese history, this would strike you as pretty fascinating and helps provide even more context to what is happening around you. As for me, I didnt know jackshit, I had to read up the texts you get for characters, Yokais and other things and still found it fascinating. The worldbuilding is done by picking up glowing yellow balls that sometimes give context to the surrounding area and provide some "ahh okay moments" and even hints to whats gonna bone you. You're gonna have to read alot in this game in order to get a better understanding still.

- The combat is slow at first and demands a different skillset as to what we're used to in your usual Soulslike game. But, the farther long you go, the game gets even more fast pace as you learn more combos and meeting new enemies. The game demand you to play aggressive whilst also busting 180 360 degree moves that actually requires you to remember combos like a fighting game, this keeps you engage the whole way through. And cause of this, i never found the combat to ever be repetitive in anyway shape or form. As well as introducing a mechanic where you could sort of "parry" with your Counter and as well as youre able to go apeshit in the Yokai Shift Mode which is an event on its own.

- Character creation is amazing and i found to be very attached to my character the whole way through. And even though some of the people you meet can be a bit flat, they do enough to drive the narrative forward and especially your best friends you meet along the way. 

- Music is excellent and was able to make me emotional in the end and the enemy varieties are extraordinary, especially the Yokai designs. Those rightfully struck "OH FUCK WHAT IS THAT" to "Omg that looks such a cool design." And each Yokai was a blast to fight over and over again.
- Online feature is there like summoning a dude via bonefire or having an online session where you could play with friends with an adjusted level settings etc etc.

-The game doesnt go the extra mile for graphics, but i think thats on purpose. As most places are passable enough and some places are just so gorgeous to look at even it may not be Horizon or TLOU2 level, it gets the job done for maintaining a constant 60 FPS all the way through. Loadtimes arent too bad either.

In the end, Nioh 2 is one of the best games ive ever played, a game that demands your attention and should not be looked away. It is not required to play the previous Nioh game as Nioh 2 is a sort of prequel, present, sequel type of game. Its like watching Parts from Jojos, you dont need to watch previous Parts to understand, but having that extra context to things does wonders to elevate things, but this isnt so much in Nioh 2. This game, tested my patience, tested my mettle, tested my mental, and in the end, I was smilling the whole way through. I thought this game was too tough at first, but after putting enough hours into it, learning how to Ki Pulse, learning my combos, learning the movesets of mobs or bosses (souls style), this game without a doubt, earned my very high praises and Im willing to crown it as best Soulslike game ever. Nioh 2 is an easy 9-10/10 game, without a doubt for most people, but after everything I mentioned, it truly deserves a 10/10.

[h1]Score: 7/10[/h1]
While this game is a souls like, it is dramatically different from the actual souls games if that is what you are looking for. Nioh 2 is more like a modern Ninja Gaiden with souls-like influences. While combat and general gameplay variety is excellent, moment to moment experiences can be extremely fun or incredibly frustrating and tedious. Several mind boggling design decision hold this game back from being a "perfect" game in the genre. 

[h1][u]The Good[/u][/h1]
[list]

[*]Very fast paced smooth and addictive combat. Combos and button timing matter, depending on the weapon.

[*]A lot of variety in gear and character builds.

[*]A good character creator. This is a major improvement over Nioh 1 that didn't have one at all.

[*]Wide selection of enemy and boss variety.

[*]Great cosmetic customization through the "refashion" system. Similar to transmog from other games. Use what you want without the fear of looking ugly. (not unlocked until the second or third mission)
[/list]

[h1][u]The Mediocre[/u][/h1]
[list]

[*]You can respec your character whenever you want and even store several builds and sets to switch between, which is a great feature. But a respec has a very annoying cost of one book of reincarnation, which dramatically increases in cost every time you buy it, up to 1 million gold! If you enjoy swapping builds frequently on the fly i would recommend just making another character. Respeccing ends up being extremely costly in the long run. 

[*]The crafting system is functionally good, but is HEAVILY random. Say goodbye to all those rare materials you just used, here is a common white item in return. In addition to this brutal crafting RNG, crafting ends up being mostly useless once you reach NG+, but at least its moderately fun to use until then.

[*]The story is just there to move you along. Despite all the (skippable) cutscenes, the story just ends up feeling bland and nonsensical. Characters you don't fight against are largely forgettable. 
[/list]

[h1][u]The Bad[/u][/h1]
[list]

[*]Frequently reused environments and bosses. Despite the good boss variety, this makes them start to feel extremely samey.

[*]Boss fight RNG. While bosses randomly deciding what attack to use is nothing new, souls like game rely on you learning the bosses to beat them. In Nioh 2 bosses have RNG in their combo lengths, vulnerability windows, and reactive attacks. This leads to a lot of deaths just feeling frustrating and unfair.

[*]Uses the same "sudden ambush" tactics as the souls games to increase difficulty, but is much more brutal about it. The game even spawns enemies behind you during some fights with no kind of indication.

[*]The game world will establish rules and mechanics, then break those rules later to increase the sense of difficulty with no explanation of why it is working the way it is. The most frequent example of this is certain boss attacks having a more narrow iframe window, meaning fewer of your iframes are actually iframes. This encourages blocking, which takes away from your sense of play style.

[*]The game will sometimes punish good play. Just dodged a string of boss attacks after learning the boss in NG? Certain bosses have attacks they never use unless you dodged their last one, and will blind side you with a one shot attack. However this doesn't happen very often until NG+.

[*] General lack of information and translation errors. While there is a tip button that generally tells you what does what, in several instances the description is either vague or just downright incorrect. If something isn't functioning like it says it does, you might have to look it up or find it out through experimentation.

[*]Inconsistent game mechanics. For example: there are several items, skills and mechanics for recovering the resources you lose on death, but the game also kills you in more unfair ways than is usual in this genre. These items are a bandaid to make unfair deaths feel less frustrating. Why add so many unfair death mechanics and then add items that let you recover from them? This seems like a sign that the devs didn't know what they wanted their game to be so several mechanics seem at odds with each other.
[/list]

TLDR: Very fun combat, very inconsistent difficulty and punishment severity for death. If you enjoy souls likes or ninja gaiden games you'll most likely enjoy this. Definitely worth getting on sale if not full price.
